Letâ€™s change the area function that has a Rectangle instance as a parameter and instead make an area method defined on the Rectangle struct, as shown in Listing 5-13.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¥å— Rectangle å®ä¾‹ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°çš„ area å‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ”¹ä¸ºå®šä¹‰åœ¨ Rectangle ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸Šçš„ area æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 5-13 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

To define the function within the context of Rectangle, we start an impl (implementation) block for Rectangle. Everything within this impl block will be associated with the Rectangle type. Then we move the area function within the impl curly brackets and change the first (and in this case, only) parameter to be self in the signature and everywhere within the body. In main, where we called the area function and passed rect1 as an argument, we can instead use method syntax to call the area method on our Rectangle instance. The method syntax goes after an instance: we add a dot followed by the method name, parentheses, and any arguments.

è¦åœ¨ Rectangle çš„ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­å®šä¹‰å‡½æ•°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€ä¸º Rectangle å¼€å¯ä¸€ä¸ª implï¼ˆå®ç°ï¼‰å—ã€‚è¯¥ impl å—å†…çš„æ‰€æœ‰å†…å®¹éƒ½å°†ä¸ Rectangle ç±»å‹å…³è”ã€‚æ¥ç€å°† area å‡½æ•°ç§»è‡³ impl çš„èŠ±æ‹¬å·å†…ï¼Œå¹¶å°†ç­¾åå’Œå‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªï¼ˆæœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å”¯ä¸€ä¸€ä¸ªï¼‰å‚æ•°æ”¹ä¸º selfã€‚åœ¨ main å‡½æ•°ä¸­ï¼ŒåŸå…ˆè°ƒç”¨ area å‡½æ•°å¹¶ä¼ å…¥ rect1 ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œç°åœ¨å¯ä½¿ç”¨æ–¹æ³•è¯­æ³•ï¼ˆmethod syntaxï¼‰åœ¨ Rectangle å®ä¾‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ area æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æ–¹æ³•è¯­æ³•ä½äºå®ä¾‹ä¹‹åï¼šæ·»åŠ ç‚¹å· .ï¼Œåæ¥æ–¹æ³•åã€æ‹¬å·åŠå‚æ•°ã€‚

In the signature for area, we use &self instead of rectangle: &Rectangle. The &self is actually short for self: &Self. Within an impl block, the type Self is an alias for the type that the impl block is for. Methods must have a parameter named self of type Self for their first parameter, so Rust lets you abbreviate this with only the name self in the first parameter spot. Note that we still need to use the & in front of the self shorthand to indicate that this method borrows the Self instance, just as we did in rectangle: &Rectangle. Methods can take ownership of self, borrow self immutably, as weâ€™ve done here, or borrow self mutably, just as they can any other parameter.

åœ¨ area çš„ç­¾åä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ &self æ›¿ä»£äº† rectangle: &Rectangleã€‚[note]&self å®é™…ä¸Šæ˜¯ self: &Self çš„ç®€å†™ã€‚åœ¨ impl å—ä¸­ï¼ŒSelf ç±»å‹æ˜¯è¯¥ impl å—æ‰€å±ç±»å‹çš„åˆ«åã€‚æ–¹æ³•çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°å¿…é¡»æ˜¯åä¸º self ä¸”ç±»å‹ä¸º Self çš„å‚æ•°ï¼Œå› æ­¤ Rust å…è®¸åœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°ä½ç½®ä»…ä½¿ç”¨ self ä½œä¸ºç¼©å†™ã€‚æ³¨æ„æˆ‘ä»¬ä»éœ€åœ¨ self ç®€å†™å‰æ·»åŠ  & è¡¨ç¤ºæ­¤æ–¹æ³•å€Ÿç”¨äº† Self å®ä¾‹ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ rectangle: &Rectangle ä¸­æ‰€åšçš„é‚£æ ·ã€‚æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥è·å– self çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€ä¸å¯å˜å€Ÿç”¨ selfï¼ˆå¦‚æœ¬ä¾‹ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ–å¯å˜å€Ÿç”¨ selfï¼Œä¸å…¶ä»–å‚æ•°çš„å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ä¸€è‡´ã€‚

We chose &self here for the same reason we used &Rectangle in the function version: we donâ€™t want to take ownership, and we just want to read the data in the struct, not write to it. If we wanted to change the instance that weâ€™ve called the method on as part of what the method does, weâ€™d use &mut self as the first parameter. Having a method that takes ownership of the instance by using just self as the first parameter is rare; this technique is usually used when the method transforms self into something else and you want to prevent the caller from using the original instance after the transformation.

æ­¤å¤„é€‰æ‹© &self çš„åŸå› ä¸å‡½æ•°ç‰ˆæœ¬ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ &Rectangle ç›¸åŒï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸æƒ³è·å–æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œä»…éœ€è¯»å–ç»“æ„ä½“æ•°æ®è€Œä¸å†™å…¥ã€‚è‹¥æƒ³åœ¨æ–¹æ³•æ‰§è¡Œè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ä¿®æ”¹è°ƒç”¨æ–¹æ³•çš„å®ä¾‹ï¼Œåˆ™éœ€å°†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°è®¾ä¸º &mut selfã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ä»…å« self ä½œä¸ºç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°çš„æ–¹æ³•è·å–å®ä¾‹æ‰€æœ‰æƒçš„æƒ…å†µè¾ƒä¸ºç½•è§ï¼›é€šå¸¸ç”¨äºæ–¹æ³•å°† self è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå…¶ä»–å†…å®¹ä¸”éœ€é˜²æ­¢è°ƒç”¨è€…åœ¨è½¬æ¢åä½¿ç”¨åŸå®ä¾‹çš„åœºæ™¯ã€‚

The main reason for using methods instead of functions, in addition to providing method syntax and not having to repeat the type of self in every methodâ€™s signature, is for organization. Weâ€™ve put all the things we can do with an instance of a type in one impl block rather than making future users of our code search for capabilities of Rectangle in various places in the library we provide.

ä½¿ç”¨æ–¹æ³•è€Œéå‡½æ•°çš„ä¸»è¦åŸå› ï¼Œé™¤äº†æä¾›æ–¹æ³•è¯­æ³•åŠé¿å…åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ç­¾åä¸­é‡å¤ self çš„ç±»å‹å¤–ï¼Œè¿˜åœ¨äºç»„ç»‡æ€§ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç±»å‹å®ä¾‹èƒ½æ‰§è¡Œçš„æ‰€æœ‰æ“ä½œé›†ä¸­åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ª impl å—ä¸­ï¼Œé¿å…ä»£ç ä½¿ç”¨è€…åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬æä¾›çš„åº“ä¸­å››å¤„æŸ¥æ‰¾ Rectangle çš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Note that we can choose to give a method the same name as one of the structâ€™s fields. For example, we can define a method on Rectangle that is also named width:

æ³¨æ„ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€‰æ‹©ä¸ºæ–¹æ³•èµ‹äºˆä¸ç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µç›¸åŒçš„åç§°ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¯åœ¨ Rectangle ä¸Šå®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªåŒæ ·åä¸º width çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

Here, weâ€™re choosing to make the width method return true if the value in the instanceâ€™s width field is greater than 0 and false if the value is 0: we can use a field within a method of the same name for any purpose. In main, when we follow rect1.width with parentheses, Rust knows we mean the method width. When we donâ€™t use parentheses, Rust knows we mean the field width.

åœ¨æ­¤ï¼Œè‹¥å®ä¾‹çš„ width å­—æ®µå€¼å¤§äº 0ï¼Œåˆ™è®© width æ–¹æ³•è¿”å› trueï¼›è‹¥å€¼ä¸º 0 åˆ™è¿”å› falseï¼šåœ¨æ–¹æ³•ä¸­å¯ä½¿ç”¨åŒåå­—æ®µå®ç°ä»»ä½•ç›®çš„ã€‚åœ¨ main ä¸­ï¼Œå½“åœ¨ rect1.width åæ·»åŠ æ‹¬å·æ—¶ï¼ŒRust çŸ¥é“æˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯ width æ–¹æ³•ï¼›ä¸åŠ æ‹¬å·æ—¶ï¼Œåˆ™æŒ‡ width å­—æ®µã€‚

Often, but not always, when we give a method the same name as a field we want it to only return the value in the field and do nothing else. Methods like this are called getters, and Rust does not implement them automatically for struct fields as some other languages do. Getters are useful because you can make the field private but the method public, and thus enable read-only access to that field as part of the typeâ€™s public API. We will discuss what public and private are and how to designate a field or method as public or private in Chapter 7.

é€šå¸¸ï¼ˆéç»å¯¹ï¼‰ï¼Œå½“æ–¹æ³•åä¸å­—æ®µåç›¸åŒæ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›å®ƒä»…è¿”å›å­—æ®µå€¼è€Œä¸åšå…¶ä»–æ“ä½œã€‚æ­¤ç±»æ–¹æ³•ç§°ä¸º getterï¼ŒRust ä¸ä¼šåƒå…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€é‚£æ ·è‡ªåŠ¨ä¸ºç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µå®ç°å®ƒä»¬ã€‚Getters å¾ˆæœ‰ç”¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå¯å°†å­—æ®µè®¾ä¸ºç§æœ‰è€Œæ–¹æ³•å…¬å¼€ï¼Œä»è€Œé€šè¿‡ç±»å‹çš„å…¬å…± API æä¾›å¯¹è¯¥å­—æ®µçš„åªè¯»è®¿é—®æƒé™ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬ 7 ç« è®¨è®ºå…¬æœ‰ä¸ç§æœ‰çš„æ¦‚å¿µåŠå¦‚ä½•å°†å­—æ®µæˆ–æ–¹æ³•æ ‡è®°ä¸ºå…¬æœ‰æˆ–ç§æœ‰ã€‚

Whereâ€™s the -> Operator? -> è¿ç®—ç¬¦åœ¨å“ªï¼Ÿ

In C and C++, two different operators are used for calling methods: you use . if youâ€™re calling a method on the object directly and -> if youâ€™re calling the method on a pointer to the object and need to dereference the pointer first. In other words, if object is a pointer, object->something() is similar to (*object).something().

åœ¨ C/C++ ä¸­ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æ–¹æ³•ä½¿ç”¨ä¸¤ç§è¿ç®—ç¬¦ï¼šç›´æ¥è°ƒç”¨å¯¹è±¡æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ç”¨ .ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æŒ‡é’ˆå¯¹è±¡çš„æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ç”¨ ->ï¼ˆéœ€å…ˆè§£å¼•ç”¨æŒ‡é’ˆï¼‰ã€‚æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œè‹¥ object æ˜¯æŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œåˆ™ object->something() ç±»ä¼¼äº (*object).something()ã€‚

Rust doesnâ€™t have an equivalent to the -> operator; instead, Rust has a feature called automatic referencing and dereferencing. Calling methods is one of the few places in Rust with this behavior.

[note]Rust æ²¡æœ‰ç­‰æ•ˆçš„ -> è¿ç®—ç¬¦ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æä¾›äº†è‡ªåŠ¨å¼•ç”¨ä¸è§£å¼•ç”¨ï¼ˆautomatic referencing and dereferencingï¼‰åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨æ˜¯ Rust ä¸­å°‘æ•°å…·æœ‰æ­¤è¡Œä¸ºçš„åœºæ™¯ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚

Hereâ€™s how it works: when you call a method with object.something(), Rust automatically adds in &, &mut, or * so object matches the signature of the method. In other words, the following are the same:

å…¶å·¥ä½œåŸç†å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼šå½“ä½¿ç”¨ object.() è°ƒç”¨æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ï¼ŒRust ä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨æ·»åŠ  &ã€&mut æˆ– * ä»¥ä½¿ object åŒ¹é…æ–¹æ³•çš„ç­¾åã€‚æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œä»¥ä¸‹ä¸¤ç§å†™æ³•ç­‰ä»·ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
#[derive(Debug,Copy,Clone)]
struct Point {
    x: f64,
    y: f64,
}

impl Point {
   fn distance(&self, other: &Point) -> f64 {
       let x_squared = f64::powi(other.x - self.x, 2);
       let y_squared = f64::powi(other.y - self.y, 2);

       f64::sqrt(x_squared + y_squared)
   }
}
let p1 = Point { x: 0.0, y: 0.0 };
let p2 = Point { x: 5.0, y: 6.5 };
p1.distance(&p2);
(&p1).distance(&p2);
}

The first one looks much cleaner. This automatic referencing behavior works because methods have a clear receiverâ€”the type of self. Given the receiver and name of a method, Rust can figure out definitively whether the method is reading (&self), mutating (&mut self), or consuming (self). The fact that Rust makes borrowing implicit for method receivers is a big part of making ownership ergonomic in practice.

ç¬¬ä¸€ç§å½¢å¼æ›´ç®€æ´ã€‚è¿™ç§è‡ªåŠ¨å¼•ç”¨è¡Œä¸ºæœ‰æ•ˆæ˜¯å› ä¸ºæ–¹æ³•å…·æœ‰æ˜ç¡®çš„æ¥æ”¶è€…ï¼ˆself çš„ç±»å‹ï¼‰ã€‚æ ¹æ®æ¥æ”¶è€…å’Œæ–¹æ³•åï¼ŒRust å¯æ˜ç¡®åˆ¤æ–­æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯è¯»å–ï¼ˆ&selfï¼‰ã€ä¿®æ”¹ï¼ˆ&mut selfï¼‰è¿˜æ˜¯æ¶ˆè´¹ï¼ˆselfï¼‰ã€‚Rust å¯¹æ–¹æ³•æ¥æ”¶è€…éšå¼å¤„ç†å€Ÿç”¨çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œæ˜¯å®ç°æ‰€æœ‰æƒå®è·µäººä½“å·¥ç¨‹å­¦çš„é‡è¦éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

Methods with More Parameters å¸¦æ›´å¤šå‚æ•°çš„æ–¹æ³•

Letâ€™s practice using methods by implementing a second method on the Rectangle struct. This time we want an instance of Rectangle to take another instance of Rectangle and return true if the second Rectangle can fit completely within self (the first Rectangle); otherwise, it should return false. That is, once weâ€™ve defined the can_hold method, we want to be able to write the program shown in Listing 5-14.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡ä¸º Rectangle ç»“æ„ä½“å®ç°ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªæ–¹æ³• can_hold æ¥ç»ƒä¹ æ–¹æ³•çš„ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚æ­¤æ–¹æ³•æ¥å—å¦ä¸€ä¸ª Rectangle å®ä¾‹ï¼Œè‹¥è¯¥å®ä¾‹èƒ½å®Œå…¨å®¹çº³åœ¨ selfï¼ˆç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª Rectangleï¼‰å†…åˆ™è¿”å› trueï¼Œå¦åˆ™è¿”å› falseã€‚å®šä¹‰ can_hold æ–¹æ³•åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›ç¼–å†™å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 5-14 æ‰€ç¤ºçš„ç¨‹åºã€‚

The expected output would look like the following because both dimensions of rect2 are smaller than the dimensions of rect1, but rect3 is wider than rect1:

ç”±äº rect2 çš„å°ºå¯¸å°äº rect1 è€Œ rect3 æ¯” rect1 å®½ï¼Œé¢„æœŸè¾“å‡ºå¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

Can rect1 hold rect2? true
Can rect1 hold rect3? false

We know we want to define a method, so it will be within the impl Rectangle block. The method name will be can_hold, and it will take an immutable borrow of another Rectangle as a parameter. We can tell what the type of the parameter will be by looking at the code that calls the method: rect1.can_hold(&rect2) passes in &rect2, which is an immutable borrow to rect2, an instance of Rectangle. This makes sense because we only need to read rect2 (rather than write, which would mean weâ€™d need a mutable borrow), and we want main to retain ownership of rect2 so we can use it again after calling the can_hold method. The return value of can_hold will be a Boolean, and the implementation will check whether the width and height of self are greater than the width and height of the other Rectangle, respectively. Letâ€™s add the new can_hold method to the impl block from Listing 5-13, shown in Listing 5-15.

æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³å®šä¹‰æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå› æ­¤å®ƒå°†ä½äº impl Rectangle å—ä¸­ã€‚æ–¹æ³•åä¸º can_holdï¼Œå‚æ•°ä¸ºå¦ä¸€ä¸ª Rectangle çš„ä¸å¯å˜å€Ÿç”¨ã€‚é€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç  rect1.can_hold(&rect2) å¯çŸ¥å‚æ•°ç±»å‹ï¼šä¼ å…¥çš„ &rect2 æ˜¯å¯¹ rect2ï¼ˆRectangle å®ä¾‹ï¼‰çš„ä¸å¯å˜å€Ÿç”¨ã€‚è¿™å¾ˆåˆç†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¯»å– rect2ï¼ˆæ— éœ€å†™å…¥ï¼Œå¦åˆ™éœ€å¯å˜å€Ÿç”¨ï¼‰ï¼Œä¸”å¸Œæœ› main ä¿ç•™ rect2 çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒä»¥ä¾¿åœ¨è°ƒç”¨ can_hold åå†æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚can_hold çš„è¿”å›å€¼æ˜¯å¸ƒå°”å€¼ï¼Œå…¶å®ç°å°†æ£€æŸ¥ self çš„å®½é«˜æ˜¯å¦åˆ†åˆ«å¤§äºå¦ä¸€ä¸ª Rectangle çš„å®½é«˜ã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ–°çš„ can_hold æ–¹æ³•æ·»åŠ åˆ°ç¤ºä¾‹ 5-13 çš„ impl å—ä¸­ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 5-15 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

When we run this code with the main function in Listing 5-14, weâ€™ll get our desired output. Methods can take multiple parameters that we add to the signature after the self parameter, and those parameters work just like parameters in functions.

ç»“åˆç¤ºä¾‹ 5-14 çš„ main å‡½æ•°è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ï¼Œå°†å¾—åˆ°é¢„æœŸè¾“å‡ºã€‚æ–¹æ³•å¯æ¥å—å¤šä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿™äº›å‚æ•°æ·»åŠ åœ¨ self å‚æ•°åçš„ç­¾åä¸­ï¼Œå…¶å·¥ä½œæ–¹å¼ä¸å‡½æ•°å‚æ•°ä¸€è‡´ã€‚

Associated Functions å…³è”å‡½æ•°

All functions defined within an impl block are called associated functions because theyâ€™re associated with the type named after the impl. We can define associated functions that donâ€™t have self as their first parameter (and thus are not methods) because they donâ€™t need an instance of the type to work with. Weâ€™ve already used one function like this: the String::from function thatâ€™s defined on the String type.

æ‰€æœ‰å®šä¹‰åœ¨ impl å—ä¸­çš„å‡½æ•°ç§°ä¸ºå…³è”å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆassociated functionï¼‰ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬ä¸ impl åçš„ç±»å‹ç›¸å…³è”ã€‚[note]å¯å®šä¹‰ä¸ä»¥ self ä¸ºç¬¬ä¸€å‚æ•°çš„å…³è”å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆå› æ­¤ä¸æ˜¯æ–¹æ³•ï¼‰ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬ä¸éœ€è¦ç±»å‹çš„å®ä¾‹æ¥å·¥ä½œã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å·²ä½¿ç”¨è¿‡æ­¤ç±»å‡½æ•°ï¼šå®šä¹‰åœ¨ String ç±»å‹ä¸Šçš„ String::from å‡½æ•°ã€‚

Associated functions that arenâ€™t methods are often used for constructors that will return a new instance of the struct. These are often called new, but new isnâ€™t a special name and isnâ€™t built into the language. For example, we could choose to provide an associated function named square that would have one dimension parameter and use that as both width and height, thus making it easier to create a square Rectangle rather than having to specify the same value twice:

éæ–¹æ³•çš„å…³è”å‡½æ•°å¸¸ç”¨äºè¿”å›ç»“æ„ä½“æ–°å®ä¾‹çš„æ„é€ å‡½æ•°ï¼Œé€šå¸¸å‘½åä¸º newï¼Œä½† new å¹¶éè¯­è¨€å†…ç½®å…³é”®å­—ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¯æä¾›åä¸º square çš„å…³è”å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå®ƒæ¥å—ä¸€ä¸ªç»´åº¦å‚æ•°å¹¶åŒæ—¶ä½œä¸ºå®½é«˜ï¼Œä»è€Œæ›´ä¾¿æ·åœ°åˆ›å»ºæ­£æ–¹å½¢ Rectangleï¼Œæ— éœ€é‡å¤æŒ‡å®šç›¸åŒå€¼ï¼š

Filename: src/main.rs

#[derive(Debug)]
struct Rectangle {
    width: u32,
    height: u32,
}

impl Rectangle {
    fn square(size: u32) -> Self {
        Self {
            width: size,
            height: size,
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    let sq = Rectangle::square(3);
}

The Self keywords in the return type and in the body of the function are aliases for the type that appears after the impl keyword, which in this case is Rectangle.

å‡½æ•°è¿”å›å€¼ç±»å‹å’Œå‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­çš„ Self å…³é”®å­—æ˜¯ impl å…³é”®å­—åç±»å‹ï¼ˆæœ¬ä¾‹ä¸º Rectangleï¼‰çš„åˆ«åã€‚

To call this associated function, we use the :: syntax with the struct name; let sq = Rectangle::square(3); is an example. This function is namespaced by the struct: the :: syntax is used for both associated functions and namespaces created by modules. Weâ€™ll discuss modules in Chapter 7.

è°ƒç”¨æ­¤å…³è”å‡½æ•°éœ€ä½¿ç”¨ç»“æ„ä½“ååŠ  :: è¯­æ³•ï¼šä¾‹å¦‚ let sq = Rectangle::square(3);ã€‚æ­¤å‡½æ•°ç”±ç»“æ„ä½“å‘½åç©ºé—´é™å®šï¼š:: è¯­æ³•æ—¢ç”¨äºå…³è”å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¹Ÿç”¨äºæ¨¡å—åˆ›å»ºçš„å‘½åç©ºé—´ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬ 7 ç« è®¨è®ºæ¨¡å—ã€‚

Multiple impl Blocks å¤šä¸ª impl å—

Each struct is allowed to have multiple impl blocks. For example, Listing 5-15 is equivalent to the code shown in Listing 5-16, which has each method in its own impl block.

æ¯ä¸ªç»“æ„ä½“å…è®¸æœ‰å¤šä¸ª impl å—ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œç¤ºä¾‹ 5-15 çš„ä»£ç ç­‰ä»·äºç¤ºä¾‹ 5-16ï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ä½äºç‹¬ç«‹çš„ impl å—ä¸­ï¼‰ã€‚

Thereâ€™s no reason to separate these methods into multiple impl blocks here, but this is valid syntax. Weâ€™ll see a case in which multiple impl blocks are useful in Chapter 10, where we discuss generic types and traits.

æ­¤å¤„æ— éœ€å°†è¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•æ‹†åˆ†åˆ°å¤šä¸ª impl å—ï¼Œä½†è¿™æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆè¯­æ³•ã€‚åœ¨ç¬¬ 10 ç« è®¨è®ºæ³›å‹å’Œ trait æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šçœ‹åˆ°å¤š impl å—çš„åº”ç”¨åœºæ™¯ã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

Structs let you create custom types that are meaningful for your domain. By using structs, you can keep associated pieces of data connected to each other and name each piece to make your code clear. In impl blocks, you can define functions that are associated with your type, and methods are a kind of associated function that let you specify the behavior that instances of your structs have.

ç»“æ„ä½“è®©ä½ èƒ½åˆ›å»ºè‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ä»¥å¥‘åˆé—®é¢˜åŸŸã€‚é€šè¿‡ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œå¯å°†å…³è”æ•°æ®ä¿æŒè¿æ¥çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºå„éƒ¨åˆ†å‘½åä½¿ä»£ç æ¸…æ™°ã€‚åœ¨ impl å—ä¸­ï¼Œå¯å®šä¹‰ä¸ç±»å‹å…³è”çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œè€Œæ–¹æ³•ä½œä¸ºä¸€ç§å…³è”å‡½æ•°ï¼Œèƒ½æŒ‡å®šç»“æ„ä½“å®ä¾‹çš„è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

But structs arenâ€™t the only way you can create custom types: letâ€™s turn to Rustâ€™s enum feature to add another tool to your toolbox.

ä½†ç»“æ„ä½“å¹¶éåˆ›å»ºè‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹çš„å”¯ä¸€æ–¹å¼ï¼šæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä»‹ç» Rust çš„æšä¸¾åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œä¸ºä½ çš„å·¥å…·ç®±å†æ·»åˆ©å™¨ã€‚

Enums and Pattern Matching æšä¸¾ä¸æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…

In this chapter, weâ€™ll look at enumerations, also referred to as enums. Enums allow you to define a type by enumerating its possible variants. First weâ€™ll define and use an enum to show how an enum can encode meaning along with data. Next, weâ€™ll explore a particularly useful enum, called Option, which expresses that a value can be either something or nothing. Then weâ€™ll look at how pattern matching in the match expression makes it easy to run different code for different values of an enum. Finally, weâ€™ll cover how the if let construct is another convenient and concise idiom available to handle enums in your code.

æœ¬ç« å°†æ¢è®¨æšä¸¾ï¼ˆenumerationsï¼‰ï¼Œé€šå¸¸ç®€ç§°ä¸ºenumsã€‚æšä¸¾å…è®¸æ‚¨é€šè¿‡åˆ—ä¸¾å…¶å¯èƒ½çš„å˜ä½“ï¼ˆvariantsï¼‰æ¥å®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ã€‚é¦–å…ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°†å®šä¹‰å¹¶ä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾æ¥å±•ç¤ºå…¶å¦‚ä½•å°†æ•°æ®ä¸å«ä¹‰ç»“åˆã€‚æ¥ç€æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢ç´¢ä¸€ä¸ªç‰¹åˆ«å®ç”¨çš„æšä¸¾Optionï¼Œå®ƒè¡¨ç¤ºä¸€ä¸ªå€¼å¯ä»¥æ˜¯æŸä¸ªå€¼æˆ–ç©ºå€¼ã€‚ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬å°†äº†è§£matchè¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­çš„æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…å¦‚ä½•ç®€åŒ–é’ˆå¯¹ä¸åŒæšä¸¾å€¼çš„ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œã€‚æœ€åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šä»‹ç»if letç»“æ„â€”â€”å¦ä¸€ç§å¤„ç†æšä¸¾çš„ä¾¿æ·ç®€æ´è¯­æ³•ã€‚

Defining an Enum å®šä¹‰æšä¸¾

Where structs give you a way of grouping together related fields and data, like a Rectangle with its width and height, enums give you a way of saying a value is one of a possible set of values. For example, we may want to say that Rectangle is one of a set of possible shapes that also includes Circle and Triangle. To do this, Rust allows us to encode these possibilities as an enum.

ç»“æ„ä½“è®©æ‚¨èƒ½å¤Ÿå°†ç›¸å…³å­—æ®µå’Œæ•°æ®åˆ†ç»„ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚åŒ…å«widthå’Œheightçš„Rectangleï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œæšä¸¾åˆ™å…è®¸æ‚¨å£°æ˜ä¸€ä¸ªå€¼å±äºå¯èƒ½çš„å–å€¼é›†åˆä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½å¸Œæœ›è¯´æ˜Rectangleæ˜¯åŒ…å«Circleå’ŒTriangleåœ¨å†…çš„å¯èƒ½å½¢çŠ¶ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼ŒRustå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬å°†è¿™äº›å¯èƒ½æ€§ç¼–ç ä¸ºæšä¸¾ã€‚

Letâ€™s look at a situation we might want to express in code and see why enums are useful and more appropriate than structs in this case. Say we need to work with IP addresses. Currently, two major standards are used for IP addresses: version four and version six. Because these are the only possibilities for an IP address that our program will come across, we can enumerate all possible variants, which is where enumeration gets its name.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½æƒ³åœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­è¡¨è¾¾çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œå¹¶çœ‹çœ‹ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆåœ¨è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µä¸‹æšä¸¾æ¯”ç»“æ„ä½“æ›´æœ‰ç”¨ä¸”æ›´åˆé€‚ã€‚å‡è®¾æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å¤„ç†IPåœ°å€ã€‚ç›®å‰IPåœ°å€ä¸»è¦ä½¿ç”¨ä¸¤ä¸ªæ ‡å‡†ï¼šIPv4å’ŒIPv6ã€‚ç”±äºç¨‹åºåªä¼šé‡åˆ°è¿™ä¸¤ç§IPåœ°å€ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æšä¸¾æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½çš„å˜ä½“â€”â€”è¿™æ­£æ˜¯æšä¸¾åç§°çš„ç”±æ¥ã€‚

Any IP address can be either a version four or a version six address, but not both at the same time. That property of IP addresses makes the enum data structure appropriate because an enum value can only be one of its variants. Both version four and version six addresses are still fundamentally IP addresses, so they should be treated as the same type when the code is handling situations that apply to any kind of IP address.

ä»»ä½•IPåœ°å€åªèƒ½æ˜¯IPv4æˆ–IPv6ï¼Œä¸èƒ½åŒæ—¶æ˜¯ä¸¤è€…ã€‚IPåœ°å€çš„è¿™ç§ç‰¹æ€§ä½¿å¾—æšä¸¾æ•°æ®ç»“æ„éå¸¸é€‚ç”¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæšä¸¾å€¼åªèƒ½æ˜¯å…¶å˜ä½“ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚IPv4å’ŒIPv6åœ°å€æœ¬è´¨ä¸Šéƒ½æ˜¯IPåœ°å€ï¼Œå› æ­¤åœ¨å¤„ç†é€‚ç”¨äºæ‰€æœ‰IPåœ°å€çš„åœºæ™¯æ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬åº”è¢«è§†ä¸ºåŒç±»å‹ã€‚

We can express this concept in code by defining an IpAddrKind enumeration and listing the possible kinds an IP address can be, V4 and V6. These are the variants of the enum:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å®šä¹‰IpAddrKindæšä¸¾å¹¶åœ¨å…¶ä¸­åˆ—å‡ºå¯èƒ½çš„ç±»å‹V4å’ŒV6ï¼Œåœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­è¡¨è¾¾è¿™ä¸€æ¦‚å¿µï¼š

enum IpAddrKind {
    V4,
    V6,
}

fn main() {
    let four = IpAddrKind::V4;
    let six = IpAddrKind::V6;

    route(IpAddrKind::V4);
    route(IpAddrKind::V6);
}

fn route(ip_kind: IpAddrKind) {}

IpAddrKind is now a custom data type that we can use elsewhere in our code.

ç°åœ¨IpAddrKindæˆä¸ºäº†å¯åœ¨ä»£ç å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹ä½¿ç”¨çš„è‡ªå®šä¹‰æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ã€‚

Enum Values æšä¸¾å€¼

We can create instances of each of the two variants of IpAddrKind like this:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è¿™æ ·åˆ›å»ºIpAddrKindä¸¤ä¸ªå˜ä½“çš„å®ä¾‹ï¼š

enum IpAddrKind {
    V4,
    V6,
}

fn main() {
    let four = IpAddrKind::V4;
    let six = IpAddrKind::V6;

    route(IpAddrKind::V4);
    route(IpAddrKind::V6);
}

fn route(ip_kind: IpAddrKind) {}

Note that the variants of the enum are namespaced under its identifier, and we use a double colon to separate the two. This is useful because now both values IpAddrKind::V4 and IpAddrKind::V6 are of the same type: IpAddrKind. We can then, for instance, define a function that takes any IpAddrKind:

æ³¨æ„æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ä½äºå…¶æ ‡è¯†ç¬¦çš„å‘½åç©ºé—´ä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨åŒå†’å·è¿›è¡Œåˆ†éš”ã€‚è¿™å¾ˆæœ‰ç”¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºIpAddrKind::V4å’ŒIpAddrKind::V6ç°åœ¨å±äºåŒä¸€ç±»å‹IpAddrKindã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ¥å—ä»»ä½•IpAddrKindçš„å‡½æ•°ï¼š

enum IpAddrKind {
    V4,
    V6,
}

fn main() {
    let four = IpAddrKind::V4;
    let six = IpAddrKind::V6;

    route(IpAddrKind::V4);
    route(IpAddrKind::V6);
}

fn route(ip_kind: IpAddrKind) {}

And we can call this function with either variant:

å¹¶ä¸”å¯ä»¥ç”¨ä»»ä¸€å˜ä½“è°ƒç”¨æ­¤å‡½æ•°ï¼š

enum IpAddrKind {
    V4,
    V6,
}

fn main() {
    let four = IpAddrKind::V4;
    let six = IpAddrKind::V6;

    route(IpAddrKind::V4);
    route(IpAddrKind::V6);
}

fn route(ip_kind: IpAddrKind) {}

Using enums has even more advantages. Thinking more about our IP address type, at the moment we donâ€™t have a way to store the actual IP address data; we only know what kind it is. Given that you just learned about structs in Chapter 5, you might be tempted to tackle this problem with structs as shown in Listing 6-1.

ä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾è¿˜æœ‰æ›´å¤šä¼˜åŠ¿ã€‚å›åˆ°IPåœ°å€ç±»å‹ï¼Œç›®å‰æˆ‘ä»¬æ— æ³•å­˜å‚¨å®é™…çš„IPåœ°å€æ•°æ®ï¼ŒåªçŸ¥é“å…¶ç±»å‹ã€‚é‰´äºæ‚¨åˆšåœ¨ç¬¬5ç« å­¦ä¹ äº†ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šæƒ³ç”¨ç»“æ„ä½“è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹6-1æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Here, weâ€™ve defined a struct IpAddr that has two fields: a kind field that is of type IpAddrKind (the enum we defined previously) and an address field of type String. We have two instances of this struct. The first is home, and it has the value IpAddrKind::V4 as its kind with associated address data of 127.0.0.1. The second instance is loopback. It has the other variant of IpAddrKind as its kind value, V6, and has address ::1 associated with it. Weâ€™ve used a struct to bundle the kind and address values together, so now the variant is associated with the value.

è¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰äº†ç»“æ„ä½“IpAddrï¼Œå®ƒæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå­—æ®µï¼šç±»å‹ä¸ºIpAddrKindï¼ˆå…ˆå‰å®šä¹‰çš„æšä¸¾ï¼‰çš„kindå­—æ®µï¼Œå’Œç±»å‹ä¸ºStringçš„addresså­—æ®µã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åˆ›å»ºäº†è¿™ä¸ªç»“æ„ä½“çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªå®ä¾‹ï¼šç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯homeï¼Œå…¶kindå€¼ä¸ºIpAddrKind::V4ï¼Œå…³è”åœ°å€æ•°æ®ä¸º127.0.0.1ï¼›ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå®ä¾‹æ˜¯loopbackï¼Œå…¶kindå€¼ä¸ºå¦ä¸€å˜ä½“V6ï¼Œå…³è”åœ°å€ä¸º::1ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ç»“æ„ä½“å°†kindå’Œaddresså€¼æ‰“åŒ…åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œç°åœ¨å˜ä½“å·²ä¸å€¼å…³è”ã€‚

However, representing the same concept using just an enum is more concise: rather than an enum inside a struct, we can put data directly into each enum variant. This new definition of the IpAddr enum says that both V4 and V6 variants will have associated String values:

ä½†ä»…ç”¨æšä¸¾è¡¨ç¤ºç›¸åŒæ¦‚å¿µä¼šæ›´ç®€æ´ï¼šæ— éœ€å°†æšä¸¾åµŒå¥—åœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥å°†æ•°æ®æ”¾å…¥æ¯ä¸ªæšä¸¾å˜ä½“ã€‚IpAddræšä¸¾çš„æ–°å®šä¹‰è¡¨æ˜V4å’ŒV6å˜ä½“éƒ½å°†å…³è”Stringå€¼ï¼š

fn main() {
    enum IpAddr {
        V4(String),
        V6(String),
    }

    let home = IpAddr::V4(String::from("127.0.0.1"));

    let loopback = IpAddr::V6(String::from("::1"));
}

We attach data to each variant of the enum directly, so there is no need for an extra struct. Here, itâ€™s also easier to see another detail of how enums work: the name of each enum variant that we define also becomes a function that constructs an instance of the enum. That is, IpAddr::V4() is a function call that takes a String argument and returns an instance of the IpAddr type. We automatically get this constructor function defined as a result of defining the enum.

æˆ‘ä»¬ç›´æ¥å°†æ•°æ®é™„åŠ åˆ°æšä¸¾çš„æ¯ä¸ªå˜ä½“ï¼Œçœå»äº†é¢å¤–çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ã€‚è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿæ›´å®¹æ˜“çœ‹åˆ°æšä¸¾çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç»†èŠ‚ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬[note]å®šä¹‰çš„æ¯ä¸ªæšä¸¾å˜ä½“åç§°ä¹Ÿä¼šæˆä¸ºæ„é€ æšä¸¾å®ä¾‹çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚å³IpAddr::V4()æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œå®ƒæ¥å—Stringå‚æ•°å¹¶è¿”å›IpAddrç±»å‹çš„å®ä¾‹ã€‚å®šä¹‰æšä¸¾æ—¶ä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨è·å¾—æ­¤æ„é€ å‡½æ•°ã€‚

Thereâ€™s another advantage to using an enum rather than a struct: each variant can have different types and amounts of associated data. Version four IP addresses will always have four numeric components that will have values between 0 and 255. If we wanted to store V4 addresses as four u8 values but still express V6 addresses as one String value, we wouldnâ€™t be able to with a struct. Enums handle this case with ease:

ä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾è€Œéç»“æ„ä½“è¿˜æœ‰å¦ä¸€ä¸ªä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼šæ¯ä¸ªå˜ä½“å¯ä»¥æ‹¥æœ‰ä¸åŒç±»å‹å’Œæ•°é‡çš„å…³è”æ•°æ®ã€‚IPv4åœ°å€æ€»æ˜¯ç”±å››ä¸ªå–å€¼èŒƒå›´åœ¨0åˆ°255çš„æ•°å€¼ç»„æˆã€‚è‹¥æƒ³å°†V4åœ°å€å­˜å‚¨ä¸ºå››ä¸ªu8å€¼ï¼Œè€ŒV6åœ°å€ä»å­˜å‚¨ä¸ºStringå€¼ï¼Œç»“æ„ä½“æ— æ³•å®ç°ï¼Œä½†æšä¸¾å¯ä»¥è½»æ¾å¤„ç†ï¼š

fn main() {
    enum IpAddr {
        V4(u8, u8, u8, u8),
        V6(String),
    }

    let home = IpAddr::V4(127, 0, 0, 1);

    let loopback = IpAddr::V6(String::from("::1"));
}

Weâ€™ve shown several different ways to define data structures to store version four and version six IP addresses. However, as it turns out, wanting to store IP addresses and encode which kind they are is so common that the standard library has a definition we can use! Letâ€™s look at how the standard library defines IpAddr: it has the exact enum and variants that weâ€™ve defined and used, but it embeds the address data inside the variants in the form of two different structs, which are defined differently for each variant:

æˆ‘ä»¬å±•ç¤ºäº†å¤šç§å®šä¹‰æ•°æ®ç»“æ„å­˜å‚¨IPv4å’ŒIPv6åœ°å€çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚ä½†å®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œå­˜å‚¨IPåœ°å€å¹¶ç¼–ç å…¶ç±»å‹çš„éœ€æ±‚å¦‚æ­¤å¸¸è§ï¼Œæ ‡å‡†åº“å·²æä¾›äº†å®šä¹‰ï¼è®©æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹çœ‹æ ‡å‡†åº“å¦‚ä½•å®šä¹‰IpAddrï¼šå®ƒä½¿ç”¨äº†ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰å®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒçš„æšä¸¾å’Œå˜ä½“ï¼Œä½†å°†åœ°å€æ•°æ®åµŒå…¥å˜ä½“ä¸­ï¼Œå½¢å¼æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªå˜ä½“æœ‰ä¸åŒå®šä¹‰ï¼‰ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
struct Ipv4Addr {
    // --snip--
}

struct Ipv6Addr {
    // --snip--
}

enum IpAddr {
    V4(Ipv4Addr),
    V6(Ipv6Addr),
}
}

This code illustrates that you can put any kind of data inside an enum variant: strings, numeric types, or structs, for example. You can even include another enum! Also, standard library types are often not much more complicated than what you might come up with.

è¿™æ®µä»£ç è¯´æ˜æ‚¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ä¸­æ”¾å…¥ä»»æ„ç±»å‹æ•°æ®ï¼šå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹æˆ–ç»“æ„ä½“ç­‰ã€‚ç”šè‡³å¯ä»¥åŒ…å«å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæšä¸¾ï¼æ ‡å‡†åº“ç±»å‹é€šå¸¸ä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šæ¯”æ‚¨èƒ½æƒ³åˆ°çš„å¤æ‚å¤šå°‘ã€‚

Note that even though the standard library contains a definition for IpAddr, we can still create and use our own definition without conflict because we havenâ€™t brought the standard libraryâ€™s definition into our scope. Weâ€™ll talk more about bringing types into scope in Chapter 7.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå³ä½¿æ ‡å‡†åº“åŒ…å«IpAddrå®šä¹‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»å¯åˆ›å»ºå¹¶ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„å®šä¹‰è€Œä¸ä¼šå†²çªï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬å°šæœªå°†æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„å®šä¹‰å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚ç¬¬7ç« å°†è¯¦ç»†è®¨è®ºç±»å‹å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚

Letâ€™s look at another example of an enum in Listing 6-2: this one has a wide variety of types embedded in its variants.

å†çœ‹[note]ç¤ºä¾‹6-2ä¸­çš„æšä¸¾ï¼Œå…¶å˜ä½“åµŒå…¥äº†å¤šç§ç±»å‹ï¼š

This enum has four variants with different types:

è¯¥æšä¸¾æœ‰å››ä¸ªä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„å˜ä½“ï¼š

  • Quit: Has no data associated with it at all
  • Quitï¼šå®Œå…¨ä¸å…³è”æ•°æ®
  • Move: Has named fields, like a struct does
  • Moveï¼šåŒ…å«å…·åå­—æ®µï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼‰
  • Write: Includes a single String
  • Writeï¼šåŒ…å«å•ä¸ªString
  • ChangeColor: Includes three i32 values
  • ChangeColorï¼šåŒ…å«ä¸‰ä¸ªi32å€¼

Defining an enum with variants such as the ones in Listing 6-2 is similar to defining different kinds of struct definitions, except the enum doesnâ€™t use the struct keyword and all the variants are grouped together under the Message type. The following structs could hold the same data that the preceding enum variants hold:

å®šä¹‰å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹6-2çš„æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ç±»ä¼¼äºå®šä¹‰ä¸åŒç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ŒåŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºæšä¸¾ä¸ä½¿ç”¨structå…³é”®å­—ï¼Œä¸”æ‰€æœ‰å˜ä½“éƒ½å½’åœ¨Messageç±»å‹ä¸‹ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹ç»“æ„ä½“å¯ä¿å­˜ä¸ä¸Šè¿°æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ç›¸åŒçš„æ•°æ®ï¼š

struct QuitMessage; // unit struct
struct MoveMessage {
    x: i32,
    y: i32,
}
struct WriteMessage(String); // tuple struct
struct ChangeColorMessage(i32, i32, i32); // tuple struct

fn main() {}

But if we used the different structs, each of which has its own type, we couldnâ€™t as easily define a function to take any of these kinds of messages as we could with the Message enum defined in Listing 6-2, which is a single type.

ä½†å¦‚æœä½¿ç”¨è¿™äº›ç‹¬ç«‹ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªéƒ½æœ‰è‡ªå·±çš„ç±»å‹ï¼‰ï¼Œå°±æ— æ³•åƒç¤ºä¾‹6-2å®šä¹‰çš„Messageæšä¸¾é‚£æ ·è½»æ¾å®šä¹‰å‡½æ•°æ¥æ¥æ”¶ä»»æ„æ¶ˆæ¯ç±»å‹ï¼ˆæšä¸¾æ˜¯å•ä¸€ç±»å‹ï¼‰ã€‚

There is one more similarity between enums and structs: just as weâ€™re able to define methods on structs using impl, weâ€™re also able to define methods on enums. Hereâ€™s a method named call that we could define on our Message enum:

æšä¸¾å’Œç»“æ„ä½“è¿˜æœ‰ä¸€ç‚¹ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼šæ­£å¦‚å¯ä»¥ç”¨implä¸ºç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¹Ÿèƒ½ä¸ºæšä¸¾å®šä¹‰æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å¯ä¸ºMessageæšä¸¾å®šä¹‰çš„callæ–¹æ³•ï¼š

fn main() {
    enum Message {
        Quit,
        Move { x: i32, y: i32 },
        Write(String),
        ChangeColor(i32, i32, i32),
    }

    impl Message {
        fn call(&self) {
            // method body would be defined here
        }
    }

    let m = Message::Write(String::from("hello"));
    m.call();
}

The body of the method would use self to get the value that we called the method on. In this example, weâ€™ve created a variable m that has the value Message::Write(String::from("hello")), and that is what self will be in the body of the call method when m.call() runs.

æ–¹æ³•ä½“ä½¿ç”¨selfè·å–è°ƒç”¨è¯¥æ–¹æ³•çš„å®ä¾‹å€¼ã€‚æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œå˜é‡mçš„å€¼æ˜¯Message::Write(String::from("hello"))ï¼Œå½“æ‰§è¡Œm.call()æ—¶ï¼Œcallæ–¹æ³•ä½“ä¸­çš„selfå³ä¸ºæ­¤å€¼ã€‚

Letâ€™s look at another enum in the standard library that is very common and useful: Option.

ç°åœ¨çœ‹çœ‹æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸­å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸è§ä¸”å®ç”¨çš„æšä¸¾ï¼šOptionã€‚

The Option Enum and Its Advantages Over Null Values Optionæšä¸¾åŠå…¶ç›¸å¯¹ç©ºå€¼çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿

This section explores a case study of Option, which is another enum defined by the standard library. The Option type encodes the very common scenario in which a value could be something or it could be nothing.

æœ¬èŠ‚æ¢è®¨æ ‡å‡†åº“å®šä¹‰çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæšä¸¾Optionã€‚Optionç±»å‹ç¼–ç äº†ä¸€ç§å¸¸è§åœºæ™¯ï¼šå€¼å¯èƒ½æœ‰æ„ä¹‰ï¼ˆæŸç‰©ï¼‰ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æ— æ„ä¹‰ï¼ˆç©ºæ— ï¼‰ã€‚

For example, if you request the first item in a non-empty list, you would get a value. If you request the first item in an empty list, you would get nothing. Expressing this concept in terms of the type system means the compiler can check whether youâ€™ve handled all the cases you should be handling; this functionality can prevent bugs that are extremely common in other programming languages.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œè¯·æ±‚éç©ºåˆ—è¡¨çš„é¦–é¡¹ä¼šå¾—åˆ°å€¼ï¼Œè€Œè¯·æ±‚ç©ºåˆ—è¡¨çš„é¦–é¡¹ä¼šå¾—åˆ°ç©ºæ— ã€‚åœ¨ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­è¡¨è¾¾æ­¤æ¦‚å¿µæ„å‘³ç€ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å¯æ£€æŸ¥æ‚¨æ˜¯å¦å¤„ç†äº†æ‰€æœ‰åº”å¤„ç†çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œæ­¤åŠŸèƒ½å¯é¢„é˜²å…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€ä¸­æä¸ºå¸¸è§çš„é”™è¯¯ã€‚

Programming language design is often thought of in terms of which features you include, but the features you exclude are important too. Rust doesnâ€™t have the null feature that many other languages have. Null is a value that means there is no value there. In languages with null, variables can always be in one of two states: null or not-null.

ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€è®¾è®¡å¸¸å…³æ³¨åŒ…å«å“ªäº›ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œä½†æ’é™¤çš„ç‰¹æ€§åŒæ ·é‡è¦ã€‚Rustæ²¡æœ‰è®¸å¤šå…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€æ‹¥æœ‰çš„ç©ºå€¼ï¼ˆnullï¼‰ç‰¹æ€§ã€‚ç©ºå€¼ï¼ˆnullï¼‰è¡¨ç¤ºâ€œæ— å€¼â€œçš„æ¦‚å¿µã€‚åœ¨æœ‰ç©ºå€¼çš„è¯­è¨€ä¸­ï¼Œå˜é‡æ€»æ˜¯å¤„äºä¸¤ç§çŠ¶æ€ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼šç©ºæˆ–éç©ºã€‚

In his 2009 presentation â€œNull References: The Billion Dollar Mistake,â€ Tony Hoare, the inventor of null, had this to say:

åœ¨2009å¹´çš„æ¼”è®²â€œç©ºå¼•ç”¨ï¼šåäº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„é”™è¯¯â€œä¸­ï¼Œç©ºå€¼å‘æ˜è€…Tony Hoareè¡¨ç¤ºï¼š

I call it my billion-dollar mistake. At that time, I was designing the first comprehensive type system for references in an object-oriented language. My goal was to ensure that all use of references should be absolutely safe, with checking performed automatically by the compiler. But I couldnâ€™t resist the temptation to put in a null reference, simply because it was so easy to implement. This has led to innumerable errors, vulnerabilities, and system crashes, which have probably caused a billion dollars of pain and damage in the last forty years.

æˆ‘ç§°ä¹‹ä¸ºåäº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„é”™è¯¯ã€‚å½“æ—¶æˆ‘åœ¨ä¸ºé¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è¯­è¨€è®¾è®¡é¦–ä¸ªå…¨é¢çš„å¼•ç”¨ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œç›®æ ‡æ˜¯ç¡®ä¿æ‰€æœ‰å¼•ç”¨ä½¿ç”¨ç»å¯¹å®‰å…¨ï¼Œç”±ç¼–è¯‘å™¨è‡ªåŠ¨æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘æœªèƒ½æŠµåˆ¶æ·»åŠ ç©ºå¼•ç”¨çš„è¯±æƒ‘ï¼Œåªå› å®ƒå¤ªå®¹æ˜“å®ç°ã€‚è¿™å¯¼è‡´äº†æ— æ•°é”™è¯¯ã€æ¼æ´å’Œç³»ç»Ÿå´©æºƒï¼Œè¿‡å»å››åå¹´å¯èƒ½å·²é€ æˆåäº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„æŸå¤±å’Œç—›è‹¦ã€‚

The problem with null values is that if you try to use a null value as a not-null value, youâ€™ll get an error of some kind. Because this null or not-null property is pervasive, itâ€™s extremely easy to make this kind of error.

ç©ºå€¼çš„é—®é¢˜åœ¨äºï¼šè‹¥å°†ç©ºå€¼å½“ä½œéç©ºå€¼ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä¼šå¯¼è‡´æŸç§é”™è¯¯ã€‚ç”±äºâ€œç©ºæˆ–éç©ºâ€œå±æ€§æ— å¤„ä¸åœ¨ï¼Œæ­¤ç±»é”™è¯¯ææ˜“å‘ç”Ÿã€‚

However, the concept that null is trying to express is still a useful one: a null is a value that is currently invalid or absent for some reason.

ç„¶è€Œï¼Œç©ºå€¼è¯•å›¾è¡¨è¾¾çš„æ¦‚å¿µä»æœ‰ä»·å€¼ï¼šç©ºå€¼è¡¨ç¤ºå½“å‰å› æ•…æ— æ•ˆæˆ–ç¼ºå¤±çš„å€¼ã€‚

The problem isnâ€™t really with the concept but with the particular implementation. As such, Rust does not have nulls, but it does have an enum that can encode the concept of a value being present or absent. This enum is Option<T>, and it is defined by the standard library as follows:

é—®é¢˜ä¸åœ¨æ¦‚å¿µæœ¬èº«ï¼Œè€Œåœ¨å…·ä½“å®ç°ã€‚å› æ­¤Rustæ²¡æœ‰ç©ºå€¼ï¼Œä½†æä¾›äº†å¯ç¼–ç â€œå€¼å­˜åœ¨æˆ–ç¼ºå¤±â€œæ¦‚å¿µçš„æšä¸¾ï¼Œå³Option<T>ï¼Œæ ‡å‡†åº“å®šä¹‰å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Option<T> {
    None,
    Some(T),
}
}

The Option<T> enum is so useful that itâ€™s even included in the prelude; you donâ€™t need to bring it into scope explicitly. Its variants are also included in the prelude: you can use Some and None directly without the Option:: prefix. The Option<T> enum is still just a regular enum, and Some(T) and None are still variants of type Option<T>.

Option<T>æšä¸¾éå¸¸å®ç”¨ï¼Œå®ƒç”šè‡³åŒ…å«åœ¨é¢„å¯¼å…¥æ¨¡å—ï¼ˆpreludeï¼‰ä¸­â€”â€”æ— éœ€æ˜¾å¼å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚å…¶å˜ä½“ä¹Ÿåœ¨é¢„å¯¼å…¥ä¸­ï¼šå¯ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨Someå’ŒNoneï¼Œæ— éœ€Option::å‰ç¼€ã€‚Option<T>ä»æ˜¯å¸¸è§„æšä¸¾ï¼ŒSome(T)å’ŒNoneä»æ˜¯å…¶å˜ä½“ã€‚

The <T> syntax is a feature of Rust we havenâ€™t talked about yet. Itâ€™s a generic type parameter, and weâ€™ll cover generics in more detail in Chapter 10. For now, all you need to know is that <T> means that the Some variant of the Option enum can hold one piece of data of any type, and that each concrete type that gets used in place of T makes the overall Option<T> type a different type. Here are some examples of using Option values to hold number types and char types:

<T>è¯­æ³•æ˜¯Rustçš„æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ï¼ˆç¬¬10ç« è¯¦è§£æ³›å‹ï¼‰ã€‚ç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥é“ï¼š<T>è¡¨ç¤ºOptionæšä¸¾çš„Someå˜ä½“èƒ½æŒæœ‰ä»»æ„ç±»å‹çš„å•å—æ•°æ®ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªæ›¿æ¢Tçš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹éƒ½ä¼šä½¿Option<T>æ•´ä½“æˆä¸ºä¸åŒç±»å‹ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨Optionå€¼ä¿å­˜æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹å’Œå­—ç¬¦ç±»å‹çš„ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š

fn main() {
    let some_number = Some(5);
    let some_char = Some('e');

    let absent_number: Option<i32> = None;
}

The type of some_number is Option<i32>. The type of some_char is Option<char>, which is a different type. Rust can infer these types because weâ€™ve specified a value inside the Some variant. For absent_number, Rust requires us to annotate the overall Option type: the compiler canâ€™t infer the type that the corresponding Some variant will hold by looking only at a None value. Here, we tell Rust that we mean for absent_number to be of type Option<i32>.

some_numberçš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯Option<i32>ï¼Œsome_charçš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯Option<char>ï¼ˆä¸åŒç±»ï¼‰ã€‚Rustèƒ½æ¨æ–­è¿™äº›ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨Someå˜ä½“ä¸­æŒ‡å®šäº†å€¼ã€‚å¯¹äºabsent_numberï¼ŒRustè¦æ±‚æ ‡æ³¨æ•´ä¸ªOptionç±»å‹â€”â€”ç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ— æ³•ä»…é€šè¿‡Noneå€¼æ¨æ–­å¯¹åº”Someå˜ä½“å°†æŒæœ‰çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚è¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ˜ç¡®å‘ŠçŸ¥Rustï¼šabsent_numberåº”ä¸ºOption<i32>ç±»å‹ã€‚

When we have a Some value, we know that a value is present and the value is held within the Some. When we have a None value, in some sense it means the same thing as null: we donâ€™t have a valid value. So why is having Option<T> any better than having null?

å½“æŒæœ‰Someå€¼æ—¶ï¼Œè¡¨æ˜å€¼å­˜åœ¨ä¸”åŒ…å«åœ¨Someä¸­ã€‚å½“æŒæœ‰Noneå€¼æ—¶ï¼ŒæŸç§æ„ä¹‰ä¸Šç­‰åŒäºç©ºå€¼ï¼šæ— æœ‰æ•ˆå€¼ã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆä¸ºä½•Option<T>ä¼˜äºç©ºå€¼ï¼Ÿ

In short, because Option<T> and T (where T can be any type) are different types, the compiler wonâ€™t let us use an Option<T> value as if it were definitely a valid value. For example, this code wonâ€™t compile, because itâ€™s trying to add an i8 to an Option<i8>:

ç®€è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºOption<T>å’ŒTï¼ˆTå¯ä¸ºä»»æ„ç±»å‹ï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸åŒç±»å‹ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¸ä¼šå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬å°†Option<T>å½“ä½œæœ‰æ•ˆå€¼ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒè¯•å›¾å°†i8ä¸Option<i8>ç›¸åŠ ï¼š

fn main() {
    let x: i8 = 5;
    let y: Option<i8> = Some(5);

    let sum = x + y;
}

If we run this code, we get an error message like this one:

è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿç±»ä¼¼é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling enums v0.1.0 (file:///projects/enums)
error[E0277]: cannot add `Option<i8>` to `i8`
 --> src/main.rs:5:17
  |
5 |     let sum = x + y;
  |                 ^ no implementation for `i8 + Option<i8>`
  |
  = help: the trait `Add<Option<i8>>` is not implemented for `i8`
  = help: the following other types implement trait `Add<Rhs>`:
            `&i8` implements `Add<i8>`
            `&i8` implements `Add`
            `i8` implements `Add<&i8>`
            `i8` implements `Add`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `enums` (bin "enums") due to 1 previous error

Intense! In effect, this error message means that Rust doesnâ€™t understand how to add an i8 and an Option<i8>, because theyâ€™re different types. When we have a value of a type like i8 in Rust, the compiler will ensure that we always have a valid value. We can proceed confidently without having to check for null before using that value. Only when we have an Option<i8> (or whatever type of value weâ€™re working with) do we have to worry about possibly not having a value, and the compiler will make sure we handle that case before using the value.

è¿™æ˜ç¡®æ„å‘³ç€ï¼šRustæ— æ³•ç†è§£å¦‚ä½•å°†i8å’ŒOption<i8>ç›¸åŠ ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬æ˜¯ä¸åŒç±»å‹ã€‚åœ¨Rustä¸­æŒæœ‰i8è¿™ç±»ç±»å‹çš„å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç¡®ä¿å®ƒæ€»æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆå€¼ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æ”¾å¿ƒä½¿ç”¨è€Œæ— éœ€ç©ºå€¼æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚åªæœ‰æŒæœ‰Option<i8>ï¼ˆæˆ–ä»»ä½•æ­£åœ¨å¤„ç†çš„ç±»å‹ï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œæ‰éœ€è€ƒè™‘å¯èƒ½æ— å€¼çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¼šç¡®ä¿æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨å€¼å‰å¤„ç†è¯¥æƒ…å†µã€‚

In other words, you have to convert an Option<T> to a T before you can perform T operations with it. Generally, this helps catch one of the most common issues with null: assuming that something isnâ€™t null when it actually is.

æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œå¿…é¡»å…ˆè½¬æ¢Option<T>ä¸ºTï¼Œæ‰èƒ½æ‰§è¡ŒTçš„æ“ä½œã€‚è¿™é€šå¸¸èƒ½æ•è·ç©ºå€¼æœ€å¸¸è§çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼šåœ¨å€¼å®é™…ä¸ºç©ºæ—¶é”™è¯¯å‡è®¾å…¶éç©ºã€‚

Eliminating the risk of incorrectly assuming a not-null value helps you to be more confident in your code. In order to have a value that can possibly be null, you must explicitly opt in by making the type of that value Option<T>. Then, when you use that value, you are required to explicitly handle the case when the value is null. Everywhere that a value has a type that isnâ€™t an Option<T>, you can safely assume that the value isnâ€™t null. This was a deliberate design decision for Rust to limit nullâ€™s pervasiveness and increase the safety of Rust code.

æ¶ˆé™¤é”™è¯¯å‡è®¾éç©ºå€¼çš„é£é™©æœ‰åŠ©äºæå‡ä»£ç ä¿¡å¿ƒã€‚è¦è®©å€¼å¯èƒ½ä¸ºç©ºï¼Œå¿…é¡»æ˜¾å¼é€‰æ‹©å°†å…¶ç±»å‹è®¾ä¸ºOption<T>ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œå¿…é¡»æ˜¾å¼å¤„ç†ç©ºå€¼æƒ…å†µã€‚å¯¹äºç±»å‹éOption<T>çš„å€¼ï¼Œæ‚¨å¯ä»¥å®‰å…¨å‡è®¾å…¶éç©ºã€‚è¿™æ˜¯Rustæœ‰æ„ä¸ºä¹‹çš„è®¾è®¡å†³ç­–ï¼Œæ—¨åœ¨é™åˆ¶ç©ºå€¼æ³›æ»¥ï¼Œæå‡Rustä»£ç å®‰å…¨æ€§ã€‚

So how do you get the T value out of a Some variant when you have a value of type Option<T> so that you can use that value? The Option<T> enum has a large number of methods that are useful in a variety of situations; you can check them out in its documentation. Becoming familiar with the methods on Option<T> will be extremely useful in your journey with Rust.

é‚£ä¹ˆå½“æŒæœ‰Option<T>ç±»å‹çš„å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œå¦‚ä½•ä»Someå˜ä½“ä¸­å–å‡ºTå€¼ä»¥ä¾¿ä½¿ç”¨ï¼ŸOption<T>æšä¸¾æä¾›å¤§é‡å®ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆè¯¦è§æ–‡æ¡£ï¼‰ã€‚ç†Ÿæ‚‰è¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•å¯¹Rustç¼–ç¨‹ä¹‹æ—…æå…¶æœ‰ç”¨ã€‚

In general, in order to use an Option<T> value, you want to have code that will handle each variant. You want some code that will run only when you have a Some(T) value, and this code is allowed to use the inner T. You want some other code to run only if you have a None value, and that code doesnâ€™t have a T value available. The match expression is a control flow construct that does just this when used with enums: it will run different code depending on which variant of the enum it has, and that code can use the data inside the matching value.

é€šå¸¸ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Option<T>å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œæ‚¨éœ€è¦å¤„ç†æ‰€æœ‰å˜ä½“çš„ä»£ç ï¼šéƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç ä»…åœ¨æŒæœ‰Some(T)æ—¶è¿è¡Œï¼Œä¸”å¯ä½¿ç”¨å†…éƒ¨çš„Tï¼›å¦ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç ä»…åœ¨æŒæœ‰Noneæ—¶è¿è¡Œï¼Œä¸”æ— æ³•ä½¿ç”¨Tå€¼ã€‚matchè¡¨è¾¾å¼æ­£æ˜¯å¤„ç†æšä¸¾çš„æ§åˆ¶æµç»“æ„ï¼šæ ¹æ®æšä¸¾å˜ä½“è¿è¡Œä¸åŒä»£ç ï¼Œä¸”è¯¥ä»£ç å¯ä½¿ç”¨åŒ¹é…å€¼å†…éƒ¨çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚

The match Control Flow Construct match æ§åˆ¶æµç»“æ„

Rust has an extremely powerful control flow construct called match that allows you to compare a value against a series of patterns and then execute code based on which pattern matches. Patterns can be made up of literal values, variable names, wildcards, and many other things; Chapter 19 covers all the different kinds of patterns and what they do. The power of match comes from the expressiveness of the patterns and the fact that the compiler confirms that all possible cases are handled.

Rust æ‹¥æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæä¸ºå¼ºå¤§çš„æ§åˆ¶æµç»“æ„ matchï¼Œå®ƒå…è®¸å°†å€¼ä¸ä¸€ç³»åˆ—æ¨¡å¼è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œå¹¶æ ¹æ®åŒ¹é…åˆ°çš„æ¨¡å¼æ‰§è¡Œå¯¹åº”ä»£ç ã€‚æ¨¡å¼å¯ç”±å­—é¢å€¼ã€å˜é‡åã€é€šé…ç¬¦ç­‰ç»„æˆï¼›ç¬¬ 19 ç« ä¼šä»‹ç»æ‰€æœ‰æ¨¡å¼ç±»å‹åŠå…¶åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚match çš„å¼ºå¤§ä¹‹å¤„åœ¨äºæ¨¡å¼çš„è¡¨ç°åŠ›ä»¥åŠç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¼šç¡®ä¿æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½æƒ…å†µéƒ½å¾—åˆ°å¤„ç†ã€‚

Think of a match expression as being like a coin-sorting machine: coins slide down a track with variously sized holes along it, and each coin falls through the first hole it encounters that it fits into. In the same way, values go through each pattern in a match, and at the first pattern the value â€œfits,â€ the value falls into the associated code block to be used during execution.

å¯ä»¥å°† match è¡¨è¾¾å¼æƒ³è±¡æˆç¡¬å¸åˆ†æ‹£æœºï¼šç¡¬å¸æ²¿è½¨é“æ»‘ä¸‹ï¼Œè½¨é“ä¸Šæœ‰å„ç§å°ºå¯¸çš„å­”æ´ï¼Œæ¯æšç¡¬å¸ä¼šä»ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ¹é…çš„å­”æ´æ‰è½ã€‚ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œå€¼ä¼šä¾æ¬¡é€šè¿‡ match ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªæ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå½“é‡åˆ°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œé€‚é…â€œçš„æ¨¡å¼æ—¶ï¼Œè¯¥å€¼ä¼šè¿›å…¥å…³è”çš„ä»£ç å—ä¸­æ‰§è¡Œã€‚

Speaking of coins, letâ€™s use them as an example using match! We can write a function that takes an unknown US coin and, in a similar way as the counting machine, determines which coin it is and returns its value in cents, as shown in Listing 6-3.

æ—¢ç„¶æåˆ°ç¡¬å¸ï¼Œè®©æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥å®ƒä»¬ä¸ºä¾‹ä½¿ç”¨ matchï¼æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç¼–å†™ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼šæ¥æ”¶æœªçŸ¥çš„ç¾å›½ç¡¬å¸ï¼Œåƒç‚¹é’æœºä¸€æ ·ç¡®å®šå…¶ç§ç±»å¹¶è¿”å›å¯¹åº”ç¾åˆ†å€¼ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-3 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Letâ€™s break down the match in the value_in_cents function. First we list the match keyword followed by an expression, which in this case is the value coin. This seems very similar to a conditional expression used with if, but thereâ€™s a big difference: with if, the condition needs to evaluate to a Boolean value, but here it can be any type. The type of coin in this example is the Coin enum that we defined on the first line.

ç°åœ¨è§£æ value_in_cents å‡½æ•°ä¸­çš„ matchã€‚é¦–å…ˆåˆ—å‡º match å…³é”®å­—åŠè¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸º coin å€¼ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™çœ‹ä¼¼ä¸ if çš„æ¡ä»¶è¡¨è¾¾å¼ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œä½†æœ‰é‡å¤§åŒºåˆ«ï¼šif çš„æ¡ä»¶å¿…é¡»è¿”å›å¸ƒå°”å€¼ï¼Œè€Œæ­¤å¤„å¯ä»¥æ˜¯ä»»æ„ç±»å‹ã€‚æœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­ coin çš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€è¡Œå®šä¹‰çš„ Coin æšä¸¾ã€‚

Next are the match arms. An arm has two parts: a pattern and some code. The first arm here has a pattern that is the value Coin::Penny and then the => operator that separates the pattern and the code to run. The code in this case is just the value 1. Each arm is separated from the next with a comma.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æ˜¯ match åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯æœ‰ä¸¤éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼šæ¨¡å¼å’Œä»£ç ã€‚ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯çš„æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å€¼ Coin::Pennyï¼Œåè·Ÿåˆ†éš”æ¨¡å¼ä¸ä»£ç çš„ => è¿ç®—ç¬¦ã€‚æ­¤å¤„çš„ä»£ç æ˜¯å€¼ 1ã€‚åˆ†æ”¯é—´ç”¨é€—å·åˆ†éš”ã€‚

When the match expression executes, it compares the resultant value against the pattern of each arm, in order. If a pattern matches the value, the code associated with that pattern is executed. If that pattern doesnâ€™t match the value, execution continues to the next arm, much as in a coin-sorting machine. We can have as many arms as we need: in Listing 6-3, our match has four arms.

æ‰§è¡Œ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼æ—¶ï¼Œä¼šæŒ‰é¡ºåºå°†ç»“æœå€¼ä¸æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯çš„æ¨¡å¼æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚è‹¥æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…å€¼ï¼Œåˆ™æ‰§è¡Œå…³è”ä»£ç ï¼›è‹¥ä¸åŒ¹é…ï¼Œåˆ™ç»§ç»­ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ç¡¬å¸åˆ†æ‹£æœºï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æ·»åŠ ä»»æ„æ•°é‡çš„åˆ†æ”¯ï¼šç¤ºä¾‹ 6-3 ä¸­æœ‰å››ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ã€‚

The code associated with each arm is an expression, and the resultant value of the expression in the matching arm is the value that gets returned for the entire match expression.

æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯çš„å…³è”ä»£ç æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼ŒåŒ¹é…åˆ†æ”¯çš„è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„è¿”å›å€¼å³æ˜¯æ•´ä¸ª match è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„è¿”å›å€¼ã€‚

We donâ€™t typically use curly brackets if the match arm code is short, as it is in Listing 6-3 where each arm just returns a value. If you want to run multiple lines of code in a match arm, you must use curly brackets, and the comma following the arm is then optional. For example, the following code prints â€œLucky penny!â€ every time the method is called with a Coin::Penny, but still returns the last value of the block, 1:

è‹¥åˆ†æ”¯ä»£ç è¾ƒçŸ­ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-3 ä¸­æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ä»…è¿”å›å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œé€šå¸¸çœç•¥èŠ±æ‹¬å·ã€‚[note]è‹¥éœ€åœ¨åˆ†æ”¯ä¸­è¿è¡Œå¤šè¡Œä»£ç ï¼Œå¿…é¡»ä½¿ç”¨èŠ±æ‹¬å·ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶åˆ†æ”¯åçš„é€—å·å¯é€‰ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç åœ¨ä¼ å…¥ Coin::Penny æ—¶æ‰“å° â€œLucky penny!â€ï¼Œä½†ä»è¿”å›ä»£ç å—æœ«å°¾å€¼ 1ï¼š

enum Coin {
    Penny,
    Nickel,
    Dime,
    Quarter,
}

fn value_in_cents(coin: Coin) -> u8 {
    match coin {
        Coin::Penny => {
            println!("Lucky penny!");
            1
        }
        Coin::Nickel => 5,
        Coin::Dime => 10,
        Coin::Quarter => 25,
    }
}

fn main() {}

Patterns That Bind to Values ç»‘å®šå€¼çš„æ¨¡å¼

Another useful feature of match arms is that they can bind to the parts of the values that match the pattern. This is how we can extract values out of enum variants.

åŒ¹é…åˆ†æ”¯çš„å¦ä¸€é¡¹å®ç”¨åŠŸèƒ½æ˜¯ï¼šå®ƒä»¬å¯ä»¥ç»‘å®šåˆ°åŒ¹é…æ¨¡å¼çš„å€¼éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œä»è€Œä»æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ä¸­æå–å€¼ã€‚

As an example, letâ€™s change one of our enum variants to hold data inside it. From 1999 through 2008, the United States minted quarters with different designs for each of the 50 states on one side. No other coins got state designs, so only quarters have this extra value. We can add this information to our enum by changing the Quarter variant to include a UsState value stored inside it, which weâ€™ve done in Listing 6-4.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä¿®æ”¹æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ä½¿å…¶åŒ…å«å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®ã€‚1999 å¹´è‡³ 2008 å¹´é—´ï¼Œç¾å›½é“¸é€ çš„ 25 ç¾åˆ†ç¡¬å¸èƒŒé¢å°æœ‰å„å·è®¾è®¡ã€‚å…¶ä»–ç¡¬å¸æ— æ­¤è®¾è®¡ï¼Œå› æ­¤åªæœ‰ 25 ç¾åˆ†æœ‰æ­¤é™„åŠ å€¼ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯é€šè¿‡ä¿®æ”¹ Quarter å˜ä½“åŒ…å« UsState å€¼æ¥æ·»åŠ æ­¤ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-4 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Letâ€™s imagine that a friend is trying to collect all 50 state quarters. While we sort our loose change by coin type, weâ€™ll also call out the name of the state associated with each quarter so that if itâ€™s one our friend doesnâ€™t have, they can add it to their collection.

å‡è®¾æœ‰æœ‹å‹æƒ³æ”¶é›†å…¨éƒ¨ 50 å·çºªå¿µå¸ã€‚å½“æŒ‰ç¡¬å¸ç±»å‹åˆ†ç±»é›¶é’±æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†åŒæ—¶å–Šå‡ºå¯¹åº”å·åï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿æœ‹å‹å°†æœªæ”¶é›†çš„ç¡¬å¸åŠ å…¥æ”¶è—ã€‚

In the match expression for this code, we add a variable called state to the pattern that matches values of the variant Coin::Quarter. When a Coin::Quarter matches, the state variable will bind to the value of that quarterâ€™s state. Then we can use state in the code for that arm, like so:

åœ¨æ­¤ä»£ç çš„ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­ï¼Œä¸ºåŒ¹é… Coin::Quarter å˜ä½“çš„æ¨¡å¼æ·»åŠ å˜é‡ stateã€‚å½“åŒ¹é…åˆ° Coin::Quarter æ—¶ï¼Œstate å°†ç»‘å®šåˆ°è¯¥ç¡¬å¸çš„å·åå€¼ã€‚éšåå³å¯åœ¨è¯¥åˆ†æ”¯ä»£ç ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ stateï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

#[derive(Debug)]
enum UsState {
    Alabama,
    Alaska,
    // --snip--
}

enum Coin {
    Penny,
    Nickel,
    Dime,
    Quarter(UsState),
}

fn value_in_cents(coin: Coin) -> u8 {
    match coin {
        Coin::Penny => 1,
        Coin::Nickel => 5,
        Coin::Dime => 10,
        Coin::Quarter(state) => {
            println!("State quarter from {state:?}!");
            25
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    value_in_cents(Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska));
}

If we were to call value_in_cents(Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska)), coin would be Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska). When we compare that value with each of the match arms, none of them match until we reach Coin::Quarter(state). At that point, the binding for state will be the value UsState::Alaska. We can then use that binding in the println! expression, thus getting the inner state value out of the Coin enum variant for Quarter.

è‹¥è°ƒç”¨ value_in_cents(Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska))ï¼Œcoin å°†æ˜¯ Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska)ã€‚å½“ä¸å„åˆ†æ”¯æ¯”è¾ƒæ—¶ï¼Œç›´åˆ° Coin::Quarter(state) æ‰ä¼šåŒ¹é…ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ state çš„ç»‘å®šå€¼ä¸º UsState::Alaskaã€‚æ¥ç€åœ¨ println! è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥ç»‘å®šï¼Œä»è€Œä» Quarter æšä¸¾å˜ä½“ä¸­æå–å‡ºå†…éƒ¨å·åå€¼ã€‚

Matching with Option<T> åŒ¹é… Option<T>

In the previous section, we wanted to get the inner T value out of the Some case when using Option<T>; we can also handle Option<T> using match, as we did with the Coin enum! Instead of comparing coins, weâ€™ll compare the variants of Option<T>, but the way the match expression works remains the same.

ä¸Šä¸€èŠ‚ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›åœ¨ Option<T> çš„ Some æƒ…å†µä¸‹è·å–å†…éƒ¨ T å€¼ï¼›ä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨ match å¤„ç† Option<T>ï¼ˆå¦‚åŒå¤„ç† Coin æšä¸¾ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™é‡Œæ¯”è¾ƒçš„æ˜¯ Option<T> çš„å˜ä½“ï¼Œä½† match çš„å·¥ä½œæ–¹å¼ä¸å˜ã€‚

Letâ€™s say we want to write a function that takes an Option<i32> and, if thereâ€™s a value inside, adds 1 to that value. If there isnâ€™t a value inside, the function should return the None value and not attempt to perform any operations.

å‡è®¾è¦ç¼–å†™å‡½æ•°ï¼šæ¥æ”¶ Option<i32>ï¼Œè‹¥å†…éƒ¨æœ‰å€¼åˆ™åŠ  1ï¼›è‹¥æ— å€¼åˆ™ç›´æ¥è¿”å› Noneã€‚

This function is very easy to write, thanks to match, and will look like Listing 6-5.

å€ŸåŠ© match å¯è½»æ¾å®ç°ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-5 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Letâ€™s examine the first execution of plus_one in more detail. When we call plus_one(five), the variable x in the body of plus_one will have the value Some(5). We then compare that against each match arm:

è¯¦ç»†è§£æç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ plus_one çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚å½“è°ƒç”¨ plus_one(five) æ—¶ï¼Œplus_one å‡½æ•°ä½“å†…çš„ x å°†ä¸º Some(5)ã€‚æ¥ç€ä¸å„åˆ†æ”¯æ¯”è¾ƒï¼š

fn main() {
    fn plus_one(x: Option<i32>) -> Option<i32> {
        match x {
            None => None,
            Some(i) => Some(i + 1),
        }
    }

    let five = Some(5);
    let six = plus_one(five);
    let none = plus_one(None);
}

The Some(5) value doesnâ€™t match the pattern None, so we continue to the next arm:

Some(5) ä¸åŒ¹é… None æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œç»§ç»­ä¸‹ä¸€åˆ†æ”¯ï¼š

fn main() {
    fn plus_one(x: Option<i32>) -> Option<i32> {
        match x {
            None => None,
            Some(i) => Some(i + 1),
        }
    }

    let five = Some(5);
    let six = plus_one(five);
    let none = plus_one(None);
}

Does Some(5) match Some(i)? It does! We have the same variant. The i binds to the value contained in Some, so i takes the value 5. The code in the match arm is then executed, so we add 1 to the value of i and create a new Some value with our total 6 inside.

Some(5) åŒ¹é… Some(i) å—ï¼ŸåŒ¹é…ï¼ä¸¤è€…ä¸ºç›¸åŒå˜ä½“ã€‚i ç»‘å®šåˆ° Some çš„å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼Œå› æ­¤ i å–å€¼ 5ã€‚æ‰§è¡Œè¯¥åˆ†æ”¯ä»£ç ï¼šå°† i çš„å€¼åŠ  1ï¼Œç”ŸæˆåŒ…å«ç»“æœ 6 çš„æ–° Some å€¼ã€‚

Now letâ€™s consider the second call of plus_one in Listing 6-5, where x is None. We enter the match and compare to the first arm:

ç°åœ¨è€ƒè™‘ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-5 ä¸­ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ plus_one çš„æƒ…å†µï¼ˆx ä¸º Noneï¼‰ã€‚è¿›å…¥ match åä¸ç¬¬ä¸€åˆ†æ”¯æ¯”è¾ƒï¼š

fn main() {
    fn plus_one(x: Option<i32>) -> Option<i32> {
        match x {
            None => None,
            Some(i) => Some(i + 1),
        }
    }

    let five = Some(5);
    let six = plus_one(five);
    let none = plus_one(None);
}

It matches! Thereâ€™s no value to add to, so the program stops and returns the None value on the right side of =>. Because the first arm matched, no other arms are compared.

åŒ¹é…æˆåŠŸï¼æ— éœ€å¢åŠ å€¼ï¼Œç¨‹åºåœæ­¢å¹¶è¿”å› => å³ä¾§çš„ None å€¼ã€‚å› ç¬¬ä¸€åˆ†æ”¯å·²åŒ¹é…ï¼Œä¸å†æ¯”è¾ƒå…¶ä»–åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚

Combining match and enums is useful in many situations. Youâ€™ll see this pattern a lot in Rust code: match against an enum, bind a variable to the data inside, and then execute code based on it. Itâ€™s a bit tricky at first, but once you get used to it, youâ€™ll wish you had it in all languages. Itâ€™s consistently a user favorite.

match ä¸æšä¸¾çš„ç»„åˆåœ¨å¤šç§åœºæ™¯ä¸­éƒ½å¾ˆæœ‰ç”¨ã€‚ä½ ä¼šåœ¨ Rust ä»£ç ä¸­é¢‘ç¹çœ‹åˆ°æ­¤æ¨¡å¼ï¼šç”¨ match åŒ¹é…æšä¸¾ï¼Œå°†å˜é‡ç»‘å®šåˆ°å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®ï¼Œå†æ®æ­¤æ‰§è¡Œä»£ç ã€‚åˆç”¨å¯èƒ½æœ‰äº›æ£˜æ‰‹ï¼Œä½†ä¹ æƒ¯åä½ ä¼šå¸Œæœ›æ‰€æœ‰è¯­è¨€éƒ½æ‹¥æœ‰æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½â€”â€”å®ƒå§‹ç»ˆæ·±å—ç”¨æˆ·å–œçˆ±ã€‚

Matches Are Exhaustive åŒ¹é…çš„ç©·å°½æ€§

Thereâ€™s one other aspect of match we need to discuss: the armsâ€™ patterns must cover all possibilities. Consider this version of our plus_one function, which has a bug and wonâ€™t compile:

match è¿˜æœ‰å¦ä¸€ç‰¹æ€§ï¼šåˆ†æ”¯æ¨¡å¼å¿…é¡»è¦†ç›–æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½æ€§ã€‚è€ƒè™‘ä»¥ä¸‹æœ‰ç¼ºé™·çš„ plus_one å‡½æ•°ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼ˆæ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼‰ï¼š

fn main() {
    fn plus_one(x: Option<i32>) -> Option<i32> {
        match x {
            Some(i) => Some(i + 1),
        }
    }

    let five = Some(5);
    let six = plus_one(five);
    let none = plus_one(None);
}

We didnâ€™t handle the None case, so this code will cause a bug. Luckily, itâ€™s a bug Rust knows how to catch. If we try to compile this code, weâ€™ll get this error:

å› æœªå¤„ç† None æƒ…å†µï¼Œæ­¤ä»£ç å­˜åœ¨é”™è¯¯ã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ Rust èƒ½æ•è·æ­¤ç±»é”™è¯¯ã€‚å°è¯•ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶å°†æç¤ºï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling enums v0.1.0 (file:///projects/enums)
error[E0004]: non-exhaustive patterns: `None` not covered
 --> src/main.rs:3:15
  |
3 |         match x {
  |               ^ pattern `None` not covered
  |
note: `Option<i32>` defined here
 --> /rustc/4eb161250e340c8f48f66e2b929ef4a5bed7c181/library/core/src/option.rs:572:1
 ::: /rustc/4eb161250e340c8f48f66e2b929ef4a5bed7c181/library/core/src/option.rs:576:5
  |
  = note: not covered
  = note: the matched value is of type `Option<i32>`
help: ensure that all possible cases are being handled by adding a match arm with a wildcard pattern or an explicit pattern as shown
  |
4 ~             Some(i) => Some(i + 1),
5 ~             None => todo!(),
  |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0004`.
error: could not compile `enums` (bin "enums") due to 1 previous error

Rust knows that we didnâ€™t cover every possible case, and even knows which pattern we forgot! Matches in Rust are exhaustive: we must exhaust every last possibility in order for the code to be valid. Especially in the case of Option<T>, when Rust prevents us from forgetting to explicitly handle the None case, it protects us from assuming that we have a value when we might have null, thus making the billion-dollar mistake discussed earlier impossible.

Rust ä¸ä»…çŸ¥é“æˆ‘ä»¬æœªè¦†ç›–æ‰€æœ‰æƒ…å†µï¼Œç”šè‡³èƒ½æŒ‡å‡ºé—æ¼çš„æ¨¡å¼ï¼Rust ä¸­çš„åŒ¹é…æ˜¯ç©·å°½çš„ï¼ˆexhaustiveï¼‰ï¼šå¿…é¡»è¦†ç›–æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½æ€§ä»£ç æ‰æœ‰æ•ˆã€‚å°¤å…¶åœ¨å¤„ç† Option<T> æ—¶ï¼ŒRust å¼ºåˆ¶æ˜¾å¼å¤„ç† None æƒ…å†µï¼Œé˜²æ­¢æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨å¯èƒ½ä¸ºç©ºæ—¶å‡å®šå­˜åœ¨å€¼ï¼Œä»è€Œé¿å…äº†ä¹‹å‰è®¨è®ºçš„â€œåäº¿ç¾å…ƒé”™è¯¯â€œã€‚

Catch-All Patterns and the _ Placeholder é€šé…æ¨¡å¼å’Œ _ å ä½ç¬¦

Using enums, we can also take special actions for a few particular values, but for all other values take one default action. Imagine weâ€™re implementing a game where, if you roll a 3 on a dice roll, your player doesnâ€™t move, but instead gets a new fancy hat. If you roll a 7, your player loses a fancy hat. For all other values, your player moves that number of spaces on the game board. Hereâ€™s a match that implements that logic, with the result of the dice roll hardcoded rather than a random value, and all other logic represented by functions without bodies because actually implementing them is out of scope for this example:

ä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾æ—¶ï¼Œå¯å¯¹ç‰¹å®šå€¼æ‰§è¡Œç‰¹æ®Šæ“ä½œï¼Œè€Œå¯¹å…¶ä»–å€¼æ‰§è¡Œé»˜è®¤æ“ä½œã€‚å‡è®¾åœ¨æ¸¸æˆä¸­ï¼šæ·éª°å­å¾— 3 æ—¶ç©å®¶è·å¾—æ–°å¸½å­ï¼›å¾— 7 æ—¶å¤±å»å¸½å­ï¼›å…¶ä»–æ•°å€¼åˆ™åœ¨æ£‹ç›˜ç§»åŠ¨å¯¹åº”æ ¼æ•°ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ç¡¬ç¼–ç éª°å­ç»“æœçš„ match å®ç°ï¼ˆå…¶ä»–é€»è¾‘ç”¨æ— ä¸»ä½“å‡½æ•°è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œå› å®é™…å®ç°è¶…å‡ºæœ¬ä¾‹èŒƒå›´ï¼‰ï¼š

fn main() {
    let dice_roll = 9;
    match dice_roll {
        3 => add_fancy_hat(),
        7 => remove_fancy_hat(),
        other => move_player(other),
    }

    fn add_fancy_hat() {}
    fn remove_fancy_hat() {}
    fn move_player(num_spaces: u8) {}
}

For the first two arms, the patterns are the literal values 3 and 7. For the last arm that covers every other possible value, the pattern is the variable weâ€™ve chosen to name other. The code that runs for the other arm uses the variable by passing it to the move_player function.

å‰ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯çš„æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å­—é¢å€¼ 3 å’Œ 7ã€‚æœ€åä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯è¦†ç›–å…¶ä»–æ‰€æœ‰å€¼ï¼Œæ¨¡å¼ä¸ºå˜é‡ otherã€‚è¯¥åˆ†æ”¯ä»£ç é€šè¿‡å‘ move_player ä¼ é€’ other æ¥ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤å˜é‡ã€‚

This code compiles, even though we havenâ€™t listed all the possible values a u8 can have, because the last pattern will match all values not specifically listed. This catch-all pattern meets the requirement that match must be exhaustive. Note that we have to put the catch-all arm last because the patterns are evaluated in order. If we put the catch-all arm earlier, the other arms would never run, so Rust will warn us if we add arms after a catch-all!

æ­¤ä»£ç å¯ç¼–è¯‘é€šè¿‡ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬æœªåˆ—å‡º u8 æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½å€¼â€”â€”æœ€åçš„æ¨¡å¼ä¼šåŒ¹é…æ‰€æœ‰æœªæ˜¾å¼åˆ—å‡ºçš„å€¼ã€‚è¿™ç§é€šé…æ¨¡å¼æ»¡è¶³äº† match å¿…é¡»ç©·å°½çš„è¦æ±‚ã€‚æ³¨æ„ï¼šé€šé…åˆ†æ”¯å¿…é¡»æ”¾åœ¨æœ€åï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ¨¡å¼æŒ‰é¡ºåºæ±‚å€¼ã€‚è‹¥å°†å…¶æå‰ï¼Œå…¶ä»–åˆ†æ”¯å°†æ— æ³•è¿è¡Œã€‚å› æ­¤è‹¥åœ¨é€šé…åˆ†æ”¯åæ·»åŠ åˆ†æ”¯ï¼ŒRust ä¼šå‘å‡ºè­¦å‘Šï¼

Rust also has a pattern we can use when we want a catch-all but donâ€™t want to use the value in the catch-all pattern: _ is a special pattern that matches any value and does not bind to that value. This tells Rust we arenâ€™t going to use the value, so Rust wonâ€™t warn us about an unused variable.

å½“éœ€è¦é€šé…ä½†ä¸æƒ³ä½¿ç”¨å€¼æ—¶ï¼ŒRust æä¾›äº†ç‰¹æ®Šæ¨¡å¼ _ï¼šå®ƒåŒ¹é…ä»»æ„å€¼ä¸”ä¸è¿›è¡Œç»‘å®šã€‚è¿™å‘ŠçŸ¥ Rust æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä¼šä½¿ç”¨è¯¥å€¼ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¸ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿæœªä½¿ç”¨å˜é‡çš„è­¦å‘Šã€‚

Letâ€™s change the rules of the game: now, if you roll anything other than a 3 or a 7, you must roll again. We no longer need to use the catch-all value, so we can change our code to use _ instead of the variable named other:

ç°åœ¨ä¿®æ”¹æ¸¸æˆè§„åˆ™ï¼šè‹¥æ·å‡ºé 3 æˆ– 7 çš„å€¼ï¼Œå¿…é¡»é‡æ·ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ä¸å†éœ€è¦é€šé…å€¼ï¼Œå¯å°† other æ”¹ä¸º _ï¼š

fn main() {
    let dice_roll = 9;
    match dice_roll {
        3 => add_fancy_hat(),
        7 => remove_fancy_hat(),
        _ => reroll(),
    }

    fn add_fancy_hat() {}
    fn remove_fancy_hat() {}
    fn reroll() {}
}

This example also meets the exhaustiveness requirement because weâ€™re explicitly ignoring all other values in the last arm; we havenâ€™t forgotten anything.

æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹åŒæ ·æ»¡è¶³ç©·å°½æ€§è¦æ±‚ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æœ€ååˆ†æ”¯æ˜¾å¼å¿½ç•¥äº†å…¶ä»–æ‰€æœ‰å€¼ã€‚

Finally, weâ€™ll change the rules of the game one more time so that nothing else happens on your turn if you roll anything other than a 3 or a 7. We can express that by using the unit value (the empty tuple type we mentioned in â€œThe Tuple Typeâ€ section) as the code that goes with the _ arm:

å†æ¬¡ä¿®æ”¹è§„åˆ™ï¼šæ·å‡ºé 3 æˆ– 7 æ—¶å›åˆæ— æ“ä½œã€‚å¯é€šè¿‡ _ åˆ†æ”¯ä½¿ç”¨å•å…ƒå€¼ï¼ˆå³â€œå…ƒç»„ç±»å‹â€œç« èŠ‚æåˆ°çš„ç©ºå…ƒç»„ç±»å‹ï¼‰å®ç°ï¼š

fn main() {
    let dice_roll = 9;
    match dice_roll {
        3 => add_fancy_hat(),
        7 => remove_fancy_hat(),
        _ => (),
    }

    fn add_fancy_hat() {}
    fn remove_fancy_hat() {}
}

Here, weâ€™re telling Rust explicitly that we arenâ€™t going to use any other value that doesnâ€™t match a pattern in an earlier arm, and we donâ€™t want to run any code in this case.

è¿™é‡Œæ˜¾å¼å‘ŠçŸ¥ Rustï¼šå¯¹äºä¸åŒ¹é…å‰åºåˆ†æ”¯çš„å€¼ï¼Œä¸æ‰§è¡Œä»»ä½•æ“ä½œã€‚

Thereâ€™s more about patterns and matching that weâ€™ll cover in Chapter 19. For now, weâ€™re going to move on to the if let syntax, which can be useful in situations where the match expression is a bit wordy.

å…³äºæ¨¡å¼ä¸åŒ¹é…çš„æ›´å¤šå†…å®¹å°†åœ¨ç¬¬ 19 ç« ä»‹ç»ã€‚ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç»§ç»­è®¨è®º if let è¯­æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒåœ¨ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼è¾ƒå†—é•¿æ—¶éå¸¸å®ç”¨ã€‚

Concise Control Flow with if let and let else ä½¿ç”¨ if let å’Œ let else ç®€åŒ–æ§åˆ¶æµ

The if let syntax lets you combine if and let into a less verbose way to handle values that match one pattern while ignoring the rest. Consider the program in Listing 6-6 that matches on an Option<u8> value in the config_max variable but only wants to execute code if the value is the Some variant.

if let è¯­æ³•å°† if å’Œ let ç»“åˆï¼Œæä¾›äº†ä¸€ç§æ›´ç®€æ´çš„æ–¹å¼æ¥å¤„ç†åŒ¹é…æŸä¸ªæ¨¡å¼çš„å€¼ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å¿½ç•¥å…¶ä»–æƒ…å†µã€‚å‚è€ƒç¤ºä¾‹ 6-6 ä¸­çš„ç¨‹åºï¼Œå®ƒå¯¹ config_max å˜é‡ä¸­çš„ Option<u8> å€¼è¿›è¡ŒåŒ¹é…ï¼Œä½†ä»…åœ¨å€¼ä¸º Some å˜ä½“æ—¶æ‰§è¡Œä»£ç ã€‚

If the value is Some, we print out the value in the Some variant by binding the value to the variable max in the pattern. We donâ€™t want to do anything with the None value. To satisfy the match expression, we have to add _ => () after processing just one variant, which is annoying boilerplate code to add.

è‹¥å€¼ä¸º Someï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡åœ¨æ¨¡å¼ä¸­å°†å€¼ç»‘å®šåˆ°å˜é‡ max æ¥æ‰“å° Some å˜ä½“ä¸­çš„å€¼ã€‚å¯¹äº None å€¼åˆ™æ— éœ€æ“ä½œã€‚ä¸ºäº†æ»¡è¶³ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„è¦æ±‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¿…é¡»åœ¨å¤„ç†ä¸€ä¸ªå˜ä½“åæ·»åŠ  _ => ()ï¼Œè¿™ç§æ ·æ¿ä»£ç æ˜¾å¾—å†—ä½™ã€‚

Instead, we could write this in a shorter way using if let. The following code behaves the same as the match in Listing 6-6:

ä½¿ç”¨ if let å¯ä»¥æ›´ç®€æ´åœ°å®ç°ç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç çš„è¡Œä¸ºä¸ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-6 ä¸­çš„ match ä¸€è‡´ï¼š

fn main() {
    let config_max = Some(3u8);
    if let Some(max) = config_max {
        println!("The maximum is configured to be {max}");
    }
}

The syntax if let takes a pattern and an expression separated by an equal sign. It works the same way as a match, where the expression is given to the match and the pattern is its first arm. In this case, the pattern is Some(max), and the max binds to the value inside the Some. We can then use max in the body of the if let block in the same way we used max in the corresponding match arm. The code in the if let block only runs if the value matches the pattern.

if let è¯­æ³•æ¥å—ç”±ç­‰å·åˆ†éš”çš„æ¨¡å¼å’Œè¡¨è¾¾å¼ã€‚å…¶å·¥ä½œæ–¹å¼ç±»ä¼¼äº matchï¼šå°†è¡¨è¾¾å¼æä¾›ç»™ matchï¼Œæ¨¡å¼ä½œä¸ºå…¶ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ã€‚æ­¤å¤„æ¨¡å¼ä¸º Some(max)ï¼Œmax ä¼šç»‘å®šåˆ° Some å†…éƒ¨çš„å€¼ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨ if let ä»£ç å—ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ maxï¼Œç”¨æ³•ä¸å¯¹åº” match åˆ†æ”¯ä¸­ä¸€è‡´ã€‚ä»…å½“å€¼åŒ¹é…æ¨¡å¼æ—¶ï¼Œif let å—ä¸­çš„ä»£ç æ‰ä¼šæ‰§è¡Œã€‚

Using if let means less typing, less indentation, and less boilerplate code. However, you lose the exhaustive checking match enforces that ensures you arenâ€™t forgetting to handle any cases. Choosing between match and if let depends on what youâ€™re doing in your particular situation and whether gaining conciseness is an appropriate trade-off for losing exhaustive checking.

ä½¿ç”¨ if let æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å°‘çš„è¾“å…¥ã€æ›´å°‘çš„ç¼©è¿›å’Œæ›´å°‘çš„æ ·æ¿ä»£ç ã€‚ä½†ä»£ä»·æ˜¯å¤±å»äº† match å¼ºåˆ¶æ‰§è¡Œçš„ç©·å°½æ€§æ£€æŸ¥ï¼ˆç¡®ä¿ä¸ä¼šé—æ¼å¤„ç†ä»»ä½•æƒ…å†µï¼‰ã€‚åœ¨ match å’Œ if let é—´çš„é€‰æ‹©å–å†³äºå…·ä½“åœºæ™¯ï¼Œéœ€æƒè¡¡ç®€æ´æ€§ä¸ç©·å°½æ€§æ£€æŸ¥çš„é‡è¦æ€§ã€‚

In other words, you can think of if let as syntax sugar for a match that runs code when the value matches one pattern and then ignores all other values.

æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œå¯å°† if let è§†ä¸º match çš„è¯­æ³•ç³–ï¼šå½“å€¼åŒ¹é…æŸä¸ªæ¨¡å¼æ—¶è¿è¡Œä»£ç ï¼Œå¹¶å¿½ç•¥æ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–å€¼ã€‚

We can include an else with an if let. The block of code that goes with the else is the same as the block of code that would go with the _ case in the match expression that is equivalent to the if let and else. Recall the Coin enum definition in Listing 6-4, where the Quarter variant also held a UsState value. If we wanted to count all non-quarter coins we see while also announcing the state of the quarters, we could do that with a match expression, like this:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨ if let åæ·»åŠ  elseã€‚else å…³è”çš„ä»£ç å—ç­‰åŒäºä¸ if let å’Œ else ç­‰ä»·çš„ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­ _ åˆ†æ”¯çš„ä»£ç å—ã€‚å›é¡¾ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-4 ä¸­çš„ Coin æšä¸¾å®šä¹‰ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ Quarter å˜ä½“åŒ…å« UsState å€¼ã€‚è‹¥è¦åœ¨ç»Ÿè®¡æ‰€æœ‰é 25 åˆ†ç¡¬å¸æ—¶åŒæ—¶æŠ¥å‘Š 25 åˆ†ç¡¬å¸çš„å·åï¼Œå¯ä½¿ç”¨ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼š

#[derive(Debug)]
enum UsState {
    Alabama,
    Alaska,
    // --snip--
}

enum Coin {
    Penny,
    Nickel,
    Dime,
    Quarter(UsState),
}

fn main() {
    let coin = Coin::Penny;
    let mut count = 0;
    match coin {
        Coin::Quarter(state) => println!("State quarter from {state:?}!"),
        _ => count += 1,
    }
}

Or we could use an if let and else expression, like this:

æˆ–ä½¿ç”¨ if let å’Œ else è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼š

#[derive(Debug)]
enum UsState {
    Alabama,
    Alaska,
    // --snip--
}

enum Coin {
    Penny,
    Nickel,
    Dime,
    Quarter(UsState),
}

fn main() {
    let coin = Coin::Penny;
    let mut count = 0;
    if let Coin::Quarter(state) = coin {
        println!("State quarter from {state:?}!");
    } else {
        count += 1;
    }
}

Staying on the â€œHappy Pathâ€ with let...else ä½¿ç”¨ let...else ä¿æŒâ€œå¿«ä¹è·¯å¾„â€œ

The common pattern is to perform some computation when a value is present and return a default value otherwise. Continuing on with our example of coins with a UsState value, if we wanted to say something funny depending on how old the state on the quarter was, we might introduce a method on UsState to check the age of a state, like so:

å¸¸è§æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å½“å€¼å­˜åœ¨æ—¶æ‰§è¡Œè®¡ç®—ï¼Œå¦åˆ™è¿”å›é»˜è®¤å€¼ã€‚å»¶ç»­åŒ…å« UsState å€¼çš„ç¡¬å¸ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼Œå‡è®¾è¦æ ¹æ® 25 åˆ†ç¡¬å¸ä¸Šå·çš„â€œå¹´é¾„â€œè¾“å‡ºè¶£å‘³ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¯ä¸º UsState æ·»åŠ æ£€æŸ¥å·å¹´é¾„çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

#[derive(Debug)] // so we can inspect the state in a minute
enum UsState {
    Alabama,
    Alaska,
    // --snip--
}

impl UsState {
    fn existed_in(&self, year: u16) -> bool {
        match self {
            UsState::Alabama => year >= 1819,
            UsState::Alaska => year >= 1959,
            // -- snip --
        }
    }
}

enum Coin {
    Penny,
    Nickel,
    Dime,
    Quarter(UsState),
}

fn describe_state_quarter(coin: Coin) -> Option<String> {
    if let Coin::Quarter(state) = coin {
        if state.existed_in(1900) {
            Some(format!("{state:?} is pretty old, for America!"))
        } else {
            Some(format!("{state:?} is relatively new."))
        }
    } else {
        None
    }
}

fn main() {
    if let Some(desc) = describe_state_quarter(Coin::Quarter(UsState::Alaska)) {
        println!("{desc}");
    }
}

Then we might use if let to match on the type of coin, introducing a state variable within the body of the condition, as in Listing 6-7.

æ¥ç€å¯ç”¨ if let åŒ¹é…ç¡¬å¸ç±»å‹ï¼Œåœ¨æ¡ä»¶ä½“å†…å¼•å…¥ state å˜é‡ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-7 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

That gets the job done, but it has pushed the work into the body of the if let statement, and if the work to be done is more complicated, it might be hard to follow exactly how the top-level branches relate. We could also take advantage of the fact that expressions produce a value either to produce the state from the if let or to return early, as in Listing 6-8. (You could do similar with a match, too.)

è¿™å®ç°äº†åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œä½†å°†é€»è¾‘æ¨å…¥äº† if let è¯­å¥å†…éƒ¨ã€‚è‹¥å¤„ç†é€»è¾‘æ›´å¤æ‚ï¼Œå°†éš¾ä»¥ç†æ¸…é¡¶å±‚åˆ†æ”¯çš„å…³ç³»ã€‚ä¹Ÿå¯åˆ©ç”¨è¡¨è¾¾å¼äº§ç”Ÿå€¼çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ if let äº§ç”Ÿ state æˆ–æå‰è¿”å›ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-8 æ‰€ç¤ºï¼ˆä½¿ç”¨ match ä¹Ÿå¯å®ç°ç±»ä¼¼æ•ˆæœï¼‰ã€‚

This is a bit annoying to follow in its own way, though! One branch of the if let produces a value, and the other one returns from the function entirely.

ä½†è¿™ç§å†™æ³•ä»æœ‰ç¼ºé™·ï¼šif let çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯äº§ç”Ÿå€¼ï¼Œå¦ä¸€åˆ†æ”¯åˆ™ç›´æ¥é€€å‡ºå‡½æ•°ã€‚

To make this common pattern nicer to express, Rust has let...else. The let...else syntax takes a pattern on the left side and an expression on the right, very similar to if let, but it does not have an if branch, only an else branch. If the pattern matches, it will bind the value from the pattern in the outer scope. If the pattern does not match, the program will flow into the else arm, which must return from the function.

ä¸ºä¼˜é›…è¡¨è¾¾æ­¤æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œ[note]Rust æä¾›äº† let...elseã€‚å…¶è¯­æ³•å·¦ä¾§æ¥å—æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå³ä¾§æ¥å—è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ if letï¼‰ï¼Œä½†æ²¡æœ‰ if åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œä»…å« else åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚è‹¥æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…ï¼Œåˆ™åœ¨å¤–éƒ¨ä½œç”¨åŸŸç»‘å®šæ¨¡å¼ä¸­çš„å€¼ï¼›è‹¥ä¸åŒ¹é…ï¼Œç¨‹åºå°†è¿›å…¥ else åˆ†æ”¯ï¼ˆè¯¥åˆ†æ”¯å¿…é¡»é€€å‡ºå‡½æ•°ï¼‰ã€‚

In Listing 6-9, you can see how Listing 6-8 looks when using let...else in place of if let.

ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-9 å±•ç¤ºäº†ç”¨ let...else é‡æ„ç¤ºä¾‹ 6-8 çš„æ•ˆæœã€‚

Notice that it stays â€œon the happy pathâ€ in the main body of the function this way, without having significantly different control flow for two branches the way the if let did.

è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼ä½¿å‡½æ•°ä¸»ä½“ä¿æŒåœ¨â€œå¿«ä¹è·¯å¾„â€œä¸Šï¼Œé¿å…äº† if let ä¸­ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯çš„æ˜¾è‘—æ§åˆ¶æµå·®å¼‚ã€‚

If you have a situation in which your program has logic that is too verbose to express using a match, remember that if let and let...else are in your Rust toolbox as well.

å½“ç¨‹åºä¸­å­˜åœ¨å› è¿‡äºå†—é•¿è€Œä¸é€‚åˆ match è¡¨è¾¾çš„é€»è¾‘æ—¶ï¼Œè¯·è®°ä½ Rust å·¥å…·ç®±ä¸­çš„ if let å’Œ let...elseã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

Weâ€™ve now covered how to use enums to create custom types that can be one of a set of enumerated values. Weâ€™ve shown how the standard libraryâ€™s Option<T> type helps you use the type system to prevent errors. When enum values have data inside them, you can use match or if let to extract and use those values, depending on how many cases you need to handle.

æˆ‘ä»¬å·²å­¦ä¹ å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾åˆ›å»ºåŒ…å«ä¸€ç»„æšä¸¾å€¼çš„è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¹¶å±•ç¤ºäº†æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ Option<T> ç±»å‹å¦‚ä½•åˆ©ç”¨ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿé¢„é˜²é”™è¯¯ã€‚å½“æšä¸¾å€¼åŒ…å«å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®æ—¶ï¼Œå¯æ ¹æ®éœ€å¤„ç†çš„æƒ…å†µæ•°é‡ï¼Œé€‰ç”¨ match æˆ– if let æå–å’Œä½¿ç”¨è¿™äº›å€¼ã€‚

Your Rust programs can now express concepts in your domain using structs and enums. Creating custom types to use in your API ensures type safety: the compiler will make certain your functions only get values of the type each function expects.

ç°åœ¨æ‚¨çš„ Rust ç¨‹åºå¯é€šè¿‡ç»“æ„ä½“å’Œæšä¸¾è¡¨è¾¾é¢†åŸŸæ¦‚å¿µã€‚åœ¨ API ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹èƒ½ç¡®ä¿ç±»å‹å®‰å…¨ï¼šç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¼šä¿è¯å‡½æ•°ä»…è·å–å…¶æœŸæœ›ç±»å‹çš„å€¼ã€‚

In order to provide a well-organized API to your users that is straightforward to use and only exposes exactly what your users will need, letâ€™s now turn to Rustâ€™s modules.

ä¸ºå‘ç”¨æˆ·æä¾›ç»„ç»‡è‰¯å¥½ã€æ˜“äºä½¿ç”¨ä¸”ç²¾å‡†æ»¡è¶³éœ€æ±‚çš„ APIï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢è®¨ Rust çš„æ¨¡å—ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚

Managing Growing Projects with Packages, Crates, and Modules ä½¿ç”¨åŒ…ã€ç®±å’Œæ¨¡å—ç®¡ç†å¢é•¿ä¸­çš„é¡¹ç›®

As you write large programs, organizing your code will become increasingly important. By grouping related functionality and separating code with distinct features, youâ€™ll clarify where to find code that implements a particular feature and where to go to change how a feature works.

éšç€ç¨‹åºè§„æ¨¡æ‰©å¤§ï¼Œä»£ç ç»„ç»‡çš„é‡è¦æ€§æ—¥ç›Šå‡¸æ˜¾ã€‚é€šè¿‡å°†ç›¸å…³åŠŸèƒ½åˆ†ç»„å¹¶åˆ†ç¦»ä¸åŒç‰¹æ€§çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œä½ èƒ½æ¸…æ™°å®šä½ç‰¹å®šåŠŸèƒ½çš„å®ç°ä»£ç æ‰€åœ¨ï¼Œä»¥åŠä¿®æ”¹åŠŸèƒ½é€»è¾‘çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚

The programs weâ€™ve written so far have been in one module in one file. As a project grows, you should organize code by splitting it into multiple modules and then multiple files. A package can contain multiple binary crates and optionally one library crate. As a package grows, you can extract parts into separate crates that become external dependencies. This chapter covers all these techniques. For very large projects comprising a set of interrelated packages that evolve together, Cargo provides workspaces, which weâ€™ll cover in â€œCargo Workspacesâ€ in Chapter 14.

ç›®å‰æˆ‘ä»¬ç¼–å†™çš„ç¨‹åºéƒ½ä½äºå•æ–‡ä»¶å•æ¨¡å—ä¸­ã€‚å½“é¡¹ç›®å¢é•¿æ—¶ï¼Œåº”é€šè¿‡æ‹†åˆ†å¤šä¸ªæ¨¡å—å†åˆ†è‡³å¤šä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶æ¥ç»„ç»‡ä»£ç ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…ï¼ˆpackageï¼‰å¯åŒ…å«å¤šä¸ªäºŒè¿›åˆ¶ç®±ï¼ˆbinary crateï¼‰ï¼Œè¿˜å¯é€‰æ‹©åŒ…å«ä¸€ä¸ªåº“ç®±ï¼ˆlibrary crateï¼‰ã€‚éšç€åŒ…ä½“é‡å¢é•¿ï¼Œå¯å°†éƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç æå–ä¸ºç‹¬ç«‹ç®±ä½œä¸ºå¤–éƒ¨ä¾èµ–ã€‚æœ¬ç« å°†æ¶µç›–æ‰€æœ‰è¿™äº›æŠ€æœ¯ã€‚å¯¹äºç”±å¤šä¸ªååŒæ¼”åŒ–çš„å…³è”åŒ…ç»„æˆçš„å¤§å‹é¡¹ç›®ï¼ŒCargo æä¾›äº† å·¥ä½œç©ºé—´ï¼ˆworkspacesï¼‰åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬14ç«  â€œCargo å·¥ä½œç©ºé—´â€ ä¸­æ¢è®¨ã€‚

Weâ€™ll also discuss encapsulating implementation details, which lets you reuse code at a higher level: once youâ€™ve implemented an operation, other code can call your code via its public interface without having to know how the implementation works. The way you write code defines which parts are public for other code to use and which parts are private implementation details that you reserve the right to change. This is another way to limit the amount of detail you have to keep in your head.

æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å°†è®¨è®ºå°è£…å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚ï¼Œè¿™èƒ½è®©ä½ åœ¨æ›´é«˜å±‚æ¬¡å¤ç”¨ä»£ç ï¼šæŸä¸ªæ“ä½œä¸€æ—¦å®ç°ï¼Œå…¶ä»–ä»£ç å¯é€šè¿‡å…¶å…¬å¼€æ¥å£è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œè€Œæ— éœ€äº†è§£å†…éƒ¨å®ç°ã€‚ä»£ç ç¼–å†™æ–¹å¼å†³å®šäº†å“ªäº›éƒ¨åˆ†å…¬å¼€ä¾›å¤–éƒ¨ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œå“ªäº›éƒ¨åˆ†ä½œä¸ºä¿ç•™ä¿®æ”¹æƒçš„ç§æœ‰å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å¦ä¸€ç§å‡å°‘å¿ƒæ™ºè´Ÿæ‹…çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

A related concept is scope: the nested context in which code is written has a set of names that are defined as â€œin scope.â€ When reading, writing, and compiling code, programmers and compilers need to know whether a particular name at a particular spot refers to a variable, function, struct, enum, module, constant, or other item and what that item means. You can create scopes and change which names are in or out of scope. You canâ€™t have two items with the same name in the same scope; tools are available to resolve name conflicts.

ç›¸å…³æ¦‚å¿µæ˜¯ä½œç”¨åŸŸï¼ˆscopeï¼‰ï¼šä»£ç æ‰€å¤„çš„åµŒå¥—ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ç¯å¢ƒåŒ…å«ä¸€ç»„â€œåœ¨ä½œç”¨åŸŸå†…â€œçš„å®šä¹‰åç§°ã€‚ç¨‹åºå‘˜å’Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨åœ¨è¯»å†™ã€ç¼–è¯‘ä»£ç æ—¶ï¼Œéœ€æ˜ç¡®ç‰¹å®šä½ç½®çš„åç§°æ‰€æŒ‡ä»£çš„æ˜¯å˜é‡ã€å‡½æ•°ã€ç»“æ„ä½“ã€æšä¸¾ã€æ¨¡å—ã€å¸¸é‡æˆ–å…¶ä»–æ¡ç›®åŠå…¶å«ä¹‰ã€‚ä½ å¯åˆ›å»ºä½œç”¨åŸŸå¹¶æ§åˆ¶åç§°çš„å¯è§æ€§ã€‚åŒä¸€ä½œç”¨åŸŸå†…ä¸å…è®¸å­˜åœ¨åŒåæ¡ç›®ï¼›Rust æä¾›äº†è§£å†³å‘½åå†²çªçš„å·¥å…·ã€‚

Rust has a number of features that allow you to manage your codeâ€™s organization, including which details are exposed, which details are private, and what names are in each scope in your programs. These features, sometimes collectively referred to as the module system, include:

Rust é€šè¿‡å¤šé¡¹ç‰¹æ€§ç®¡ç†ä»£ç ç»„ç»‡æ–¹å¼ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬ç»†èŠ‚çš„å…¬å¼€æ€§ã€ç§æœ‰æ€§ä»¥åŠç¨‹åºä¸­å„ä½œç”¨åŸŸçš„åç§°ç®¡ç†ã€‚è¿™äº›å¸¸è¢«ç»Ÿç§°ä¸ºæ¨¡å—ç³»ç»Ÿçš„ç‰¹æ€§åŒ…å«ï¼š

  • Packages: A Cargo feature that lets you build, test, and share crates
  • åŒ…ï¼ˆPackagesï¼‰ï¼šCargo æä¾›çš„æ„å»ºã€æµ‹è¯•å’Œå…±äº«ç®±çš„åŠŸèƒ½
  • Crates: A tree of modules that produces a library or executable
  • ç®±ï¼ˆCratesï¼‰ï¼šç”Ÿæˆåº“æˆ–å¯æ‰§è¡Œæ–‡ä»¶çš„æ¨¡å—æ ‘ç»“æ„
  • Modules and use: Let you control the organization, scope, and privacy of
  • æ¨¡å—ä¸ useï¼šæ§åˆ¶è·¯å¾„çš„ç»„ç»‡æ–¹å¼ã€ä½œç”¨åŸŸå’Œç§æœ‰æ€§ paths
  • Paths: A way of naming an item, such as a struct, function, or module
  • è·¯å¾„ï¼ˆPathsï¼‰ï¼šå‘½åæ¡ç›®çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼Œå¦‚ç»“æ„ä½“ã€å‡½æ•°æˆ–æ¨¡å—

In this chapter, weâ€™ll cover all these features, discuss how they interact, and explain how to use them to manage scope. By the end, you should have a solid understanding of the module system and be able to work with scopes like a pro!

æœ¬ç« å°†æ¶µç›–æ‰€æœ‰ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œé˜é‡Šå…¶åä½œæœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå¹¶è¯´æ˜å¦‚ä½•åˆ©ç”¨å®ƒä»¬ç®¡ç†ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚å­¦å®Œæœ¬ç« ï¼Œä½ å°†å¯¹æ¨¡å—ç³»ç»Ÿå»ºç«‹æ‰å®ç†è§£ï¼Œå¹¶èƒ½åƒä¸“å®¶èˆ¬é©¾é©­ä½œç”¨åŸŸï¼

Packages and Crates åŒ…ä¸ç®±

The first parts of the module system weâ€™ll cover are packages and crates.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†è¦æ¢è®¨æ¨¡å—ç³»ç»Ÿçš„ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†æ˜¯åŒ…ï¼ˆpackagesï¼‰å’Œç®±ï¼ˆcratesï¼‰ã€‚

A crate is the smallest amount of code that the Rust compiler considers at a time. Even if you run rustc rather than cargo and pass a single source code file (as we did all the way back in â€œWriting and Running a Rust Programâ€ in Chapter 1), the compiler considers that file to be a crate. Crates can contain modules, and the modules may be defined in other files that get compiled with the crate, as weâ€™ll see in the coming sections.

ä¸€ä¸ªç®±ï¼ˆcrateï¼‰æ˜¯ Rust ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¸€æ¬¡å¤„ç†çš„æœ€å°ä»£ç å•å…ƒã€‚å³ä½¿ä½ ç›´æ¥è¿è¡Œ rustc è€Œé cargo å¹¶ä¼ é€’å•ä¸ªæºä»£ç æ–‡ä»¶ï¼ˆå¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 1 ç« â€œç¼–å†™å¹¶è¿è¡Œ Rust ç¨‹åºâ€ä¸­æ‰€åšçš„é‚£æ ·ï¼‰ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¹Ÿä¼šå°†è¯¥æ–‡ä»¶è§†ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªç®±ã€‚ç®±å¯ä»¥åŒ…å«æ¨¡å—ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ¨¡å—å¯ä»¥å®šä¹‰åœ¨ä¸ç®±å…±åŒç¼–è¯‘çš„å…¶ä»–æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­ï¼ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨åç»­ç« èŠ‚ä¸­çœ‹åˆ°ï¼‰ã€‚

A crate can come in one of two forms: a binary crate or a library crate. Binary crates are programs you can compile to an executable that you can run, such as a command line program or a server. Each must have a function called main that defines what happens when the executable runs. All the crates weâ€™ve created so far have been binary crates.

ç®±æœ‰ä¸¤ç§å½¢å¼ï¼šäºŒè¿›åˆ¶ç®±æˆ–åº“ç®±ã€‚äºŒè¿›åˆ¶ç®±å¯ç¼–è¯‘æˆå¯æ‰§è¡Œç¨‹åºè¿è¡Œï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå·¥å…·æˆ–æœåŠ¡å™¨ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªäºŒè¿›åˆ¶ç®±å¿…é¡»åŒ…å«åä¸º main çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç”¨äºå®šä¹‰å¯æ‰§è¡Œæ–‡ä»¶è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„è¡Œä¸ºã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ç›®å‰åˆ›å»ºçš„æ‰€æœ‰ç®±éƒ½æ˜¯äºŒè¿›åˆ¶ç®±ã€‚

Library crates donâ€™t have a main function, and they donâ€™t compile to an executable. Instead, they define functionality intended to be shared with multiple projects. For example, the rand crate we used in Chapter 2 provides functionality that generates random numbers. Most of the time when Rustaceans say â€œcrate,â€ they mean library crate, and they use â€œcrateâ€ interchangeably with the general programming concept of a â€œlibrary.â€

åº“ç®±æ²¡æœ‰ main å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šç¼–è¯‘æˆå¯æ‰§è¡Œæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚å®ƒä»¬å®šä¹‰çš„åŠŸèƒ½æ—¨åœ¨ä¾›å¤šä¸ªé¡¹ç›®å…±äº«ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 2 ç« ä½¿ç”¨çš„ rand ç®±æä¾›äº†ç”Ÿæˆéšæœºæ•°çš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚å½“ Rust å¼€å‘è€…æåˆ°â€œç®±â€æ—¶ï¼Œé€šå¸¸æŒ‡åº“ç®±ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸é€šç”¨ç¼–ç¨‹æ¦‚å¿µä¸­çš„â€œåº“â€ï¼ˆlibraryï¼‰äº’æ¢ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚
