æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 4 ç« è®¨è®ºè¿‡å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œç°åœ¨å°†æ›´æ·±å…¥åœ°æ¢è®¨å®ƒä»¬ã€‚Rust æ–°æ‰‹é€šå¸¸ä¼šåœ¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸Šé‡åˆ°å›°éš¾ï¼ŒåŸå› æœ‰ä¸‰ç‚¹ç»„åˆï¼šRust å€¾å‘äºæš´éœ²å¯èƒ½çš„é”™è¯¯ã€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ˜¯æ¯”è®¸å¤šç¨‹åºå‘˜è®¤ä¸ºçš„æ›´å¤æ‚çš„æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ã€ä»¥åŠ UTF-8ã€‚å½“ä½ ä»å…¶ä»–ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€è½¬å‘ Rust æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™äº›å› ç´ ç»“åˆåœ¨ä¸€èµ·å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ˜¾å¾—å›°éš¾ã€‚

We discuss strings in the context of collections because strings are implemented as a collection of bytes, plus some methods to provide useful functionality when those bytes are interpreted as text. In this section, weâ€™ll talk about the operations on String that every collection type has, such as creating, updating, and reading. Weâ€™ll also discuss the ways in which String is different from the other collections, namely how indexing into a String is complicated by the differences between how people and computers interpret String data.

æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨é›†åˆçš„ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­è®¨è®ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æœ¬è´¨ä¸Šæ˜¯å­—èŠ‚çš„é›†åˆï¼ŒåŠ ä¸Šä¸€äº›åœ¨å°†è¿™äº›å­—èŠ‚è§£é‡Šä¸ºæ–‡æœ¬æ—¶æä¾›å®ç”¨åŠŸèƒ½çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æœ¬èŠ‚ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†è®¨è®ºæ¯ä¸ªé›†åˆç±»å‹éƒ½æœ‰çš„ String æ“ä½œï¼Œå¦‚åˆ›å»ºã€æ›´æ–°å’Œè¯»å–ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å°†æ¢è®¨ String ä¸å…¶ä»–é›†åˆçš„ä¸åŒä¹‹å¤„ï¼Œå³ç”±äºäººå’Œè®¡ç®—æœºè§£é‡Š String æ•°æ®æ–¹å¼çš„å·®å¼‚ï¼Œå¯¹ String è¿›è¡Œç´¢å¼•æ“ä½œä¼šå˜å¾—å¤æ‚ã€‚

What Is a String? ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Ÿ

Weâ€™ll first define what we mean by the term string. Rust has only one string type in the core language, which is the string slice str that is usually seen in its borrowed form &str. In Chapter 4, we talked about string slices, which are references to some UTF-8 encoded string data stored elsewhere. String literals, for example, are stored in the programâ€™s binary and are therefore string slices.

æˆ‘ä»¬é¦–å…ˆå®šä¹‰æœ¯è¯­å­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„å«ä¹‰ã€‚[note]Rust æ ¸å¿ƒè¯­è¨€ä¸­åªæœ‰ä¸€ç§å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç±»å‹ï¼Œå³å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ strï¼Œé€šå¸¸ä»¥å€Ÿç”¨çš„å½¢å¼ &str å‡ºç°ã€‚åœ¨ç¬¬ 4 ç« ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è®¨è®ºè¿‡å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬æ˜¯å¯¹å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹çš„ UTF-8 ç¼–ç å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°æ®çš„å¼•ç”¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—é¢å€¼å­˜å‚¨åœ¨ç¨‹åºäºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­ï¼Œå› æ­¤å±äºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ã€‚

The String type, which is provided by Rustâ€™s standard library rather than coded into the core language, is a growable, mutable, owned, UTF-8 encoded string type. When Rustaceans refer to â€œstringsâ€ in Rust, they might be referring to either the String or the string slice &str types, not just one of those types. Although this section is largely about String, both types are used heavily in Rustâ€™s standard library, and both String and string slices are UTF-8 encoded.

String ç±»å‹ç”± Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›ï¼ˆè€Œéå†…ç½®äºæ ¸å¿ƒè¯­è¨€ï¼‰ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ç§å¯å¢é•¿ã€å¯å˜ã€æ‹¥æœ‰æ‰€æœ‰æƒçš„ UTF-8 ç¼–ç å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç±»å‹ã€‚å½“ Rustacean æåˆ° Rust ä¸­çš„â€œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²â€œæ—¶ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æŒ‡ String æˆ–å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ &str ç±»å‹ï¼Œè€Œéç‰¹æŒ‡å…¶ä¸€ã€‚è™½ç„¶æœ¬èŠ‚ä¸»è¦è®¨è®º Stringï¼Œä½†ä¸¤ç§ç±»å‹åœ¨ Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸­éƒ½å¤§é‡ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä¸” String å’Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡éƒ½æ˜¯ UTF-8 ç¼–ç çš„ã€‚

Creating a New String åˆ›å»ºæ–°å­—ç¬¦ä¸²

Many of the same operations available with Vec<T> are available with String as well because String is actually implemented as a wrapper around a vector of bytes with some extra guarantees, restrictions, and capabilities. An example of a function that works the same way with Vec<T> and String is the new function to create an instance, shown in Listing 8-11.

è®¸å¤šå¯ç”¨äº Vec<T> çš„æ“ä½œåŒæ ·é€‚ç”¨äº Stringï¼Œå› ä¸º String æœ¬è´¨ä¸Šæ˜¯å­—èŠ‚å‘é‡çš„åŒ…è£…å™¨ï¼Œå¹¶å…·æœ‰é¢å¤–çš„ä¿è¯ã€é™åˆ¶å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚Vec<T> å’Œ String ç”¨æ³•ç›¸åŒçš„å‡½æ•°ç¤ºä¾‹æ˜¯åˆ›å»ºå®ä¾‹çš„ new å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-11 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

This line creates a new, empty string called s, into which we can then load data. Often, weâ€™ll have some initial data with which we want to start the string. For that, we use the to_string method, which is available on any type that implements the Display trait, as string literals do. Listing 8-12 shows two examples.

æ­¤è¡Œä»£ç åˆ›å»ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªåä¸º s çš„æ–°ç©ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œéšåå¯å‘å…¶åŠ è½½æ•°æ®ã€‚é€šå¸¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šç”¨åˆå§‹æ•°æ®åˆå§‹åŒ–å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶[note]å¯ä½¿ç”¨ to_string æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¯¥æ–¹æ³•é€‚ç”¨äºä»»ä½•å®ç°äº† Display trait çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—é¢å€¼å³å±æ­¤ç±»ï¼‰ã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-12 å±•ç¤ºäº†ä¸¤ä¸ªç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚

This code creates a string containing initial contents.

æ­¤ä»£ç åˆ›å»ºäº†åŒ…å« initial contents çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚

We can also use the function String::from to create a String from a string literal. The code in Listing 8-13 is equivalent to the code in Listing 8-12 that uses to_string.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ä½¿ç”¨ String::from å‡½æ•°ä»å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—é¢å€¼åˆ›å»º Stringã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-13 ç­‰æ•ˆäºä½¿ç”¨ to_string çš„ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-12ã€‚

Because strings are used for so many things, we can use many different generic APIs for strings, providing us with a lot of options. Some of them can seem redundant, but they all have their place! In this case, String::from and to_string do the same thing, so which one you choose is a matter of style and readability.

ç”±äºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç”¨é€”å¹¿æ³›ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨è®¸å¤šä¸åŒçš„é€šç”¨ APIï¼Œæä¾›äº†å¤šç§é€‰æ‹©ã€‚å…¶ä¸­æœ‰äº›çœ‹ä¼¼å†—ä½™ï¼Œä½†å„æœ‰é€‚ç”¨åœºæ™¯ï¼æ­¤å¤„ String::from å’Œ to_string åŠŸèƒ½ç›¸åŒï¼Œé€‰æ‹©å–å†³äºä»£ç é£æ ¼å’Œå¯è¯»æ€§ã€‚

Remember that strings are UTF-8 encoded, so we can include any properly encoded data in them, as shown in Listing 8-14.

è¯·è®°ä½å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ˜¯ UTF-8 ç¼–ç çš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯ä»¥åŒ…å«ä»»ä½•æ­£ç¡®ç¼–ç çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-14 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

All of these are valid String values.

ä»¥ä¸Šæ‰€æœ‰å­—ç¬¦ä¸²éƒ½æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆçš„ String å€¼ã€‚

Updating a String æ›´æ–°å­—ç¬¦ä¸²

A String can grow in size and its contents can change, just like the contents of a Vec<T>, if you push more data into it. In addition, you can conveniently use the + operator or the format! macro to concatenate String values.

String çš„å¤§å°å¯ä»¥å¢é•¿ï¼Œå†…å®¹ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥æ›´æ”¹ï¼Œå°±åƒ Vec<T> çš„å†…å®¹ä¸€æ ·â€”â€”åªéœ€å‘å…¶ä¸­æ¨é€æ›´å¤šæ•°æ®ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥æ–¹ä¾¿åœ°ä½¿ç”¨ + è¿ç®—ç¬¦æˆ– format! å®æ¥æ‹¼æ¥ String å€¼ã€‚

Appending to a String with push_str and push ä½¿ç”¨ push_str å’Œ push è¿½åŠ å­—ç¬¦ä¸²

We can grow a String by using the push_str method to append a string slice, as shown in Listing 8-15.

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ push_str æ–¹æ³•è¿½åŠ å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡æ¥å¢é•¿ Stringï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-15 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

After these two lines, s will contain foobar. The push_str method takes a string slice because we donâ€™t necessarily want to take ownership of the parameter. For example, in the code in Listing 8-16, we want to be able to use s2 after appending its contents to s1.

æ‰§è¡Œè¿™ä¸¤è¡Œåï¼Œs å°†åŒ…å« foobarã€‚push_str æ–¹æ³•æ¥æ”¶å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡å‚æ•°ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä¸€å®šéœ€è¦è·å–å‚æ•°çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-16 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›å°† s2 çš„å†…å®¹è¿½åŠ åˆ° s1 åä»èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ s2ã€‚

If the push_str method took ownership of s2, we wouldnâ€™t be able to print its value on the last line. However, this code works as weâ€™d expect!

å¦‚æœ push_str æ–¹æ³•è·å–äº† s2 çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±æ— æ³•åœ¨æœ€åä¸€è¡Œæ‰“å°å…¶å€¼ã€‚ä½†è¿™æ®µä»£ç èƒ½æŒ‰é¢„æœŸå·¥ä½œï¼

The push method takes a single character as a parameter and adds it to the String. Listing 8-17 adds the letter l to a String using the push method.

push æ–¹æ³•æ¥æ”¶å•ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°å¹¶å°†å…¶æ·»åŠ åˆ° Stringã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-17 ä½¿ç”¨ push æ–¹æ³•å°†å­—æ¯ l æ·»åŠ åˆ° Stringã€‚

As a result, s will contain lol.

æœ€ç»ˆ s å°†åŒ…å« lolã€‚

Concatenation with the + Operator or the format! Macro ä½¿ç”¨ + è¿ç®—ç¬¦æˆ– format! å®è¿›è¡Œæ‹¼æ¥

Often, youâ€™ll want to combine two existing strings. One way to do so is to use the + operator, as shown in Listing 8-18.

é€šå¸¸éœ€è¦ç»„åˆä¸¤ä¸ªç°æœ‰å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ + è¿ç®—ç¬¦ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-18 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

The string s3 will contain Hello, world!. The reason s1 is no longer valid after the addition, and the reason we used a reference to s2, has to do with the signature of the method thatâ€™s called when we use the + operator. The + operator uses the add method, whose signature looks something like this:

å­—ç¬¦ä¸² s3 å°†åŒ…å« Hello, world!ã€‚[note]s1 åœ¨åŠ æ³•åä¸å†æœ‰æ•ˆä»¥åŠæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ s2 å¼•ç”¨çš„åŸå› ï¼Œä¸ä½¿ç”¨ + è¿ç®—ç¬¦æ—¶è°ƒç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åæœ‰å…³ã€‚+ è¿ç®—ç¬¦ä½¿ç”¨ add æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå…¶ç­¾åç±»ä¼¼å¦‚ä¸‹å½¢å¼ï¼š

fn add(self, s: &str) -> String {

In the standard library, youâ€™ll see add defined using generics and associated types. Here, weâ€™ve substituted in concrete types, which is what happens when we call this method with String values. Weâ€™ll discuss generics in Chapter 10. This signature gives us the clues we need in order to understand the tricky bits of the + operator.

åœ¨æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸­ï¼Œä½ ä¼šçœ‹åˆ° add ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹å’Œå…³è”ç±»å‹å®šä¹‰ã€‚è¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºå…·ä½“ç±»å‹ï¼ˆä½¿ç”¨ String å€¼è°ƒç”¨æ­¤æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿè¿™ç§æ›¿æ¢ï¼‰ã€‚ç¬¬ 10 ç« å°†è®¨è®ºæ³›å‹ã€‚æ­¤ç­¾åæ­ç¤ºäº† + è¿ç®—ç¬¦çš„å¾®å¦™ä¹‹å¤„ã€‚

First, s2 has an &, meaning that weâ€™re adding a reference of the second string to the first string. This is because of the s parameter in the add function: we can only add a &str to a String; we canâ€™t add two String values together. But waitâ€”the type of &s2 is &String, not &str, as specified in the second parameter to add. So why does Listing 8-18 compile?

é¦–å…ˆï¼Œs2 å¸¦æœ‰ &ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„å¼•ç”¨æ·»åŠ åˆ°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸º add å‡½æ•°çš„ s å‚æ•°ï¼šåªèƒ½å°† &str æ·»åŠ åˆ° Stringï¼Œä¸èƒ½ç›´æ¥æ·»åŠ ä¸¤ä¸ª String å€¼ã€‚ä½†è¯·æ³¨æ„â€”â€”&s2 çš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯ &String è€Œé add ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå‚æ•°è¦æ±‚çš„ &strã€‚ä¸ºä½•ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-18 èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Ÿ

The reason weâ€™re able to use &s2 in the call to add is that the compiler can coerce the &String argument into a &str. When we call the add method, Rust uses a deref coercion, which here turns &s2 into &s2[..]. Weâ€™ll discuss deref coercion in more depth in Chapter 15. Because add does not take ownership of the s parameter, s2 will still be a valid String after this operation.

åŸå› åœ¨äºç¼–è¯‘å™¨èƒ½å°† &String å‚æ•°å¼ºåˆ¶è½¬æ¢ä¸º &strã€‚è°ƒç”¨ add æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ï¼ŒRust ä½¿ç”¨è§£å¼•ç”¨å¼ºåˆ¶è½¬æ¢ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„å°† &s2 è½¬æ¢ä¸º &s2[..]ï¼‰ã€‚ç¬¬ 15 ç« å°†æ·±å…¥è®¨è®ºè§£å¼•ç”¨å¼ºåˆ¶è½¬æ¢ã€‚ç”±äº add ä¸è·å–å‚æ•° s çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œs2 åœ¨æ­¤æ“ä½œåä»æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆçš„ Stringã€‚

Second, we can see in the signature that add takes ownership of self because self does not have an &. This means s1 in Listing 8-18 will be moved into the add call and will no longer be valid after that. So, although let s3 = s1 + &s2; looks like it will copy both strings and create a new one, this statement actually takes ownership of s1, appends a copy of the contents of s2, and then returns ownership of the result. In other words, it looks like itâ€™s making a lot of copies, but it isnâ€™t; the implementation is more efficient than copying.

å…¶æ¬¡ï¼Œä»ç­¾åå¯è§ add è·å–äº† self çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼ˆå›  self æ²¡æœ‰ &ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-18 ä¸­çš„ s1 å°†è¢«ç§»å…¥ add è°ƒç”¨å¹¶åœ¨ä¹‹åå¤±æ•ˆã€‚å› æ­¤å°½ç®¡ let s3 = s1 + &s2; çœ‹ä¼¼ä¼šå¤åˆ¶ä¸¤ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹¶åˆ›å»ºæ–°å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œå®é™…æ˜¯è·å– s1 çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œè¿½åŠ  s2 å†…å®¹çš„å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œç„¶åè¿”å›ç»“æœçš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œçœ‹ä¼¼æ‰§è¡Œå¤šæ¬¡å¤åˆ¶ï¼Œå®åˆ™ä¸ç„¶ï¼›å…¶å®ç°æ¯”å¤åˆ¶æ›´é«˜æ•ˆã€‚

If we need to concatenate multiple strings, the behavior of the + operator gets unwieldy:

è‹¥éœ€æ‹¼æ¥å¤šä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œ+ è¿ç®—ç¬¦ä¼šå˜å¾—ç¬¨æ‹™ï¼š

fn main() {
    let s1 = String::from("tic");
    let s2 = String::from("tac");
    let s3 = String::from("toe");

    let s = s1 + "-" + &s2 + "-" + &s3;
}

At this point, s will be tic-tac-toe. With all of the + and " characters, itâ€™s difficult to see whatâ€™s going on. For combining strings in more complicated ways, we can instead use the format! macro:

æ­¤æ—¶ s å°†ä¸º tic-tac-toeã€‚è¿‡å¤šçš„ + å’Œ " ä½¿ä»£ç éš¾ä»¥é˜…è¯»ã€‚å¯¹äºå¤æ‚å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç»„åˆï¼Œå¯æ”¹ç”¨ format! å®ï¼š

fn main() {
    let s1 = String::from("tic");
    let s2 = String::from("tac");
    let s3 = String::from("toe");

    let s = format!("{s1}-{s2}-{s3}");
}

This code also sets s to tic-tac-toe. The format! macro works like println!, but instead of printing the output to the screen, it returns a String with the contents. The version of the code using format! is much easier to read, and the code generated by the format! macro uses references so that this call doesnâ€™t take ownership of any of its parameters.

æ­¤ä»£ç åŒæ ·è®¾ç½® s ä¸º tic-tac-toeã€‚[note]format! å®ç±»ä¼¼ println!ï¼Œä½†ä¸è¾“å‡ºåˆ°å±å¹•è€Œæ˜¯è¿”å›åŒ…å«å†…å®¹çš„ Stringã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ format! çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬æ›´æ˜“è¯»ï¼Œä¸”å…¶ç”Ÿæˆçš„ä»£ç ä½¿ç”¨å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œä¸ä¼šè·å–ä»»ä½•å‚æ•°çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚

Indexing into Strings å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç´¢å¼•

In many other programming languages, accessing individual characters in a string by referencing them by index is a valid and common operation. However, if you try to access parts of a String using indexing syntax in Rust, youâ€™ll get an error. Consider the invalid code in Listing 8-19.

åœ¨è®¸å¤šç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ä¸­ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ç´¢å¼•è®¿é—®å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸­çš„å•ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆä¸”å¸¸è§çš„æ“ä½œã€‚ä½†åœ¨ Rust ä¸­å°è¯•ä½¿ç”¨ç´¢å¼•è¯­æ³•è®¿é—® String éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹ä¼šå¯¼è‡´é”™è¯¯ã€‚å‚è€ƒä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-19 ä¸­çš„æ— æ•ˆä»£ç ã€‚

This code will result in the following error:

æ­¤ä»£ç å°†å¯¼è‡´ä»¥ä¸‹é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling collections v0.1.0 (file:///projects/collections)
error[E0277]: the type `str` cannot be indexed by `{integer}`
 --> src/main.rs:3:16
  |
3 |     let h = s1[0];
  |                ^ string indices are ranges of `usize`
  |
  = note: you can use `.chars().nth()` or `.bytes().nth()`
          for more information, see chapter 8 in The Book: <https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch08-02-strings.html#indexing-into-strings>
  = help: the trait `SliceIndex<str>` is not implemented for `{integer}`
          but trait `SliceIndex<[_]>` is implemented for `usize`
  = help: for that trait implementation, expected `[_]`, found `str`
  = note: required for `String` to implement `Index<{integer}>`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `collections` (bin "collections") due to 1 previous error

The error and the note tell the story: Rust strings donâ€™t support indexing. But why not? To answer that question, we need to discuss how Rust stores strings in memory.

é”™è¯¯å’Œè¯´æ˜æ­ç¤ºäº†åŸå› ï¼šRust å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸æ”¯æŒç´¢å¼•ã€‚ä½†ä¸ºä½•å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Ÿè¦å›ç­”æ­¤é—®é¢˜ï¼Œéœ€æ¢è®¨ Rust å¦‚ä½•åœ¨å†…å­˜ä¸­å­˜å‚¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚

Internal Representation å†…éƒ¨è¡¨ç¤º

A String is a wrapper over a Vec<u8>. Letâ€™s look at some of our properly encoded UTF-8 example strings from Listing 8-14. First, this one:

String æ˜¯ Vec<u8> çš„åŒ…è£…å™¨ã€‚è§‚å¯Ÿä»£ç æ¸…å• 8-14 ä¸­æ­£ç¡®ç¼–ç çš„ UTF-8 ç¤ºä¾‹å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚é¦–å…ˆæ˜¯ï¼š

fn main() {
    let hello = String::from("Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ…");
    let hello = String::from("DobrÃ½ den");
    let hello = String::from("Hello");
    let hello = String::from("×©×œ×•×");
    let hello = String::from("à¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡");
    let hello = String::from("ã“ã‚“ã«ã¡ã¯");
    let hello = String::from("ì•ˆë…•í•˜ì„¸ìš”");
    let hello = String::from("ä½ å¥½");
    let hello = String::from("OlÃ¡");
    let hello = String::from("Ğ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ");
    let hello = String::from("Hola");
}

In this case, len will be 4, which means the vector storing the string "Hola" is 4 bytes long. Each of these letters takes one byte when encoded in UTF-8. The following line, however, may surprise you (note that this string begins with the capital Cyrillic letter Ze, not the number 3):

æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸­ len ä¸º 4ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºå­˜å‚¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸² "Hola" çš„å‘é‡é•¿åº¦ä¸º 4 å­—èŠ‚ï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªå­—æ¯åœ¨ UTF-8 ç¼–ç ä¸­å„å  1 å­—èŠ‚ï¼‰ã€‚ä½†ä¸‹é¢ä¸€è¡Œå¯èƒ½ä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶ï¼ˆæ³¨æ„æ­¤å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä»¥å¤§å†™è¥¿é‡Œå°”å­—æ¯ Ze å¼€å¤´ï¼Œè€Œéæ•°å­— 3ï¼‰ï¼š

fn main() {
    let hello = String::from("Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù„Ø§Ù… Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙƒÙ…");
    let hello = String::from("DobrÃ½ den");
    let hello = String::from("Hello");
    let hello = String::from("×©×œ×•×");
    let hello = String::from("à¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡");
    let hello = String::from("ã“ã‚“ã«ã¡ã¯");
    let hello = String::from("ì•ˆë…•í•˜ì„¸ìš”");
    let hello = String::from("ä½ å¥½");
    let hello = String::from("OlÃ¡");
    let hello = String::from("Ğ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ");
    let hello = String::from("Hola");
}

If you were asked how long the string is, you might say 12. In fact, Rustâ€™s answer is 24: thatâ€™s the number of bytes it takes to encode â€œĞ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµâ€ in UTF-8, because each Unicode scalar value in that string takes 2 bytes of storage. Therefore, an index into the stringâ€™s bytes will not always correlate to a valid Unicode scalar value. To demonstrate, consider this invalid Rust code:

è‹¥é—®æ­¤å­—ç¬¦ä¸²é•¿åº¦ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½å›ç­” 12ã€‚ä½† Rust ç»™å‡ºçš„ç­”æ¡ˆæ˜¯ 24â€”â€”è¿™æ˜¯ â€œĞ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµâ€ çš„ UTF-8 ç¼–ç å­—èŠ‚æ•°ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸­æ¯ä¸ª Unicode æ ‡é‡å€¼å  2 å­—èŠ‚å­˜å‚¨ç©ºé—´ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—èŠ‚çš„ç´¢å¼•å¹¶ä¸æ€»æ˜¯å¯¹åº”æœ‰æ•ˆçš„ Unicode æ ‡é‡å€¼ã€‚å‚è€ƒä»¥ä¸‹æ— æ•ˆ Rust ä»£ç ï¼š

let hello = "Ğ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ";
let answer = &hello[0];

You already know that answer will not be Ğ—, the first letter. When encoded in UTF-8, the first byte of Ğ— is 208 and the second is 151, so it would seem that answer should in fact be 208, but 208 is not a valid character on its own. Returning 208 is likely not what a user would want if they asked for the first letter of this string; however, thatâ€™s the only data that Rust has at byte index 0. Users generally donâ€™t want the byte value returned, even if the string contains only Latin letters: if &"hi"[0] were valid code that returned the byte value, it would return 104, not h.

å·²çŸ¥ answer ä¸ä¼šæ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå­—æ¯ Ğ—ã€‚Ğ— çš„ UTF-8 ç¼–ç é¦–å­—èŠ‚ä¸º 208ï¼Œæ¬¡å­—èŠ‚ä¸º 151ï¼Œå› æ­¤ answer å®é™…åº”ä¸º 208ï¼Œä½† 208 æœ¬èº«ä¸æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆå­—ç¬¦ã€‚è¿”å› 208 å¾ˆå¯èƒ½ä¸ç¬¦åˆç”¨æˆ·è·å–é¦–å­—æ¯çš„é¢„æœŸï¼›ä½†è¿™æ˜¯ Rust åœ¨å­—èŠ‚ç´¢å¼• 0 å¤„çš„å”¯ä¸€æ•°æ®ã€‚å³ä½¿å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä»…å«æ‹‰ä¸å­—æ¯ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·é€šå¸¸ä¹Ÿä¸éœ€è¦è¿”å›å­—èŠ‚å€¼ï¼šè‹¥ &"hi"[0] æ˜¯è¿”å›å­—èŠ‚å€¼çš„æœ‰æ•ˆä»£ç ï¼Œå°†è¿”å› 104 è€Œé hã€‚

The answer, then, is that to avoid returning an unexpected value and causing bugs that might not be discovered immediately, Rust doesnâ€™t compile this code at all and prevents misunderstandings early in the development process.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œä¸ºé¿å…è¿”å›æ„å¤–å€¼å¹¶å¯¼è‡´å¯èƒ½æ— æ³•ç«‹å³å‘ç°çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼ŒRust ç›´æ¥æ‹’ç»ç¼–è¯‘æ­¤ç±»ä»£ç ï¼Œä»è€Œåœ¨å¼€å‘æ—©æœŸé˜²æ­¢è¯¯è§£ã€‚

Bytes and Scalar Values and Grapheme Clusters! Oh My! å­—èŠ‚ã€æ ‡é‡å€¼å’Œå­—å½¢ç°‡ï¼å¤©å“ªï¼

Another point about UTF-8 is that there are actually three relevant ways to look at strings from Rustâ€™s perspective: as bytes, scalar values, and grapheme clusters (the closest thing to what we would call letters).

å…³äº UTF-8 çš„å¦ä¸€ç‚¹æ˜¯ï¼šä» Rust è§†è§’çœ‹å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æœ‰ä¸‰ç§ç›¸å…³æ–¹å¼ï¼šå­—èŠ‚ï¼ˆbytesï¼‰ã€æ ‡é‡å€¼ï¼ˆscalar valuesï¼‰å’Œå­—å½¢ç°‡ï¼ˆgrapheme clustersï¼‰ï¼ˆæœ€æ¥è¿‘æˆ‘ä»¬æ‰€è¯´çš„å­—æ¯ï¼‰ã€‚

If we look at the Hindi word â€œà¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€ written in the Devanagari script, it is stored as a vector of u8 values that looks like this:

è§‚å¯Ÿæ¢µæ–‡ä¹¦å†™çš„å°åœ°è¯­å•è¯ â€œà¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€ï¼Œå…¶å­˜å‚¨çš„ u8 å€¼å‘é‡å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

[224, 164, 168, 224, 164, 174, 224, 164, 184, 224, 165, 141, 224, 164, 164,
224, 165, 135]

Thatâ€™s 18 bytes and is how computers ultimately store this data. If we look at them as Unicode scalar values, which are what Rustâ€™s char type is, those bytes look like this:

å…± 18 å­—èŠ‚ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯è®¡ç®—æœºå­˜å‚¨çš„åŸå§‹æ•°æ®ã€‚è‹¥è§†ä¸º Unicode æ ‡é‡å€¼ï¼ˆå³ Rust çš„ char ç±»å‹ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™äº›å­—èŠ‚å‘ˆç°ä¸ºï¼š

['à¤¨', 'à¤®', 'à¤¸', 'à¥', 'à¤¤', 'à¥‡']

There are six char values here, but the fourth and sixth are not letters: theyâ€™re diacritics that donâ€™t make sense on their own. Finally, if we look at them as grapheme clusters, weâ€™d get what a person would call the four letters that make up the Hindi word:

è¿™é‡Œæœ‰å…­ä¸ª char å€¼ï¼Œä½†ç¬¬å››å’Œç¬¬å…­ä¸ªä¸æ˜¯ç‹¬ç«‹å­—æ¯ï¼šå®ƒä»¬æ˜¯å˜éŸ³ç¬¦å·ã€‚æœ€åï¼Œè‹¥è§†ä¸ºå­—å½¢ç°‡ï¼Œå°†å¾—åˆ°ç»„æˆå°åœ°è¯­å•è¯çš„å››ä¸ªå­—æ¯å•ä½ï¼š

["à¤¨", "à¤®", "à¤¸à¥", "à¤¤à¥‡"]

Rust provides different ways of interpreting the raw string data that computers store so that each program can choose the interpretation it needs, no matter what human language the data is in.

Rust æä¾›äº†å¤šç§è§£é‡Šè®¡ç®—æœºåŸå§‹å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°æ®çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä½¿æ¯ä¸ªç¨‹åºæ— è®ºæ•°æ®ä½¿ç”¨ä½•ç§äººç±»è¯­è¨€ï¼Œéƒ½èƒ½é€‰æ‹©æ‰€éœ€è§£é‡Šã€‚

A final reason Rust doesnâ€™t allow us to index into a String to get a character is that indexing operations are expected to always take constant time (O(1)). But it isnâ€™t possible to guarantee that performance with a String, because Rust would have to walk through the contents from the beginning to the index to determine how many valid characters there were.

Rust ä¸å…è®¸é€šè¿‡ç´¢å¼•è·å–å­—ç¬¦çš„æœ€ç»ˆåŸå› æ˜¯ï¼šç´¢å¼•æ“ä½œé¢„æœŸå§‹ç»ˆæ˜¯å¸¸æ•°æ—¶é—´ (O(1))ã€‚ä½† String æ— æ³•ä¿è¯æ­¤æ€§èƒ½ï¼Œå› ä¸º Rust å¿…é¡»ä»å¼€å¤´éå†åˆ°ç´¢å¼•ä½ç½®æ‰èƒ½ç¡®å®šæœ‰æ•ˆå­—ç¬¦çš„æ•°é‡ã€‚

Slicing Strings å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡

Indexing into a string is often a bad idea because itâ€™s not clear what the return type of the string-indexing operation should be: a byte value, a character, a grapheme cluster, or a string slice. If you really need to use indices to create string slices, therefore, Rust asks you to be more specific.

å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç´¢å¼•é€šå¸¸ä¸å¯å–ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç´¢å¼•æ“ä½œçš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸æ˜ç¡®ï¼šå­—èŠ‚å€¼ã€å­—ç¬¦ã€å­—å½¢ç°‡è¿˜æ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Ÿå› æ­¤è‹¥ç¡®å®éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨ç´¢å¼•åˆ›å»ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼ŒRust è¦æ±‚æ›´æ˜ç¡®æŒ‡å®šã€‚

Rather than indexing using [] with a single number, you can use [] with a range to create a string slice containing particular bytes:

[note]å¯é€šè¿‡èŒƒå›´ç´¢å¼•ï¼ˆè€Œéå•æ•°å­—ç´¢å¼•ï¼‰åˆ›å»ºåŒ…å«ç‰¹å®šå­—èŠ‚çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
let hello = "Ğ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ";

let s = &hello[0..4];
}

Here, s will be a &str that contains the first four bytes of the string. Earlier, we mentioned that each of these characters was two bytes, which means s will be Ğ—Ğ´.

æ­¤å¤„ s æ˜¯åŒ…å«å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å‰ 4 å­—èŠ‚çš„ &strã€‚å‰æ–‡æåˆ°æ¯ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦å  2 å­—èŠ‚ï¼Œå› æ­¤ s å°†ä¸º Ğ—Ğ´ã€‚

If we were to try to slice only part of a characterâ€™s bytes with something like &hello[0..1], Rust would panic at runtime in the same way as if an invalid index were accessed in a vector:

è‹¥å°è¯•åˆ‡ç‰‡å­—ç¬¦çš„éƒ¨åˆ†å­—èŠ‚ï¼ˆå¦‚ &hello[0..1]ï¼‰ï¼ŒRust ä¼šåœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶ panicï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼äºè®¿é—®æ— æ•ˆçš„å‘é‡ç´¢å¼•ï¼‰ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling collections v0.1.0 (file:///projects/collections)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.43s
     Running `target/debug/collections`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:4:19:
byte index 1 is not a char boundary; it is inside 'Ğ—' (bytes 0..2) of `Ğ—Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ`
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

You should use caution when creating string slices with ranges, because doing so can crash your program.

ä½¿ç”¨èŒƒå›´åˆ›å»ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡æ—¶åº”è°¨æ…ï¼Œå› å…¶å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´ç¨‹åºå´©æºƒã€‚

Methods for Iterating Over Strings å­—ç¬¦ä¸²éå†æ–¹æ³•

The best way to operate on pieces of strings is to be explicit about whether you want characters or bytes. For individual Unicode scalar values, use the chars method. Calling chars on â€œĞ—Ğ´â€ separates out and returns two values of type char, and you can iterate over the result to access each element:

æ“ä½œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç‰‡æ®µçš„æœ€ä½³æ–¹å¼æ˜¯æ˜ç¡®éœ€è¦å­—ç¬¦è¿˜æ˜¯å­—èŠ‚ã€‚[note]å¯¹äºå•ä¸ª Unicode æ ‡é‡å€¼ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ chars æ–¹æ³•ã€‚åœ¨ â€œĞ—Ğ´â€ ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ chars ä¼šåˆ†ç¦»å¹¶è¿”å›ä¸¤ä¸ª char ç±»å‹å€¼ï¼Œå¯é€šè¿‡éå†ç»“æœè®¿é—®æ¯ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
for c in "Ğ—Ğ´".chars() {
    println!("{c}");
}
}

This code will print the following:

æ­¤ä»£ç å°†æ‰“å°ï¼š

Ğ—
Ğ´

Alternatively, the bytes method returns each raw byte, which might be appropriate for your domain:

æˆ–è€…ï¼Œ[note]bytes æ–¹æ³•è¿”å›æ¯ä¸ªåŸå§‹å­—èŠ‚ï¼ˆé€‚ç”¨äºç‰¹å®šåœºæ™¯ï¼‰ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
for b in "Ğ—Ğ´".bytes() {
    println!("{b}");
}
}

This code will print the four bytes that make up this string:

æ­¤ä»£ç å°†æ‰“å°ç»„æˆå­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„å››ä¸ªå­—èŠ‚ï¼š

208
151
208
180

But be sure to remember that valid Unicode scalar values may be made up of more than one byte.

ä½†éœ€æ³¨æ„ï¼šæœ‰æ•ˆçš„ Unicode æ ‡é‡å€¼å¯èƒ½ç”±å¤šä¸ªå­—èŠ‚ç»„æˆã€‚

Getting grapheme clusters from strings, as with the Devanagari script, is complex, so this functionality is not provided by the standard library. Crates are available on crates.io if this is the functionality you need.

ä»å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è·å–å­—å½¢ç°‡ï¼ˆå¦‚æ¢µæ–‡æ¡ˆä¾‹ï¼‰è¾ƒä¸ºå¤æ‚ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ ‡å‡†åº“æœªæä¾›æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚è‹¥éœ€æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¯åœ¨ crates.io è·å–ç›¸å…³ crateã€‚

Strings Are Not So Simple å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹¶ä¸ç®€å•

To summarize, strings are complicated. Different programming languages make different choices about how to present this complexity to the programmer. Rust has chosen to make the correct handling of String data the default behavior for all Rust programs, which means programmers have to put more thought into handling UTF-8 data up front. This trade-off exposes more of the complexity of strings than is apparent in other programming languages, but it prevents you from having to handle errors involving non-ASCII characters later in your development life cycle.

æ€»ç»“æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ˜¯å¤æ‚çš„ã€‚ä¸åŒç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€é€‰æ‹©ä»¥ä¸åŒæ–¹å¼å‘ç¨‹åºå‘˜å‘ˆç°è¿™ç§å¤æ‚æ€§ã€‚Rust é€‰æ‹©å°†æ­£ç¡®å¤„ç† String æ•°æ®ä½œä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰ Rust ç¨‹åºçš„é»˜è®¤è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€ç¨‹åºå‘˜å¿…é¡»æå‰æŠ•å…¥æ›´å¤šç²¾åŠ›å¤„ç† UTF-8 æ•°æ®ã€‚è¿™ç§æƒè¡¡æš´éœ²äº†æ¯”å…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€æ›´æ˜æ˜¾çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¤æ‚æ€§ï¼Œä½†èƒ½é¿å…åœ¨å¼€å‘å‘¨æœŸåæœŸå¤„ç†é ASCII å­—ç¬¦ç›¸å…³çš„é”™è¯¯ã€‚

The good news is that the standard library offers a lot of functionality built off the String and &str types to help handle these complex situations correctly. Be sure to check out the documentation for useful methods like contains for searching in a string and replace for substituting parts of a string with another string.

å¥½æ¶ˆæ¯æ˜¯æ ‡å‡†åº“åŸºäº String å’Œ &str ç±»å‹æä¾›äº†ä¸°å¯ŒåŠŸèƒ½æ¥æ­£ç¡®å¤„ç†å¤æ‚æƒ…å†µã€‚åŠ¡å¿…æŸ¥é˜…æ–‡æ¡£ä»¥äº†è§£å®ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¦‚ containsï¼ˆå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æœç´¢ï¼‰å’Œ replaceï¼ˆå­—ç¬¦ä¸²éƒ¨åˆ†æ›¿æ¢ï¼‰ã€‚

Letâ€™s switch to something a bit less complex: hash maps!

ç°åœ¨è®©æˆ‘ä»¬è½¬å‘ç®€å•äº›çš„å†…å®¹ï¼šå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ï¼

Storing Keys with Associated Values in Hash Maps åœ¨å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸­å­˜å‚¨é”®å€¼å¯¹

The last of our common collections is the hash map. The type HashMap<K, V> stores a mapping of keys of type K to values of type V using a hashing function, which determines how it places these keys and values into memory. Many programming languages support this kind of data structure, but they often use a different name, such as hash, map, object, hash table, dictionary, or associative array, just to name a few.

æœ€åä¸€ç§å¸¸è§çš„é›†åˆç±»å‹æ˜¯ å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ï¼ˆhash mapï¼‰ã€‚ç±»å‹ HashMap<K, V> é€šè¿‡ å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°ï¼ˆhashing functionï¼‰ å­˜å‚¨é”®ç±»å‹ K åˆ°å€¼ç±»å‹ V çš„æ˜ å°„ï¼Œè¯¥å‡½æ•°å†³å®šäº†é”®å€¼å¯¹åœ¨å†…å­˜ä¸­çš„å­˜å‚¨æ–¹å¼ã€‚è®¸å¤šç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€æ”¯æŒæ­¤ç±»æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼Œä½†å‘½åå¯èƒ½ä¸åŒï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ hashã€mapã€objectã€hash tableã€dictionary æˆ– associative array ç­‰ã€‚

Hash maps are useful when you want to look up data not by using an index, as you can with vectors, but by using a key that can be of any type. For example, in a game, you could keep track of each teamâ€™s score in a hash map in which each key is a teamâ€™s name and the values are each teamâ€™s score. Given a team name, you can retrieve its score.

å½“ä½ å¸Œæœ›åŸºäºä»»æ„ç±»å‹çš„é”®ï¼ˆè€Œéåƒå‘é‡é‚£æ ·ä½¿ç”¨ç´¢å¼•ï¼‰æ¥æŸ¥æ‰¾æ•°æ®æ—¶ï¼Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„éå¸¸æœ‰ç”¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨æ¸¸æˆä¸­å¯ä»¥ç”¨å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„è·Ÿè¸ªå„é˜Ÿä¼åˆ†æ•°ï¼šé”®æ˜¯é˜Ÿä¼åï¼Œå€¼æ˜¯å¯¹åº”åˆ†æ•°ã€‚è¾“å…¥é˜Ÿä¼åå³å¯è·å–å…¶åˆ†æ•°ã€‚

Weâ€™ll go over the basic API of hash maps in this section, but many more goodies are hiding in the functions defined on HashMap<K, V> by the standard library. As always, check the standard library documentation for more information.

æœ¬èŠ‚å°†ä»‹ç»å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„çš„åŸºç¡€ APIï¼Œä½†æ ‡å‡†åº“åœ¨ HashMap<K, V> ä¸Šå®šä¹‰çš„å‡½æ•°è¿˜éšè—ç€æ›´å¤šåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚è¯·ä¸€å¦‚æ—¢å¾€åœ°æŸ¥é˜…æ ‡å‡†åº“æ–‡æ¡£ä»¥è·å–æ›´å¤šä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Creating a New Hash Map åˆ›å»ºæ–°å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„

One way to create an empty hash map is to use new and to add elements with insert. In Listing 8-20, weâ€™re keeping track of the scores of two teams whose names are Blue and Yellow. The Blue team starts with 10 points, and the Yellow team starts with 50.

åˆ›å»ºç©ºå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„çš„ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ new å¹¶é€šè¿‡ insert æ·»åŠ å…ƒç´ ã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-20 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è®°å½•åä¸º Blue å’Œ Yellow çš„ä¸¤æ”¯é˜Ÿä¼åˆ†æ•°ã€‚è“é˜Ÿåˆå§‹ 10 åˆ†ï¼Œé»„é˜Ÿåˆå§‹ 50 åˆ†ã€‚

Note that we need to first use the HashMap from the collections portion of the standard library. Of our three common collections, this one is the least often used, so itâ€™s not included in the features brought into scope automatically in the prelude. Hash maps also have less support from the standard library; thereâ€™s no built-in macro to construct them, for example.

æ³¨æ„éœ€å…ˆä»æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„é›†åˆéƒ¨åˆ† use å¼•å…¥ HashMapã€‚åœ¨ä¸‰ç§å¸¸è§é›†åˆä¸­ï¼Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„æœ€ä¸å¸¸ç”¨ï¼Œå› æ­¤æœªè¢«é¢„å¯¼å…¥ï¼ˆpreludeï¼‰è‡ªåŠ¨å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚æ ‡å‡†åº“å¯¹å…¶æ”¯æŒä¹Ÿè¾ƒå°‘ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ²¡æœ‰å†…ç½®å®æ¥æ„é€ å®ƒä»¬ã€‚

Just like vectors, hash maps store their data on the heap. This HashMap has keys of type String and values of type i32. Like vectors, hash maps are homogeneous: all of the keys must have the same type, and all of the values must have the same type.

ä¸å‘é‡ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å°†æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å †ä¸Šã€‚æ­¤å¤„çš„ HashMap é”®ç±»å‹ä¸º Stringï¼Œå€¼ç±»å‹ä¸º i32ã€‚åŒæ ·åœ°ï¼Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„æ˜¯åŒè´¨çš„ï¼šæ‰€æœ‰é”®ç±»å‹å¿…é¡»ç›¸åŒï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰å€¼ç±»å‹ä¹Ÿå¿…é¡»ç›¸åŒã€‚

Accessing Values in a Hash Map è®¿é—®å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸­çš„å€¼

We can get a value out of the hash map by providing its key to the get method, as shown in Listing 8-21.

[note]å¯é€šè¿‡ get æ–¹æ³•ä¼ å…¥é”®æ¥è·å–å€¼ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-21 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Here, score will have the value thatâ€™s associated with the Blue team, and the result will be 10. The get method returns an Option<&V>; if thereâ€™s no value for that key in the hash map, get will return None. This program handles the Option by calling copied to get an Option<i32> rather than an Option<&i32>, then unwrap_or to set score to zero if scores doesnâ€™t have an entry for the key.

æ­¤å¤„ score å°†è·å¾—ä¸è“é˜Ÿå…³è”çš„å€¼ï¼Œç»“æœä¸º 10ã€‚[note]get æ–¹æ³•è¿”å› Option<&V>ï¼›è‹¥é”®æ— å¯¹åº”å€¼åˆ™è¿”å› Noneã€‚æ­¤ä»£ç é€šè¿‡ copied å°† Option<&i32> è½¬ä¸º Option<i32>ï¼Œå†ç”¨ unwrap_or åœ¨é”®ä¸å­˜åœ¨æ—¶å°† score ç½®é›¶ã€‚

We can iterate over each key-value pair in a hash map in a similar manner as we do with vectors, using a for loop:

å¯ç”¨ for å¾ªç¯éå†é”®å€¼å¯¹ï¼Œæ–¹å¼ç±»ä¼¼å‘é‡éå†ï¼š

fn main() {
    use std::collections::HashMap;

    let mut scores = HashMap::new();

    scores.insert(String::from("Blue"), 10);
    scores.insert(String::from("Yellow"), 50);

    for (key, value) in &scores {
        println!("{key}: {value}");
    }
}

This code will print each pair in an arbitrary order:

æ­¤ä»£ç ä¼šä»¥ä»»æ„é¡ºåºæ‰“å°å„é”®å€¼å¯¹ï¼š

Yellow: 50
Blue: 10

Hash Maps and Ownership å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸æ‰€æœ‰æƒ

For types that implement the Copy trait, like i32, the values are copied into the hash map. For owned values like String, the values will be moved and the hash map will be the owner of those values, as demonstrated in Listing 8-22.

å¯¹äºå®ç° Copy trait çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ i32ï¼‰ï¼Œå€¼ä¼šè¢«å¤åˆ¶åˆ°å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸­ã€‚å¯¹äºæ‹¥æœ‰æ‰€æœ‰æƒçš„å€¼ï¼ˆå¦‚ Stringï¼‰ï¼Œå€¼ä¼šè¢«ç§»åŠ¨ä¸”å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å°†æˆä¸ºå…¶æ–°æ‰€æœ‰è€…ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-22 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

We arenâ€™t able to use the variables field_name and field_value after theyâ€™ve been moved into the hash map with the call to insert.

åœ¨é€šè¿‡ insert è°ƒç”¨å°† field_name å’Œ field_value ç§»å…¥å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„åï¼Œæ— æ³•å†ä½¿ç”¨è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ã€‚

If we insert references to values into the hash map, the values wonâ€™t be moved into the hash map. The values that the references point to must be valid for at least as long as the hash map is valid. Weâ€™ll talk more about these issues in â€œValidating References with Lifetimesâ€ in Chapter 10.

è‹¥æ’å…¥å€¼çš„å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œåˆ™å€¼ä¸ä¼šè¢«ç§»å…¥å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ã€‚å¼•ç”¨æŒ‡å‘çš„å€¼åœ¨å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„æœ‰æ•ˆæœŸé—´å¿…é¡»ä¿æŒæœ‰æ•ˆã€‚ç¬¬ 10 ç« â€œç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸéªŒè¯å¼•ç”¨â€œå°†æ·±å…¥è®¨è®ºæ­¤é—®é¢˜ã€‚

Updating a Hash Map æ›´æ–°å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„

Although the number of key and value pairs is growable, each unique key can only have one value associated with it at a time (but not vice versa: for example, both the Blue team and the Yellow team could have the value 10 stored in the scores hash map).

å°½ç®¡é”®å€¼å¯¹æ•°é‡å¯å˜ï¼Œä½†åŒä¸€æ—¶åˆ»æ¯ä¸ªå”¯ä¸€é”®åªèƒ½å…³è”ä¸€ä¸ªå€¼ï¼ˆåä¹‹åˆ™ä¸ç„¶ï¼šä¾‹å¦‚è“é˜Ÿå’Œé»„é˜Ÿå¯åŒæ—¶åœ¨ scores å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸­å­˜å‚¨å€¼ 10ï¼‰ã€‚

When you want to change the data in a hash map, you have to decide how to handle the case when a key already has a value assigned. You could replace the old value with the new value, completely disregarding the old value. You could keep the old value and ignore the new value, only adding the new value if the key doesnâ€™t already have a value. Or you could combine the old value and the new value. Letâ€™s look at how to do each of these!

æ›´æ–°å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„æ•°æ®æ—¶ï¼Œéœ€å¤„ç†é”®å·²å­˜åœ¨å€¼çš„æƒ…å†µï¼šå¯å®Œå…¨å¿½ç•¥æ—§å€¼å¹¶ç”¨æ–°å€¼è¦†ç›–ï¼›å¯ä¿ç•™æ—§å€¼å¿½ç•¥æ–°å€¼ï¼Œä»…å½“é”® æ—  å€¼æ—¶æ’å…¥æ–°å€¼ï¼›äº¦å¯åˆå¹¶æ–°æ—§å€¼ã€‚ä¸‹é¢åˆ†åˆ«è¯´æ˜ï¼š

Overwriting a Value è¦†ç›–å€¼

If we insert a key and a value into a hash map and then insert that same key with a different value, the value associated with that key will be replaced. Even though the code in Listing 8-23 calls insert twice, the hash map will only contain one key-value pair because weâ€™re inserting the value for the Blue teamâ€™s key both times.

è‹¥å¯¹åŒä¸€é”®é‡å¤æ’å…¥ä¸åŒå€¼ï¼Œæ—§å€¼ä¼šè¢«æ›¿æ¢ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-23 è™½è°ƒç”¨ä¸¤æ¬¡ insertï¼Œä½†å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä»…å­˜ä¸€ä¸ªé”®å€¼å¯¹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä¸¤æ¬¡å‡ä¸ºè“é˜Ÿé”®æ’å…¥å€¼ã€‚

This code will print {"Blue": 25}. The original value of 10 has been overwritten.

æ­¤ä»£ç å°†æ‰“å° {"Blue": 25}ï¼ŒåŸå§‹å€¼ 10 å·²è¢«è¦†ç›–ã€‚

Adding a Key and Value Only If a Key Isnâ€™t Present ä»…å½“é”®ä¸å­˜åœ¨æ—¶æ’å…¥

Itâ€™s common to check whether a particular key already exists in the hash map with a value and then to take the following actions: if the key does exist in the hash map, the existing value should remain the way it is; if the key doesnâ€™t exist, insert it and a value for it.

å¸¸è§æ“ä½œæ˜¯æ£€æŸ¥ç‰¹å®šé”®æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨å€¼ï¼šè‹¥å­˜åœ¨åˆ™ä¿ç•™åŸå€¼ï¼›è‹¥ä¸å­˜åœ¨åˆ™æ’å…¥é”®åŠå…¶å€¼ã€‚

Hash maps have a special API for this called entry that takes the key you want to check as a parameter. The return value of the entry method is an enum called Entry that represents a value that might or might not exist. Letâ€™s say we want to check whether the key for the Yellow team has a value associated with it. If it doesnâ€™t, we want to insert the value 50, and the same for the Blue team. Using the entry API, the code looks like Listing 8-24.

[note]å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸ºæ­¤æä¾› entry APIï¼Œå®ƒä»¥å¾…æ£€æŸ¥é”®ä¸ºå‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿”å›è¡¨ç¤ºå€¼å¯èƒ½å­˜åœ¨çš„æšä¸¾ Entryã€‚å‡è®¾è¦æ£€æŸ¥é»„é˜Ÿé”®æ˜¯å¦æœ‰å€¼ï¼Œè‹¥æ— åˆ™æ’å…¥ 50ï¼Œè“é˜ŸåŒç†ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ entry API çš„ä»£ç å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-24 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

The or_insert method on Entry is defined to return a mutable reference to the value for the corresponding Entry key if that key exists, and if not, it inserts the parameter as the new value for this key and returns a mutable reference to the new value. This technique is much cleaner than writing the logic ourselves and, in addition, plays more nicely with the borrow checker.

[note]Entry çš„ or_insert æ–¹æ³•åœ¨é”®å­˜åœ¨æ—¶è¿”å›å…¶å€¼çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œä¸å­˜åœ¨æ—¶æ’å…¥å‚æ•°ä½œä¸ºæ–°å€¼å¹¶è¿”å›æ–°å€¼çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ã€‚æ­¤æ–¹æ³•æ¯”æ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°é€»è¾‘æ›´ç®€æ´ï¼Œä¸”æ›´å…¼å®¹å€Ÿç”¨æ£€æŸ¥å™¨ã€‚

Running the code in Listing 8-24 will print {"Yellow": 50, "Blue": 10}. The first call to entry will insert the key for the Yellow team with the value 50 because the Yellow team doesnâ€™t have a value already. The second call to entry will not change the hash map because the Blue team already has the value 10.

è¿è¡Œç¤ºä¾‹ 8-24 å°†æ‰“å° {"Yellow": 50, "Blue": 10}ã€‚é¦–æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ entry ä¼šä¸ºé»„é˜Ÿæ’å…¥å€¼ 50ï¼ˆå› å…¶åŸæ— å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ä¸ä¼šæ”¹å˜å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ï¼ˆå› è“é˜Ÿå·²æœ‰å€¼ 10ï¼‰ã€‚

Updating a Value Based on the Old Value åŸºäºæ—§å€¼æ›´æ–°

Another common use case for hash maps is to look up a keyâ€™s value and then update it based on the old value. For instance, Listing 8-25 shows code that counts how many times each word appears in some text. We use a hash map with the words as keys and increment the value to keep track of how many times weâ€™ve seen that word. If itâ€™s the first time weâ€™ve seen a word, weâ€™ll first insert the value 0.

å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å¦ä¸€å¸¸è§ç”¨é€”æ˜¯æŸ¥æ‰¾é”®çš„å€¼å¹¶åŸºäºæ—§å€¼æ›´æ–°ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-25 ç»Ÿè®¡æ–‡æœ¬ä¸­å•è¯å‡ºç°æ¬¡æ•°ï¼šä»¥å•è¯ä¸ºé”®ï¼Œå¢åŠ å€¼ä»¥è·Ÿè¸ªå‡ºç°é¢‘ç‡ã€‚è‹¥å•è¯é¦–æ¬¡å‡ºç°ï¼Œå…ˆæ’å…¥å€¼ 0ã€‚

This code will print {"world": 2, "hello": 1, "wonderful": 1}. You might see the same key-value pairs printed in a different order: recall from â€œAccessing Values in a Hash Mapâ€ that iterating over a hash map happens in an arbitrary order.

æ­¤ä»£ç å¯èƒ½æ‰“å° {"world": 2, "hello": 1, "wonderful": 1}ï¼ˆé¡ºåºå¯èƒ½ä¸åŒï¼Œå›å¿†â€œè®¿é—®å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„ä¸­çš„å€¼â€œå¯çŸ¥è¿­ä»£é¡ºåºæ˜¯ä»»æ„çš„ï¼‰ã€‚

The split_whitespace method returns an iterator over subslices, separated by whitespace, of the value in text. The or_insert method returns a mutable reference (&mut V) to the value for the specified key. Here, we store that mutable reference in the count variable, so in order to assign to that value, we must first dereference count using the asterisk (*). The mutable reference goes out of scope at the end of the for loop, so all of these changes are safe and allowed by the borrowing rules.

split_whitespace æ–¹æ³•è¿”å›åŸºäºç©ºç™½åˆ†éš”çš„æ–‡æœ¬å­åˆ‡ç‰‡è¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚or_insert è¿”å›é”®å¯¹åº”å€¼çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼ˆ&mut Vï¼‰ã€‚æ­¤å¤„å°†å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨å­˜å…¥ count å˜é‡ï¼Œèµ‹å€¼æ—¶éœ€å…ˆç”¨æ˜Ÿå·ï¼ˆ*ï¼‰è§£å¼•ç”¨ countã€‚å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨åœ¨ for å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸæ—¶ç¦»å¼€ä½œç”¨åŸŸï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿™äº›å˜æ›´å‡ç¬¦åˆå€Ÿç”¨è§„åˆ™ä¸”å®‰å…¨ã€‚

Hashing Functions å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°

By default, HashMap uses a hashing function called SipHash that can provide resistance to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks involving hash tables. This is not the fastest hashing algorithm available, but the trade-off for better security that comes with the drop in performance is worth it. If you profile your code and find that the default hash function is too slow for your purposes, you can switch to another function by specifying a different hasher. A hasher is a type that implements the BuildHasher trait. Weâ€™ll talk about traits and how to implement them in Chapter 10. You donâ€™t necessarily have to implement your own hasher from scratch; crates.io has libraries shared by other Rust users that provide hashers implementing many common hashing algorithms.

é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒHashMap ä½¿ç”¨åä¸º SipHash çš„å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¯æŠµå¾¡æ¶‰åŠå“ˆå¸Œè¡¨çš„æ‹’ç»æœåŠ¡ï¼ˆDoSï¼‰æ”»å‡»ã€‚æ­¤éæœ€å¿«çš„å“ˆå¸Œç®—æ³•ï¼Œä½†ä»¥æ€§èƒ½æ¢å–æ›´é«˜å®‰å…¨æ€§æ˜¯å€¼å¾—çš„ã€‚è‹¥æ€§èƒ½åˆ†æè¡¨æ˜é»˜è®¤å“ˆå¸Œå‡½æ•°è¿‡æ…¢ï¼Œå¯é€šè¿‡æŒ‡å®šä¸åŒçš„ hasher åˆ‡æ¢ç®—æ³•ã€‚hasher æ˜¯å®ç°äº† BuildHasher trait çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚ç¬¬ 10 ç« å°†è®¨è®º trait åŠå…¶å®ç°ã€‚ä¸å¿…ä»å¤´å®ç°è‡ªå·±çš„ hasherï¼Œcrates.io ä¸Šæœ‰å…¶ä»– Rust ç”¨æˆ·å…±äº«çš„æä¾›å¸¸è§å“ˆå¸Œç®—æ³•çš„åº“ã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

Vectors, strings, and hash maps will provide a large amount of functionality necessary in programs when you need to store, access, and modify data. Here are some exercises you should now be equipped to solve:

å½“ä½ éœ€è¦å­˜å‚¨ã€è®¿é—®å’Œä¿®æ”¹æ•°æ®æ—¶ï¼Œå‘é‡ã€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å’Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å°†æä¾›å¤§é‡å¿…è¦åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä½ å·²èƒ½è§£å†³ä»¥ä¸‹ç»ƒä¹ ï¼š

  • Given a list of integers, use a vector and return the median (when sorted, the value in the middle position) and mode (the value that occurs most often; a hash map will be helpful here) of the list.
  • ç»™å®šæ•´æ•°åˆ—è¡¨ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å‘é‡è¿”å›ä¸­ä½æ•°ï¼ˆæ’åºåä½äºä¸­é—´çš„å€¼ï¼‰å’Œä¼—æ•°ï¼ˆå‡ºç°æœ€é¢‘ç¹çš„å€¼ï¼Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å¯¹æ­¤å¾ˆæœ‰å¸®åŠ©ï¼‰ã€‚
  • Convert strings to pig latin. The first consonant of each word is moved to the end of the word and ay is added, so first becomes irst-fay. Words that start with a vowel have hay added to the end instead (apple becomes apple-hay). Keep in mind the details about UTF-8 encoding!
  • å°†å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæ‹‰ä¸çŒªæ–‡ï¼šå•è¯é¦–è¾…éŸ³ç§»è‡³æœ«å°¾å¹¶æ·»åŠ  ayï¼ˆå¦‚ first å˜ä¸º irst-fayï¼‰ï¼›å…ƒéŸ³å¼€å¤´çš„å•è¯åˆ™æ·»åŠ  hayï¼ˆå¦‚ apple å˜ä¸º apple-hayï¼‰ã€‚è¯·æ³¨æ„ UTF-8 ç¼–ç ç»†èŠ‚ï¼
  • Using a hash map and vectors, create a text interface to allow a user to add employee names to a department in a company; for example, â€œAdd Sally to Engineeringâ€ or â€œAdd Amir to Sales.â€ Then let the user retrieve a list of all people in a department or all people in the company by department, sorted alphabetically.
  • ä½¿ç”¨å“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„å’Œå‘é‡åˆ›å»ºæ–‡æœ¬æ¥å£ï¼šç”¨æˆ·å¯æ·»åŠ å‘˜å·¥å§“ååˆ°å…¬å¸éƒ¨é—¨ï¼ˆå¦‚â€œAdd Sally to Engineeringâ€œæˆ–â€œAdd Amir to Salesâ€œï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶æ”¯æŒæŒ‰éƒ¨é—¨æ£€ç´¢äººå‘˜åˆ—è¡¨æˆ–æŒ‰éƒ¨é—¨æ’åºçš„å…¨å…¬å¸äººå‘˜åˆ—è¡¨ã€‚

The standard library API documentation describes methods that vectors, strings, and hash maps have that will be helpful for these exercises!

æ ‡å‡†åº“ API æ–‡æ¡£æè¿°äº†å‘é‡ã€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å’Œå“ˆå¸Œæ˜ å°„çš„æœ‰ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼

Weâ€™re getting into more complex programs in which operations can fail, so itâ€™s a perfect time to discuss error handling. Weâ€™ll do that next!

æˆ‘ä»¬æ­£è¿›å…¥æ›´å¤æ‚çš„ç¨‹åºé¢†åŸŸï¼Œæ“ä½œå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼Œæ˜¯æ—¶å€™è®¨è®ºé”™è¯¯å¤„ç†äº†ã€‚ä¸‹ä¸€ç« è§ï¼

Error Handling é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†

Errors are a fact of life in software, so Rust has a number of features for handling situations in which something goes wrong. In many cases, Rust requires you to acknowledge the possibility of an error and take some action before your code will compile. This requirement makes your program more robust by ensuring that youâ€™ll discover errors and handle them appropriately before deploying your code to production!

è½¯ä»¶ä¸­çš„é”™è¯¯æ˜¯ä¸å¯é¿å…çš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤ Rust æä¾›äº†ä¸€ç³»åˆ—ç‰¹æ€§æ¥å¤„ç†ç¨‹åºå‡ºé”™çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚åœ¨è®¸å¤šæƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒRust è¦æ±‚ä½ åœ¨ä»£ç ç¼–è¯‘å‰å¿…é¡»æ‰¿è®¤é”™è¯¯å­˜åœ¨çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§å¹¶é‡‡å–ç›¸åº”æªæ–½ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªè¦æ±‚ç¡®ä¿äº†åœ¨å°†ä»£ç éƒ¨ç½²åˆ°ç”Ÿäº§ç¯å¢ƒå‰ï¼Œä½ èƒ½å‘ç°é”™è¯¯å¹¶å¦¥å–„å¤„ç†å®ƒä»¬ï¼Œä»è€Œä½¿ç¨‹åºæ›´åŠ å¥å£®ï¼

Rust groups errors into two major categories: recoverable and unrecoverable errors. For a recoverable error, such as a file not found error, we most likely just want to report the problem to the user and retry the operation. Unrecoverable errors are always symptoms of bugs, such as trying to access a location beyond the end of an array, and so we want to immediately stop the program.

Rust å°†é”™è¯¯åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤å¤§ç±»åˆ«ï¼šå¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯å’Œä¸å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯ã€‚å¯¹äºå¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚â€œæ–‡ä»¶æœªæ‰¾åˆ°â€œï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é€šå¸¸åªéœ€å‘ç”¨æˆ·æŠ¥å‘Šé—®é¢˜å¹¶é‡è¯•æ“ä½œå³å¯ã€‚ä¸å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯å¾€å¾€æ˜¯ä»£ç ç¼ºé™·çš„è¡¨ç°ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚å°è¯•è®¿é—®è¶…å‡ºæ•°ç»„æœ«å°¾çš„ä½ç½®ï¼‰ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›ç«‹å³ç»ˆæ­¢ç¨‹åºã€‚

Most languages donâ€™t distinguish between these two kinds of errors and handle both in the same way, using mechanisms such as exceptions. Rust doesnâ€™t have exceptions. Instead, it has the type Result<T, E> for recoverable errors and the panic! macro that stops execution when the program encounters an unrecoverable error. This chapter covers calling panic! first and then talks about returning Result<T, E> values. Additionally, weâ€™ll explore considerations when deciding whether to try to recover from an error or to stop execution.

å¤§å¤šæ•°è¯­è¨€ä¸åŒºåˆ†è¿™ä¸¤ç±»é”™è¯¯ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚å¸¸ç­‰æœºåˆ¶ç»Ÿä¸€å¤„ç†ã€‚Rust æ²¡æœ‰å¼‚å¸¸æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå®ƒé€šè¿‡ Result<T, E> ç±»å‹å¤„ç†å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯ï¼Œè€Œ panic! å®åˆ™ç”¨äºåœ¨ç¨‹åºé‡åˆ°ä¸å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯æ—¶ç»ˆæ­¢æ‰§è¡Œã€‚æœ¬ç« å°†å…ˆè®²è§£ panic! çš„è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œæ¥ç€è®¨è®ºå¦‚ä½•è¿”å› Result<T, E> å€¼ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å°†æ¢è®¨åœ¨å†³å®šâ€œå°è¯•ä»é”™è¯¯ä¸­æ¢å¤â€œè¿˜æ˜¯â€œç»ˆæ­¢ç¨‹åºâ€œæ—¶çš„è€ƒé‡å› ç´ ã€‚

Unrecoverable Errors with panic! ä½¿ç”¨ panic! å¤„ç†ä¸å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯

Sometimes bad things happen in your code, and thereâ€™s nothing you can do about it. In these cases, Rust has the panic! macro. There are two ways to cause a panic in practice: by taking an action that causes our code to panic (such as accessing an array past the end) or by explicitly calling the panic! macro. In both cases, we cause a panic in our program. By default, these panics will print a failure message, unwind, clean up the stack, and quit. Via an environment variable, you can also have Rust display the call stack when a panic occurs to make it easier to track down the source of the panic.

å½“ä»£ç ä¸­å‘ç”Ÿæ— æ³•æŒ½å›çš„é—®é¢˜æ—¶ï¼ŒRust æä¾›äº† panic! å®ã€‚å®è·µä¸­è§¦å‘ panic æœ‰ä¸¤ç§æ–¹å¼ï¼šæ‰§è¡Œå¯¼è‡´ä»£ç  panic çš„æ“ä½œï¼ˆå¦‚è¶Šç•Œè®¿é—®æ•°ç»„ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ–æ˜¾å¼è°ƒç”¨ panic! å®ã€‚ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µä¸‹ç¨‹åºéƒ½ä¼šè§¦å‘ panicã€‚é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œpanic ä¼šæ‰“å°é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€å›é€€æ ˆï¼ˆunwindï¼‰ã€æ¸…ç†æ ˆæ•°æ®å¹¶é€€å‡ºã€‚é€šè¿‡ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡ï¼Œä½ è¿˜å¯ä»¥è®© Rust åœ¨ panic æ—¶æ˜¾ç¤ºè°ƒç”¨æ ˆï¼Œä¾¿äºè¿½è¸ª panic æ ¹æºã€‚

Unwinding the Stack or Aborting in Response to a Panic å›é€€æ ˆæˆ–ç«‹å³ç»ˆæ­¢

By default, when a panic occurs the program starts unwinding, which means Rust walks back up the stack and cleans up the data from each function it encounters. However, walking back and cleaning up is a lot of work. Rust, therefore, allows you to choose the alternative of immediately aborting, which ends the program without cleaning up.

[note]é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå‘ç”Ÿ panic æ—¶ç¨‹åºä¼šå¯åŠ¨å›é€€è¿‡ç¨‹â€”â€”Rust å°†æ²¿è°ƒç”¨æ ˆé€å±‚å›æº¯å¹¶æ¸…ç†é‡åˆ°çš„å‡½æ•°æ•°æ®ã€‚ä½†å›æº¯æ¸…ç†å·¥ä½œé‡å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œå› æ­¤ Rust å…è®¸ä½ é€‰æ‹©ç«‹å³ç»ˆæ­¢çš„æ›¿ä»£æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶ç¨‹åºç›´æ¥ç»“æŸè€Œä¸è¿›è¡Œæ¸…ç†ã€‚

Memory that the program was using will then need to be cleaned up by the operating system. If in your project you need to make the resultant binary as small as possible, you can switch from unwinding to aborting upon a panic by adding panic = 'abort' to the appropriate [profile] sections in your Cargo.toml file. For example, if you want to abort on panic in release mode, add this:

ç¨‹åºå ç”¨çš„å†…å­˜å°†ç”±æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿå›æ”¶ã€‚è‹¥éœ€è¦ç”Ÿæˆå°½å¯èƒ½å°çš„äºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œ[note]å¯åœ¨ Cargo.toml æ–‡ä»¶çš„ç›¸åº” [profile] åŒºåŸŸæ·»åŠ  panic = 'abort'ï¼Œå°† panic è¡Œä¸ºä»å›é€€æ”¹ä¸ºç«‹å³ç»ˆæ­¢ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚è¦åœ¨å‘å¸ƒæ¨¡å¼ä¸­å¯ç”¨ panic ç»ˆæ­¢ï¼š

[profile.release]
panic = 'abort'

Letâ€™s try calling panic! in a simple program:

åœ¨ç®€å•ç¨‹åºä¸­è°ƒç”¨ panic! çš„ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š

When you run the program, youâ€™ll see something like this:

è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºåå°†çœ‹åˆ°ç±»ä¼¼è¾“å‡ºï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling panic v0.1.0 (file:///projects/panic)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.25s
     Running `target/debug/panic`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:2:5:
crash and burn
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

The call to panic! causes the error message contained in the last two lines. The first line shows our panic message and the place in our source code where the panic occurred: src/main.rs:2:5 indicates that itâ€™s the second line, fifth character of our src/main.rs file.

panic! è°ƒç”¨å¯¼è‡´æœ€åä¸¤è¡Œæ˜¾ç¤ºé”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚é¦–è¡Œæ˜¾ç¤º panic æ¶ˆæ¯åŠæºç ä½ç½®ï¼šsrc/main.rs:2:5 è¡¨ç¤ºæ–‡ä»¶ç¬¬äºŒè¡Œç¬¬äº”ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ã€‚

In this case, the line indicated is part of our code, and if we go to that line, we see the panic! macro call. In other cases, the panic! call might be in code that our code calls, and the filename and line number reported by the error message will be someone elseâ€™s code where the panic! macro is called, not the line of our code that eventually led to the panic! call.

æ­¤å¤„æ ‡è®°çš„è¡Œå±äºæˆ‘ä»¬çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œå®šä½åå¯çœ‹åˆ° panic! å®è°ƒç”¨ã€‚ä½†æœ‰æ—¶ panic! å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨è°ƒç”¨é“¾çš„æ·±å±‚ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯æ˜¾ç¤ºçš„æ–‡ä»¶åå’Œè¡Œå·ä¼šæ˜¯ä»–äººè°ƒç”¨ panic! çš„ä»£ç ä½ç½®ï¼Œè€Œéæœ€ç»ˆè§¦å‘ panic çš„æºå¤´ã€‚

We can use the backtrace of the functions the panic! call came from to figure out the part of our code that is causing the problem. To understand how to use a panic! backtrace, letâ€™s look at another example and see what itâ€™s like when a panic! call comes from a library because of a bug in our code instead of from our code calling the macro directly. Listing 9-1 has some code that attempts to access an index in a vector beyond the range of valid indexes.

é€šè¿‡ panic! è°ƒç”¨æ¥æºçš„å‡½æ•°å›æº¯ï¼Œå¯å®šä½å¼•å‘é—®é¢˜çš„ä»£ç æ®µã€‚ä¸ºç†è§£å¦‚ä½•åˆ©ç”¨ panic å›æº¯ï¼Œè¯·çœ‹å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç¤ºä¾‹â€”â€”å½“å› ä»£ç ç¼ºé™·å¯¼è‡´åº“å‡½æ•°è§¦å‘ panic! æ—¶çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 9-1 å°è¯•è®¿é—®å‘é‡èŒƒå›´å¤–çš„ç´¢å¼•ï¼š

Here, weâ€™re attempting to access the 100th element of our vector (which is at index 99 because indexing starts at zero), but the vector has only three elements. In this situation, Rust will panic. Using [] is supposed to return an element, but if you pass an invalid index, thereâ€™s no element that Rust could return here that would be correct.

æ­¤å¤„æˆ‘ä»¬å°è¯•è®¿é—®å‘é‡çš„ç¬¬ 100 ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ï¼ˆç´¢å¼•ä¸º 99ï¼Œå› ç´¢å¼•ä» 0 å¼€å§‹ï¼‰ï¼Œä½†å‘é‡ä»…æœ‰ä¸‰ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ Rust å°†è§¦å‘ panicã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ [] æœ¬åº”è¿”å›å…ƒç´ ï¼Œä½†å½“ä¼ å…¥æ— æ•ˆç´¢å¼•æ—¶ï¼ŒRust æ— æ³•è¿”å›æœ‰æ•ˆå…ƒç´ ã€‚

In C, attempting to read beyond the end of a data structure is undefined behavior. You might get whatever is at the location in memory that would correspond to that element in the data structure, even though the memory doesnâ€™t belong to that structure. This is called a buffer overread and can lead to security vulnerabilities if an attacker is able to manipulate the index in such a way as to read data they shouldnâ€™t be allowed to that is stored after the data structure.

åœ¨ C è¯­è¨€ä¸­ï¼Œå°è¯•è¯»å–æ•°æ®ç»“æ„æœ«å°¾ä¹‹å¤–çš„æ•°æ®å±äºæœªå®šä¹‰è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ä½ å¯èƒ½è·å¾—å†…å­˜ä¸­å¯¹åº”ä½ç½®çš„ä»»æ„æ•°æ®ï¼ˆå³ä¾¿è¯¥å†…å­˜ä¸å±äºè¯¥ç»“æ„ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™ç§°ä¸ºç¼“å†²åŒºè¶Šç•Œè¯»å–ï¼Œè‹¥æ”»å‡»è€…èƒ½æ“çºµç´¢å¼•è¯»å–æ•°æ®ç»“æ„åçš„æœªæˆæƒæ•°æ®ï¼Œå°†å¯¼è‡´å®‰å…¨æ¼æ´ã€‚

To protect your program from this sort of vulnerability, if you try to read an element at an index that doesnâ€™t exist, Rust will stop execution and refuse to continue. Letâ€™s try it and see:

ä¸ºé˜²æ­¢æ­¤ç±»æ¼æ´ï¼Œå½“å°è¯•è¯»å–ä¸å­˜åœ¨çš„ç´¢å¼•æ—¶ï¼ŒRust ä¼šåœæ­¢æ‰§è¡Œå¹¶æ‹’ç»ç»§ç»­ã€‚è¿è¡Œç»“æœå¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling panic v0.1.0 (file:///projects/panic)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.27s
     Running `target/debug/panic`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:4:6:
index out of bounds: the len is 3 but the index is 99
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

This error points at line 4 of our main.rs where we attempt to access index 99 of the vector in v.

è¯¥é”™è¯¯æŒ‡å‘ main.rs ç¬¬ 4 è¡Œï¼Œå³å°è¯•è®¿é—®å‘é‡ v çš„ç¬¬ 99 ä¸ªç´¢å¼•å¤„ã€‚

The note: line tells us that we can set the RUST_BACKTRACE environment variable to get a backtrace of exactly what happened to cause the error. A backtrace is a list of all the functions that have been called to get to this point. Backtraces in Rust work as they do in other languages: the key to reading the backtrace is to start from the top and read until you see files you wrote. Thatâ€™s the spot where the problem originated. The lines above that spot are code that your code has called; the lines below are code that called your code. These before-and-after lines might include core Rust code, standard library code, or crates that youâ€™re using. Letâ€™s try getting a backtrace by setting the RUST_BACKTRACE environment variable to any value except 0. Listing 9-2 shows output similar to what youâ€™ll see.

note: è¡Œæç¤ºå¯é€šè¿‡è®¾ç½® RUST_BACKTRACE ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡è·å–å¯¼è‡´é”™è¯¯çš„è¯¦ç»†å›æº¯ã€‚å›æº¯æ˜¯åˆ—å‡ºæ‰€æœ‰è°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•°çš„é“¾å¼åˆ—è¡¨ã€‚Rust çš„å›æº¯æœºåˆ¶ä¸å…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€ç›¸åŒï¼šè§£è¯»å›æº¯çš„å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»é¡¶éƒ¨å¼€å§‹é˜…è¯»ï¼Œç›´åˆ°å‘ç°ä½ ç¼–å†™çš„æ–‡ä»¶â€”â€”é‚£å°±æ˜¯é—®é¢˜æ ¹æºã€‚è¯¥ä½ç½®ä¹‹ä¸Šæ˜¯ä½ ä»£ç è°ƒç”¨çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¹‹ä¸‹æ˜¯è°ƒç”¨ä½ ä»£ç çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆå¯èƒ½åŒ…å« Rust æ ¸å¿ƒåº“ã€æ ‡å‡†åº“æˆ–ç¬¬ä¸‰æ–¹åº“ä»£ç ï¼‰ã€‚å°è¯•è®¾ç½® RUST_BACKTRACE ä¸ºä»»æ„é 0 å€¼è·å–å›æº¯ï¼Œç¤ºä¾‹ 9-2 å±•ç¤ºäº†å…¸å‹è¾“å‡ºï¼š

Thatâ€™s a lot of output! The exact output you see might be different depending on your operating system and Rust version. In order to get backtraces with this information, debug symbols must be enabled. Debug symbols are enabled by default when using cargo build or cargo run without the --release flag, as we have here.

è¾“å‡ºä¿¡æ¯é‡å¾ˆå¤§ï¼å…·ä½“å†…å®¹å¯èƒ½å› æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿå’Œ Rust ç‰ˆæœ¬è€Œå¼‚ã€‚[note]è¦è·å¾—å¸¦è°ƒè¯•ä¿¡æ¯çš„å›æº¯ï¼Œéœ€å¯ç”¨è°ƒè¯•ç¬¦å·ï¼ˆdebug symbolsï¼‰ã€‚å½“ä½¿ç”¨ cargo build æˆ– cargo run ä¸”ä¸å¸¦ --release æ ‡å¿—æ—¶ï¼ˆå¦‚æœ¬ä¾‹ï¼‰ï¼Œè°ƒè¯•ç¬¦å·é»˜è®¤å¯ç”¨ã€‚

In the output in Listing 9-2, line 6 of the backtrace points to the line in our project thatâ€™s causing the problem: line 4 of src/main.rs. If we donâ€™t want our program to panic, we should start our investigation at the location pointed to by the first line mentioning a file we wrote. In Listing 9-1, where we deliberately wrote code that would panic, the way to fix the panic is to not request an element beyond the range of the vector indexes. When your code panics in the future, youâ€™ll need to figure out what action the code is taking with what values to cause the panic and what the code should do instead.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 9-2 çš„è¾“å‡ºä¸­ï¼Œå›æº¯ç¬¬ 6 è¡ŒæŒ‡å‘é—®é¢˜æ ¹æºï¼šsrc/main.rs ç¬¬ 4 è¡Œã€‚è‹¥ä¸æƒ³ç¨‹åº panicï¼Œåº”é¦–å…ˆæ£€æŸ¥å›æº¯ä¸­é¦–æ¬¡æåŠçš„è‡ªå†™æ–‡ä»¶ä½ç½®ã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 9-1 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ•…æ„ç¼–å†™äº†ä¼š panic çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œä¿®å¤æ–¹å¼æ˜¯é¿å…è¯·æ±‚è¶…å‡ºå‘é‡èŒƒå›´çš„ç´¢å¼•ã€‚æœªæ¥å½“ä»£ç  panic æ—¶ï¼Œä½ éœ€è¦å®šä½ä»£ç æ“ä½œã€è§¦å‘ panic çš„å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶ä¿®æ­£ä»£ç é€»è¾‘ã€‚

Weâ€™ll come back to panic! and when we should and should not use panic! to handle error conditions in the â€œTo panic! or Not to panic!â€ section later in this chapter. Next, weâ€™ll look at how to recover from an error using Result.

æœ¬ç« åç»­åœ¨ã€Šè¯¥ä¸è¯¥ç”¨ panic!ã€‹ç« èŠ‚å°†å†æ¬¡è®¨è®º panic! çš„ä½¿ç”¨åœºæ™¯ã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å­¦ä¹ å¦‚ä½•ç”¨ Result ä»é”™è¯¯ä¸­æ¢å¤ã€‚

Recoverable Errors with Result å¯æ¢å¤çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼šResult

Most errors arenâ€™t serious enough to require the program to stop entirely. Sometimes when a function fails itâ€™s for a reason that you can easily interpret and respond to. For example, if you try to open a file and that operation fails because the file doesnâ€™t exist, you might want to create the file instead of terminating the process.

å¤§å¤šæ•°é”™è¯¯å¹¶ä¸ä¸¥é‡åˆ°éœ€è¦ç¨‹åºå®Œå…¨åœæ­¢çš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚æœ‰æ—¶å‡½æ•°å¤±è´¥çš„åŸå› å¯ä»¥è½»æ¾è§£è¯»å¹¶å“åº”ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå°è¯•æ‰“å¼€æ–‡ä»¶æ—¶å› æ–‡ä»¶ä¸å­˜åœ¨è€Œå¤±è´¥ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½å¸Œæœ›åˆ›å»ºæ–‡ä»¶è€Œéç»ˆæ­¢è¿›ç¨‹ã€‚

Recall from â€œHandling Potential Failure with Resultâ€ in Chapter 2 that the Result enum is defined as having two variants, Ok and Err, as follows:

å›å¿†ç¬¬2ç« ä¸­ â€œç”¨ Result å¤„ç†æ½œåœ¨å¤±è´¥â€ çš„å†…å®¹ï¼ŒResult æšä¸¾å®šä¹‰ä¸ºä¸¤ä¸ªå˜ä½“ Ok å’Œ Errï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E),
}
}

The T and E are generic type parameters: weâ€™ll discuss generics in more detail in Chapter 10. What you need to know right now is that T represents the type of the value that will be returned in a success case within the Ok variant, and E represents the type of the error that will be returned in a failure case within the Err variant. Because Result has these generic type parameters, we can use the Result type and the functions defined on it in many different situations where the success value and error value we want to return may differ.

T å’Œ E æ˜¯æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ï¼šç¬¬10ç« å°†è¯¦ç»†è®¨è®ºæ³›å‹ã€‚ç°åœ¨åªéœ€çŸ¥é“ï¼šT ä»£è¡¨æˆåŠŸæ—¶ Ok å˜ä½“è¿”å›çš„å€¼çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ŒE ä»£è¡¨å¤±è´¥æ—¶ Err å˜ä½“è¿”å›çš„é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ã€‚ç”±äº Result å…·æœ‰è¿™äº›æ³›å‹å‚æ•°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨å¤šç§åœºæ™¯ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ Result ç±»å‹åŠå…¶å®šä¹‰çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¿™äº›åœºæ™¯ä¸­è¦è¿”å›çš„æˆåŠŸå€¼å’Œé”™è¯¯å€¼å¯èƒ½ä¸åŒã€‚

Letâ€™s call a function that returns a Result value because the function could fail. In Listing 9-3 we try to open a file.

è°ƒç”¨å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥çš„å‡½æ•°æ—¶ä¼šè¿”å› Result å€¼ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹9-3å°è¯•æ‰“å¼€æ–‡ä»¶ï¼š

The return type of File::open is a Result<T, E>. The generic parameter T has been filled in by the implementation of File::open with the type of the success value, std::fs::File, which is a file handle. The type of E used in the error value is std::io::Error. This return type means the call to File::open might succeed and return a file handle that we can read from or write to. The function call also might fail: for example, the file might not exist, or we might not have permission to access the file. The File::open function needs to have a way to tell us whether it succeeded or failed and at the same time give us either the file handle or error information. This information is exactly what the Result enum conveys.

File::open çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹æ˜¯ Result<T, E>ã€‚æ³›å‹å‚æ•° T ç”± File::open çš„å®ç°å¡«å……ä¸ºæˆåŠŸå€¼ç±»å‹ std::fs::Fileï¼ˆæ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„ï¼‰ã€‚é”™è¯¯å€¼ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨çš„ E ç±»å‹æ˜¯ std::io::Errorã€‚æ­¤è¿”å›ç±»å‹æ„å‘³ç€å¯¹ File::open çš„è°ƒç”¨å¯èƒ½æˆåŠŸå¹¶è¿”å›å¯è¯»å†™çš„æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚æ–‡ä»¶ä¸å­˜åœ¨æˆ–æ— è®¿é—®æƒé™ï¼‰ã€‚File::open å‡½æ•°éœ€å‘ŠçŸ¥æˆåŠŸä¸å¦ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶æä¾›æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„æˆ–é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯ Result æšä¸¾æ‰€ä¼ é€’çš„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

In the case where File::open succeeds, the value in the variable greeting_file_result will be an instance of Ok that contains a file handle. In the case where it fails, the value in greeting_file_result will be an instance of Err that contains more information about the kind of error that occurred.

è‹¥ File::open æˆåŠŸï¼Œå˜é‡ greeting_file_result çš„å€¼å°†æ˜¯åŒ…å«æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„çš„ Ok å®ä¾‹ï¼›è‹¥å¤±è´¥ï¼Œåˆ™æ˜¯åŒ…å«é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯çš„ Err å®ä¾‹ã€‚

We need to add to the code in Listing 9-3 to take different actions depending on the value File::open returns. Listing 9-4 shows one way to handle the Result using a basic tool, the match expression that we discussed in Chapter 6.

æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦æ‰©å±•ç¤ºä¾‹9-3çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œæ ¹æ® File::open çš„è¿”å›å€¼æ‰§è¡Œä¸åŒæ“ä½œã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹9-4å±•ç¤ºäº†ç”¨ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼å¤„ç† Result çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

Note that, like the Option enum, the Result enum and its variants have been brought into scope by the prelude, so we donâ€™t need to specify Result:: before the Ok and Err variants in the match arms.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šä¸ Option æšä¸¾ç±»ä¼¼ï¼ŒResult æšä¸¾åŠå…¶å˜ä½“å·²é€šè¿‡é¢„å¯¼å…¥ï¼ˆpreludeï¼‰å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸï¼Œå› æ­¤ match åˆ†æ”¯ä¸­æ— éœ€åœ¨ Ok å’Œ Err å‰æŒ‡å®š Result::ã€‚

When the result is Ok, this code will return the inner file value out of the Ok variant, and we then assign that file handle value to the variable greeting_file. After the match, we can use the file handle for reading or writing.

å½“ç»“æœä¸º Ok æ—¶ï¼Œæ­¤ä»£ç ä» Ok å˜ä½“ä¸­å–å‡ºå†…éƒ¨ file å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶å°†è¯¥æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„èµ‹ç»™å˜é‡ greeting_fileã€‚match ä¹‹åå³å¯ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„è¿›è¡Œè¯»å†™ã€‚

The other arm of the match handles the case where we get an Err value from File::open. In this example, weâ€™ve chosen to call the panic! macro. If thereâ€™s no file named hello.txt in our current directory and we run this code, weâ€™ll see the following output from the panic! macro:

match çš„å¦ä¸€åˆ†æ”¯å¤„ç†ä» File::open è·å– Err å€¼çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚æœ¬ä¾‹é€‰æ‹©è°ƒç”¨ panic! å®ã€‚è‹¥å½“å‰ç›®å½•æ—  hello.txt æ–‡ä»¶æ—¶è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ï¼Œå°†çœ‹åˆ° panic! å®çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling error-handling v0.1.0 (file:///projects/error-handling)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.73s
     Running `target/debug/error-handling`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:8:23:
Problem opening the file: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

As usual, this output tells us exactly what has gone wrong.

æ­¤è¾“å‡ºç²¾ç¡®æŒ‡å‡ºäº†é—®é¢˜æ‰€åœ¨ã€‚

Matching on Different Errors åŒ¹é…ä¸åŒé”™è¯¯

The code in Listing 9-4 will panic! no matter why File::open failed. However, we want to take different actions for different failure reasons. If File::open failed because the file doesnâ€™t exist, we want to create the file and return the handle to the new file. If File::open failed for any other reasonâ€”for example, because we didnâ€™t have permission to open the fileâ€”we still want the code to panic! in the same way it did in Listing 9-4. For this, we add an inner match expression, shown in Listing 9-5.

ç¤ºä¾‹9-4çš„ä»£ç æ— è®º File::open ä¸ºä½•å¤±è´¥éƒ½ä¼šè§¦å‘ panic!ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦é’ˆå¯¹ä¸åŒå¤±è´¥åŸå› é‡‡å–ä¸åŒæ“ä½œï¼šè‹¥å› æ–‡ä»¶ä¸å­˜åœ¨å¤±è´¥ï¼Œåˆ™åˆ›å»ºæ–‡ä»¶å¹¶è¿”å›æ–°æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„ï¼›è‹¥å› å…¶ä»–åŸå› ï¼ˆå¦‚æ— æƒé™ï¼‰å¤±è´¥ï¼Œä»æŒ‰ç¤ºä¾‹9-4çš„æ–¹å¼è§¦å‘ panic!ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ·»åŠ å†…éƒ¨ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹9-5ï¼‰ã€‚

The type of the value that File::open returns inside the Err variant is io::Error, which is a struct provided by the standard library. This struct has a method kind that we can call to get an io::ErrorKind value. The enum io::ErrorKind is provided by the standard library and has variants representing the different kinds of errors that might result from an io operation. The variant we want to use is ErrorKind::NotFound, which indicates the file weâ€™re trying to open doesnâ€™t exist yet. So we match on greeting_file_result, but we also have an inner match on error.kind().

File::open åœ¨ Err å˜ä½“ä¸­è¿”å›çš„å€¼ç±»å‹æ˜¯æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ io::Errorã€‚è¯¥ç»“æ„ä½“æœ‰ kind æ–¹æ³•å¯è·å– io::ErrorKind å€¼ã€‚æšä¸¾ io::ErrorKind ç”±æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›ï¼Œå…¶å˜ä½“è¡¨ç¤º io æ“ä½œå¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´çš„ä¸åŒé”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„å˜ä½“æ˜¯ ErrorKind::NotFoundï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºè¦æ‰“å¼€çš„æ–‡ä»¶å°šä¸å­˜åœ¨ã€‚å› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬åŒ¹é… greeting_file_resultï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ error.kind() ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œå†…éƒ¨åŒ¹é…ã€‚

The condition we want to check in the inner match is whether the value returned by error.kind() is the NotFound variant of the ErrorKind enum. If it is, we try to create the file with File::create. However, because File::create could also fail, we need a second arm in the inner match expression. When the file canâ€™t be created, a different error message is printed. The second arm of the outer match stays the same, so the program panics on any error besides the missing file error.

å†…éƒ¨åŒ¹é…ä¸­æ£€æŸ¥çš„æ¡ä»¶æ˜¯ï¼šerror.kind() è¿”å›çš„å€¼æ˜¯å¦ä¸º ErrorKind æšä¸¾çš„ NotFound å˜ä½“ã€‚è‹¥æ˜¯ï¼Œåˆ™å°è¯•ç”¨ File::create åˆ›å»ºæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚ä½† File::create ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼Œå› æ­¤å†…éƒ¨ match éœ€è¦ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯å¤„ç†æ–‡ä»¶åˆ›å»ºå¤±è´¥çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚å¤–éƒ¨ match çš„ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ä¿æŒä¸å˜ï¼Œç¨‹åºå¯¹é™¤æ–‡ä»¶ä¸å­˜åœ¨ä¹‹å¤–çš„å…¶ä»–é”™è¯¯å‡è§¦å‘ææ…Œã€‚

Alternatives to Using match with Result<T, E> æ›¿ä»£æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼šResult<T, E> çš„å…¶ä»–å¤„ç†æ–¹æ³•

Thatâ€™s a lot of match! The match expression is very useful but also very much a primitive. In Chapter 13, youâ€™ll learn about closures, which are used with many of the methods defined on Result<T, E>. These methods can be more concise than using match when handling Result<T, E> values in your code.

match å¤ªå¤šäº†ï¼match è¡¨è¾¾å¼è™½å®ç”¨ä½†è¾ƒåŸå§‹ã€‚ç¬¬13ç« å°†å­¦ä¹ é—­åŒ…ï¼Œå…¶å¯ä¸ Result<T, E> çš„è®¸å¤šæ–¹æ³•ç»“åˆä½¿ç”¨ã€‚è¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•åœ¨å¤„ç† Result<T, E> å€¼æ—¶æ¯” match æ›´ç®€æ´ã€‚

For example, hereâ€™s another way to write the same logic as shown in Listing 9-5, this time using closures and the unwrap_or_else method:

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å®ç°ä¸ç¤ºä¾‹9-5ç›¸åŒé€»è¾‘çš„å¦ä¸€ç§æ–¹å¼ï¼ˆä½¿ç”¨é—­åŒ…å’Œ unwrap_or_else æ–¹æ³•ï¼‰ï¼š

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::ErrorKind;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt").unwrap_or_else(|error| {
        if error.kind() == ErrorKind::NotFound {
            File::create("hello.txt").unwrap_or_else(|error| {
                panic!("Problem creating the file: {error:?}");
            })
        } else {
            panic!("Problem opening the file: {error:?}");
        }
    });
}

Although this code has the same behavior as Listing 9-5, it doesnâ€™t contain any match expressions and is cleaner to read. Come back to this example after youâ€™ve read Chapter 13, and look up the unwrap_or_else method in the standard library documentation. Many more of these methods can clean up huge nested match expressions when youâ€™re dealing with errors.

æ­¤ä»£ç è¡Œä¸ºä¸ç¤ºä¾‹9-5ç›¸åŒï¼Œä½†æ—  match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸”æ›´æ˜“è¯»ã€‚é˜…è¯»ç¬¬13ç« åå¯å›é¡¾æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼Œå¹¶æŸ¥é˜…æ ‡å‡†åº“æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­çš„ unwrap_or_else æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•èƒ½å¤§å¹…ç®€åŒ–åµŒå¥—çš„ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ã€‚

Shortcuts for Panic on Error: unwrap and expect é”™è¯¯æ—¶ææ…Œçš„å¿«æ·æ–¹æ³•ï¼šunwrap å’Œ expect

Using match works well enough, but it can be a bit verbose and doesnâ€™t always communicate intent well. The Result<T, E> type has many helper methods defined on it to do various, more specific tasks. The unwrap method is a shortcut method implemented just like the match expression we wrote in Listing 9-4. If the Result value is the Ok variant, unwrap will return the value inside the Ok. If the Result is the Err variant, unwrap will call the panic! macro for us. Here is an example of unwrap in action:

match è™½æœ‰æ•ˆä½†è¾ƒå†—é•¿ã€‚Result<T, E> ç±»å‹å®šä¹‰äº†è®¸å¤šè¾…åŠ©æ–¹æ³•æ‰§è¡Œç‰¹å®šä»»åŠ¡ã€‚unwrap æ–¹æ³•ä½œä¸ºå¿«æ·æ–¹å¼ï¼Œå…¶å®ç°ç±»ä¼¼ç¤ºä¾‹9-4çš„ matchï¼šè‹¥ Result ä¸º Ok å˜ä½“ï¼Œunwrap è¿”å›å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼›è‹¥ä¸º Err å˜ä½“ï¼Œåˆ™æ›¿æˆ‘ä»¬è°ƒç”¨ panic! å®ã€‚unwrap çš„å®ä¾‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

If we run this code without a hello.txt file, weâ€™ll see an error message from the panic! call that the unwrap method makes:

è‹¥æ—  hello.txt æ–‡ä»¶è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ï¼Œå°†çœ‹åˆ° unwrap è§¦å‘çš„ panic! é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼š

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:4:49:
called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }

Similarly, the expect method lets us also choose the panic! error message. Using expect instead of unwrap and providing good error messages can convey your intent and make tracking down the source of a panic easier. The syntax of expect looks like this:

ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œexpect æ–¹æ³•å…è®¸è‡ªå®šä¹‰ panic! é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ expect è€Œé unwrap å¹¶æä¾›æ¸…æ™°é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œèƒ½æ›´å¥½è¡¨è¾¾æ„å›¾å¹¶ç®€åŒ–ææ…Œæº¯æºã€‚expect è¯­æ³•å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

We use expect in the same way as unwrap: to return the file handle or call the panic! macro. The error message used by expect in its call to panic! will be the parameter that we pass to expect, rather than the default panic! message that unwrap uses. Hereâ€™s what it looks like:

expect ç”¨æ³•åŒ unwrapï¼šè¿”å›æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„æˆ–è°ƒç”¨ panic! å®ã€‚ä½† expect è°ƒç”¨ panic! æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼ é€’çš„å‚æ•°è€Œéé»˜è®¤ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚è¾“å‡ºå¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:5:10:
hello.txt should be included in this project: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }

In production-quality code, most Rustaceans choose expect rather than unwrap and give more context about why the operation is expected to always succeed. That way, if your assumptions are ever proven wrong, you have more information to use in debugging.

åœ¨ç”Ÿäº§çº§ä»£ç ä¸­ï¼Œå¤šæ•°Rustå¼€å‘è€…é€‰æ‹© expect è€Œé unwrapï¼Œä»¥æä¾›æ›´å¤šæ“ä½œæˆåŠŸé¢„æœŸçš„ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ã€‚è¿™æ ·åœ¨å‡è®¾é”™è¯¯æ—¶ï¼Œå¯æœ‰æ›´å¤šè°ƒè¯•ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Propagating Errors ä¼ æ’­é”™è¯¯

When a functionâ€™s implementation calls something that might fail, instead of handling the error within the function itself, you can return the error to the calling code so that it can decide what to do. This is known as propagating the error and gives more control to the calling code, where there might be more information or logic that dictates how the error should be handled than what you have available in the context of your code.

å‡½æ•°å®ç°è°ƒç”¨å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥çš„æ“ä½œæ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä¸ç›´æ¥å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯ï¼Œè€Œå°†é”™è¯¯è¿”å›ç»™è°ƒç”¨æ–¹å†³å®šå¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†ã€‚è¿™ç§°ä¸ºé”™è¯¯ä¼ æ’­ï¼Œèµ‹äºˆè°ƒç”¨æ–¹æ›´å¤šæ§åˆ¶æƒâ€”â€”ç›¸æ¯”å½“å‰ä»£ç ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æ–¹å¯èƒ½æŒæ¡æ›´å¤šä¿¡æ¯æˆ–é€»è¾‘æ¥å†³å®šé”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ã€‚

For example, Listing 9-6 shows a function that reads a username from a file. If the file doesnâ€™t exist or canâ€™t be read, this function will return those errors to the code that called the function.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œç¤ºä¾‹9-6çš„å‡½æ•°ä»æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–ç”¨æˆ·åã€‚è‹¥æ–‡ä»¶ä¸å­˜åœ¨æˆ–è¯»å–å¤±è´¥ï¼Œå‡½æ•°å°†é”™è¯¯è¿”å›ç»™è°ƒç”¨æ–¹ã€‚

This function can be written in a much shorter way, but weâ€™re going to start by doing a lot of it manually in order to explore error handling; at the end, weâ€™ll show the shorter way. Letâ€™s look at the return type of the function first: Result<String, io::Error>. This means the function is returning a value of the type Result<T, E>, where the generic parameter T has been filled in with the concrete type String and the generic type E has been filled in with the concrete type io::Error.

æ­¤å‡½æ•°å¯æ›´ç®€æ´å®ç°ï¼Œä½†ä¸ºæ¢ç´¢é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†å…ˆæ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°ï¼Œæœ€åå±•ç¤ºç®€æ´å†™æ³•ã€‚é¦–å…ˆçœ‹å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ç±»å‹ï¼šResult<String, io::Error>ã€‚è¡¨ç¤ºå‡½æ•°è¿”å› Result<T, E> ç±»å‹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æ³›å‹å‚æ•° T æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºå…·ä½“ç±»å‹ Stringï¼ŒE æ›¿æ¢ä¸º io::Errorã€‚

If this function succeeds without any problems, the code that calls this function will receive an Ok value that holds a Stringâ€”the username that this function read from the file. If this function encounters any problems, the calling code will receive an Err value that holds an instance of io::Error that contains more information about what the problems were. We chose io::Error as the return type of this function because that happens to be the type of the error value returned from both of the operations weâ€™re calling in this functionâ€™s body that might fail: the File::open function and the read_to_string method.

è‹¥å‡½æ•°æˆåŠŸï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æ–¹å°†æ”¶åˆ°åŒ…å«ç”¨æˆ·åçš„ Ok å€¼ï¼›è‹¥é‡åˆ°é—®é¢˜ï¼Œåˆ™æ”¶åˆ°åŒ…å« io::Error å®ä¾‹çš„ Err å€¼ã€‚é€‰æ‹© io::Error ä½œä¸ºè¿”å›ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå‡½æ•°ä½“å†…å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªæ“ä½œï¼ˆFile::open å’Œ read_to_stringï¼‰å‡è¿”å›æ­¤é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ã€‚

The body of the function starts by calling the File::open function. Then we handle the Result value with a match similar to the match in Listing 9-4. If File::open succeeds, the file handle in the pattern variable file becomes the value in the mutable variable username_file and the function continues. In the Err case, instead of calling panic!, we use the return keyword to return early out of the function entirely and pass the error value from File::open, now in the pattern variable e, back to the calling code as this functionâ€™s error value.

å‡½æ•°ä½“é¦–å…ˆè°ƒç”¨ File::openï¼Œç„¶åç”¨ç±»ä¼¼ç¤ºä¾‹9-4çš„ match å¤„ç† Resultã€‚è‹¥ File::open æˆåŠŸï¼Œæ¨¡å¼å˜é‡ file çš„å€¼å°†èµ‹ç»™å¯å˜å˜é‡ username_fileï¼Œå‡½æ•°ç»§ç»­æ‰§è¡Œã€‚åœ¨ Err åˆ†æ”¯ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ return å…³é”®å­—æå‰è¿”å›æ•´ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¹¶å°† File::open çš„é”™è¯¯å€¼ï¼ˆç°ä½äºæ¨¡å¼å˜é‡ eï¼‰ä½œä¸ºå‡½æ•°é”™è¯¯å€¼è¿”å›ç»™è°ƒç”¨æ–¹ã€‚

So, if we have a file handle in username_file, the function then creates a new String in variable username and calls the read_to_string method on the file handle in username_file to read the contents of the file into username. The read_to_string method also returns a Result because it might fail, even though File::open succeeded. So we need another match to handle that Result: if read_to_string succeeds, then our function has succeeded, and we return the username from the file thatâ€™s now in username wrapped in an Ok. If read_to_string fails, we return the error value in the same way that we returned the error value in the match that handled the return value of File::open. However, we donâ€™t need to explicitly say return, because this is the last expression in the function.

è‹¥ username_file ä¸­æœ‰æ–‡ä»¶å¥æŸ„ï¼Œå‡½æ•°åœ¨å˜é‡ username ä¸­åˆ›å»ºæ–° Stringï¼Œå¹¶è°ƒç”¨ username_file çš„ read_to_string æ–¹æ³•å°†æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹è¯»å…¥ usernameã€‚å³ä½¿ File::open æˆåŠŸï¼Œread_to_string ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼Œæ•…éœ€å¦ä¸€ä¸ª match å¤„ç†å…¶è¿”å›çš„ Resultï¼šè‹¥ read_to_string æˆåŠŸï¼Œå‡½æ•°è¿”å›åŒ…å«ç”¨æˆ·åçš„ Okï¼›è‹¥å¤±è´¥ï¼Œåˆ™æŒ‰ç›¸åŒæ–¹å¼è¿”å›é”™è¯¯å€¼ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„æ— éœ€æ˜¾å¼ returnï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™æ˜¯å‡½æ•°æœ€åè¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼‰ã€‚

The code that calls this code will then handle getting either an Ok value that contains a username or an Err value that contains an io::Error. Itâ€™s up to the calling code to decide what to do with those values. If the calling code gets an Err value, it could call panic! and crash the program, use a default username, or look up the username from somewhere other than a file, for example. We donâ€™t have enough information on what the calling code is actually trying to do, so we propagate all the success or error information upward for it to handle appropriately.

è°ƒç”¨æ­¤å‡½æ•°çš„ä»£ç å°†å¤„ç†è·å–ç”¨æˆ·åï¼ˆOkï¼‰æˆ– io::Errorï¼ˆErrï¼‰ã€‚ç”±è°ƒç”¨æ–¹å†³å®šåç»­æ“ä½œï¼šå¯è°ƒç”¨ panic! ç»ˆæ­¢ç¨‹åºã€ä½¿ç”¨é»˜è®¤ç”¨æˆ·åæˆ–ä»æ–‡ä»¶å¤–è·å–ç”¨æˆ·åç­‰ã€‚å› æ— æ³•è·çŸ¥è°ƒç”¨æ–¹å…·ä½“æ„å›¾ï¼Œæ•…å‘ä¸Šä¼ æ’­æ‰€æœ‰æˆåŠŸæˆ–é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ä¾›å…¶å¦¥å–„å¤„ç†ã€‚

This pattern of propagating errors is so common in Rust that Rust provides the question mark operator ? to make this easier.

æ­¤é”™è¯¯ä¼ æ’­æ¨¡å¼åœ¨Rustä¸­éå¸¸å¸¸è§ï¼Œå› æ­¤Rustæä¾›äº†é—®å·æ“ä½œç¬¦ ? æ¥ç®€åŒ–ã€‚

A Shortcut for Propagating Errors: The ? Operator ä¼ æ’­é”™è¯¯çš„å¿«æ·æ–¹å¼ï¼š? æ“ä½œç¬¦

Listing 9-7 shows an implementation of read_username_from_file that has the same functionality as in Listing 9-6, but this implementation uses the ? operator.

ç¤ºä¾‹9-7çš„ read_username_from_file å®ç°ä¸ç¤ºä¾‹9-6åŠŸèƒ½ç›¸åŒï¼Œä½†ä½¿ç”¨äº† ? æ“ä½œç¬¦ï¼š

The ? placed after a Result value is defined to work in almost the same way as the match expressions we defined to handle the Result values in Listing 9-6. If the value of the Result is an Ok, the value inside the Ok will get returned from this expression, and the program will continue. If the value is an Err, the Err will be returned from the whole function as if we had used the return keyword so the error value gets propagated to the calling code.

Result å€¼åçš„ ? å®šä¹‰çš„å·¥ä½œæ–¹å¼å‡ ä¹ä¸ç¤ºä¾‹9-6ä¸­å¤„ç† Result çš„ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼ç›¸åŒï¼šè‹¥ Result å€¼ä¸º Okï¼Œåˆ™è¿”å› Ok å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼Œç¨‹åºç»§ç»­ï¼›è‹¥ä¸º Errï¼Œåˆ™ä»æ•´ä¸ªå‡½æ•°è¿”å› Errï¼ˆå¦‚åŒä½¿ç”¨äº† returnï¼‰ï¼Œé”™è¯¯å€¼ä¼ æ’­ç»™è°ƒç”¨æ–¹ã€‚

There is a difference between what the match expression from Listing 9-6 does and what the ? operator does: error values that have the ? operator called on them go through the from function, defined in the From trait in the standard library, which is used to convert values from one type into another. When the ? operator calls the from function, the error type received is converted into the error type defined in the return type of the current function. This is useful when a function returns one error type to represent all the ways a function might fail, even if parts might fail for many different reasons.

ç¤ºä¾‹9-6çš„ match ä¸ ? æ“ä½œç¬¦çš„åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºï¼š? æ“ä½œç¬¦è°ƒç”¨çš„é”™è¯¯å€¼ä¼šé€šè¿‡æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸­ From trait å®šä¹‰çš„ from å‡½æ•°è¿›è¡Œç±»å‹è½¬æ¢ã€‚? è°ƒç”¨ from å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶çš„é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ä¼šè¢«è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå½“å‰å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ç±»å‹æ‰€å®šä¹‰çš„é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ã€‚å½“å‡½æ•°éœ€è¿”å›ç»Ÿä¸€é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ä»£è¡¨æ‰€æœ‰å¤±è´¥å¯èƒ½ï¼ˆå³ä½¿å„éƒ¨åˆ†å¤±è´¥åŸå› ä¸åŒï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œæ­¤æœºåˆ¶éå¸¸æœ‰ç”¨ã€‚

For example, we could change the read_username_from_file function in Listing 9-7 to return a custom error type named OurError that we define. If we also define impl From<io::Error> for OurError to construct an instance of OurError from an io::Error, then the ? operator calls in the body of read_username_from_file will call from and convert the error types without needing to add any more code to the function.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¯å°†ç¤ºä¾‹9-7ä¸­çš„ read_username_from_file æ”¹ä¸ºè¿”å›è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ OurErrorã€‚è‹¥åŒæ—¶ä¸º OurError å®ç° impl From<io::Error> for OurErrorï¼ˆä» io::Error æ„é€  OurErrorï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™ read_username_from_file ä¸­çš„ ? ä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨è°ƒç”¨ from è½¬æ¢é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ï¼Œæ— éœ€é¢å¤–ä»£ç ã€‚

In the context of Listing 9-7, the ? at the end of the File::open call will return the value inside an Ok to the variable username_file. If an error occurs, the ? operator will return early out of the whole function and give any Err value to the calling code. The same thing applies to the ? at the end of the read_to_string call.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹9-7ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­ï¼ŒFile::open è°ƒç”¨æœ«å°¾çš„ ? å°†è¿”å› Ok å†…éƒ¨å€¼ç»™å˜é‡ username_fileï¼›è‹¥å‡ºé”™ï¼Œåˆ™æå‰è¿”å›é”™è¯¯å€¼ç»™è°ƒç”¨æ–¹ã€‚read_to_string è°ƒç”¨æœ«å°¾çš„ ? åŒç†ã€‚

The ? operator eliminates a lot of boilerplate and makes this functionâ€™s implementation simpler. We could even shorten this code further by chaining method calls immediately after the ?, as shown in Listing 9-8.

? æ“ä½œç¬¦æ¶ˆé™¤äº†å¤§é‡æ ·æ¿ä»£ç ï¼Œä½¿å‡½æ•°å®ç°æ›´ç®€æ´ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å¯é€šè¿‡é“¾å¼æ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨æ¥è¿›ä¸€æ­¥ç¼©çŸ­ä»£ç ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹9-8ï¼‰ã€‚

Weâ€™ve moved the creation of the new String in username to the beginning of the function; that part hasnâ€™t changed. Instead of creating a variable username_file, weâ€™ve chained the call to read_to_string directly onto the result of File::open("hello.txt")?. We still have a ? at the end of the read_to_string call, and we still return an Ok value containing username when both File::open and read_to_string succeed rather than returning errors. The functionality is again the same as in Listing 9-6 and Listing 9-7; this is just a different, more ergonomic way to write it.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åˆ›å»ºæ–° String çš„ä»£ç ç§»åˆ°å‡½æ•°å¼€å¤´ï¼ˆæ­¤éƒ¨åˆ†æœªå˜ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸å†åˆ›å»ºå˜é‡ username_fileï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç›´æ¥åœ¨ File::open("hello.txt")? çš„ç»“æœä¸Šé“¾å¼è°ƒç”¨ read_to_stringã€‚read_to_string è°ƒç”¨æœ«å°¾ä»æœ‰ ?ï¼Œä¸”å½“ä¸¤è€…å‡æˆåŠŸæ—¶è¿”å›åŒ…å«ç”¨æˆ·åçš„ Okã€‚åŠŸèƒ½ä¸ç¤ºä¾‹9-6å’Œ9-7ç›¸åŒï¼Œä½†å†™æ³•æ›´ç¬¦åˆäººä½“å·¥å­¦ã€‚

Listing 9-9 shows a way to make this even shorter using fs::read_to_string.

ç¤ºä¾‹9-9å±•ç¤ºäº†ä½¿ç”¨ fs::read_to_string çš„æ›´ç®€æ´å®ç°ã€‚

Reading a file into a string is a fairly common operation, so the standard library provides the convenient fs::read_to_string function that opens the file, creates a new String, reads the contents of the file, puts the contents into that String, and returns it. Of course, using fs::read_to_string doesnâ€™t give us the opportunity to explain all the error handling, so we did it the longer way first.

å°†æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å…¥å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ˜¯å¸¸è§æ“ä½œï¼Œå› æ­¤æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›äº†ä¾¿æ·çš„ fs::read_to_string å‡½æ•°ï¼šæ‰“å¼€æ–‡ä»¶ã€åˆ›å»ºæ–° Stringã€è¯»å–å†…å®¹å¹¶è¿”å›ã€‚å½“ç„¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ fs::read_to_string æ— æ³•å±•ç¤ºé”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ï¼Œæ•…æˆ‘ä»¬å…ˆé‡‡ç”¨è¾ƒé•¿å®ç°ã€‚

Where the ? Operator Can Be Used ? æ“ä½œç¬¦çš„ä½¿ç”¨åœºæ™¯

The ? operator can only be used in functions whose return type is compatible with the value the ? is used on. This is because the ? operator is defined to perform an early return of a value out of the function, in the same manner as the match expression we defined in Listing 9-6. In Listing 9-6, the match was using a Result value, and the early return arm returned an Err(e) value. The return type of the function has to be a Result so that itâ€™s compatible with this return.

? æ“ä½œç¬¦ä»…å¯ç”¨äºè¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸ ? æ‰€ä½œç”¨å€¼å…¼å®¹çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚å› ä¸º ? å®šä¹‰ä¸ºä»å‡½æ•°ä¸­æå‰è¿”å›å€¼ï¼Œæ–¹å¼ç±»ä¼¼ç¤ºä¾‹9-6çš„ matchã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹9-6ä¸­ï¼Œmatch å¤„ç† Result å€¼ï¼Œæå‰è¿”å›åˆ†æ”¯è¿”å› Err(e)ã€‚å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ç±»å‹å¿…é¡»æ˜¯ Result æ‰èƒ½å…¼å®¹æ­¤ returnã€‚

In Listing 9-10, letâ€™s look at the error weâ€™ll get if we use the ? operator in a main function with a return type that is incompatible with the type of the value we use ? on.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹9-10ä¸­ï¼Œè‹¥åœ¨è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸å…¼å®¹çš„ main å‡½æ•°ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ ?ï¼Œå°†çœ‹åˆ°é”™è¯¯ã€‚

This code opens a file, which might fail. The ? operator follows the Result value returned by File::open, but this main function has the return type of (), not Result. When we compile this code, we get the following error message:
