æ­¤ä»£ç å°è¯•æ‰“å¼€å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥çš„æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚? ä½œç”¨äº File::open è¿”å›çš„ Resultï¼Œä½† main å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸º () è€Œé Resultã€‚ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶æŠ¥é”™ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling error-handling v0.1.0 (file:///projects/error-handling)
error[E0277]: the `?` operator can only be used in a function that returns `Result` or `Option` (or another type that implements `FromResidual`)
 --> src/main.rs:4:48
  |
3 | fn main() {
  | --------- this function should return `Result` or `Option` to accept `?`
4 |     let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
  |                                                ^ cannot use the `?` operator in a function that returns `()`
  |
  = help: the trait `FromResidual<Result<Infallible, std::io::Error>>` is not implemented for `()`
help: consider adding return type
  |
3 ~ fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
4 |     let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
5 +     Ok(())
  |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `error-handling` (bin "error-handling") due to 1 previous error

This error points out that weâ€™re only allowed to use the ? operator in a function that returns Result, Option, or another type that implements FromResidual.

æ­¤é”™è¯¯æŒ‡å‡ºï¼š[note]åªèƒ½åœ¨è¿”å› Resultã€Option æˆ–å®ç°äº† FromResidual ç±»å‹çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ ?ã€‚

To fix the error, you have two choices. One choice is to change the return type of your function to be compatible with the value youâ€™re using the ? operator on as long as you have no restrictions preventing that. The other choice is to use a match or one of the Result<T, E> methods to handle the Result<T, E> in whatever way is appropriate.

ä¿®å¤æ–¹æ³•æœ‰ä¸¤ç§ï¼šè‹¥æ— é™åˆ¶ï¼Œå¯æ›´æ”¹å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä»¥å…¼å®¹ ? æ‰€ä½œç”¨çš„å€¼ï¼›ä½¿ç”¨ match æˆ– Result<T, E> çš„æ–¹æ³•ä»¥é€‚å½“æ–¹å¼å¤„ç†å€¼ã€‚

The error message also mentioned that ? can be used with Option<T> values as well. As with using ? on Result, you can only use ? on Option in a function that returns an Option. The behavior of the ? operator when called on an Option<T> is similar to its behavior when called on a Result<T, E>: if the value is None, the None will be returned early from the function at that point. If the value is Some, the value inside the Some is the resultant value of the expression, and the function continues. Listing 9-11 has an example of a function that finds the last character of the first line in the given text.

é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯è¿˜æåˆ° ? ä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨äº Option<T> å€¼ã€‚ä¸ Result ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œåªèƒ½åœ¨è¿”å› Option çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­å¯¹ Option ä½¿ç”¨ ?ã€‚? ä½œç”¨äº Option<T> çš„è¡Œä¸ºç±»ä¼¼ä½œç”¨äº Result<T, E>ï¼šè‹¥å€¼ä¸º Noneï¼Œåˆ™æå‰ä»å‡½æ•°è¿”å› Noneï¼›è‹¥ä¸º Someï¼Œåˆ™ Some å†…éƒ¨çš„å€¼ä½œä¸ºè¡¨è¾¾å¼ç»“æœï¼Œå‡½æ•°ç»§ç»­æ‰§è¡Œã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹9-11å±•ç¤ºåœ¨ç»™å®šæ–‡æœ¬ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾é¦–è¡Œæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼š

This function returns Option<char> because itâ€™s possible that there is a character there, but itâ€™s also possible that there isnâ€™t. This code takes the text string slice argument and calls the lines method on it, which returns an iterator over the lines in the string. Because this function wants to examine the first line, it calls next on the iterator to get the first value from the iterator. If text is the empty string, this call to next will return None, in which case we use ? to stop and return None from last_char_of_first_line. If text is not the empty string, next will return a Some value containing a string slice of the first line in text.

æ­¤å‡½æ•°è¿”å› Option<char>ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå¯èƒ½æ‰¾åˆ°å­—ç¬¦ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æ‰¾ä¸åˆ°ã€‚ä»£ç æ¥æ”¶å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡å‚æ•° textï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ lines æ–¹æ³•è·å–å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è¡Œçš„è¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚ä¸ºæ£€æŸ¥é¦–è¡Œï¼Œè°ƒç”¨è¿­ä»£å™¨çš„ next æ–¹æ³•è·å–ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå€¼ã€‚è‹¥ text ä¸ºç©ºï¼Œnext è¿”å› Noneï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶ç”¨ ? åœæ­¢å¹¶è¿”å› Noneï¼›è‹¥ä¸ä¸ºç©ºï¼Œåˆ™è¿”å›åŒ…å«é¦–è¡Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡çš„ Someã€‚

The ? extracts the string slice, and we can call chars on that string slice to get an iterator of its characters. Weâ€™re interested in the last character in this first line, so we call last to return the last item in the iterator. This is an Option because itâ€™s possible that the first line is the empty string; for example, if text starts with a blank line but has characters on other lines, as in "\nhi". However, if there is a last character on the first line, it will be returned in the Some variant. The ? operator in the middle gives us a concise way to express this logic, allowing us to implement the function in one line. If we couldnâ€™t use the ? operator on Option, weâ€™d have to implement this logic using more method calls or a match expression.

? è§£å‡ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ chars è·å–å­—ç¬¦è¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦é¦–è¡Œæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ï¼Œæ•…è°ƒç”¨ last è¿”å›è¿­ä»£å™¨æœ«é¡¹ã€‚è¿”å› Option æ˜¯å› ä¸ºé¦–è¡Œå¯èƒ½ä¸ºç©ºï¼ˆå¦‚ "\nhi"ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥é¦–è¡Œå­˜åœ¨æœ«å­—ç¬¦ï¼Œåˆ™è¿”å› Someã€‚ä¸­é—´çš„ ? æ“ä½œç¬¦ç®€æ´è¡¨è¾¾äº†æ­¤é€»è¾‘ï¼Œå•è¡Œå³å¯å®ç°å‡½æ•°ã€‚è‹¥ä¸èƒ½å¯¹ Option ä½¿ç”¨ ?ï¼Œåˆ™éœ€æ›´å¤šæ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨æˆ– match å®ç°ã€‚

Note that you can use the ? operator on a Result in a function that returns Result, and you can use the ? operator on an Option in a function that returns Option, but you canâ€™t mix and match. The ? operator wonâ€™t automatically convert a Result to an Option or vice versa; in those cases, you can use methods like the ok method on Result or the ok_or method on Option to do the conversion explicitly.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå¯åœ¨è¿”å› Result çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­å¯¹ Result ä½¿ç”¨ ?ï¼Œåœ¨è¿”å› Option çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­å¯¹ Option ä½¿ç”¨ ?ï¼Œä½†ä¸èƒ½æ··ç”¨ã€‚? ä¸ä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨è½¬æ¢ Result å’Œ Optionï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶å¯ç”¨ Result çš„ ok æ–¹æ³•æˆ– Option çš„ ok_or æ–¹æ³•æ˜¾å¼è½¬æ¢ã€‚

So far, all the main functions weâ€™ve used return (). The main function is special because itâ€™s the entry point and exit point of an executable program, and there are restrictions on what its return type can be for the program to behave as expected.

ç›®å‰æ‰€æœ‰ main å‡½æ•°å‡è¿”å› ()ã€‚main å‡½æ•°ç‰¹æ®Šï¼Œå› å®ƒæ˜¯å¯æ‰§è¡Œç¨‹åºçš„å…¥å£å’Œå‡ºå£ç‚¹ï¼Œå…¶è¿”å›ç±»å‹å—é™ä»¥ä¿è¯ç¨‹åºè¡Œä¸ºç¬¦åˆé¢„æœŸã€‚

Luckily, main can also return a Result<(), E>. Listing 9-12 has the code from Listing 9-10, but weâ€™ve changed the return type of main to be Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> and added a return value Ok(()) to the end. This code will now compile.

å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œ[note]main ä¹Ÿå¯è¿”å› Result<(), E>ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹9-12ä¿®æ”¹äº†ç¤ºä¾‹9-10ä¸­ main çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸º Result<(), Box<dyn Error>>ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨æœ«å°¾æ·»åŠ è¿”å›å€¼ Ok(())ã€‚æ­¤ä»£ç å¯ç¼–è¯‘ï¼š

The Box<dyn Error> type is a trait object, which weâ€™ll talk about in â€œUsing Trait Objects That Allow for Values of Different Typesâ€ in Chapter 18. For now, you can read Box<dyn Error> to mean â€œany kind of error.â€ Using ? on a Result value in a main function with the error type Box<dyn Error> is allowed because it allows any Err value to be returned early. Even though the body of this main function will only ever return errors of type std::io::Error, by specifying Box<dyn Error>, this signature will continue to be correct even if more code that returns other errors is added to the body of main.

Box<dyn Error> æ˜¯ traitå¯¹è±¡ï¼ˆç¬¬18ç« è®¨è®ºï¼‰ã€‚ç›®å‰å¯å°†å…¶ç†è§£ä¸ºâ€œä»»ä½•ç±»å‹çš„é”™è¯¯â€œã€‚åœ¨é”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ä¸º Box<dyn Error> çš„ main å‡½æ•°ä¸­å¯¹ Result ä½¿ç”¨ ? æ˜¯å…è®¸çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»»ä½• Err å€¼å‡å¯æå‰è¿”å›ã€‚å³ä½¿æ­¤ main å‡½æ•°ä»…è¿”å› std::io::Error ç±»å‹é”™è¯¯ï¼ŒæŒ‡å®š Box<dyn Error> åï¼Œå³ä½¿å‡½æ•°ä½“æ·»åŠ è¿”å›å…¶ä»–é”™è¯¯çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œç­¾åä»ä¿æŒæ­£ç¡®ã€‚

When a main function returns a Result<(), E>, the executable will exit with a value of 0 if main returns Ok(()) and will exit with a nonzero value if main returns an Err value. Executables written in C return integers when they exit: programs that exit successfully return the integer 0, and programs that error return some integer other than 0. Rust also returns integers from executables to be compatible with this convention.

å½“ main è¿”å› Result<(), E> æ—¶ï¼Œè‹¥è¿”å› Ok(()) åˆ™ç¨‹åºä»¥ 0 é€€å‡ºï¼›è‹¥è¿”å› Err åˆ™ä»¥éé›¶å€¼é€€å‡ºã€‚Cè¯­è¨€ç¨‹åºé€€å‡ºæ—¶è¿”å›æ•´æ•°ï¼šæˆåŠŸè¿”å› 0ï¼Œé”™è¯¯è¿”å›é 0 æ•´æ•°ã€‚ä¸ºå…¼å®¹æ­¤çº¦å®šï¼ŒRustå¯æ‰§è¡Œç¨‹åºä¹Ÿè¿”å›æ•´æ•°ã€‚

The main function may return any types that implement the std::process::Termination trait, which contains a function report that returns an ExitCode. Consult the standard library documentation for more information on implementing the Termination trait for your own types.

[note]main å‡½æ•°å¯è¿”å›ä»»ä½•å®ç°äº† std::process::Termination trait çš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œè¯¥ trait åŒ…å«è¿”å› ExitCode çš„ report å‡½æ•°ã€‚æœ‰å…³ä¸ºè‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹å®ç° Termination trait çš„æ›´å¤šä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¯·æŸ¥é˜…æ ‡å‡†åº“æ–‡æ¡£ã€‚

Now that weâ€™ve discussed the details of calling panic! or returning Result, letâ€™s return to the topic of how to decide which is appropriate to use in which cases.

è‡³æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å·²è®¨è®ºè°ƒç”¨ panic! æˆ–è¿”å› Result çš„ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚ç°åœ¨å›åˆ°æ ¸å¿ƒé—®é¢˜ï¼šå¦‚ä½•å†³å®šåœ¨ä½•ç§åœºæ™¯ä½¿ç”¨ä½•ç§æ–¹å¼ã€‚

To panic! or Not to panic! è¯¥ä½¿ç”¨ panic! è¿˜æ˜¯ä¸è¯¥ç”¨ panic!

So how do you decide when you should call panic! and when you should return Result? When code panics, thereâ€™s no way to recover. You could call panic! for any error situation, whether thereâ€™s a possible way to recover or not, but then youâ€™re making the decision that a situation is unrecoverable on behalf of the calling code. When you choose to return a Result value, you give the calling code options. The calling code could choose to attempt to recover in a way thatâ€™s appropriate for its situation, or it could decide that an Err value in this case is unrecoverable, so it can call panic! and turn your recoverable error into an unrecoverable one. Therefore, returning Result is a good default choice when youâ€™re defining a function that might fail.

é‚£ä¹ˆè¯¥å¦‚ä½•å†³å®šä½•æ—¶åº”è¯¥è°ƒç”¨ panic! ä»¥åŠä½•æ—¶åº”è¯¥è¿”å› Result å‘¢ï¼Ÿå½“ä»£ç  panic æ—¶ï¼Œæ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰æ¢å¤é€”å¾„çš„ã€‚ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨ä»»ä½•é”™è¯¯åœºæ™¯ä¸‹è°ƒç”¨ panic!ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨å¯èƒ½çš„æ¢å¤æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä½†è¿™æ ·åšå°±æ„å‘³ç€ä½ ä»£è¡¨è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç åšå‡ºäº†è¯¥åœºæ™¯ä¸å¯æ¢å¤çš„å†³å®šã€‚å½“ä½ é€‰æ‹©è¿”å› Result å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œåˆ™èµ‹äºˆäº†è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç é€‰æ‹©æƒã€‚è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç å¯ä»¥æ ¹æ®è‡ªèº«æƒ…å†µé€‰æ‹©å°è¯•æ¢å¤ï¼Œæˆ–è€…åˆ¤å®šæ­¤å¤„çš„ Err å€¼ä¸å¯æ¢å¤ï¼Œä»è€Œè°ƒç”¨ panic! å°†ä½ çš„å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯è½¬ä¸ºä¸å¯æ¢å¤é”™è¯¯ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨å®šä¹‰å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥çš„å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œè¿”å› Result æ˜¯è‰¯å¥½çš„é»˜è®¤é€‰æ‹©ã€‚

In situations such as examples, prototype code, and tests, itâ€™s more appropriate to write code that panics instead of returning a Result. Letâ€™s explore why, then discuss situations in which the compiler canâ€™t tell that failure is impossible, but you as a human can. The chapter will conclude with some general guidelines on how to decide whether to panic in library code.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ã€åŸå‹ä»£ç å’Œæµ‹è¯•ç­‰åœºæ™¯ä¸­ï¼Œç¼–å†™ panic çš„ä»£ç æ¯”è¿”å› Result æ›´åˆé€‚ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢è®¨åŸå› ï¼Œç„¶åè®¨è®ºç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ— æ³•åˆ¤æ–­å¤±è´¥ä¸å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿã€ä½†å¼€å‘è€…å¯ä»¥ç¡®è®¤çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚æœ¬ç« æœ€åä¼šç»™å‡ºåœ¨åº“ä»£ç ä¸­å†³å®šæ˜¯å¦ panic çš„é€šç”¨æŒ‡å¯¼åŸåˆ™ã€‚

Examples, Prototype Code, and Tests ç¤ºä¾‹ã€åŸå‹ä»£ç å’Œæµ‹è¯•

When youâ€™re writing an example to illustrate some concept, also including robust error-handling code can make the example less clear. In examples, itâ€™s understood that a call to a method like unwrap that could panic is meant as a placeholder for the way youâ€™d want your application to handle errors, which can differ based on what the rest of your code is doing.

å½“ä½ ç¼–å†™ç¤ºä¾‹é˜è¿°æŸä¸ªæ¦‚å¿µæ—¶ï¼ŒåŒ…å«å¥å£®çš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ä»£ç åè€Œä¼šé™ä½ç¤ºä¾‹çš„æ¸…æ™°åº¦ã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œåƒ unwrap è¿™ç±»å¯èƒ½ panic çš„æ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œåº”è¢«ç†è§£ä¸ºåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºé”™è¯¯å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼çš„å ä½ç¬¦â€”â€”å…·ä½“å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼å¯èƒ½å› ä»£ç å…¶ä»–éƒ¨åˆ†è€Œå¼‚ã€‚

Similarly, the unwrap and expect methods are very handy when prototyping, before youâ€™re ready to decide how to handle errors. They leave clear markers in your code for when youâ€™re ready to make your program more robust.

ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œåœ¨åŸå‹è®¾è®¡é˜¶æ®µï¼Œå½“ä½ å°šæœªå†³å®šå¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯æ—¶ï¼Œunwrap å’Œ expect æ–¹æ³•éå¸¸æ–¹ä¾¿ã€‚å®ƒä»¬ä¼šåœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­ç•™ä¸‹æ¸…æ™°çš„æ ‡è®°ï¼Œä¾¿äºåç»­æ”¹è¿›ç¨‹åºçš„å¥å£®æ€§ã€‚

If a method call fails in a test, youâ€™d want the whole test to fail, even if that method isnâ€™t the functionality under test. Because panic! is how a test is marked as a failure, calling unwrap or expect is exactly what should happen.

å¦‚æœæµ‹è¯•ä¸­çš„æ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨å¤±è´¥ï¼Œå³ä½¿è¯¥æ–¹æ³•å¹¶éè¢«æµ‹åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œä½ ä¹Ÿå¸Œæœ›æ•´ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•å¤±è´¥ã€‚å› ä¸º panic! æ­£æ˜¯æ ‡è®°æµ‹è¯•å¤±è´¥çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶è°ƒç”¨ unwrap æˆ– expect æ˜¯å®Œå…¨åˆç†çš„ã€‚

Cases in Which You Have More Information Than the Compiler ä½ æ¯”ç¼–è¯‘å™¨æŒæ¡æ›´å¤šä¿¡æ¯çš„æƒ…å†µ

It would also be appropriate to call expect when you have some other logic that ensures the Result will have an Ok value, but the logic isnâ€™t something the compiler understands. Youâ€™ll still have a Result value that you need to handle: whatever operation youâ€™re calling still has the possibility of failing in general, even though itâ€™s logically impossible in your particular situation. If you can ensure by manually inspecting the code that youâ€™ll never have an Err variant, itâ€™s perfectly acceptable to call expect and document the reason you think youâ€™ll never have an Err variant in the argument text. Hereâ€™s an example:

å½“ä½ é€šè¿‡å…¶ä»–é€»è¾‘ç¡®ä¿ Result å¿…å®šæ˜¯ Ok å€¼ï¼Œä½†è¯¥é€»è¾‘è¶…å‡ºç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç†è§£èŒƒå›´æ—¶ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ expect ä¹Ÿæ˜¯åˆé€‚çš„ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ä½ ä»éœ€å¤„ç† Result å€¼ï¼šä»æ™®éè§’åº¦çœ‹ï¼Œè¢«è°ƒç”¨çš„æ“ä½œä»æœ‰å¤±è´¥å¯èƒ½ï¼Œå°½ç®¡åœ¨ä½ çš„ç‰¹å®šåœºæ™¯ä¸­é€»è¾‘ä¸Šä¸å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿã€‚è‹¥é€šè¿‡äººå·¥æ£€æŸ¥ä»£ç èƒ½ç¡®ä¿ç»ä¸ä¼šå‡ºç° Err å˜ä½“ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè°ƒç”¨ expect å¹¶åœ¨å‚æ•°æ–‡æœ¬ä¸­è¯´æ˜åŸå› å®Œå…¨å¯æ¥å—ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š

fn main() {
    use std::net::IpAddr;

    let home: IpAddr = "127.0.0.1"
        .parse()
        .expect("Hardcoded IP address should be valid");
}

Weâ€™re creating an IpAddr instance by parsing a hardcoded string. We can see that 127.0.0.1 is a valid IP address, so itâ€™s acceptable to use expect here. However, having a hardcoded, valid string doesnâ€™t change the return type of the parse method: we still get a Result value, and the compiler will still make us handle the Result as if the Err variant is a possibility because the compiler isnâ€™t smart enough to see that this string is always a valid IP address. If the IP address string came from a user rather than being hardcoded into the program and therefore did have a possibility of failure, weâ€™d definitely want to handle the Result in a more robust way instead. Mentioning the assumption that this IP address is hardcoded will prompt us to change expect to better error-handling code if, in the future, we need to get the IP address from some other source instead.

è¿™é‡Œé€šè¿‡è§£æç¡¬ç¼–ç å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ›å»º IpAddr å®ä¾‹ã€‚æ˜¾ç„¶ 127.0.0.1 æ˜¯æœ‰æ•ˆ IP åœ°å€ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä½¿ç”¨ expect åˆç†ã€‚ä½†ç¡¬ç¼–ç çš„æœ‰æ•ˆå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸ä¼šæ”¹å˜ parse æ–¹æ³•çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬ä¾ç„¶å¾—åˆ° Result å€¼ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä»ä¼šè¦æ±‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¤„ç†è¯¥ Resultï¼ˆä»¿ä½›å¯èƒ½å‡ºç° Err å˜ä½“ï¼‰ï¼Œå› ä¸ºç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ— æ³•æ™ºèƒ½æ¨æ–­æ­¤å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ°¸è¿œæœ‰æ•ˆã€‚å¦‚æœ IP åœ°å€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ¥è‡ªç”¨æˆ·è¾“å…¥è€Œéç¡¬ç¼–ç ï¼ˆå³ç¡®å®å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¿…ç„¶éœ€è¦ç”¨æ›´å¥å£®çš„æ–¹å¼å¤„ç† Resultã€‚æ­¤å¤„æ³¨æ˜ IP åœ°å€æ˜¯ç¡¬ç¼–ç çš„å‡è®¾ï¼Œèƒ½ä¿ƒä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æœªæ¥éœ€è¦ä»å…¶ä»–æ¥æºè·å– IP æ—¶ï¼Œå°† expect å‡çº§ä¸ºæ›´å¥½çš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ä»£ç ã€‚

Guidelines for Error Handling é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†æŒ‡å¯¼åŸåˆ™

Itâ€™s advisable to have your code panic when itâ€™s possible that your code could end up in a bad state. In this context, a bad state is when some assumption, guarantee, contract, or invariant has been broken, such as when invalid values, contradictory values, or missing values are passed to your codeâ€”plus one or more of the following:

å½“ä»£ç å¯èƒ½é™·å…¥åçŠ¶æ€ï¼ˆbad stateï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œå»ºè®®ç›´æ¥ panicã€‚æ­¤å¤„çš„åçŠ¶æ€æŒ‡æŸäº›å‡è®¾ã€ä¿è¯ã€å¥‘çº¦æˆ–ä¸å˜é‡è¢«ç ´åçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å‘ä»£ç ä¼ å…¥æ— æ•ˆå€¼ã€çŸ›ç›¾å€¼æˆ–ç¼ºå¤±å€¼ï¼Œä¸”æ»¡è¶³ä»¥ä¸‹è‡³å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶ï¼š

  • The bad state is something that is unexpected, as opposed to something that will likely happen occasionally, like a user entering data in the wrong format.
  • è¯¥åçŠ¶æ€æ˜¯æ„å¤–äº‹ä»¶ï¼Œè€Œéå¶å°”ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿçš„æƒ…å†µï¼ˆå¦‚ç”¨æˆ·è¾“å…¥æ ¼å¼é”™è¯¯ï¼‰
  • Your code after this point needs to rely on not being in this bad state, rather than checking for the problem at every step.
  • åç»­ä»£ç éœ€è¦ä¾èµ–ä¸å¤„äºæ­¤åçŠ¶æ€çš„å‰æï¼Œè€Œéæ¯ä¸€æ­¥éƒ½æ£€æŸ¥é—®é¢˜
  • Thereâ€™s not a good way to encode this information in the types you use. Weâ€™ll work through an example of what we mean in â€œEncoding States and Behavior as Typesâ€ in Chapter 18.
  • æ— æ³•é€šè¿‡ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿæœ‰æ•ˆç¼–ç æ­¤ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆç¬¬ 18 ç« â€œå°†çŠ¶æ€å’Œè¡Œä¸ºç¼–ç ä¸ºç±»å‹â€œå°†ä¸¾ä¾‹è¯´æ˜ï¼‰

If someone calls your code and passes in values that donâ€™t make sense, itâ€™s best to return an error if you can so the user of the library can decide what they want to do in that case. However, in cases where continuing could be insecure or harmful, the best choice might be to call panic! and alert the person using your library to the bug in their code so they can fix it during development. Similarly, panic! is often appropriate if youâ€™re calling external code that is out of your control and it returns an invalid state that you have no way of fixing.

è‹¥ç”¨æˆ·è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç æ—¶ä¼ å…¥æ— æ„ä¹‰çš„å€¼ï¼Œæœ€ä½³å®è·µæ˜¯è¿”å›é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆä»¥ä¾¿åº“ä½¿ç”¨è€…å†³å®šå¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ï¼‰ã€‚ä½†å½“ç»§ç»­æ‰§è¡Œå¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´å®‰å…¨éšæ‚£æ—¶ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ panic! å‘Šè­¦å¹¶æç¤ºä½¿ç”¨è€…ä¿®å¤ä»£ç ç¼ºé™·æ›´ä¸ºåˆé€‚ã€‚åŒæ ·ï¼Œå½“è°ƒç”¨ä¸å—æ§çš„å¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç è¿”å›æ— æ•ˆçŠ¶æ€ä¸”æ— æ³•ä¿®å¤æ—¶ï¼Œpanic! ä¹Ÿå¸¸é€‚ç”¨ã€‚

However, when failure is expected, itâ€™s more appropriate to return a Result than to make a panic! call. Examples include a parser being given malformed data or an HTTP request returning a status that indicates you have hit a rate limit. In these cases, returning a Result indicates that failure is an expected possibility that the calling code must decide how to handle.

ä½†é¢„æœŸå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥æ—¶ï¼ˆå¦‚è§£æå™¨æ”¶åˆ°ç•¸å½¢æ•°æ®ã€HTTP è¯·æ±‚è¿”å›é€Ÿç‡é™åˆ¶çŠ¶æ€ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿”å› Result æ¯”è°ƒç”¨ panic! æ›´åˆé€‚ã€‚è¿™è¡¨æ˜å¤±è´¥æ˜¯é¢„æœŸå†…çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§ï¼Œéœ€ç”±è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç å†³å®šå¤„ç†ç­–ç•¥ã€‚

When your code performs an operation that could put a user at risk if itâ€™s called using invalid values, your code should verify the values are valid first and panic if the values arenâ€™t valid. This is mostly for safety reasons: attempting to operate on invalid data can expose your code to vulnerabilities. This is the main reason the standard library will call panic! if you attempt an out-of-bounds memory access: trying to access memory that doesnâ€™t belong to the current data structure is a common security problem. Functions often have contracts: their behavior is only guaranteed if the inputs meet particular requirements. Panicking when the contract is violated makes sense because a contract violation always indicates a caller-side bug, and itâ€™s not a kind of error you want the calling code to have to explicitly handle. In fact, thereâ€™s no reasonable way for calling code to recover; the calling programmers need to fix the code. Contracts for a function, especially when a violation will cause a panic, should be explained in the API documentation for the function.

å½“ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œå¯èƒ½å› æ— æ•ˆå€¼å±åŠç”¨æˆ·å®‰å…¨çš„æ“ä½œæ—¶ï¼Œåº”ä¼˜å…ˆéªŒè¯å€¼æœ‰æ•ˆæ€§å¹¶åœ¨æ— æ•ˆæ—¶ panicã€‚è¿™ä¸»è¦å‡ºäºå®‰å…¨è€ƒé‡ï¼šæ— æ•ˆæ•°æ®æ“ä½œå¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´æ¼æ´ã€‚æ ‡å‡†åº“åœ¨å†…å­˜è¶Šç•Œè®¿é—®æ—¶è°ƒç”¨ panic! æ­£æºäºæ­¤â€”â€”è®¿é—®ä¸å±äºå½“å‰æ•°æ®ç»“æ„çš„å†…å­˜æ˜¯å¸¸è§å®‰å…¨é—®é¢˜ã€‚å‡½æ•°é€šå¸¸å­˜åœ¨å¥‘çº¦ï¼ˆcontractï¼‰ï¼šä»…å½“è¾“å…¥æ»¡è¶³ç‰¹å®šè¦æ±‚æ—¶è¡Œä¸ºæ‰æœ‰ä¿è¯ã€‚è¿åå¥‘çº¦æ—¶ panic æ˜¯åˆç†çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå¥‘çº¦ç ´åæ€»æ˜¯è°ƒç”¨æ–¹ bugï¼Œä¸”ä¸åº”ç”±è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç æ˜¾å¼å¤„ç†ã€‚äº‹å®ä¸Šï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ä»£ç æ— æ³•åˆç†æ¢å¤ï¼›éœ€è¦ç¨‹åºå‘˜ä¿®å¤ä»£ç ã€‚å‡½æ•°çš„å¥‘çº¦ï¼ˆå°¤å…¶æ˜¯è¿åä¼šå¯¼è‡´ panic æ—¶ï¼‰åº”åœ¨ API æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­è¯´æ˜ã€‚

However, having lots of error checks in all of your functions would be verbose and annoying. Fortunately, you can use Rustâ€™s type system (and thus the type checking done by the compiler) to do many of the checks for you. If your function has a particular type as a parameter, you can proceed with your codeâ€™s logic knowing that the compiler has already ensured you have a valid value. For example, if you have a type rather than an Option, your program expects to have something rather than nothing. Your code then doesnâ€™t have to handle two cases for the Some and None variants: it will only have one case for definitely having a value. Code trying to pass nothing to your function wonâ€™t even compile, so your function doesnâ€™t have to check for that case at runtime. Another example is using an unsigned integer type such as u32, which ensures the parameter is never negative.

ç„¶è€Œåœ¨æ‰€æœ‰å‡½æ•°ä¸­å¤§é‡æ£€æŸ¥é”™è¯¯ä¼šå†—é•¿ç¹çã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œå¯åˆ©ç”¨ Rust ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ˆåŠç¼–è¯‘å™¨çš„ç±»å‹æ£€æŸ¥ï¼‰è‡ªåŠ¨å®Œæˆå¤šæ•°æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚è‹¥å‡½æ•°å‚æ•°ä¸ºç‰¹å®šç±»å‹ï¼Œå¯ç¡®ä¿¡ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å·²ç¡®ä¿å€¼æœ‰æ•ˆã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨é Option ç±»å‹æ—¶ï¼Œç¨‹åºé¢„æœŸå¿…æœ‰å€¼è€Œéç©ºå€¼ã€‚ä»£ç æ— éœ€å¤„ç† Some å’Œ None ä¸¤ç§å˜ä½“ï¼Œåªéœ€å¤„ç†ç¡®å®šæœ‰å€¼çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚å°è¯•ä¼ å…¥ç©ºå€¼çš„ä»£ç ç”šè‡³æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œå› æ­¤å‡½æ•°æ— éœ€åœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶æ£€æŸ¥è¯¥æƒ…å†µã€‚å¦ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ u32 ç­‰æ— ç¬¦å·æ•´æ•°ç±»å‹å¯ç¡®ä¿å‚æ•°æ°¸ä¸å°äºé›¶ã€‚

Creating Custom Types for Validation åˆ›å»ºè‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹è¿›è¡ŒéªŒè¯

Letâ€™s take the idea of using Rustâ€™s type system to ensure we have a valid value one step further and look at creating a custom type for validation. Recall the guessing game in Chapter 2 in which our code asked the user to guess a number between 1 and 100. We never validated that the userâ€™s guess was between those numbers before checking it against our secret number; we only validated that the guess was positive. In this case, the consequences were not very dire: our output of â€œToo highâ€ or â€œToo lowâ€ would still be correct. But it would be a useful enhancement to guide the user toward valid guesses and have different behavior when the user guesses a number thatâ€™s out of range versus when the user types, for example, letters instead.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬è¿›ä¸€æ­¥åˆ©ç”¨ Rust ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿç¡®ä¿å€¼æœ‰æ•ˆæ€§ï¼Œæ¢ç´¢å¦‚ä½•åˆ›å»ºéªŒè¯ç”¨çš„è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ã€‚å›é¡¾ç¬¬ 2 ç« çš„çŒœæ•°æ¸¸æˆï¼šä»£ç è¦æ±‚ç”¨æˆ·çŒœæµ‹ 1 åˆ° 100 ä¹‹é—´çš„æ•°å­—ï¼Œä½†åœ¨ä¸ç§˜å¯†æ•°å­—æ¯”è¾ƒå‰ä»æœªéªŒè¯ç”¨æˆ·çŒœæµ‹å€¼æ˜¯å¦åœ¨æ­¤èŒƒå›´å†…ï¼Œä»…éªŒè¯äº†å…¶ä¸ºæ­£æ•°ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶åæœä¸ä¸¥é‡ï¼šâ€œè¿‡é«˜/è¿‡ä½â€œçš„åé¦ˆä»æ­£ç¡®ã€‚ä½†å¼•å¯¼ç”¨æˆ·æœ‰æ•ˆçŒœæµ‹ï¼Œå¹¶å¯¹è¶Šç•Œè¾“å…¥ä¸å­—æ¯è¾“å…¥ç­‰è¡Œä¸ºåŒºåˆ«å¤„ç†ï¼Œä¼šæ˜¯å®ç”¨å¢å¼ºã€‚

One way to do this would be to parse the guess as an i32 instead of only a u32 to allow potentially negative numbers, and then add a check for the number being in range, like so:

ä¸€ç§å®ç°æ–¹å¼æ˜¯å°†çŒœæµ‹å€¼è§£æä¸º i32ï¼ˆè€Œéä»… u32ï¼‰ä»¥å…è®¸è´Ÿæ•°ï¼Œç„¶åæ£€æŸ¥èŒƒå›´ï¼š

The if expression checks whether our value is out of range, tells the user about the problem, and calls continue to start the next iteration of the loop and ask for another guess. After the if expression, we can proceed with the comparisons between guess and the secret number knowing that guess is between 1 and 100.

if è¡¨è¾¾å¼æ£€æŸ¥å€¼æ˜¯å¦è¶Šç•Œï¼Œå‘ç”¨æˆ·åé¦ˆé—®é¢˜å¹¶è°ƒç”¨ continue é‡å¯å¾ªç¯ç­‰å¾…æ–°è¾“å…¥ã€‚æ­¤åè¿›è¡ŒçŒœæµ‹å€¼ä¸ç§˜å¯†æ•°å­—æ¯”è¾ƒæ—¶ï¼Œå¯ç¡®ä¿¡ guess å¿…åœ¨ 1 åˆ° 100 ä¹‹é—´ã€‚

However, this is not an ideal solution: if it were absolutely critical that the program only operated on values between 1 and 100, and it had many functions with this requirement, having a check like this in every function would be tedious (and might impact performance).

ä½†è¿™ä¸æ˜¯ç†æƒ³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼šè‹¥ç¨‹åºå¿…é¡»ä¸¥æ ¼æ“ä½œ 1 åˆ° 100 çš„å€¼ï¼Œä¸”å¤šä¸ªå‡½æ•°æœ‰æ­¤è¦æ±‚ï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå‡½æ•°é‡å¤æ­¤æ£€æŸ¥å°†å†—é•¿ä¹å‘³ï¼ˆå¹¶å¯èƒ½å½±å“æ€§èƒ½ï¼‰ã€‚

Instead, we can make a new type in a dedicated module and put the validations in a function to create an instance of the type rather than repeating the validations everywhere. That way, itâ€™s safe for functions to use the new type in their signatures and confidently use the values they receive. Listing 9-13 shows one way to define a Guess type that will only create an instance of Guess if the new function receives a value between 1 and 100.

æ›¿ä»£æ–¹æ¡ˆæ˜¯åœ¨ä¸“ç”¨æ¨¡å—ä¸­åˆ›å»ºæ–°ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¹¶å°†éªŒè¯é€»è¾‘æ”¾åœ¨åˆ›å»ºç±»å‹å®ä¾‹çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­ï¼ˆè€Œéåˆ°å¤„é‡å¤ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ ·å‡½æ•°å¯å®‰å…¨åœ°åœ¨ç­¾åä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æ–°ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¹¶æ”¾å¿ƒä½¿ç”¨æ¥æ”¶åˆ°çš„å€¼ã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 9-13 å±•ç¤ºäº†å®šä¹‰ Guess ç±»å‹çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼šä»…å½“ new å‡½æ•°æ”¶åˆ° 1 åˆ° 100 çš„å€¼æ—¶æ‰åˆ›å»ºå®ä¾‹ã€‚

Note that this code in src/guessing_game.rs depends on adding a module declaration mod guessing_game; in src/lib.rs that we havenâ€™t shown here. Within this new moduleâ€™s file, we define a struct in that module named Guess that has a field named value that holds an i32. This is where the number will be stored.

æ³¨æ„ src/guessing_game.rs ä¸­çš„ä»£ç ä¾èµ–äºåœ¨ src/lib.rs ä¸­æ·»åŠ æœªå±•ç¤ºçš„æ¨¡å—å£°æ˜ mod guessing_game;ã€‚åœ¨æ­¤æ–°æ¨¡å—æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰åŒ…å« i32 ç±»å‹å­—æ®µ value çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ Guessï¼ˆè¯¥å­—æ®µå­˜å‚¨æ•°å€¼ï¼‰ã€‚

Then we implement an associated function named new on Guess that creates instances of Guess values. The new function is defined to have one parameter named value of type i32 and to return a Guess. The code in the body of the new function tests value to make sure itâ€™s between 1 and 100. If value doesnâ€™t pass this test, we make a panic! call, which will alert the programmer who is writing the calling code that they have a bug they need to fix, because creating a Guess with a value outside this range would violate the contract that Guess::new is relying on. The conditions in which Guess::new might panic should be discussed in its public-facing API documentation; weâ€™ll cover documentation conventions indicating the possibility of a panic! in the API documentation that you create in Chapter 14. If value does pass the test, we create a new Guess with its value field set to the value parameter and return the Guess.

éšåä¸º Guess å®ç°å…³è”å‡½æ•° new æ¥åˆ›å»ºå®ä¾‹ã€‚new å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ä¸ºï¼šæ¥æ”¶ i32 ç±»å‹å‚æ•° valueï¼Œè¿”å› Guessã€‚å‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­çš„ä»£ç ä¼šæ£€éªŒ value æ˜¯å¦åœ¨ 1 åˆ° 100 ä¹‹é—´ã€‚è‹¥æœªé€šè¿‡æ£€éªŒï¼Œåˆ™è°ƒç”¨ panic! æé†’è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç çš„å¼€å‘è€…ä¿®å¤ bugâ€”â€”å› ä¸ºåœ¨æ­¤èŒƒå›´å¤–åˆ›å»º Guess å°†è¿å Guess::new ä¾èµ–çš„å¥‘çº¦ã€‚Guess::new [note]å¯èƒ½ panic çš„æ¡ä»¶åº”åœ¨å…¶å…¬å¼€ API æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­è¯´æ˜ï¼›ç¬¬ 14 ç« å°†ä»‹ç»å¦‚ä½•åœ¨ API æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­æ ‡æ³¨ panic! å¯èƒ½æ€§ã€‚è‹¥é€šè¿‡æ£€éªŒï¼Œåˆ™ç”¨ value å‚æ•°åˆ›å»ºæ–° Guess å¹¶è¿”å›ã€‚

Next, we implement a method named value that borrows self, doesnâ€™t have any other parameters, and returns an i32. This kind of method is sometimes called a getter because its purpose is to get some data from its fields and return it. This public method is necessary because the value field of the Guess struct is private. Itâ€™s important that the value field be private so code using the Guess struct is not allowed to set value directly: code outside the guessing_game module must use the Guess::new function to create an instance of Guess, thereby ensuring thereâ€™s no way for a Guess to have a value that hasnâ€™t been checked by the conditions in the Guess::new function.

æ¥ç€å®ç°æ–¹æ³• valueï¼šå€Ÿç”¨ selfï¼Œæ— å…¶ä»–å‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿”å› i32ã€‚æ­¤ç±»æ–¹æ³•ç§°ä¸ºè·å–å™¨ï¼ˆgetterï¼‰ï¼Œå› å…¶ç”¨äºä»å­—æ®µæå–æ•°æ®ã€‚ç”±äº Guess ç»“æ„ä½“çš„ value å­—æ®µæ˜¯ç§æœ‰çš„ï¼Œæ­¤å…¬å¼€æ–¹æ³•å¾ˆæœ‰å¿…è¦ã€‚value çš„ç§æœ‰æ€§ç¡®ä¿äº†å¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç æ— æ³•ç›´æ¥è®¾ç½®è¯¥å€¼ï¼šguessing_game æ¨¡å—å¤–çš„ä»£ç å¿…é¡»é€šè¿‡ Guess::new åˆ›å»ºå®ä¾‹ï¼Œä»è€Œä¿è¯ Guess çš„å€¼å¿…å·²é€šè¿‡ Guess::new çš„æ¡ä»¶æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚

A function that has a parameter or returns only numbers between 1 and 100 could then declare in its signature that it takes or returns a Guess rather than an i32 and wouldnâ€™t need to do any additional checks in its body.

æ¥æ”¶æˆ–è¿”å› 1 åˆ° 100 æ•°å­—çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¯åœ¨ç­¾åä¸­å£°æ˜ä½¿ç”¨ Guess ç±»å‹ï¼ˆè€Œé i32ï¼‰ï¼Œæ— éœ€åœ¨å‡½æ•°ä½“å†…é¢å¤–æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

Rustâ€™s error-handling features are designed to help you write more robust code. The panic! macro signals that your program is in a state it canâ€™t handle and lets you tell the process to stop instead of trying to proceed with invalid or incorrect values. The Result enum uses Rustâ€™s type system to indicate that operations might fail in a way that your code could recover from. You can use Result to tell code that calls your code that it needs to handle potential success or failure as well. Using panic! and Result in the appropriate situations will make your code more reliable in the face of inevitable problems.

Rust çš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†åŠŸèƒ½æ—¨åœ¨åŠ©ä½ ç¼–å†™æ›´å¥å£®çš„ä»£ç ã€‚panic! å®è¡¨ç¤ºç¨‹åºé‡åˆ°æ— æ³•å¤„ç†çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œè®©è¿›ç¨‹åœæ­¢è€Œéç”¨æ— æ•ˆå€¼ç»§ç»­æ‰§è¡Œã€‚Result æšä¸¾åˆ™åˆ©ç”¨ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿè¡¨æ˜æ“ä½œå¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼ˆä½†ä»£ç å¯æ¢å¤ï¼‰ã€‚é€šè¿‡ Result å¯å‘ŠçŸ¥è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç éœ€å¤„ç†æ½œåœ¨çš„æˆåŠŸæˆ–å¤±è´¥ã€‚åœ¨é€‚å½“åœºæ™¯ä½¿ç”¨ panic! å’Œ Result èƒ½ä½¿ä»£ç åœ¨é¢ä¸´é—®é¢˜æ—¶æ›´å¯é ã€‚

Now that youâ€™ve seen useful ways that the standard library uses generics with the Option and Result enums, weâ€™ll talk about how generics work and how you can use them in your code.

æ—¢ç„¶ä½ å·²è§è¯†æ ‡å‡†åº“å¦‚ä½•é«˜æ•ˆåˆ©ç”¨æ³›å‹ï¼ˆé€šè¿‡ Option å’Œ Result æšä¸¾ï¼‰ï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢è®¨æ³›å‹çš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†åŠå¦‚ä½•åœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨å®ƒä»¬ã€‚

Generic Types, Traits, and Lifetimes æ³›å‹ã€ç‰¹è´¨ä¸ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸ

Every programming language has tools for effectively handling the duplication of concepts. In Rust, one such tool is generics: abstract stand-ins for concrete types or other properties. We can express the behavior of generics or how they relate to other generics without knowing what will be in their place when compiling and running the code.

æ¯ç§ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€éƒ½æœ‰é«˜æ•ˆå¤„ç†æ¦‚å¿µé‡å¤çš„å·¥å…·ã€‚åœ¨ Rust ä¸­ï¼Œè¿™ç±»å·¥å…·ä¹‹ä¸€å°±æ˜¯æ³›å‹ï¼ˆgenericsï¼‰ï¼šå…·ä½“ç±»å‹æˆ–å…¶ä»–å±æ€§çš„æŠ½è±¡å ä½ç¬¦ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨ç¼–è¯‘å’Œè¿è¡Œä»£ç æ—¶æ— éœ€çŸ¥æ™“å®é™…ç±»å‹çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œè¡¨è¾¾æ³›å‹çš„è¡Œä¸ºæˆ–å®ƒä»¬ä¸å…¶ä»–æ³›å‹çš„å…³ç³»ã€‚

Functions can take parameters of some generic type, instead of a concrete type like i32 or String, in the same way they take parameters with unknown values to run the same code on multiple concrete values. In fact, weâ€™ve already used generics in Chapter 6 with Option<T>, in Chapter 8 with Vec<T> and HashMap<K, V>, and in Chapter 9 with Result<T, E>. In this chapter, youâ€™ll explore how to define your own types, functions, and methods with generics!

å‡½æ•°å¯ä»¥æ¥æ”¶æ³›å‹ç±»å‹çš„å‚æ•°ï¼ˆè€Œéåƒ i32 æˆ– String è¿™æ ·çš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ï¼‰ï¼Œå°±åƒå‡½æ•°æ¥æ”¶æœªçŸ¥å€¼çš„å‚æ•°ä»¥ä¾¿åœ¨å¤šä¸ªå…·ä½“å€¼ä¸Šè¿è¡Œç›¸åŒä»£ç é‚£æ ·ã€‚å®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 6 ç« çš„ Option<T>ã€ç¬¬ 8 ç« çš„ Vec<T> å’Œ HashMap<K, V>ï¼Œä»¥åŠç¬¬ 9 ç« çš„ Result<T, E> ä¸­å·²ç»ä½¿ç”¨è¿‡æ³›å‹ã€‚æœ¬ç« å°†æ¢ç´¢å¦‚ä½•ç”¨æ³›å‹å®šä¹‰ä½ è‡ªå·±çš„ç±»å‹ã€å‡½æ•°å’Œæ–¹æ³•ï¼

First weâ€™ll review how to extract a function to reduce code duplication. Weâ€™ll then use the same technique to make a generic function from two functions that differ only in the types of their parameters. Weâ€™ll also explain how to use generic types in struct and enum definitions.

é¦–å…ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°†å›é¡¾å¦‚ä½•æå–å‡½æ•°ä»¥å‡å°‘ä»£ç é‡å¤ã€‚æ¥ç€ç”¨ç›¸åŒæŠ€æœ¯ï¼Œä»ä¸¤ä¸ªä»…åœ¨å‚æ•°ç±»å‹ä¸Šä¸åŒçš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­åˆ›å»ºæ³›å‹å‡½æ•°ã€‚è¿˜ä¼šè§£é‡Šå¦‚ä½•åœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“å’Œæšä¸¾å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ã€‚

Then youâ€™ll learn how to use traits to define behavior in a generic way. You can combine traits with generic types to constrain a generic type to accept only those types that have a particular behavior, as opposed to just any type.

ç„¶åä½ å°†å­¦ä¹ ä½¿ç”¨ç‰¹è´¨ï¼ˆtraitsï¼‰ä»¥æ³›å‹æ–¹å¼å®šä¹‰è¡Œä¸ºã€‚å¯ä»¥å°†ç‰¹è´¨ä¸æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ç»“åˆï¼Œçº¦æŸæ³›å‹ç±»å‹åªæ¥å—å…·æœ‰ç‰¹å®šè¡Œä¸ºçš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œè€Œéä»»æ„ç±»å‹ã€‚

Finally, weâ€™ll discuss lifetimes: a variety of generics that give the compiler information about how references relate to each other. Lifetimes allow us to give the compiler enough information about borrowed values so that it can ensure references will be valid in more situations than it could without our help.

æœ€åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†è®¨è®ºç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸï¼ˆlifetimesï¼‰ï¼šä¸€ç§å‘ç¼–è¯‘å™¨æä¾›å¼•ç”¨é—´å…³ç³»ä¿¡æ¯çš„æ³›å‹ã€‚ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ºå€Ÿç”¨å€¼æä¾›è¶³å¤Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œä½¿ç¼–è¯‘å™¨èƒ½åœ¨æ›´å¤šåœºæ™¯ä¸­ç¡®ä¿å¼•ç”¨æœ‰æ•ˆæ€§ã€‚

Removing Duplication by Extracting a Function é€šè¿‡æå–å‡½æ•°æ¶ˆé™¤é‡å¤

Generics allow us to replace specific types with a placeholder that represents multiple types to remove code duplication. Before diving into generics syntax, letâ€™s first look at how to remove duplication in a way that doesnâ€™t involve generic types by extracting a function that replaces specific values with a placeholder that represents multiple values. Then weâ€™ll apply the same technique to extract a generic function! By looking at how to recognize duplicated code you can extract into a function, youâ€™ll start to recognize duplicated code that can use generics.

æ³›å‹å…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ä»£è¡¨å¤šç§ç±»å‹çš„å ä½ç¬¦æ›¿æ¢ç‰¹å®šç±»å‹ï¼Œä»è€Œæ¶ˆé™¤ä»£ç é‡å¤ã€‚åœ¨æ·±å…¥æ³›å‹è¯­æ³•ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå…ˆçœ‹å¦‚ä½•é€šè¿‡æå–å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆå°†ç‰¹å®šå€¼æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºä»£è¡¨å¤šä¸ªå€¼çš„å ä½ç¬¦ï¼‰æ¥æ¶ˆé™¤é‡å¤ã€‚ç„¶åå°†åº”ç”¨ç›¸åŒæŠ€æœ¯æå–æ³›å‹å‡½æ•°ï¼é€šè¿‡è¯†åˆ«å¯æå–åˆ°å‡½æ•°ä¸­çš„é‡å¤ä»£ç ï¼Œä½ ä¼šå¼€å§‹è¯†åˆ«å¯ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹çš„é‡å¤ä»£ç ã€‚

Weâ€™ll begin with the short program in Listing 10-1 that finds the largest number in a list.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-1 çš„ç®€çŸ­ç¨‹åºå¼€å§‹ï¼Œå®ƒæŸ¥æ‰¾åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­çš„æœ€å¤§æ•°ã€‚

We store a list of integers in the variable number_list and place a reference to the first number in the list in a variable named largest. We then iterate through all the numbers in the list, and if the current number is greater than the number stored in largest, we replace the reference in that variable. However, if the current number is less than or equal to the largest number seen so far, the variable doesnâ€™t change, and the code moves on to the next number in the list. After considering all the numbers in the list, largest should refer to the largest number, which in this case is 100.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ•´æ•°åˆ—è¡¨å­˜å…¥å˜é‡ number_listï¼Œå¹¶å°†åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—çš„å¼•ç”¨å­˜å…¥å˜é‡ largestã€‚ç„¶åéå†åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰æ•°å­—ï¼Œè‹¥å½“å‰æ•°å­—å¤§äº largest ä¸­çš„å€¼ï¼Œåˆ™æ›¿æ¢è¯¥å˜é‡çš„å¼•ç”¨ã€‚è‹¥å½“å‰æ•°å­—å°äºæˆ–ç­‰äºå·²è§æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Œå˜é‡ä¿æŒä¸å˜ï¼Œä»£ç ç»§ç»­å¤„ç†ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—ã€‚å¤„ç†å®Œæ‰€æœ‰æ•°å­—åï¼Œlargest åº”æŒ‡å‘æœ€å¤§æ•°ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸º 100ï¼‰ã€‚

Weâ€™ve now been tasked with finding the largest number in two different lists of numbers. To do so, we can choose to duplicate the code in Listing 10-1 and use the same logic at two different places in the program, as shown in Listing 10-2.

ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒæ•°å­—åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤å¯é€‰æ‹©å¤åˆ¶ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-1 çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œåœ¨ç¨‹åºä¸­ä¸¤å¤„ä¸åŒä½ç½®ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒé€»è¾‘ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-2 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Although this code works, duplicating code is tedious and error prone. We also have to remember to update the code in multiple places when we want to change it.

è™½ç„¶ä»£ç å¯ç”¨ï¼Œä½†å¤åˆ¶ä»£ç å†—é•¿ä¸”æ˜“é”™ã€‚ä¿®æ”¹æ—¶è¿˜éœ€è®°ä½æ›´æ–°å¤šå¤„ä»£ç ã€‚

To eliminate this duplication, weâ€™ll create an abstraction by defining a function that operates on any list of integers passed in as a parameter. This solution makes our code clearer and lets us express the concept of finding the largest number in a list abstractly.

ä¸ºæ¶ˆé™¤é‡å¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡å®šä¹‰å‡½æ•°æ¥åˆ›å»ºæŠ½è±¡ï¼Œè¯¥å‡½æ•°æ“ä½œä¼ å…¥çš„ä»»æ„æ•´æ•°åˆ—è¡¨å‚æ•°ã€‚æ­¤æ–¹æ¡ˆä½¿ä»£ç æ›´æ¸…æ™°ï¼Œå¹¶æŠ½è±¡è¡¨è¾¾äº†â€œåœ¨åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼â€œçš„æ¦‚å¿µã€‚

In Listing 10-3, we extract the code that finds the largest number into a function named largest. Then we call the function to find the largest number in the two lists from Listing 10-2. We could also use the function on any other list of i32 values we might have in the future.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-3 ä¸­ï¼Œå°†æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼çš„ä»£ç æå–åˆ°åä¸º largest çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­ã€‚ç„¶åç”¨è¯¥å‡½æ•°å¤„ç†ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-2 çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ—è¡¨ã€‚æœªæ¥ä¹Ÿå¯å°†æ­¤å‡½æ•°ç”¨äºä»»ä½•å…¶ä»– i32 å€¼åˆ—è¡¨ã€‚

The largest function has a parameter called list, which represents any concrete slice of i32 values we might pass into the function. As a result, when we call the function, the code runs on the specific values that we pass in.

largest å‡½æ•°æœ‰ä¸ª list å‚æ•°ï¼Œä»£è¡¨å¯èƒ½ä¼ å…¥çš„ä»»æ„å…·ä½“ i32 åˆ‡ç‰‡ã€‚å› æ­¤è°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œä»£ç ä¼šé’ˆå¯¹ä¼ å…¥çš„å…·ä½“å€¼è¿è¡Œã€‚

In summary, here are the steps we took to change the code from Listing 10-2 to Listing 10-3:

æ€»ç»“ä»ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-2 æ”¹ä¸º 10-3 çš„æ­¥éª¤ï¼š

  • Identify duplicate code.
  • è¯†åˆ«é‡å¤ä»£ç 
  • Extract the duplicate code into the body of the function, and specify the inputs and return values of that code in the function signature.
  • å°†é‡å¤ä»£ç æå–åˆ°å‡½æ•°ä½“ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨å‡½æ•°ç­¾åä¸­æŒ‡å®šè¾“å…¥è¾“å‡º
  • Update the two instances of duplicated code to call the function instead.
  • æ›´æ–°é‡å¤ä»£ç å¤„æ”¹ä¸ºè°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•°

Next, weâ€™ll use these same steps with generics to reduce code duplication. In the same way that the function body can operate on an abstract list instead of specific values, generics allow code to operate on abstract types.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç”¨æ³›å‹é€šè¿‡ç›¸åŒæ­¥éª¤å‡å°‘ä»£ç é‡å¤ã€‚å¦‚åŒå‡½æ•°ä½“èƒ½æ“ä½œæŠ½è±¡ list è€Œéå…·ä½“å€¼ï¼Œæ³›å‹å…è®¸ä»£ç æ“ä½œæŠ½è±¡ç±»å‹ã€‚

For example, say we had two functions: one that finds the largest item in a slice of i32 values and one that finds the largest item in a slice of char values. How would we eliminate that duplication? Letâ€™s find out!

ä¾‹å¦‚æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼šä¸€ä¸ªåœ¨ i32 åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªåœ¨ char åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼ã€‚å¦‚ä½•æ¶ˆé™¤é‡å¤ï¼Ÿè®©æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€æ¢ç©¶ç«Ÿï¼

Generic Data Types æ³›å‹æ•°æ®ç±»å‹

We use generics to create definitions for items like function signatures or structs, which we can then use with many different concrete data types. Letâ€™s first look at how to define functions, structs, enums, and methods using generics. Then weâ€™ll discuss how generics affect code performance.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ä¸ºå‡½æ•°ç­¾åæˆ–ç»“æ„ä½“ç­‰é¡¹åˆ›å»ºå®šä¹‰ï¼Œéšåå¯æ­é…å¤šç§å…·ä½“æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚å…ˆçœ‹å¦‚ä½•ç”¨æ³›å‹å®šä¹‰å‡½æ•°ã€ç»“æ„ä½“ã€æšä¸¾å’Œæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå†è®¨è®ºæ³›å‹å¯¹ä»£ç æ€§èƒ½çš„å½±å“ã€‚

In Function Definitions å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ³›å‹

When defining a function that uses generics, we place the generics in the signature of the function where we would usually specify the data types of the parameters and return value. Doing so makes our code more flexible and provides more functionality to callers of our function while preventing code duplication.

å®šä¹‰ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹çš„å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œå°†æ³›å‹æ”¾åœ¨å‡½æ•°ç­¾åä¸­é€šå¸¸æŒ‡å®šå‚æ•°å’Œè¿”å›å€¼ç±»å‹çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚è¿™æ ·ä½¿ä»£ç æ›´çµæ´»ï¼Œä¸ºè°ƒç”¨è€…æä¾›æ›´å¤šåŠŸèƒ½ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶é¿å…ä»£ç é‡å¤ã€‚

Continuing with our largest function, Listing 10-4 shows two functions that both find the largest value in a slice. Weâ€™ll then combine these into a single function that uses generics.

å»¶ç»­ largest å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç¤ºä¾‹ 10-4 å±•ç¤ºä¸¤ä¸ªåœ¨åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€å¤§å€¼çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚éšåå°†å®ƒä»¬åˆå¹¶ä¸ºä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹çš„å•ä¸€å‡½æ•°ã€‚

The largest_i32 function is the one we extracted in Listing 10-3 that finds the largest i32 in a slice. The largest_char function finds the largest char in a slice. The function bodies have the same code, so letâ€™s eliminate the duplication by introducing a generic type parameter in a single function.

largest_i32 æ˜¯ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-3 æå–çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç”¨äºæŸ¥æ‰¾åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸­çš„æœ€å¤§ i32ã€‚largest_char å‡½æ•°æŸ¥æ‰¾åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸­çš„æœ€å¤§ charã€‚ç”±äºå‡½æ•°ä½“ç›¸åŒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¼•å…¥æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°æ¥æ¶ˆé™¤é‡å¤ã€‚

To parameterize the types in a new single function, we need to name the type parameter, just as we do for the value parameters to a function. You can use any identifier as a type parameter name. But weâ€™ll use T because, by convention, type parameter names in Rust are short, often just one letter, and Rustâ€™s type-naming convention is CamelCase. Short for type, T is the default choice of most Rust programmers.

è¦åœ¨æ–°å‡½æ•°ä¸­å‚æ•°åŒ–ç±»å‹ï¼Œéœ€å‘½åç±»å‹å‚æ•°ï¼ˆå¦‚åŒå‡½æ•°å€¼å‚æ•°çš„å‘½åï¼‰ã€‚å¯ç”¨ä»»æ„æ ‡è¯†ç¬¦ä½œä¸ºç±»å‹å‚æ•°åï¼Œä½†æŒ‰ Rust æƒ¯ä¾‹ï¼ˆé©¼å³°å‘½åæ³•ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ Tï¼ˆâ€œtypeâ€œçš„ç¼©å†™ï¼‰ã€‚T æ˜¯å¤šæ•° Rust ç¨‹åºå‘˜çš„é¦–é€‰ã€‚

When we use a parameter in the body of the function, we have to declare the parameter name in the signature so the compiler knows what that name means. Similarly, when we use a type parameter name in a function signature, we have to declare the type parameter name before we use it. To define the generic largest function, we place type name declarations inside angle brackets, <>, between the name of the function and the parameter list, like this:

åœ¨å‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨å‚æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œéœ€åœ¨ç­¾åä¸­å£°æ˜å‚æ•°åä»¥ä¾¿ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç†è§£å«ä¹‰ã€‚ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œåœ¨å‡½æ•°ç­¾åä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ç±»å‹å‚æ•°åå‰éœ€å…ˆå£°æ˜ã€‚å®šä¹‰æ³›å‹ largest å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œå°†ç±»å‹å£°æ˜æ”¾åœ¨å‡½æ•°åä¸å‚æ•°åˆ—è¡¨é—´çš„å°–æ‹¬å· <> ä¸­ï¼š

fn largest<T>(list: &[T]) -> &T {

We read this definition as: the function largest is generic over some type T. This function has one parameter named list, which is a slice of values of type T. The largest function will return a reference to a value of the same type T.

æ­¤å®šä¹‰è¯»ä½œï¼šå‡½æ•° largest é’ˆå¯¹ç±»å‹ T æ˜¯æ³›å‹çš„ã€‚å®ƒæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª list å‚æ•°ï¼ˆç±»å‹ä¸º T çš„åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿”å›åŒç±»å‹ T å€¼çš„å¼•ç”¨ã€‚

Listing 10-5 shows the combined largest function definition using the generic data type in its signature. The listing also shows how we can call the function with either a slice of i32 values or char values. Note that this code wonâ€™t compile yet.

ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-5 å±•ç¤ºäº†åœ¨ç­¾åä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹æ•°æ®ç±»å‹çš„åˆå¹¶ largest å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ï¼Œä»¥åŠç”¨ i32 åˆ‡ç‰‡æˆ– char åˆ‡ç‰‡è°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•°çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚æ³¨æ„ï¼šæ­¤ä»£ç æš‚ä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

If we compile this code right now, weâ€™ll get this error:

è‹¥ç°åœ¨ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œå°†å‡ºç°é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0369]: binary operation `>` cannot be applied to type `&T`
 --> src/main.rs:5:17
  |
5 |         if item > largest {
  |            ---- ^ ------- &T
  |            |
  |            &T
  |
help: consider restricting type parameter `T` with trait `PartialOrd`
  |
1 | fn largest<T: std::cmp::PartialOrd>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
  |             ++++++++++++++++++++++

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0369`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` (bin "chapter10") due to 1 previous error

The help text mentions std::cmp::PartialOrd, which is a trait, and weâ€™re going to talk about traits in the next section. For now, know that this error states that the body of largest wonâ€™t work for all possible types that T could be. Because we want to compare values of type T in the body, we can only use types whose values can be ordered. To enable comparisons, the standard library has the std::cmp::PartialOrd trait that you can implement on types (see Appendix C for more on this trait). To fix Listing 10-5, we can follow the help textâ€™s suggestion and restrict the types valid for T to only those that implement PartialOrd. The listing will then compile, because the standard library implements PartialOrd on both i32 and char.

å¸®åŠ©æ–‡æœ¬æåˆ° std::cmp::PartialOrdï¼ˆä¸€ç§ç‰¹è´¨ï¼‰ï¼Œä¸‹èŠ‚å°†è®¨è®ºç‰¹è´¨ã€‚ç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥é“ï¼šè¯¥é”™è¯¯è¡¨æ˜ largest å‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸èƒ½é€‚ç”¨äº T çš„æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½ç±»å‹ã€‚å› ä¸ºéœ€åœ¨å‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­æ¯”è¾ƒ T ç±»å‹å€¼ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªèƒ½ä½¿ç”¨å¯æ’åºçš„ç±»å‹ã€‚ä¸ºå®ç°æ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œæ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›äº†å¯é’ˆå¯¹ç±»å‹å®ç°çš„ std::cmp::PartialOrd ç‰¹è´¨ï¼ˆé™„å½• C æœ‰è¯¦ç»†ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰ã€‚ä¿®å¤ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-5 çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯éµå¾ªå¸®åŠ©æ–‡æœ¬å»ºè®®ï¼Œé™åˆ¶ T ä¸ºå®ç°äº† PartialOrd çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆæ ‡å‡†åº“å·²ä¸º i32 å’Œ char å®ç°è¯¥ç‰¹è´¨ï¼‰ã€‚

In Struct Definitions ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ³›å‹

We can also define structs to use a generic type parameter in one or more fields using the <> syntax. Listing 10-6 defines a Point<T> struct to hold x and y coordinate values of any type.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨ <> è¯­æ³•å®šä¹‰ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œä½¿å…¶ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªå­—æ®µä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-6 å®šä¹‰äº† Point<T> ç»“æ„ä½“æ¥ä¿å­˜ä»»æ„ç±»å‹çš„ x å’Œ y åæ ‡å€¼ã€‚

The syntax for using generics in struct definitions is similar to that used in function definitions. First we declare the name of the type parameter inside angle brackets just after the name of the struct. Then we use the generic type in the struct definition where we would otherwise specify concrete data types.

ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹çš„è¯­æ³•ç±»ä¼¼äºå‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ã€‚é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“ååçš„å°–æ‹¬å·å†…å£°æ˜ç±»å‹å‚æ•°åï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ï¼ˆæ›¿ä»£å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ï¼‰ã€‚

Note that because weâ€™ve used only one generic type to define Point<T>, this definition says that the Point<T> struct is generic over some type T, and the fields x and y are both that same type, whatever that type may be. If we create an instance of a Point<T> that has values of different types, as in Listing 10-7, our code wonâ€™t compile.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå›  Point<T> åªä½¿ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ³›å‹ç±»å‹å®šä¹‰ï¼Œè¯¥å®šä¹‰è¡¨ç¤º Point<T> ç»“æ„ä½“é’ˆå¯¹ç±»å‹ T æ˜¯æ³›å‹çš„ï¼Œä¸”å­—æ®µ x å’Œ y å‡ä¸ºåŒä¸€ç±»å‹ï¼ˆæ— è®ºå…·ä½“ç±»å‹æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥åˆ›å»ºåŒ…å«ä¸åŒç±»å‹å€¼çš„ Point<T> å®ä¾‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-7ï¼‰ï¼Œä»£ç å°†æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

In this example, when we assign the integer value 5 to x, we let the compiler know that the generic type T will be an integer for this instance of Point<T>. Then when we specify 4.0 for y, which weâ€™ve defined to have the same type as x, weâ€™ll get a type mismatch error like this:

æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œå°†æ•´æ•°å€¼ 5 èµ‹ç»™ x æ—¶ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨å·²çŸ¥è¯¥ Point<T> å®ä¾‹çš„æ³›å‹ T ä¸ºæ•´æ•°ç±»å‹ã€‚æ¥ç€ä¸º y æŒ‡å®š 4.0ï¼ˆå®šä¹‰ä¸­è¦æ±‚ä¸ x åŒç±»å‹ï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œä¼šå‡ºç°ç±»å‹ä¸åŒ¹é…é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:7:38
  |
7 |     let wont_work = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
  |                                      ^^^ expected integer, found floating-point number

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` (bin "chapter10") due to 1 previous error

To define a Point struct where x and y are both generics but could have different types, we can use multiple generic type parameters. For example, in Listing 10-8, we change the definition of Point to be generic over types T and U where x is of type T and y is of type U.

è¦å®šä¹‰ x å’Œ y å‡ä¸ºæ³›å‹ä½†ç±»å‹å¯ä¸åŒçš„ Point ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œå¯ä½¿ç”¨å¤šä¸ªæ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-8 ä¸­ï¼Œå°† Point å®šä¹‰ä¸ºé’ˆå¯¹ç±»å‹ T å’Œ U çš„æ³›å‹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ x ä¸º T ç±»å‹ï¼Œy ä¸º U ç±»å‹ã€‚

Now all the instances of Point shown are allowed! You can use as many generic type parameters in a definition as you want, but using more than a few makes your code hard to read. If youâ€™re finding you need lots of generic types in your code, it could indicate that your code needs restructuring into smaller pieces.

ç°åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ Point å®ä¾‹å‡æœ‰æ•ˆï¼å®šä¹‰ä¸­å¯ä½¿ç”¨ä»»æ„æ•°é‡çš„æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ï¼Œä½†è¿‡å¤šä¼šä½¿ä»£ç éš¾ä»¥é˜…è¯»ã€‚è‹¥éœ€å¤§é‡æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ„å‘³ç€éœ€è¦é‡æ„ä»£ç ä¸ºæ›´å°çš„æ¨¡å—ã€‚

In Enum Definitions æšä¸¾å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ³›å‹

As we did with structs, we can define enums to hold generic data types in their variants. Letâ€™s take another look at the Option<T> enum that the standard library provides, which we used in Chapter 6:

å¦‚åŒç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯å®šä¹‰æšä¸¾ä½¿å…¶å˜ä½“æŒæœ‰æ³›å‹æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ã€‚å†çœ‹æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ Option<T> æšä¸¾ï¼ˆç¬¬ 6 ç« ç”¨è¿‡ï¼‰ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Option<T> {
    Some(T),
    None,
}
}

This definition should now make more sense to you. As you can see, the Option<T> enum is generic over type T and has two variants: Some, which holds one value of type T, and a None variant that doesnâ€™t hold any value. By using the Option<T> enum, we can express the abstract concept of an optional value, and because Option<T> is generic, we can use this abstraction no matter what the type of the optional value is.

ç°åœ¨ä½ åº”æ›´ç†è§£æ­¤å®šä¹‰äº†ã€‚å¦‚ä½ æ‰€è§ï¼ŒOption<T> æšä¸¾é’ˆå¯¹ç±»å‹ T æ˜¯æ³›å‹çš„ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜ä½“ï¼šSomeï¼ˆæŒæœ‰ç±»å‹ T çš„å€¼ï¼‰å’Œ Noneï¼ˆä¸æŒæœ‰å€¼ï¼‰ã€‚é€šè¿‡ Option<T> æšä¸¾ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½è¡¨è¾¾å¯é€‰å€¼çš„æŠ½è±¡æ¦‚å¿µã€‚ç”±äº Option<T> æ˜¯æ³›å‹çš„ï¼Œæ— è®ºå¯é€‰å€¼æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆç±»å‹éƒ½å¯ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤æŠ½è±¡ã€‚

Enums can use multiple generic types as well. The definition of the Result enum that we used in Chapter 9 is one example:

æšä¸¾ä¹Ÿå¯ä½¿ç”¨å¤šä¸ªæ³›å‹ç±»å‹ã€‚ç¬¬ 9 ç« ç”¨è¿‡çš„ Result æšä¸¾å®šä¹‰å³ä¸ºä¸€ä¾‹ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E),
}
}

The Result enum is generic over two types, T and E, and has two variants: Ok, which holds a value of type T, and Err, which holds a value of type E. This definition makes it convenient to use the Result enum anywhere we have an operation that might succeed (return a value of some type T) or fail (return an error of some type E). In fact, this is what we used to open a file in Listing 9-3, where T was filled in with the type std::fs::File when the file was opened successfully and E was filled in with the type std::io::Error when there were problems opening the file.

Result æšä¸¾é’ˆå¯¹ T å’Œ E ä¸¤ç§ç±»å‹æ˜¯æ³›å‹çš„ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜ä½“ï¼šOkï¼ˆæŒæœ‰ç±»å‹ T çš„å€¼ï¼‰å’Œ Errï¼ˆæŒæœ‰ç±»å‹ E çš„å€¼ï¼‰ã€‚æ­¤å®šä¹‰ä¾¿äºåœ¨ä»»ä½•å¯èƒ½æˆåŠŸï¼ˆè¿”å›ç±»å‹ T çš„å€¼ï¼‰æˆ–å¤±è´¥ï¼ˆè¿”å›ç±»å‹ E çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼‰çš„æ“ä½œä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ Result æšä¸¾ã€‚å®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯ç¤ºä¾‹ 9-3 ä¸­æ‰“å¼€æ–‡ä»¶çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼šæˆåŠŸæ‰“å¼€æ—¶ T ä¸º std::fs::File ç±»å‹ï¼Œå‡ºé—®é¢˜æ—¶ E ä¸º std::io::Error ç±»å‹ã€‚

When you recognize situations in your code with multiple struct or enum definitions that differ only in the types of the values they hold, you can avoid duplication by using generic types instead.

å½“å‘ç°ä»£ç ä¸­æœ‰å¤šä¸ªç»“æ„ä½“æˆ–æšä¸¾å®šä¹‰ä»…å› æ‰€æŒå€¼ç±»å‹ä¸åŒè€Œå­˜åœ¨æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹é¿å…é‡å¤ã€‚

In Method Definitions æ–¹æ³•å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ³›å‹

We can implement methods on structs and enums (as we did in Chapter 5) and use generic types in their definitions too. Listing 10-9 shows the Point<T> struct we defined in Listing 10-6 with a method named x implemented on it.

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯åœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“å’Œæšä¸¾ä¸Šå®ç°æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¬¬ 5 ç« ï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-9 å±•ç¤ºäº†åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-6 å®šä¹‰çš„ Point<T> ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸Šå®ç°åä¸º x çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Here, weâ€™ve defined a method named x on Point<T> that returns a reference to the data in the field x.

æ­¤å¤„æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ Point<T> ä¸Šå®šä¹‰äº†è¿”å›å­—æ®µ x æ•°æ®å¼•ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³• xã€‚

Note that we have to declare T just after impl so we can use T to specify that weâ€™re implementing methods on the type Point<T>. By declaring T as a generic type after impl, Rust can identify that the type in the angle brackets in Point is a generic type rather than a concrete type. We could have chosen a different name for this generic parameter than the generic parameter declared in the struct definition, but using the same name is conventional. If you write a method within an impl that declares a generic type, that method will be defined on any instance of the type, no matter what concrete type ends up substituting for the generic type.

[note]æ³¨æ„å¿…é¡»åœ¨ impl åå£°æ˜ Tï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ‰èƒ½ç”¨ T æŒ‡å®šæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ Point<T> ç±»å‹ä¸Šå®ç°æ–¹æ³•ã€‚é€šè¿‡åœ¨ impl åå£°æ˜ Tï¼ŒRust èƒ½è¯†åˆ« Point å°–æ‹¬å·ä¸­çš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯æ³›å‹è€Œéå…·ä½“ç±»å‹ã€‚æœ¬å¯ä¸ºè¯¥æ³›å‹å‚æ•°é€‰æ‹©ä¸ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä¸åŒçš„åç§°ï¼Œä½†ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒåç§°æ˜¯æƒ¯ä¾‹ã€‚è‹¥åœ¨ impl å—å†…å£°æ˜æ³›å‹ç±»å‹çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œåˆ™æ— è®ºæœ€ç»ˆæ›¿æ¢æ³›å‹çš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œè¯¥æ–¹æ³•éƒ½å°†åœ¨è¯¥ç±»å‹çš„æ‰€æœ‰å®ä¾‹ä¸Šå®šä¹‰ã€‚

We can also specify constraints on generic types when defining methods on the type. We could, for example, implement methods only on Point<f32> instances rather than on Point<T> instances with any generic type. In Listing 10-10 we use the concrete type f32, meaning we donâ€™t declare any types after impl.

å®šä¹‰ç±»å‹æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ä¹Ÿå¯æŒ‡å®šæ³›å‹ç±»å‹çš„çº¦æŸã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚å¯ä»…ä¸º Point<f32> å®ä¾‹å®ç°æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè€Œéä»»æ„æ³›å‹ç±»å‹çš„ Point<T> å®ä¾‹ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-10 ä½¿ç”¨äº†å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ f32ï¼ˆimpl åæœªå£°æ˜ä»»ä½•ç±»å‹ï¼‰ã€‚

This code means the type Point<f32> will have a distance_from_origin method; other instances of Point<T> where T is not of type f32 will not have this method defined. The method measures how far our point is from the point at coordinates (0.0, 0.0) and uses mathematical operations that are available only for floating-point types.

æ­¤ä»£ç æ„å‘³ç€ Point<f32> ç±»å‹å°†æœ‰ distance_from_origin æ–¹æ³•ï¼›è€Œ T é f32 ç±»å‹çš„ Point<T> å®ä¾‹åˆ™æ— æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•è®¡ç®—ç‚¹è·ç¦»åæ ‡ (0.0, 0.0) çš„è¿œè¿‘ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨äº†ä»…æµ®ç‚¹ç±»å‹å¯ç”¨çš„æ•°å­¦è¿ç®—ã€‚

Generic type parameters in a struct definition arenâ€™t always the same as those you use in that same structâ€™s method signatures. Listing 10-11 uses the generic types X1 and Y1 for the Point struct and X2 Y2 for the mixup method signature to make the example clearer. The method creates a new Point instance with the x value from the self Point (of type X1) and the y value from the passed-in Point (of type Y2).

ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°ä¸ä¸€å®šä¸æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åä¸­çš„ç›¸åŒã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-11 ä¸­ä¸ºæ¸…æ™°èµ·è§ï¼Œç»“æ„ä½“ Point ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹ X1 å’Œ Y1ï¼Œæ–¹æ³• mixup çš„ç­¾åä½¿ç”¨ X2 å’Œ Y2ã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•ç”¨ self çš„ Pointï¼ˆç±»å‹ X1ï¼‰çš„ x å€¼ä¸ä¼ å…¥ Pointï¼ˆç±»å‹ Y2ï¼‰çš„ y å€¼åˆ›å»ºæ–° Point å®ä¾‹ã€‚

In main, weâ€™ve defined a Point that has an i32 for x (with value 5) and an f64 for y (with value 10.4). The p2 variable is a Point struct that has a string slice for x (with value "Hello") and a char for y (with value c). Calling mixup on p1 with the argument p2 gives us p3, which will have an i32 for x because x came from p1. The p3 variable will have a char for y because y came from p2. The println! macro call will print p3.x = 5, p3.y = c.

åœ¨ main ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰äº† x ä¸º i32ï¼ˆå€¼ 5ï¼‰ã€y ä¸º f64ï¼ˆå€¼ 10.4ï¼‰çš„ Pointã€‚å˜é‡ p2 æ˜¯ x ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼ˆå€¼ "Hello"ï¼‰ã€y ä¸º charï¼ˆå€¼ cï¼‰çš„ Point ç»“æ„ä½“ã€‚ä»¥ p2 ä¸ºå‚æ•°å¯¹ p1 è°ƒç”¨ mixup å¾—åˆ° p3ï¼Œå…¶ x æ¥è‡ª p1 æ•…ä¸º i32 ç±»å‹ã€‚å˜é‡ p3 çš„ y æ¥è‡ª p2 æ•…ä¸º char ç±»å‹ã€‚println! å®è°ƒç”¨å°†æ‰“å° p3.x = 5, p3.y = cã€‚

The purpose of this example is to demonstrate a situation in which some generic parameters are declared with impl and some are declared with the method definition. Here, the generic parameters X1 and Y1 are declared after impl because they go with the struct definition. The generic parameters X2 and Y2 are declared after fn mixup because theyâ€™re only relevant to the method.

æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹æ—¨åœ¨å±•ç¤ºï¼šéƒ¨åˆ†æ³›å‹å‚æ•°åœ¨ impl ä¸­å£°æ˜ï¼Œéƒ¨åˆ†åœ¨æ–¹æ³•å®šä¹‰ä¸­å£°æ˜ã€‚æ­¤å¤„æ³›å‹å‚æ•° X1 å’Œ Y1 åœ¨ impl åå£°æ˜ï¼ˆå› å®ƒä»¬ä¸ç»“æ„ä½“å®šä¹‰ç›¸å…³ï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œ X2 å’Œ Y2 åœ¨ fn mixup åå£°æ˜ï¼ˆå› å®ƒä»¬ä»…ä¸æ–¹æ³•ç›¸å…³ï¼‰ã€‚

Performance of Code Using Generics ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ä»£ç çš„æ€§èƒ½

You might be wondering whether there is a runtime cost when using generic type parameters. The good news is that using generic types wonâ€™t make your program run any slower than it would with concrete types.

ä½ å¯èƒ½å¥½å¥‡ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°æ˜¯å¦ä¼šå¸¦æ¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¼€é”€ã€‚å¥½æ¶ˆæ¯æ˜¯ï¼šä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ä¸ä¼šæ¯”ä½¿ç”¨å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ä½¿ç¨‹åºè¿è¡Œå¾—æ›´æ…¢ã€‚

Rust accomplishes this by performing monomorphization of the code using generics at compile time. Monomorphization is the process of turning generic code into specific code by filling in the concrete types that are used when compiled. In this process, the compiler does the opposite of the steps we used to create the generic function in Listing 10-5: the compiler looks at all the places where generic code is called and generates code for the concrete types the generic code is called with.

Rust é€šè¿‡åœ¨ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶å¯¹ä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹çš„ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œå•æ€åŒ–ï¼ˆmonomorphizationï¼‰å®ç°è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚å•æ€åŒ–æ˜¯å°†æ³›å‹ä»£ç è½¬æ¢ä¸ºç‰¹å®šä»£ç çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ï¼Œé€šè¿‡å¡«å……ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨çš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹å®ç°ã€‚åœ¨æ­¤è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ‰§è¡Œä¸ç¤ºä¾‹ 10-5 åˆ›å»ºæ³›å‹å‡½æ•°ç›¸åçš„æ­¥éª¤ï¼šæŸ¥çœ‹æ‰€æœ‰è°ƒç”¨æ³›å‹ä»£ç çš„ä½ç½®ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºè°ƒç”¨æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨çš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ç”Ÿæˆä»£ç ã€‚

Letâ€™s look at how this works by using the standard libraryâ€™s generic Option<T> enum:

é€šè¿‡æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„æ³›å‹ Option<T> æšä¸¾æ¥çœ‹å…¶å·¥ä½œåŸç†ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
let integer = Some(5);
let float = Some(5.0);
}

When Rust compiles this code, it performs monomorphization. During that process, the compiler reads the values that have been used in Option<T> instances and identifies two kinds of Option<T>: one is i32 and the other is f64. As such, it expands the generic definition of Option<T> into two definitions specialized to i32 and f64, thereby replacing the generic definition with the specific ones.

Rust ç¼–è¯‘æ­¤ä»£ç æ—¶ä¼šæ‰§è¡Œå•æ€åŒ–ã€‚ç¼–è¯‘å™¨è¯»å– Option<T> å®ä¾‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨çš„å€¼ï¼Œè¯†åˆ«å‡ºä¸¤ç§ Option<T>ï¼šä¸€ç§æ˜¯ i32ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ç§æ˜¯ f64ã€‚å› æ­¤å®ƒå°† Option<T> çš„æ³›å‹å®šä¹‰æ‰©å±•ä¸ºé’ˆå¯¹ i32 å’Œ f64 ç‰¹åŒ–çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªå®šä¹‰ï¼Œä»è€Œç”¨å…·ä½“å®šä¹‰æ›¿æ¢æ³›å‹å®šä¹‰ã€‚

The monomorphized version of the code looks similar to the following (the compiler uses different names than what weâ€™re using here for illustration):

å•æ€åŒ–åçš„ä»£ç ç±»ä¼¼äºä»¥ä¸‹å½¢å¼ï¼ˆç¼–è¯‘å™¨å®é™…ä½¿ç”¨ä¸åŒåç§°ï¼Œæ­¤å¤„ä¸ºè¯´æ˜ï¼‰ï¼š

The generic Option<T> is replaced with the specific definitions created by the compiler. Because Rust compiles generic code into code that specifies the type in each instance, we pay no runtime cost for using generics. When the code runs, it performs just as it would if we had duplicated each definition by hand. The process of monomorphization makes Rustâ€™s generics extremely efficient at runtime.

æ³›å‹ Option<T> è¢«ç¼–è¯‘å™¨åˆ›å»ºçš„å…·ä½“å®šä¹‰æ›¿ä»£ã€‚ç”±äº Rust å°†æ³›å‹ä»£ç ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºé’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸ªå®ä¾‹æŒ‡å®šç±»å‹çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ³›å‹ä¸ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿè¿è¡Œæ—¶å¼€é”€ã€‚ä»£ç è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼Œå…¶æ€§èƒ½å¦‚åŒæ‰‹åŠ¨å¤åˆ¶æ¯ä¸ªå®šä¹‰ä¸€èˆ¬ã€‚å•æ€åŒ–è¿‡ç¨‹ä½¿ Rust çš„æ³›å‹åœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶æå…¶é«˜æ•ˆã€‚

Traits: Defining Shared Behavior ç‰¹è´¨ï¼šå®šä¹‰å…±äº«è¡Œä¸º

A trait defines the functionality a particular type has and can share with other types. We can use traits to define shared behavior in an abstract way. We can use trait bounds to specify that a generic type can be any type that has certain behavior.

ç‰¹è´¨å®šä¹‰äº†ç‰¹å®šç±»å‹æ‹¥æœ‰çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¹¶èƒ½ä¸å…¶ä»–ç±»å‹å…±äº«ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ç‰¹è´¨ä»¥æŠ½è±¡æ–¹å¼å®šä¹‰å…±äº«è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡ç‰¹è´¨é™å®šæ¥æŒ‡å®šæ³›å‹ç±»å‹å¿…é¡»æ˜¯å…·æœ‰ç‰¹å®šè¡Œä¸ºçš„ä»»æ„ç±»å‹ã€‚

Note: Traits are similar to a feature often called interfaces in other languages, although with some differences.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šç‰¹è´¨ç±»ä¼¼äºå…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€ä¸­å¸¸ç§°ä¸ºæ¥å£çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œä½†å­˜åœ¨ä¸€äº›å·®å¼‚ã€‚

Defining a Trait å®šä¹‰ç‰¹è´¨

A typeâ€™s behavior consists of the methods we can call on that type. Different types share the same behavior if we can call the same methods on all of those types. Trait definitions are a way to group method signatures together to define a set of behaviors necessary to accomplish some purpose.

ç±»å‹çš„è¡Œä¸ºç”±å¯åœ¨è¯¥ç±»å‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•ç»„æˆã€‚è‹¥èƒ½åœ¨ä¸åŒç±»å‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œåˆ™è¿™äº›ç±»å‹å…±äº«ç›¸åŒçš„è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ç‰¹è´¨å®šä¹‰é€šè¿‡å°†æ–¹æ³•ç­¾ååˆ†ç»„ï¼Œå®šä¹‰å®ç°ç‰¹å®šç›®çš„æ‰€éœ€çš„ä¸€ç»„è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

For example, letâ€™s say we have multiple structs that hold various kinds and amounts of text: a NewsArticle struct that holds a news story filed in a particular location and a SocialPost that can have, at most, 280 characters along with metadata that indicates whether it was a new post, a repost, or a reply to another post.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå‡è®¾æœ‰å¤šä¸ªç»“æ„ä½“ç”¨äºå­˜å‚¨ä¸åŒç§ç±»å’Œæ•°é‡çš„æ–‡æœ¬ï¼šNewsArticle ç»“æ„ä½“å­˜å‚¨ç‰¹å®šåœ°åŒºæäº¤çš„æ–°é—»æŠ¥é“ï¼ŒSocialPost æœ€å¤šå¯å­˜å‚¨ 280 ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä»¥åŠå…ƒæ•°æ®ï¼ˆæ ‡æ˜æ˜¯æ–°å¸–å­ã€è½¬å‘è¿˜æ˜¯å¯¹å…¶ä»–å¸–å­çš„å›å¤ï¼‰ã€‚

We want to make a media aggregator library crate named aggregator that can display summaries of data that might be stored in a NewsArticle or SocialPost instance. To do this, we need a summary from each type, and weâ€™ll request that summary by calling a summarize method on an instance. Listing 10-12 shows the definition of a public Summary trait that expresses this behavior.

æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªåä¸º aggregator çš„åª’ä½“èšåˆå™¨åº“ crateï¼Œå®ƒèƒ½æ˜¾ç¤ºå¯èƒ½å­˜å‚¨åœ¨ NewsArticle æˆ– SocialPost å®ä¾‹ä¸­çš„æ•°æ®æ‘˜è¦ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä»æ¯ç§ç±»å‹è·å–æ‘˜è¦ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨å®ä¾‹çš„ summarize æ–¹æ³•æ¥è¯·æ±‚æ‘˜è¦ã€‚[note]ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-12 å±•ç¤ºäº†è¡¨è¾¾æ­¤è¡Œä¸ºçš„å…¬å…± Summary ç‰¹è´¨å®šä¹‰ã€‚

Here, we declare a trait using the trait keyword and then the traitâ€™s name, which is Summary in this case. We also declare the trait as pub so that crates depending on this crate can make use of this trait too, as weâ€™ll see in a few examples. Inside the curly brackets, we declare the method signatures that describe the behaviors of the types that implement this trait, which in this case is fn summarize(&self) -> String.

æ­¤å¤„ä½¿ç”¨ trait å…³é”®å­—å£°æ˜ç‰¹è´¨ï¼Œåè·Ÿç‰¹è´¨åç§°ï¼ˆæœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­ä¸º Summaryï¼‰ã€‚åŒæ—¶å°†ç‰¹è´¨å£°æ˜ä¸º pubï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ä¾èµ–æ­¤ crate çš„å…¶ä»– crate ä¹Ÿèƒ½ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥ç‰¹è´¨ï¼ˆåç»­ç¤ºä¾‹å°†å±•ç¤ºï¼‰ã€‚åœ¨å¤§æ‹¬å·å†…å£°æ˜æè¿°å®ç°æ­¤ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹è¡Œä¸ºçš„æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åï¼Œæœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­ä¸º fn summarize(&self) -> Stringã€‚

After the method signature, instead of providing an implementation within curly brackets, we use a semicolon. Each type implementing this trait must provide its own custom behavior for the body of the method. The compiler will enforce that any type that has the Summary trait will have the method summarize defined with this signature exactly.

åœ¨æ–¹æ³•ç­¾ååï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨åˆ†å·è€Œéåœ¨å¤§æ‹¬å·å†…æä¾›å®ç°ã€‚å®ç°æ­¤ç‰¹è´¨çš„æ¯ä¸ªç±»å‹å¿…é¡»ä¸ºæ–¹æ³•ä½“æä¾›è‡ªå®šä¹‰è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å°†ç¡®ä¿ä»»ä½•æ‹¥æœ‰ Summary ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹éƒ½å‡†ç¡®å®šä¹‰äº†å…·æœ‰æ­¤ç­¾åçš„ summarize æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

A trait can have multiple methods in its body: the method signatures are listed one per line, and each line ends in a semicolon.

ç‰¹è´¨ä¸»ä½“å¯åŒ…å«å¤šä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ï¼šæ–¹æ³•ç­¾åé€è¡Œåˆ—ç¤ºï¼Œæ¯è¡Œä»¥åˆ†å·ç»“å°¾ã€‚

Implementing a Trait on a Type ä¸ºç±»å‹å®ç°ç‰¹è´¨

Now that weâ€™ve defined the desired signatures of the Summary traitâ€™s methods, we can implement it on the types in our media aggregator. Listing 10-13 shows an implementation of the Summary trait on the NewsArticle struct that uses the headline, the author, and the location to create the return value of summarize. For the SocialPost struct, we define summarize as the username followed by the entire text of the post, assuming that the post content is already limited to 280 characters.

å®šä¹‰äº† Summary ç‰¹è´¨æ–¹æ³•çš„æœŸæœ›ç­¾ååï¼Œå³å¯åœ¨åª’ä½“èšåˆå™¨ä¸­çš„ç±»å‹ä¸Šå®ç°å®ƒã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-13 å±•ç¤ºäº†åœ¨ NewsArticle ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸Šå®ç° Summary ç‰¹è´¨ï¼Œå®ƒä½¿ç”¨æ ‡é¢˜ã€ä½œè€…å’Œåœ°ç‚¹åˆ›å»º summarize çš„è¿”å›å€¼ã€‚å¯¹äº SocialPost ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°† summarize å®šä¹‰ä¸ºç”¨æˆ·ååè·Ÿå¸–å­å…¨æ–‡ï¼ˆå‡è®¾å†…å®¹å·²é™åˆ¶åœ¨ 280 å­—ç¬¦å†…ï¼‰ã€‚

Implementing a trait on a type is similar to implementing regular methods. The difference is that after impl, we put the trait name we want to implement, then use the for keyword, and then specify the name of the type we want to implement the trait for. Within the impl block, we put the method signatures that the trait definition has defined. Instead of adding a semicolon after each signature, we use curly brackets and fill in the method body with the specific behavior that we want the methods of the trait to have for the particular type.

ä¸ºç±»å‹å®ç°ç‰¹è´¨ç±»ä¼¼äºå®ç°å¸¸è§„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äº impl åéœ€æ”¾ç½®è¦å®ç°çš„ trait åï¼Œæ¥ç€ä½¿ç”¨ for å…³é”®å­—ï¼Œå†æŒ‡å®šè¦ä¸ºå…¶å®ç°ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹åã€‚åœ¨ impl å—å†…æ”¾ç½®ç‰¹è´¨å®šä¹‰ä¸­çš„æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ä¸åœ¨ç­¾åååŠ åˆ†å·ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨å¤§æ‹¬å·å¡«å……æ–¹æ³•ä½“ï¼Œå®šä¹‰è¯¥ç‰¹è´¨æ–¹æ³•åœ¨ç‰¹å®šç±»å‹ä¸Šçš„å…·ä½“è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

Now that the library has implemented the Summary trait on NewsArticle and SocialPost, users of the crate can call the trait methods on instances of NewsArticle and SocialPost in the same way we call regular methods. The only difference is that the user must bring the trait into scope as well as the types. Hereâ€™s an example of how a binary crate could use our aggregator library crate:

åº“åœ¨ NewsArticle å’Œ SocialPost ä¸Šå®ç° Summary ç‰¹è´¨åï¼Œcrate ç”¨æˆ·å¯åœ¨å…¶å®ä¾‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ç‰¹è´¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæ–¹å¼ä¸å¸¸è§„æ–¹æ³•ç›¸åŒã€‚å”¯ä¸€åŒºåˆ«æ˜¯ç”¨æˆ·éœ€å°†ç‰¹è´¨å’Œç±»å‹åŒæ—¶å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹ç¤ºä¾‹å±•ç¤ºäºŒè¿›åˆ¶ crate å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ aggregator åº“ crateï¼š

use aggregator::{SocialPost, Summary};

fn main() {
    let post = SocialPost {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "of course, as you probably already know, people",
        ),
        reply: false,
        repost: false,
    };

    println!("1 new post: {}", post.summarize());
}

This code prints 1 new post: horse_ebooks: of course, as you probably already know, people.

æ­¤ä»£ç è¾“å‡ºï¼š1 new post: horse_ebooks: of course, as you probably already know, peopleã€‚

Other crates that depend on the aggregator crate can also bring the Summary trait into scope to implement Summary on their own types. One restriction to note is that we can implement a trait on a type only if either the trait or the type, or both, are local to our crate. For example, we can implement standard library traits like Display on a custom type like SocialPost as part of our aggregator crate functionality because the type SocialPost is local to our aggregator crate. We can also implement Summary on Vec<T> in our aggregator crate because the trait Summary is local to our aggregator crate.

ä¾èµ– aggregator crate çš„å…¶ä»– crate ä¹Ÿå¯å°† Summary ç‰¹è´¨å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸï¼Œä»¥åœ¨å…¶ç±»å‹ä¸Šå®ç° Summaryã€‚éœ€æ³¨æ„çš„ä¸€ä¸ªé™åˆ¶æ˜¯ï¼Œä»…å½“ç‰¹è´¨æˆ–ç±»å‹è‡³å°‘å…¶ä¸€æ˜¯æœ¬åœ° crate æ‰€æœ‰æ—¶ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½ä¸ºç±»å‹å®ç°ç‰¹è´¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¯åœ¨è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ SocialPost ä¸Šå®ç°æ ‡å‡†åº“ç‰¹è´¨ï¼ˆå¦‚ Displayï¼‰ï¼Œå› ä¸º SocialPost æ˜¯æœ¬åœ° crate æ‰€æœ‰ï¼›ä¹Ÿå¯åœ¨ Vec<T> ä¸Šå®ç° Summaryï¼Œå› ä¸º Summary æ˜¯æœ¬åœ° crate æ‰€æœ‰ã€‚

But we canâ€™t implement external traits on external types. For example, we canâ€™t implement the Display trait on Vec<T> within our aggregator crate because Display and Vec<T> are both defined in the standard library and arenâ€™t local to our aggregator crate. This restriction is part of a property called coherence, and more specifically the orphan rule, so named because the parent type is not present. This rule ensures that other peopleâ€™s code canâ€™t break your code and vice versa. Without the rule, two crates could implement the same trait for the same type, and Rust wouldnâ€™t know which implementation to use.

ä½†[note]æ— æ³•åœ¨å¤–éƒ¨ç±»å‹ä¸Šå®ç°å¤–éƒ¨ç‰¹è´¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä¸èƒ½åœ¨ aggregator crate ä¸­ä¸º Vec<T> å®ç° Display ç‰¹è´¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä¸¤è€…å‡å®šä¹‰äºæ ‡å‡†åº“ã€‚æ­¤é™åˆ¶æºäºä¸€è‡´æ€§åŸåˆ™ï¼ˆå…·ä½“ä¸ºå­¤å„¿è§„åˆ™ï¼Œå› çˆ¶ç±»å‹ä¸å­˜åœ¨ï¼‰ã€‚è¯¥è§„åˆ™ç¡®ä¿ä»–äººä»£ç ä¸ä¼šç ´åä½ çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œåä¹‹äº¦ç„¶ã€‚è‹¥æ— æ­¤è§„åˆ™ï¼Œä¸¤ä¸ª crate å¯èƒ½ä¸ºåŒä¸€ç±»å‹å®ç°ç›¸åŒç‰¹è´¨ï¼ŒRust å°†æ— æ³•ç¡®å®šä½¿ç”¨å“ªä¸ªå®ç°ã€‚

Default Implementations é»˜è®¤å®ç°

Sometimes itâ€™s useful to have default behavior for some or all of the methods in a trait instead of requiring implementations for all methods on every type. Then, as we implement the trait on a particular type, we can keep or override each methodâ€™s default behavior.

æœ‰æ—¶ä¸ºç‰¹è´¨çš„éƒ¨åˆ†æˆ–å…¨éƒ¨æ–¹æ³•æä¾›é»˜è®¤è¡Œä¸ºå¾ˆæœ‰ç”¨ï¼Œæ— éœ€ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªç±»å‹å®ç°æ‰€æœ‰æ–¹æ³•ã€‚è¿™æ ·åœ¨ç‰¹å®šç±»å‹ä¸Šå®ç°ç‰¹è´¨æ—¶ï¼Œå¯é€‰æ‹©ä¿ç•™æˆ–è¦†ç›–æ¯ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•çš„é»˜è®¤è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

In Listing 10-14, we specify a default string for the summarize method of the Summary trait instead of only defining the method signature, as we did in Listing 10-12.

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-14 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸º Summary ç‰¹è´¨çš„ summarize æ–¹æ³•æŒ‡å®šäº†é»˜è®¤å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œè€Œéä»…å®šä¹‰æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åï¼ˆå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-12ï¼‰ã€‚

To use a default implementation to summarize instances of NewsArticle, we specify an empty impl block with impl Summary for NewsArticle {}.

è¦ä½¿ç”¨é»˜è®¤å®ç°æ±‡æ€» NewsArticle å®ä¾‹ï¼Œéœ€æŒ‡å®šä¸€ä¸ªç©ºçš„ impl å—ï¼šimpl Summary for NewsArticle {}ã€‚

Even though weâ€™re no longer defining the summarize method on NewsArticle directly, weâ€™ve provided a default implementation and specified that NewsArticle implements the Summary trait. As a result, we can still call the summarize method on an instance of NewsArticle, like this:

å°½ç®¡ä¸å†ç›´æ¥åœ¨ NewsArticle ä¸Šå®šä¹‰ summarize æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬æä¾›äº†é»˜è®¤å®ç°å¹¶å£°æ˜ NewsArticle å®ç°äº† Summary ç‰¹è´¨ã€‚å› æ­¤ä»å¯åœ¨å…¶å®ä¾‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ summarize æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

use aggregator::{self, NewsArticle, Summary};

fn main() {
    let article = NewsArticle {
        headline: String::from("Penguins win the Stanley Cup Championship!"),
        location: String::from("Pittsburgh, PA, USA"),
        author: String::from("Iceburgh"),
        content: String::from(
            "The Pittsburgh Penguins once again are the best \
             hockey team in the NHL.",
        ),
    };

    println!("New article available! {}", article.summarize());
}

This code prints New article available! (Read more...).

æ­¤ä»£ç è¾“å‡ºï¼šNew article available! (Read more...)ã€‚

Creating a default implementation doesnâ€™t require us to change anything about the implementation of Summary on SocialPost in Listing 10-13. The reason is that the syntax for overriding a default implementation is the same as the syntax for implementing a trait method that doesnâ€™t have a default implementation.

åˆ›å»ºé»˜è®¤å®ç°æ— éœ€æ›´æ”¹ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-13 ä¸­ SocialPost çš„ Summary å®ç°ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¦†ç›–é»˜è®¤å®ç°çš„è¯­æ³•ä¸å®ç°æ— é»˜è®¤æ–¹æ³•çš„ç‰¹è´¨æ–¹æ³•ç›¸åŒã€‚

Default implementations can call other methods in the same trait, even if those other methods donâ€™t have a default implementation. In this way, a trait can provide a lot of useful functionality and only require implementors to specify a small part of it. For example, we could define the Summary trait to have a summarize_author method whose implementation is required, and then define a summarize method that has a default implementation that calls the summarize_author method:

[note]é»˜è®¤å®ç°å¯è°ƒç”¨åŒä¸€ç‰¹è´¨ä¸­çš„å…¶ä»–æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆå³ä½¿è¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•æ— é»˜è®¤å®ç°ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ ·ï¼Œç‰¹è´¨å¯æä¾›å¤§é‡åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œä»…è¦æ±‚å®ç°è€…æŒ‡å®šä¸€å°éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå¯å®šä¹‰ Summary ç‰¹è´¨åŒ…å«éœ€å®ç°çš„ summarize_author æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå†å®šä¹‰è°ƒç”¨ summarize_author çš„é»˜è®¤ summarize æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String;

    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("(Read more from {}...)", self.summarize_author())
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String {
        format!("@{}", self.username)
    }
}

To use this version of Summary, we only need to define summarize_author when we implement the trait on a type:

ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤ç‰ˆæœ¬ Summary æ—¶ï¼Œå®ç°ç‰¹è´¨ä»…éœ€å®šä¹‰ summarize_authorï¼š

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String;

    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("(Read more from {}...)", self.summarize_author())
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String {
        format!("@{}", self.username)
    }
}

After we define summarize_author, we can call summarize on instances of the SocialPost struct, and the default implementation of summarize will call the definition of summarize_author that weâ€™ve provided. Because weâ€™ve implemented summarize_author, the Summary trait has given us the behavior of the summarize method without requiring us to write any more code. Hereâ€™s what that looks like:

å®šä¹‰ summarize_author åï¼Œå³å¯åœ¨ SocialPost å®ä¾‹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ summarizeã€‚é»˜è®¤å®ç°å°†è°ƒç”¨æˆ‘ä»¬æä¾›çš„ summarize_author å®ç°ã€‚ç”±äºå®ç°äº† summarize_authorï¼ŒSummary ç‰¹è´¨ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬æä¾›äº† summarize çš„è¡Œä¸ºè€Œæ— éœ€é¢å¤–ç¼–ç ï¼š

use aggregator::{self, SocialPost, Summary};

fn main() {
    let post = SocialPost {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "of course, as you probably already know, people",
        ),
        reply: false,
        repost: false,
    };

    println!("1 new post: {}", post.summarize());
}

This code prints 1 new post: (Read more from @horse_ebooks...).

æ­¤ä»£ç è¾“å‡ºï¼š1 new post: (Read more from @horse_ebooks...)ã€‚

Note that it isnâ€™t possible to call the default implementation from an overriding implementation of that same method.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šæ— æ³•ä»è¦†ç›–å®ç°ä¸­è°ƒç”¨æ­¤æ–¹æ³•çš„é»˜è®¤å®ç°ã€‚

Traits as Parameters ç‰¹è´¨ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°

Now that you know how to define and implement traits, we can explore how to use traits to define functions that accept many different types. Weâ€™ll use the Summary trait we implemented on the NewsArticle and SocialPost types in Listing 10-13 to define a notify function that calls the summarize method on its item parameter, which is of some type that implements the Summary trait. To do this, we use the impl Trait syntax, like this:

äº†è§£å¦‚ä½•å®šä¹‰å’Œä½¿ç”¨ç‰¹è´¨åï¼Œå¯æ¢ç´¢å¦‚ä½•ç”¨ç‰¹è´¨å®šä¹‰æ¥å—å¤šç§ç±»å‹çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä½¿ç”¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-13 ä¸­ä¸º NewsArticle å’Œ SocialPost å®ç°çš„ Summary ç‰¹è´¨ï¼Œå®šä¹‰ notify å‡½æ•°ï¼šåœ¨å…¶å‚æ•° itemï¼ˆæŸå®ç° Summary ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹ï¼‰ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ summarize æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ impl Trait è¯­æ³•å®ç°ï¼š

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, by {} ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

pub fn notify(item: &impl Summary) {
    println!("Breaking news! {}", item.summarize());
}

Instead of a concrete type for the item parameter, we specify the impl keyword and the trait name. This parameter accepts any type that implements the specified trait. In the body of notify, we can call any methods on item that come from the Summary trait, such as summarize. We can call notify and pass in any instance of NewsArticle or SocialPost. Code that calls the function with any other type, such as a String or an i32, wonâ€™t compile because those types donâ€™t implement Summary.

item å‚æ•°ä½¿ç”¨ impl å…³é”®å­—åŠ ç‰¹è´¨åæ›¿ä»£å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ï¼Œæ¥å—ä»»ä½•å®ç°æŒ‡å®šç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚åœ¨ notify ä¸»ä½“ä¸­ï¼Œå¯è°ƒç”¨æ¥è‡ª Summary ç‰¹è´¨çš„ä»»ä½•æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆå¦‚ summarizeï¼‰ã€‚å¯ä¼ å…¥ NewsArticle æˆ– SocialPost å®ä¾‹è°ƒç”¨ notifyã€‚è‹¥ä¼ å…¥ String æˆ– i32 ç­‰æœªå®ç° Summary çš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œä»£ç å°†æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

Trait Bound Syntax ç‰¹è´¨é™å®šè¯­æ³•

The impl Trait syntax works for straightforward cases but is actually syntax sugar for a longer form known as a trait bound; it looks like this:

[note]impl Trait è¯­æ³•é€‚ç”¨äºç®€å•æƒ…å†µï¼Œå®ä¸º ç‰¹è´¨é™å®šï¼ˆtrait boundï¼‰ çš„è¯­æ³•ç³–ï¼š

pub fn notify<T: Summary>(item: &T) {
    println!("Breaking news! {}", item.summarize());
}

This longer form is equivalent to the example in the previous section but is more verbose. We place trait bounds with the declaration of the generic type parameter after a colon and inside angle brackets.

æ­¤å®Œæ•´å½¢å¼ç­‰åŒäºä¸Šä¾‹ä½†æ›´å†—é•¿ã€‚ç‰¹è´¨é™å®šä½äºæ³›å‹å‚æ•°å£°æ˜åï¼Œä»¥å†’å·åˆ†éš”å¹¶ç½®äºå°–æ‹¬å·å†…ã€‚

The impl Trait syntax is convenient and makes for more concise code in simple cases, while the fuller trait bound syntax can express more complexity in other cases. For example, we can have two parameters that implement Summary. Doing so with the impl Trait syntax looks like this:

impl Trait è¯­æ³•å¾ˆæ–¹ä¾¿ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”åœ¨ç®€å•æƒ…å†µä¸‹èƒ½å¤Ÿè®©ä»£ç æ›´åŠ ç®€æ´ï¼Œè€Œå®Œæ•´çš„ trait çº¦æŸè¯­æ³•åˆ™èƒ½åœ¨å…¶ä»–æƒ…å†µä¸‹è¡¨è¾¾æ›´å¤šçš„å¤æ‚æ€§ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå®ç°äº† Summary çš„å‚æ•°ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ impl Trait è¯­æ³•çš„å†™æ³•å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

pub fn notify(item1: &impl Summary, item2: &impl Summary) {

Using impl Trait is appropriate if we want this function to allow item1 and item2 to have different types (as long as both types implement Summary). If we want to force both parameters to have the same type, however, we must use a trait bound, like this:

å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›æ­¤å‡½æ•°å…è®¸ item1 å’Œ item2 å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆåªè¦å®ƒä»¬éƒ½å®ç°äº† Summary æ¥å£ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ impl Traitã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³å¼ºåˆ¶ä¸¤ä¸ªå‚æ•°å…·æœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œåˆ™å¿…é¡»ä½¿ç”¨ trait boundï¼š

pub fn notify<T: Summary>(item1: &T, item2: &T) {

The generic type T specified as the type of the item1 and item2 parameters constrains the function such that the concrete type of the value passed as an argument for item1 and item2 must be the same.

è¿™é‡Œï¼Œæ³›å‹ç±»å‹ T è¢«æŒ‡å®šä¸º item1 å’Œ item2 å‚æ•°çš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œé™åˆ¶äº†è¯¥å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä½¿å¾—ä¼ é€’ç»™ item1 å’Œ item2 çš„å®é™…ç±»å‹å¿…é¡»ç›¸åŒã€‚

Specifying Multiple Trait Bounds with the + Syntax ä½¿ç”¨ + è¯­æ³•æŒ‡å®šå¤šä¸ªç‰¹è´¨é™å®š

We can also specify more than one trait bound. Say we wanted notify to use display formatting as well as summarize on item: we specify in the notify definition that item must implement both Display and Summary. We can do so using the + syntax:

[note]å¯æŒ‡å®šå¤šä¸ªç‰¹è´¨é™å®šã€‚è‹¥éœ€ notify åŒæ—¶ä½¿ç”¨æ˜¾ç¤ºæ ¼å¼åŒ–å’Œ summarizeï¼Œåˆ™è¦æ±‚ item å®ç° Display å’Œ Summaryï¼š

pub fn notify(item: &(impl Summary + Display)) {

The + syntax is also valid with trait bounds on generic types:

+ è¯­æ³•ä¹Ÿé€‚ç”¨äºæ³›å‹çš„ç‰¹è´¨é™å®šï¼š

pub fn notify<T: Summary + Display>(item: &T) {

With the two trait bounds specified, the body of notify can call summarize and use {} to format item.

æŒ‡å®šä¸¤ä¸ªç‰¹è´¨é™å®šåï¼Œnotify ä¸»ä½“å¯è°ƒç”¨ summarize å¹¶ä½¿ç”¨ {} æ ¼å¼åŒ– itemã€‚

Clearer Trait Bounds with where Clauses ä½¿ç”¨ where å­å¥å¢å¼ºå¯è¯»æ€§

Using too many trait bounds has its downsides. Each generic has its own trait bounds, so functions with multiple generic type parameters can contain lots of trait bound information between the functionâ€™s name and its parameter list, making the function signature hard to read. For this reason, Rust has alternate syntax for specifying trait bounds inside a where clause after the function signature. So, instead of writing this:

ä½¿ç”¨è¿‡å¤šçš„ç‰¹å¾çº¦æŸæ˜¯æœ‰ç¼ºç‚¹çš„ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªæ³›å‹éƒ½æœ‰è‡ªå·±çš„ç‰¹å¾çº¦æŸï¼Œå› æ­¤å…·æœ‰å¤šä¸ªæ³›å‹ç±»å‹å‚æ•°çš„å‡½æ•°å¯èƒ½ä¼šåœ¨å‡½æ•°åå’Œå‚æ•°åˆ—è¡¨ä¹‹é—´åŒ…å«å¤§é‡ç‰¹å¾çº¦æŸä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¿™ä½¿å¾—å‡½æ•°ç­¾åå˜å¾—éš¾ä»¥é˜…è¯»ã€‚ä¸ºäº†è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼ŒRust æä¾›äº†å¦ä¸€ç§è¯­æ³•ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åœ¨å‡½æ•°ç­¾ååä½¿ç”¨ where å­å¥æ¥æŒ‡å®šç‰¹å¾çº¦æŸã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ— éœ€å†™æˆè¿™æ ·ï¼š

fn some_function<T: Display + Clone, U: Clone + Debug>(t: &T, u: &U) -> i32 {

we can use a where clause, like this:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ where å­å¥ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

fn some_function<T, U>(t: &T, u: &U) -> i32
where
    T: Display + Clone,
    U: Clone + Debug,
{
    unimplemented!()
}

This functionâ€™s signature is less cluttered: the function name, parameter list, and return type are close together, similar to a function without lots of trait bounds.

è¿™ä¸ªå‡½æ•°çš„ç­¾åæ›´åŠ ç®€æ´ï¼šå‡½æ•°åã€å‚æ•°åˆ—è¡¨å’Œè¿”å›ç±»å‹ç´§å¯†ç›¸è¿ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºæ²¡æœ‰è¿‡å¤šç‰¹å¾çº¦æŸçš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚

Returning Types That Implement Traits è¿”å›å®ç°ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹

We can also use the impl Trait syntax in the return position to return a value of some type that implements a trait, as shown here:

å¯åœ¨è¿”å›ä½ç½®ä½¿ç”¨ impl Trait è¯­æ³•è¿”å›å®ç°æŸç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹ï¼š
