This pattern is about separating concerns: main.rs handles running the program and lib.rs handles all the logic of the task at hand. Because you canâ€™t test the main function directly, this structure lets you test all of your programâ€™s logic by moving it out of the main function. The code that remains in the main function will be small enough to verify its correctness by reading it. Letâ€™s rework our program by following this process.

æ­¤æ¨¡å¼çš„æ ¸å¿ƒæ˜¯åˆ†ç¦»å…³æ³¨ç‚¹ï¼šmain.rs è´Ÿè´£è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºï¼Œè€Œ lib.rs å¤„ç†æ‰€æœ‰å®é™…ä»»åŠ¡é€»è¾‘ã€‚ç”±äºæ— æ³•ç›´æ¥æµ‹è¯• main å‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ­¤ç»“æ„å…è®¸ä½ å°†æ‰€æœ‰ç¨‹åºé€»è¾‘ç§»å‡º main å‡½æ•°è¿›è¡Œæµ‹è¯•ã€‚ä¿ç•™åœ¨ main ä¸­çš„ä»£ç é‡è¶³å¤Ÿå°ï¼Œå¯é€šè¿‡é˜…è¯»éªŒè¯æ­£ç¡®æ€§ã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‰æ­¤æµç¨‹æ”¹é€ ç¨‹åºã€‚

Extracting the Argument Parser æå–å‚æ•°è§£æå™¨

Weâ€™ll extract the functionality for parsing arguments into a function that main will call. Listing 12-5 shows the new start of the main function that calls a new function parse_config, which weâ€™ll define in src/main.rs.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å‚æ•°è§£æåŠŸèƒ½æå–åˆ° main è°ƒç”¨çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­ã€‚æ¸…å• 12-5 å±•ç¤ºäº†æ–°çš„ main å‡½æ•°èµ·å§‹éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå®ƒè°ƒç”¨æ–°å®šä¹‰çš„ parse_config å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆåœ¨ src/main.rs ä¸­ï¼‰ã€‚

Weâ€™re still collecting the command line arguments into a vector, but instead of assigning the argument value at index 1 to the variable query and the argument value at index 2 to the variable file_path within the main function, we pass the whole vector to the parse_config function. The parse_config function then holds the logic that determines which argument goes in which variable and passes the values back to main. We still create the query and file_path variables in main, but main no longer has the responsibility of determining how the command line arguments and variables correspond.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä»å°†å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°æ”¶é›†åˆ°å‘é‡ä¸­ï¼Œä½†ä¸å†åœ¨ main å‡½æ•°ä¸­å°†ç´¢å¼• 1 çš„å€¼èµ‹ç»™ queryã€ç´¢å¼• 2 çš„å€¼èµ‹ç»™ file_pathï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å°†æ•´ä¸ªå‘é‡ä¼ é€’ç»™ parse_config å‡½æ•°ã€‚parse_config å‡½æ•°åŒ…å«ç¡®å®šå‚æ•°ä¸å˜é‡å¯¹åº”å…³ç³»çš„é€»è¾‘ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å€¼ä¼ å› mainã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä»åœ¨ main ä¸­åˆ›å»º query å’Œ file_path å˜é‡ï¼Œä½† main ä¸å†è´Ÿè´£ç¡®å®šå‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°ä¸å˜é‡çš„å¯¹åº”å…³ç³»ã€‚

This rework may seem like overkill for our small program, but weâ€™re refactoring in small, incremental steps. After making this change, run the program again to verify that the argument parsing still works. Itâ€™s good to check your progress often, to help identify the cause of problems when they occur.

å¯¹å°ç¨‹åºæ¥è¯´è¿™ç§æ”¹é€ å¯èƒ½æ˜¾å¾—è¿‡åº¦ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬æ­£ä»¥å°æ­¥å¢é‡æ–¹å¼è¿›è¡Œé‡æ„ã€‚ä¿®æ”¹åè¯·å†æ¬¡è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºä»¥éªŒè¯å‚æ•°è§£æä»æ­£å¸¸å·¥ä½œã€‚ç»å¸¸æ£€æŸ¥è¿›å±•æœ‰åŠ©äºå¿«é€Ÿå®šä½é—®é¢˜æ ¹æºã€‚

Grouping Configuration Values åˆ†ç»„é…ç½®å€¼

We can take another small step to improve the parse_config function further. At the moment, weâ€™re returning a tuple, but then we immediately break that tuple into individual parts again. This is a sign that perhaps we donâ€™t have the right abstraction yet.

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è¿›ä¸€æ­¥æ”¹è¿› parse_config å‡½æ•°ã€‚å½“å‰è¿”å›å…ƒç»„åç«‹å³å°†å…¶æ‹†åˆ†ä¸ºç‹¬ç«‹éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œè¿™è¡¨æ˜å½“å‰çš„æŠ½è±¡å¯èƒ½ä¸å¤Ÿåˆç†ã€‚

Another indicator that shows thereâ€™s room for improvement is the config part of parse_config, which implies that the two values we return are related and are both part of one configuration value. Weâ€™re not currently conveying this meaning in the structure of the data other than by grouping the two values into a tuple; weâ€™ll instead put the two values into one struct and give each of the struct fields a meaningful name. Doing so will make it easier for future maintainers of this code to understand how the different values relate to each other and what their purpose is.

å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¯æ”¹è¿›çš„è¿¹è±¡æ˜¯ parse_config ä¸­çš„ config éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œæš—ç¤ºè¿”å›çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªå€¼ç›¸å…³ä¸”åŒå±ä¸€ä¸ªé…ç½®å€¼ã€‚å½“å‰ä»…é€šè¿‡å…ƒç»„åˆ†ç»„æ¥ä¼ é€’è¿™ç§å…³è”æ€§ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æŠŠè¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªå€¼æ”¾å…¥ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªå­—æ®µèµ‹äºˆæœ‰æ„ä¹‰çš„åç§°ã€‚è¿™æ ·åšå°†ä½¿æœªæ¥ä»£ç ç»´æŠ¤è€…æ›´å®¹æ˜“ç†è§£ä¸åŒå€¼é—´çš„å…³è”åŠå…¶ç”¨é€”ã€‚

Listing 12-6 shows the improvements to the parse_config function.

æ¸…å• 12-6 å±•ç¤ºäº†å¯¹ parse_config å‡½æ•°çš„æ”¹è¿›ã€‚

Weâ€™ve added a struct named Config defined to have fields named query and file_path. The signature of parse_config now indicates that it returns a Config value. In the body of parse_config, where we used to return string slices that reference String values in args, we now define Config to contain owned String values. The args variable in main is the owner of the argument values and is only letting the parse_config function borrow them, which means weâ€™d violate Rustâ€™s borrowing rules if Config tried to take ownership of the values in args.

æˆ‘ä»¬æ·»åŠ äº†åŒ…å« query å’Œ file_path å­—æ®µçš„ Config ç»“æ„ä½“ã€‚parse_config çš„ç­¾åç°è¡¨æ˜å®ƒè¿”å› Config å€¼ã€‚åœ¨å‡½æ•°ä½“ä¸­ï¼Œè¿‡å»è¿”å›å¼•ç”¨ args ä¸­ String å€¼çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œç°åœ¨æ”¹ä¸ºå®šä¹‰ Config åŒ…å«æ‹¥æœ‰æ‰€æœ‰æƒçš„ String å€¼ã€‚main ä¸­çš„ args å˜é‡æ˜¯å‚æ•°å€¼çš„æ‰€æœ‰è€…ï¼Œä»…å€Ÿç»™ parse_config ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€è‹¥ Config å°è¯•è·å– args ä¸­å€¼çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œå°†è¿å Rust çš„å€Ÿç”¨è§„åˆ™ã€‚

There are a number of ways we could manage the String data; the easiest, though somewhat inefficient, route is to call the clone method on the values. This will make a full copy of the data for the Config instance to own, which takes more time and memory than storing a reference to the string data. However, cloning the data also makes our code very straightforward because we donâ€™t have to manage the lifetimes of the references; in this circumstance, giving up a little performance to gain simplicity is a worthwhile trade-off.

æœ‰å¤šç§æ–¹å¼ç®¡ç† String æ•°æ®ï¼›æœ€ç®€å•ï¼ˆä½†æ•ˆç‡è¾ƒä½ï¼‰çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯è°ƒç”¨å€¼çš„ clone æ–¹æ³•ã€‚è¿™ä¼šä¸º Config å®ä¾‹åˆ›å»ºæ•°æ®çš„å®Œæ•´å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œæ¯”å­˜å‚¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°æ®çš„å¼•ç”¨æ›´è€—æ—¶é—´å’Œå†…å­˜ã€‚ä½†å…‹éš†æ•°æ®ä¹Ÿä½¿ä»£ç æ›´ç®€æ´ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬æ— éœ€ç®¡ç†å¼•ç”¨çš„ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸï¼›åœ¨æ­¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œç‰ºç‰²å°‘é‡æ€§èƒ½æ¢å–ç®€å•æ€§æ˜¯å€¼å¾—çš„ã€‚

The Trade-Offs of Using clone ä½¿ç”¨ clone çš„æƒè¡¡

Thereâ€™s a tendency among many Rustaceans to avoid using clone to fix ownership problems because of its runtime cost. In Chapter 13, youâ€™ll learn how to use more efficient methods in this type of situation. But for now, itâ€™s okay to copy a few strings to continue making progress because youâ€™ll make these copies only once and your file path and query string are very small. Itâ€™s better to have a working program thatâ€™s a bit inefficient than to try to hyperoptimize code on your first pass. As you become more experienced with Rust, itâ€™ll be easier to start with the most efficient solution, but for now, itâ€™s perfectly acceptable to call clone.

è®¸å¤š Rust å¼€å‘è€…å€¾å‘äºé¿å…ç”¨ clone è§£å†³æ‰€æœ‰æƒé—®é¢˜ï¼Œå› å…¶æœ‰è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¼€é”€ã€‚åœ¨ç¬¬ 13 ç« ï¼Œä½ å°†å­¦ä¹ åœ¨æ­¤ç±»æƒ…å†µä¸‹ä½¿ç”¨æ›´é«˜æ•ˆçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ä½†å½“å‰å¤åˆ¶å°‘é‡å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä»¥ç»§ç»­æ¨è¿›æ˜¯å¯ä»¥æ¥å—çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™äº›å¤åˆ¶ä»…å‘ç”Ÿä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œä¸”æ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„å’ŒæŸ¥è¯¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸²éå¸¸å°ã€‚æ‹¥æœ‰ç¨ä½æ•ˆä½†å¯å·¥ä½œçš„ç¨‹åºï¼Œæ¯”é¦–æ¬¡å°è¯•å°±è¿‡åº¦ä¼˜åŒ–æ›´å¥½ã€‚éšç€ Rust ç»éªŒå¢é•¿ï¼Œä½ ä¼šæ›´æ˜“ä»é«˜æ•ˆæ–¹æ¡ˆèµ·æ­¥ï¼Œä½†ç›®å‰è°ƒç”¨ clone å®Œå…¨å¯æ¥å—ã€‚

Weâ€™ve updated main so it places the instance of Config returned by parse_config into a variable named config, and we updated the code that previously used the separate query and file_path variables so it now uses the fields on the Config struct instead.

æˆ‘ä»¬æ›´æ–°äº† mainï¼Œå°† parse_config è¿”å›çš„ Config å®ä¾‹å­˜å…¥å˜é‡ configï¼Œå¹¶å°†ä¹‹å‰ä½¿ç”¨ç‹¬ç«‹å˜é‡ query å’Œ file_path çš„ä»£ç æ”¹ä¸ºä½¿ç”¨ Config ç»“æ„ä½“çš„å­—æ®µã€‚

Now our code more clearly conveys that query and file_path are related and that their purpose is to configure how the program will work. Any code that uses these values knows to find them in the config instance in the fields named for their purpose.

ç°åœ¨ä»£ç æ›´æ¸…æ™°åœ°è¡¨æ˜ query å’Œ file_path ç›¸å…³ï¼Œå…¶ç›®çš„æ˜¯é…ç½®ç¨‹åºå·¥ä½œæ–¹å¼ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨è¿™äº›å€¼çš„ä»£ç åªéœ€åœ¨ config å®ä¾‹çš„å¯¹åº”å­—æ®µä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾å³å¯ã€‚

Creating a Constructor for Config ä¸º Config åˆ›å»ºæ„é€ å‡½æ•°

So far, weâ€™ve extracted the logic responsible for parsing the command line arguments from main and placed it in the parse_config function. Doing so helped us see that the query and file_path values were related, and that relationship should be conveyed in our code. We then added a Config struct to name the related purpose of query and file_path and to be able to return the valuesâ€™ names as struct field names from the parse_config function.

è‡³æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å·²å°†å‚æ•°è§£æé€»è¾‘ä» main æå–åˆ° parse_config å‡½æ•°ã€‚è¿™è®©æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹åˆ° query å’Œ file_path çš„å…³è”æ€§åº”ä½“ç°åœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­ã€‚æ¥ç€æ·»åŠ  Config ç»“æ„ä½“å‘½åå…¶å…³è”ç›®çš„ï¼Œå¹¶ä» parse_config è¿”å›å­—æ®µåã€‚

So now that the purpose of the parse_config function is to create a Config instance, we can change parse_config from a plain function to a function named new that is associated with the Config struct. Making this change will make the code more idiomatic. We can create instances of types in the standard library, such as String, by calling String::new. Similarly, by changing parse_config into a new function associated with Config, weâ€™ll be able to create instances of Config by calling Config::new. Listing 12-7 shows the changes we need to make.

æ—¢ç„¶ parse_config çš„ç›®çš„æ˜¯åˆ›å»º Config å®ä¾‹ï¼Œå¯å°†å…¶ä»æ™®é€šå‡½æ•°æ”¹ä¸ºä¸ Config ç»“æ„ä½“å…³è”çš„ new å‡½æ•°ã€‚æ­¤å˜æ›´ä½¿ä»£ç æ›´ç¬¦åˆ Rust æƒ¯ä¾‹ã€‚åˆ›å»ºæ ‡å‡†åº“ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ Stringï¼‰çš„å®ä¾‹å¯è°ƒç”¨ String::newã€‚ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œå°† parse_config æ”¹ä¸º Config çš„å…³è”å‡½æ•° new åï¼Œå¯é€šè¿‡ Config::new åˆ›å»ºå®ä¾‹ã€‚æ¸…å• 12-7 å±•ç¤ºäº†éœ€è¦åšçš„æ›´æ”¹ã€‚

Weâ€™ve updated main where we were calling parse_config to instead call Config::new. Weâ€™ve changed the name of parse_config to new and moved it within an impl block, which associates the new function with Config. Try compiling this code again to make sure it works.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°† main ä¸­è°ƒç”¨ parse_config çš„åœ°æ–¹æ”¹ä¸ºè°ƒç”¨ Config::newã€‚æŠŠ parse_config é‡å‘½åä¸º new å¹¶ç§»è‡³ impl å—å†…ï¼Œä½¿ new å‡½æ•°ä¸ Config å…³è”ã€‚è¯·å†æ¬¡ç¼–è¯‘æ­¤ä»£ç ç¡®ä¿å…¶å·¥ä½œã€‚

Fixing the Error Handling ä¿®å¤é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†

Now weâ€™ll work on fixing our error handling. Recall that attempting to access the values in the args vector at index 1 or index 2 will cause the program to panic if the vector contains fewer than three items. Try running the program without any arguments; it will look like this:

ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬æ¥ä¿®å¤é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ã€‚å›æƒ³ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œè‹¥å‘é‡åŒ…å«å°‘äºä¸‰é¡¹æ—¶è®¿é—®ç´¢å¼• 1 æˆ– 2 ä¼šå¯¼è‡´ç¨‹åº panicã€‚å°è¯•ä¸å¸¦å‚æ•°è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:27:21:
index out of bounds: the len is 1 but the index is 1
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

The line index out of bounds: the len is 1 but the index is 1 is an error message intended for programmers. It wonâ€™t help our end users understand what they should do instead. Letâ€™s fix that now.

index out of bounds: the len is 1 but the index is 1 è¿™æ¡é¢å‘ç¨‹åºå‘˜çš„æ¶ˆæ¯å¯¹ç»ˆç«¯ç”¨æˆ·æ— å¸®åŠ©ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä¿®å¤å®ƒã€‚

Improving the Error Message æ”¹è¿›é”™è¯¯æ¶ˆæ¯

In Listing 12-8, we add a check in the new function that will verify that the slice is long enough before accessing index 1 and index 2. If the slice isnâ€™t long enough, the program panics and displays a better error message.

åœ¨æ¸…å• 12-8 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ new å‡½æ•°æ·»åŠ æ£€æŸ¥ï¼Œç¡®ä¿åœ¨è®¿é—®ç´¢å¼• 1 å’Œ 2 å‰åˆ‡ç‰‡è¶³å¤Ÿé•¿ã€‚è‹¥é•¿åº¦ä¸è¶³ï¼Œç¨‹åº panic å¹¶æ˜¾ç¤ºæ›´å¥½çš„é”™è¯¯æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

This code is similar to the Guess::new function we wrote in Listing 9-13, where we called panic! when the value argument was out of the range of valid values. Instead of checking for a range of values here, weâ€™re checking that the length of args is at least 3 and the rest of the function can operate under the assumption that this condition has been met. If args has fewer than three items, this condition will be true, and we call the panic! macro to end the program immediately.

æ­¤ä»£ç ç±»ä¼¼æ¸…å• 9-13 çš„ Guess::new å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆå½“ value å‚æ•°è¶…å‡ºæœ‰æ•ˆèŒƒå›´æ—¶è°ƒç”¨ panic!ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™é‡Œä¸æ£€æŸ¥å€¼èŒƒå›´ï¼Œè€Œæ£€æŸ¥ args é•¿åº¦æ˜¯å¦è‡³å°‘ä¸º 3ï¼Œå‡½æ•°å…¶ä½™éƒ¨åˆ†å¯åŸºäºæ­¤æ¡ä»¶è¿è¡Œã€‚è‹¥ args å°‘äºä¸‰é¡¹ï¼Œæ­¤æ¡ä»¶ä¸ºçœŸï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ panic! å®ç«‹å³ç»ˆæ­¢ç¨‹åºã€‚

With these extra few lines of code in new, letâ€™s run the program without any arguments again to see what the error looks like now:

åœ¨ new ä¸­æ·»åŠ è¿™å‡ è¡Œåï¼Œå†æ¬¡ä¸å¸¦å‚æ•°è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºæŸ¥çœ‹é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep`

thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:26:13:
not enough arguments
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

This output is better: we now have a reasonable error message. However, we also have extraneous information we donâ€™t want to give to our users. Perhaps the technique we used in Listing 9-13 isnâ€™t the best one to use here: a call to panic! is more appropriate for a programming problem than a usage problem, as discussed in Chapter 9. Instead, weâ€™ll use the other technique you learned about in Chapter 9â€”returning a Result that indicates either success or an error.

æ­¤è¾“å‡ºæ›´åˆç†ï¼Œä½†ä»æœ‰å†—ä½™ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚æ¸…å• 9-13 çš„æŠ€æœ¯å¯èƒ½ä¸é€‚ç”¨ï¼šå¦‚ç¬¬ 9 ç« æ‰€è¿°ï¼Œpanic! æ›´é€‚åˆç¼–ç¨‹é—®é¢˜è€Œéç”¨æ³•é—®é¢˜ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ”¹ç”¨ç¬¬ 9 ç« çš„å¦ä¸€æŠ€æœ¯â€”â€”è¿”å›è¡¨ç¤ºæˆåŠŸæˆ–é”™è¯¯çš„ Resultã€‚

Returning a Result Instead of Calling panic! è¿”å› Result è€Œéè°ƒç”¨ panic!

We can instead return a Result value that will contain a Config instance in the successful case and will describe the problem in the error case. Weâ€™re also going to change the function name from new to build because many programmers expect new functions to never fail. When Config::build is communicating to main, we can use the Result type to signal there was a problem. Then we can change main to convert an Err variant into a more practical error for our users without the surrounding text about thread 'main' and RUST_BACKTRACE that a call to panic! causes.

æˆ‘ä»¬æ”¹ä¸ºè¿”å› Resultï¼ŒæˆåŠŸæ—¶åŒ…å« Config å®ä¾‹ï¼Œé”™è¯¯æ—¶æè¿°é—®é¢˜ã€‚åŒæ—¶å°†å‡½æ•°åä» new æ”¹ä¸º buildï¼Œå› ä¸º[note]è®¸å¤šå¼€å‘è€…æœŸæœ› new å‡½æ•°æ°¸ä¸å¤±è´¥ã€‚å½“ Config::build ä¸ main é€šä¿¡æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ç”¨ Result ç±»å‹è¡¨ç¤ºé—®é¢˜ã€‚æ¥ç€ä¿®æ”¹ mainï¼Œå°† Err å˜ä½“è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå¯¹ç”¨æˆ·æ›´å‹å¥½çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼Œé¿å… panic! å¼•èµ·çš„ thread 'main' å’Œ RUST_BACKTRACE ç­‰æ–‡æœ¬ã€‚

Listing 12-9 shows the changes we need to make to the return value of the function weâ€™re now calling Config::build and the body of the function needed to return a Result. Note that this wonâ€™t compile until we update main as well, which weâ€™ll do in the next listing.

æ¸…å• 12-9 å±•ç¤ºäº†éœ€å¯¹ Config::build è¿”å›å€¼å’Œå‡½æ•°ä½“åšçš„æ›´æ”¹ï¼ˆè¿”å› Resultï¼‰ã€‚æ³¨æ„åœ¨æ›´æ–° mainï¼ˆä¸‹ä¸ªæ¸…å•ï¼‰å‰æ­¤ä»£ç æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

Our build function returns a Result with a Config instance in the success case and a string literal in the error case. Our error values will always be string literals that have the 'static lifetime.

build å‡½æ•°è¿”å› Resultï¼ŒæˆåŠŸæ—¶åŒ…å« Config å®ä¾‹ï¼Œé”™è¯¯æ—¶ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—é¢é‡ï¼ˆå…·æœ‰ 'static ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸï¼‰ã€‚

Weâ€™ve made two changes in the body of the function: instead of calling panic! when the user doesnâ€™t pass enough arguments, we now return an Err value, and weâ€™ve wrapped the Config return value in an Ok. These changes make the function conform to its new type signature.

å‡½æ•°ä½“å†…æœ‰ä¸¤å¤„æ”¹åŠ¨ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æœªæä¾›è¶³å¤Ÿå‚æ•°æ—¶ä¸å†è°ƒç”¨ panic! è€Œæ˜¯è¿”å› Err å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶å°† Config è¿”å›å€¼åŒ…è£…åœ¨ Ok ä¸­ã€‚è¿™äº›å˜æ›´ä½¿å‡½æ•°ç¬¦åˆæ–°ç­¾åã€‚

Returning an Err value from Config::build allows the main function to handle the Result value returned from the build function and exit the process more cleanly in the error case.

ä» Config::build è¿”å› Err å…è®¸ main å¤„ç†è¿”å›çš„ Resultï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨é”™è¯¯æ—¶æ›´æ¸…æ™°åœ°é€€å‡ºè¿›ç¨‹ã€‚

Calling Config::build and Handling Errors è°ƒç”¨ Config::build å¹¶å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯

To handle the error case and print a user-friendly message, we need to update main to handle the Result being returned by Config::build, as shown in Listing 12-10. Weâ€™ll also take the responsibility of exiting the command line tool with a nonzero error code away from panic! and instead implement it by hand. A nonzero exit status is a convention to signal to the process that called our program that the program exited with an error state.

ä¸ºå¤„ç†é”™è¯¯å¹¶æ‰“å°ç”¨æˆ·å‹å¥½æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œéœ€æ›´æ–° main å¤„ç† Config::build è¿”å›çš„ Resultï¼Œå¦‚æ¸…å• 12-10 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å°†æ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°ä»¥éé›¶é”™è¯¯ç é€€å‡ºçš„é€»è¾‘ï¼ˆè€Œéä¾èµ– panic!ï¼‰ã€‚éé›¶é€€å‡ºçŠ¶æ€æ˜¯å‘è°ƒç”¨è¿›ç¨‹è¡¨æ˜ç¨‹åºä»¥é”™è¯¯çŠ¶æ€ç»ˆæ­¢çš„çº¦å®šã€‚

In this listing, weâ€™ve used a method we havenâ€™t covered in detail yet: unwrap_or_else, which is defined on Result<T, E> by the standard library. Using unwrap_or_else allows us to define some custom, non-panic! error handling. If the Result is an Ok value, this methodâ€™s behavior is similar to unwrap: it returns the inner value that Ok is wrapping. However, if the value is an Err value, this method calls the code in the closure, which is an anonymous function we define and pass as an argument to unwrap_or_else. Weâ€™ll cover closures in more detail in Chapter 13. For now, you just need to know that unwrap_or_else will pass the inner value of the Err, which in this case is the static string "not enough arguments" that we added in Listing 12-9, to our closure in the argument err that appears between the vertical pipes. The code in the closure can then use the err value when it runs.

æ­¤æ¸…å•ä½¿ç”¨äº†æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸º Result<T, E> å®šä¹‰çš„ unwrap_or_else æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆå°šæœªè¯¦ç»†è®²è§£ï¼‰ã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•å…è®¸è‡ªå®šä¹‰é panic! çš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ï¼šè‹¥ Result æ˜¯ Ok å€¼ï¼Œå…¶è¡Œä¸ºç±»ä¼¼ unwrapâ€”â€”è¿”å› Ok åŒ…è£…çš„å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼›è‹¥æ˜¯ Err å€¼ï¼Œåˆ™è°ƒç”¨é—­åŒ…ï¼ˆä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°ä¼ é€’çš„åŒ¿åå‡½æ•°ï¼‰ä¸­çš„ä»£ç ã€‚ç¬¬ 13 ç« å°†æ·±å…¥è®²è§£é—­åŒ…ã€‚ç°åœ¨åªéœ€çŸ¥é“ï¼šunwrap_or_else ä¼šå°† Err çš„å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸ºæ¸…å• 12-9 æ·»åŠ çš„ "not enough arguments" é™æ€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼‰ä¼ é€’ç»™é—­åŒ…å‚æ•° errï¼ˆç«–çº¿é—´ï¼‰ã€‚é—­åŒ…ä»£ç è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¯ä½¿ç”¨ err å€¼ã€‚

Weâ€™ve added a new use line to bring process from the standard library into scope. The code in the closure that will be run in the error case is only two lines: we print the err value and then call process::exit. The process::exit function will stop the program immediately and return the number that was passed as the exit status code. This is similar to the panic!-based handling we used in Listing 12-8, but we no longer get all the extra output. Letâ€™s try it:

æˆ‘ä»¬æ·»åŠ äº† use è¡Œå°†æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ process å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚é”™è¯¯æƒ…å†µä¸‹çš„é—­åŒ…ä»£ç ä»…ä¸¤è¡Œï¼šæ‰“å° err å€¼å¹¶[note]è°ƒç”¨ process::exitã€‚è¯¥å‡½æ•°ä¼šç«‹å³åœæ­¢ç¨‹åºå¹¶è¿”å›ä¼ å…¥çš„é€€å‡ºçŠ¶æ€ç ã€‚è¿™ç±»ä¼¼æ¸…å• 12-8 åŸºäº panic! çš„å¤„ç†ï¼Œä½†ä¸å†æœ‰é¢å¤–è¾“å‡ºã€‚å°è¯•è¿è¡Œï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.48s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep`
Problem parsing arguments: not enough arguments

Great! This output is much friendlier for our users.

è¾“å‡ºå¯¹ç”¨æˆ·å‹å¥½å¤šäº†ï¼

Extracting Logic from the main Function ä» main æå–é€»è¾‘

Now that weâ€™ve finished refactoring the configuration parsing, letâ€™s turn to the programâ€™s logic. As we stated in â€œSeparation of Concerns for Binary Projectsâ€, weâ€™ll extract a function named run that will hold all the logic currently in the main function that isnâ€™t involved with setting up configuration or handling errors. When weâ€™re done, the main function will be concise and easy to verify by inspection, and weâ€™ll be able to write tests for all the other logic.

å®Œæˆé…ç½®è§£æçš„é‡æ„åï¼Œç°åœ¨å¤„ç†ç¨‹åºé€»è¾‘ã€‚å¦‚â€œäºŒè¿›åˆ¶é¡¹ç›®çš„èŒè´£åˆ†ç¦»â€æ‰€è¿°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æå–åä¸º run çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼ŒåŒ…å«å½“å‰ main ä¸­ä¸é…ç½®è®¾ç½®æˆ–é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†æ— å…³çš„æ‰€æœ‰é€»è¾‘ã€‚å®Œæˆåï¼Œmain å‡½æ•°å°†ç®€æ´æ˜“éªŒè¯ï¼Œå…¶ä»–é€»è¾‘å‡å¯æµ‹è¯•ã€‚

Listing 12-11 shows the small, incremental improvement of extracting a run function.

æ¸…å• 12-11 å±•ç¤ºäº†æå– run å‡½æ•°çš„æ¸è¿›æ”¹è¿›ã€‚

The run function now contains all the remaining logic from main, starting from reading the file. The run function takes the Config instance as an argument.

run å‡½æ•°ç°åœ¨åŒ…å«ä»æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–å¼€å§‹çš„ main æ‰€æœ‰å‰©ä½™é€»è¾‘ï¼Œå¹¶ä»¥ Config å®ä¾‹ä¸ºå‚æ•°ã€‚

Returning Errors from the run Function ä» run å‡½æ•°è¿”å›é”™è¯¯

With the remaining program logic separated into the run function, we can improve the error handling, as we did with Config::build in Listing 12-9. Instead of allowing the program to panic by calling expect, the run function will return a Result<T, E> when something goes wrong. This will let us further consolidate the logic around handling errors into main in a user-friendly way. Listing 12-12 shows the changes we need to make to the signature and body of run.

å°†å‰©ä½™é€»è¾‘åˆ†ç¦»åˆ° run å‡½æ•°åï¼Œå¯æ”¹è¿›é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼æ¸…å• 12-9 å¯¹ Config::build çš„æ”¹è¿›ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸å†é€šè¿‡ expect è°ƒç”¨å¼•å‘ panicï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è®© run åœ¨å‡ºé”™æ—¶è¿”å› Result<T, E>ã€‚è¿™è®©æˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½å°†é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†é€»è¾‘é›†ä¸­åˆ° mainï¼Œä»¥æ›´å‹å¥½çš„æ–¹å¼å¤„ç†ã€‚æ¸…å• 12-12 å±•ç¤ºäº†éœ€å¯¹ run ç­¾åå’Œå‡½æ•°ä½“åšçš„æ›´æ”¹ã€‚

Weâ€™ve made three significant changes here. First, we changed the return type of the run function to Result<(), Box<dyn Error>>. This function previously returned the unit type, (), and we keep that as the value returned in the Ok case.

æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è¿™é‡Œåšäº†ä¸‰å¤„é‡è¦çš„ä¿®æ”¹ã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°† run å‡½æ•°çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹æ›´æ”¹ä¸º Result<(), Box<dyn Error>>ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ä¹‹å‰è¿”å›çš„æ˜¯å•ä½ç±»å‹ ()ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¿ç•™äº†åœ¨ Ok æƒ…å†µä¸‹è¿”å›çš„å€¼ã€‚

For the error type, we used the trait object Box<dyn Error> (and weâ€™ve brought std::error::Error into scope with a use statement at the top). Weâ€™ll cover trait objects in Chapter 18. For now, just know that Box<dyn Error> means the function will return a type that implements the Error trait, but we donâ€™t have to specify what particular type the return value will be. This gives us flexibility to return error values that may be of different types in different error cases. The dyn keyword is short for dynamic.

å¯¹äºé”™è¯¯ç±»å‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨äº† ç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡ Box<dyn Error>ï¼ˆå¹¶ä¸”æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨é¡¶éƒ¨é€šè¿‡ use è¯­å¥å¼•å…¥äº† std::error::Errorï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬18ç« è®¨è®ºç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡ã€‚ç°åœ¨ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦çŸ¥é“ Box<dyn Error> è¡¨ç¤ºå‡½æ•°å°†è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªå®ç°äº† Error ç‰¹å¾çš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸éœ€è¦æŒ‡å®šè¿”å›å€¼çš„å…·ä½“ç±»å‹ã€‚è¿™è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥çµæ´»åœ°è¿”å›ä¸åŒé”™è¯¯æƒ…å†µå¯èƒ½å‡ºç°çš„ä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„é”™è¯¯å€¼ã€‚dyn å…³é”®å­—æ˜¯ åŠ¨æ€ çš„ç¼©å†™ã€‚

Second, weâ€™ve removed the call to expect in favor of the ? operator, as we talked about in Chapter 9. Rather than panic! on an error, ? will return the error value from the current function for the caller to handle.

ç¬¬äºŒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åˆ é™¤äº†å¯¹ expect çš„è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œæ”¹ç”¨äº† ? è¿ç®—ç¬¦ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬9ç« è®¨è®ºçš„é‚£æ ·ã€‚ä¸å…¶åœ¨å‡ºé”™æ—¶è°ƒç”¨ panic!ï¼Œ? ä¼šå°†é”™è¯¯å€¼ä»å½“å‰å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ï¼Œä¾›è°ƒç”¨è€…å¤„ç†ã€‚

Third, the run function now returns an Ok value in the success case. Weâ€™ve declared the run functionâ€™s success type as () in the signature, which means we need to wrap the unit type value in the Ok value. This Ok(()) syntax might look a bit strange at first, but using () like this is the idiomatic way to indicate that weâ€™re calling run for its side effects only; it doesnâ€™t return a value we need.

ç¬¬ä¸‰ï¼Œrun å‡½æ•°ç°åœ¨åœ¨æˆåŠŸçš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ª Ok å€¼ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨å‡½æ•°ç­¾åä¸­å°† run å‡½æ•°çš„æˆåŠŸç±»å‹å£°æ˜ä¸º ()ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å°†å•ä½ç±»å‹å€¼åŒ…è£¹åœ¨ Ok ä¸­ã€‚è¿™ä¸ª Ok(()) è¯­æ³•èµ·åˆå¯èƒ½çœ‹èµ·æ¥æœ‰ç‚¹å¥‡æ€ªï¼Œä½†åƒè¿™æ ·ä½¿ç”¨ () æ˜¯è¡¨ç¤ºæˆ‘ä»¬ä»…ä»…æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å‰¯ä½œç”¨è°ƒç”¨ run çš„æƒ¯ç”¨æ–¹å¼ï¼›å®ƒå¹¶æ²¡æœ‰è¿”å›æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„å€¼ã€‚

When you run this code, it will compile but will display a warning:

è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç æ—¶ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿè­¦å‘Šï¼š

$ cargo run -- the poem.txt
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
warning: unused `Result` that must be used
  --> src/main.rs:19:5
   |
19 |     run(config);
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^
   |
   = note: this `Result` may be an `Err` variant, which should be handled
   = note: `#[warn(unused_must_use)]` on by default
help: use `let _ = ...` to ignore the resulting value
   |
19 |     let _ = run(config);
   |     +++++++

warning: `minigrep` (bin "minigrep") generated 1 warning
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.71s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep the poem.txt`
Searching for the
In file poem.txt
With text:
I'm nobody! Who are you?
Are you nobody, too?
Then there's a pair of us - don't tell!
They'd banish us, you know.

How dreary to be somebody!
How public, like a frog
To tell your name the livelong day
To an admiring bog!

Rust tells us that our code ignored the Result value and the Result value might indicate that an error occurred. But weâ€™re not checking to see whether or not there was an error, and the compiler reminds us that we probably meant to have some error-handling code here! Letâ€™s rectify that problem now.

Rust å‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ä»£ç å¿½ç•¥äº† Result å€¼ï¼Œè€Œ Result å€¼å¯èƒ½è¡¨æ˜å‘ç”Ÿäº†é”™è¯¯ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘ä»¬æ²¡æœ‰æ£€æŸ¥æ˜¯å¦å‘ç”Ÿäº†é”™è¯¯ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨æé†’æˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½åœ¨è¿™é‡Œæ¼æ‰äº†é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ä»£ç ï¼è®©æˆ‘ä»¬ç°åœ¨æ¥è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ã€‚

Handling Errors Returned from run in main åœ¨ main ä¸­å¤„ç† run è¿”å›çš„é”™è¯¯

Weâ€™ll check for errors and handle them using a technique similar to one we used with Config::build in Listing 12-10, but with a slight difference:

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç”¨ç±»ä¼¼æ¸…å• 12-10 å¤„ç† Config::build çš„æŠ€æœ¯å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä½†ç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒï¼š

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::env;
use std::error::Error;
use std::fs;
use std::process;

fn main() {
    // --snip--

    let args: Vec<String> = env::args().collect();

    let config = Config::build(&args).unwrap_or_else(|err| {
        println!("Problem parsing arguments: {err}");
        process::exit(1);
    });

    println!("Searching for {}", config.query);
    println!("In file {}", config.file_path);

    if let Err(e) = run(config) {
        println!("Application error: {e}");
        process::exit(1);
    }
}

fn run(config: Config) -> Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> {
    let contents = fs::read_to_string(config.file_path)?;

    println!("With text:\n{contents}");

    Ok(())
}

struct Config {
    query: String,
    file_path: String,
}

impl Config {
    fn build(args: &[String]) -> Result<Config, &'static str> {
        if args.len() < 3 {
            return Err("not enough arguments");
        }

        let query = args[1].clone();
        let file_path = args[2].clone();

        Ok(Config { query, file_path })
    }
}

We use if let rather than unwrap_or_else to check whether run returns an Err value and to call process::exit(1) if it does. The run function doesnâ€™t return a value that we want to unwrap in the same way that Config::build returns the Config instance. Because run returns () in the success case, we only care about detecting an error, so we donâ€™t need unwrap_or_else to return the unwrapped value, which would only be ().

è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨ if let è€Œé unwrap_or_else æ£€æŸ¥ run æ˜¯å¦è¿”å› Errï¼Œæ˜¯åˆ™è°ƒç”¨ process::exit(1)ã€‚å› ä¸º run æˆåŠŸæ—¶è¿”å› ()ï¼ˆè€Œ Config::build è¿”å› Config å®ä¾‹ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªå…³å¿ƒæ˜¯å¦å‡ºé”™ï¼Œæ— éœ€åƒ unwrap_or_else é‚£æ ·è§£åŒ…å€¼ï¼ˆè§£åŒ…ç»“æœåªä¼šæ˜¯ ()ï¼‰ã€‚

The bodies of the if let and the unwrap_or_else functions are the same in both cases: we print the error and exit.

if let å’Œ unwrap_or_else çš„å‡½æ•°ä½“ç›¸åŒï¼šæ‰“å°é”™è¯¯å¹¶é€€å‡ºã€‚

Splitting Code into a Library Crate å°†ä»£ç æ‹†åˆ†ä¸ºåº“ crate

Our minigrep project is looking good so far! Now weâ€™ll split the src/main.rs file and put some code into the src/lib.rs file. That way, we can test the code and have a src/main.rs file with fewer responsibilities.

ç›®å‰ minigrep é¡¹ç›®è¿›å±•é¡ºåˆ©ï¼ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ‹†åˆ† src/main.rs æ–‡ä»¶ï¼ŒæŠŠéƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç æ”¾å…¥ src/lib.rsã€‚è¿™æ ·å³å¯æµ‹è¯•ä»£ç ï¼Œå¹¶è®© src/main.rs èŒè´£æ›´å°‘ã€‚

Letâ€™s define the code responsible for searching text in src/lib.rs rather than in src/main.rs, which will let us (or anyone else using our minigrep library) call the searching function from more contexts than our minigrep binary.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ src/lib.rs ä¸­å®šä¹‰æ–‡æœ¬æœç´¢é€»è¾‘ï¼ˆè€Œé src/main.rsï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼ˆæˆ–å…¶ä»–ä½¿ç”¨ minigrep åº“çš„äººï¼‰å°±èƒ½åœ¨æ›´å¤šä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­è°ƒç”¨æœç´¢å‡½æ•°ã€‚

First, letâ€™s define the search function signature in src/lib.rs as shown in Listing 12-13, with a body that calls the unimplemented! macro. Weâ€™ll explain the signature in more detail when we fill in the implementation.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ src/lib.rs ä¸­å®šä¹‰ search å‡½æ•°ç­¾åï¼ˆå¦‚æ¸…å• 12-13ï¼‰ï¼Œå…¶å‡½æ•°ä½“è°ƒç”¨ unimplemented! å®ã€‚å®ç°æ—¶ä¼šè¯¦ç»†è§£é‡Šç­¾åã€‚

Weâ€™ve used the pub keyword on the function definition to designate search as part of our library crateâ€™s public API. We now have a library crate that we can use from our binary crate and that we can test!

åœ¨å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ pub å…³é”®å­—å°† search è®¾ä¸ºåº“ crate å…¬å…± API çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚ç°åœ¨æœ‰äº†å¯ä»äºŒè¿›åˆ¶ crate ä½¿ç”¨ä¸”å¯æµ‹è¯•çš„åº“ crateï¼

Now we need to bring the code defined in src/lib.rs into the scope of the binary crate in src/main.rs and call it, as shown in Listing 12-14.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥éœ€å°† src/lib.rs ä¸­çš„ä»£ç å¼•å…¥äºŒè¿›åˆ¶ crateï¼ˆåœ¨ src/main.rs ä¸­ï¼‰å¹¶è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œå¦‚æ¸…å• 12-14 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

We add a use minigrep::search line to bring the search function from the library crate into the binary crateâ€™s scope. Then, in the run function, rather than printing out the contents of the file, we call the search function and pass the config.query value and contents as arguments. Then run will use a for loop to print each line returned from search that matched the query. This is also a good time to remove the println! calls in the main function that displayed the query and the file path so that our program only prints the search results (if no errors occur).

æ·»åŠ  use minigrep::search å°†åº“ crate çš„ search å‡½æ•°å¼•å…¥äºŒè¿›åˆ¶ crate ä½œç”¨åŸŸã€‚æ¥ç€åœ¨ run å‡½æ•°ä¸­ï¼Œä¸å†æ‰“å°æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è°ƒç”¨ search å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆä¼ å…¥ config.query å’Œ contents å‚æ•°ï¼‰ã€‚run å‡½æ•°é€šè¿‡ for å¾ªç¯æ‰“å° search è¿”å›çš„æ¯ä¸ªåŒ¹é…è¡Œã€‚åŒæ—¶ç§»é™¤ main ä¸­æ‰“å°æŸ¥è¯¢å’Œæ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„çš„ println! è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œä½¿ç¨‹åºä»…è¾“å‡ºæœç´¢ç»“æœï¼ˆæ— é”™è¯¯æ—¶ï¼‰ã€‚

Note that the search function will be collecting all the results into a vector it returns before any printing happens. This implementation could be slow to display results when searching large files because results arenâ€™t printed as theyâ€™re found; weâ€™ll discuss a possible way to fix this using iterators in Chapter 13.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šsearch å‡½æ•°ä¼šåœ¨æ‰“å°å‰å°†æ‰€æœ‰ç»“æœæ”¶é›†åˆ°è¿”å›çš„å‘é‡ä¸­ã€‚å½“æœç´¢å¤§æ–‡ä»¶æ—¶ï¼Œæ­¤å®ç°å¯èƒ½å› æ— æ³•å®æ—¶æ‰“å°è€Œæ˜¾æ…¢ï¼›ç¬¬ 13 ç« å°†è®¨è®ºç”¨è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¿®å¤æ­¤é—®é¢˜çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Whew! That was a lot of work, but weâ€™ve set ourselves up for success in the future. Now itâ€™s much easier to handle errors, and weâ€™ve made the code more modular. Almost all of our work will be done in src/lib.rs from here on out.

å“‡ï¼è™½ç„¶å·¥ä½œé‡å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ºæœªæ¥æˆåŠŸå¥ å®šäº†åŸºç¡€ã€‚ç°åœ¨é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†æ›´ç®€å•ï¼Œä»£ç ä¹Ÿæ›´æ¨¡å—åŒ–ã€‚æ­¤åå‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰å·¥ä½œéƒ½å°†åœ¨ src/lib.rs ä¸­å®Œæˆã€‚

Letâ€™s take advantage of this newfound modularity by doing something that would have been difficult with the old code but is easy with the new code: weâ€™ll write some tests!

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬åˆ©ç”¨æ–°è·å¾—çš„æ¨¡å—åŒ–ä¼˜åŠ¿åšäº›æ—§ä»£ç éš¾ä»¥å®ç°çš„äº‹ï¼šç¼–å†™æµ‹è¯•ï¼

Developing the Libraryâ€™s Functionality with Test-Driven Development ä½¿ç”¨æµ‹è¯•é©±åŠ¨å¼€å‘å®Œå–„åº“åŠŸèƒ½

Now that we have the search logic in src/lib.rs separate from the main function, itâ€™s much easier to write tests for the core functionality of our code. We can call functions directly with various arguments and check return values without having to call our binary from the command line.

ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬å·²ç»å°† src/lib.rs ä¸­çš„æœç´¢é€»è¾‘ä¸ main å‡½æ•°åˆ†ç¦»ï¼Œè¿™è®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ›´å®¹æ˜“ä¸ºä»£ç çš„æ ¸å¿ƒåŠŸèƒ½ç¼–å†™æµ‹è¯•ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨å„ç§å‚æ•°è°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•°å¹¶æ£€æŸ¥è¿”å›å€¼ï¼Œè€Œæ— éœ€ä»å‘½ä»¤è¡Œè°ƒç”¨äºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚

In this section, weâ€™ll add the searching logic to the minigrep program using the test-driven development (TDD) process with the following steps:

æœ¬èŠ‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é€šè¿‡æµ‹è¯•é©±åŠ¨å¼€å‘ï¼ˆTDDï¼‰æµç¨‹å‘ minigrep ç¨‹åºæ·»åŠ æœç´¢é€»è¾‘ï¼Œæ­¥éª¤å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

  • Write a test that fails and run it to make sure it fails for the reason you expect.
  • ç¼–å†™ä¸€ä¸ªå¤±è´¥çš„æµ‹è¯•å¹¶è¿è¡Œå®ƒï¼Œç¡®ä¿å®ƒå› é¢„æœŸåŸå› å¤±è´¥ã€‚
  • Write or modify just enough code to make the new test pass.
  • ç¼–å†™æˆ–ä¿®æ”¹æœ€å°‘é‡çš„ä»£ç ä½¿æ–°æµ‹è¯•é€šè¿‡ã€‚
  • Refactor the code you just added or changed and make sure the tests continue to pass.
  • é‡æ„åˆšæ·»åŠ æˆ–ä¿®æ”¹çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œå¹¶ç¡®ä¿æµ‹è¯•ç»§ç»­é€šè¿‡ã€‚
  • Repeat from step 1!
  • ä»æ­¥éª¤1å¼€å§‹é‡å¤ï¼

Though itâ€™s just one of many ways to write software, TDD can help drive code design. Writing the test before you write the code that makes the test pass helps to maintain high test coverage throughout the process.

è™½ç„¶è¿™åªæ˜¯ä¼—å¤šè½¯ä»¶å¼€å‘æ–¹æ³•ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œä½†TDDæœ‰åŠ©äºé©±åŠ¨ä»£ç è®¾è®¡ã€‚åœ¨ç¼–å†™ä½¿æµ‹è¯•é€šè¿‡çš„ä»£ç ä¹‹å‰å…ˆç¼–å†™æµ‹è¯•ï¼Œæœ‰åŠ©äºåœ¨æ•´ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ä¿æŒé«˜æµ‹è¯•è¦†ç›–ç‡ã€‚

Weâ€™ll test-drive the implementation of the functionality that will actually do the searching for the query string in the file contents and produce a list of lines that match the query. Weâ€™ll add this functionality in a function called search.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é€šè¿‡æµ‹è¯•é©±åŠ¨çš„æ–¹å¼å®ç°å®é™…åŠŸèƒ½ï¼šåœ¨æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹ä¸­æœç´¢æŸ¥è¯¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹¶ç”ŸæˆåŒ¹é…æŸ¥è¯¢çš„è¡Œåˆ—è¡¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªåä¸º search çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­æ·»åŠ æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Writing a Failing Test ç¼–å†™å¤±è´¥æµ‹è¯•

In src/lib.rs, weâ€™ll add a tests module with a test function, as we did in Chapter 11. The test function specifies the behavior we want the search function to have: it will take a query and the text to search, and it will return only the lines from the text that contain the query. Listing 12-15 shows this test.

åœ¨ src/lib.rs ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ·»åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å«æµ‹è¯•å‡½æ•°çš„ tests æ¨¡å—ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¬¬11ç« æ‰€åšï¼‰ã€‚è¯¥æµ‹è¯•å‡½æ•°æ˜ç¡®äº†æœŸæœ› search å‡½æ•°å…·å¤‡çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼šå®ƒæ¥æ”¶æŸ¥è¯¢è¯å’Œå¾…æœç´¢æ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œä»…è¿”å›æ–‡æœ¬ä¸­åŒ…å«æŸ¥è¯¢è¯çš„è¡Œã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-15å±•ç¤ºäº†è¿™ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•ã€‚

This test searches for the string "duct". The text weâ€™re searching is three lines, only one of which contains "duct" (note that the backslash after the opening double quote tells Rust not to put a newline character at the beginning of the contents of this string literal). We assert that the value returned from the search function contains only the line we expect.

è¯¥æµ‹è¯•æœç´¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸² "duct"ã€‚å¾…æœç´¢æ–‡æœ¬æœ‰ä¸‰è¡Œï¼Œå…¶ä¸­åªæœ‰ä¸€è¡ŒåŒ…å« "duct"ï¼ˆæ³¨æ„[note]å¼€å¤´åŒå¼•å·åçš„åæ–œæ å‘Šè¯‰ Rust ä¸è¦åœ¨æ­¤å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å­—é¢é‡å¼€å¤´æ·»åŠ æ¢è¡Œç¬¦ï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æ–­è¨€ search å‡½æ•°è¿”å›çš„å€¼ä»…åŒ…å«é¢„æœŸçš„é‚£ä¸€è¡Œã€‚

If we run this test, it will currently fail because the unimplemented! macro panics with the message â€œnot implementedâ€. In accordance with TDD principles, weâ€™ll take a small step of adding just enough code to get the test to not panic when calling the function by defining the search function to always return an empty vector, as shown in Listing 12-16. Then the test should compile and fail because an empty vector doesnâ€™t match a vector containing the line "safe, fast, productive."

å¦‚æœè¿è¡Œæ­¤æµ‹è¯•ï¼Œå®ƒå½“å‰ä¼šå¤±è´¥ï¼Œå› ä¸º unimplemented! å®ä¼šå› â€œæœªå®ç°â€œçš„æ¶ˆæ¯è€Œææ…Œï¼ˆpanicï¼‰ã€‚éµå¾ªTDDåŸåˆ™ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†é‡‡å–ä¸€ä¸ªå°æ­¥éª¤ï¼šæ·»åŠ åˆšå¥½è¶³å¤Ÿçš„ä»£ç ä½¿å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨æ—¶ä¸ææ…Œï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-16æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œå°† search å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ä¸ºå§‹ç»ˆè¿”å›ç©ºå‘é‡ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶æµ‹è¯•åº”èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ä½†ä¼šå¤±è´¥ï¼Œå› ä¸ºç©ºå‘é‡ä¸åŒ…å«è¡Œ "safe, fast, productive." çš„å‘é‡ä¸åŒ¹é…ã€‚

Now letâ€™s discuss why we need to define an explicit lifetime 'a in the signature of search and use that lifetime with the contents argument and the return value. Recall in Chapter 10 that the lifetime parameters specify which argument lifetime is connected to the lifetime of the return value. In this case, we indicate that the returned vector should contain string slices that reference slices of the argument contents (rather than the argument query).

ç°åœ¨è®¨è®ºä¸ºä½•éœ€è¦åœ¨ search ç­¾åä¸­å®šä¹‰æ˜¾å¼ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸ 'aï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ contents å‚æ•°å’Œè¿”å›å€¼ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨å®ƒã€‚å›é¡¾ç¬¬10ç« ï¼Œç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸå‚æ•°æŒ‡å®šå“ªä¸ªå‚æ•°ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸä¸è¿”å›å€¼ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸç›¸å…³è”ã€‚æ­¤å¤„æˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‡æ˜è¿”å›çš„å‘é‡åº”åŒ…å«å¼•ç”¨å‚æ•° contentsï¼ˆè€Œéå‚æ•° queryï¼‰åˆ‡ç‰‡çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ã€‚

In other words, we tell Rust that the data returned by the search function will live as long as the data passed into the search function in the contents argument. This is important! The data referenced by a slice needs to be valid for the reference to be valid; if the compiler assumes weâ€™re making string slices of query rather than contents, it will do its safety checking incorrectly.

æ¢å¥è¯è¯´ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å‘Šè¯‰ Rustï¼šsearch å‡½æ•°è¿”å›çš„æ•°æ®å­˜æ´»æ—¶é—´å°†ä¸ä¼ å…¥ search å‡½æ•°çš„ contents å‚æ•°æ•°æ®ä¸€æ ·é•¿ã€‚è¿™å¾ˆé‡è¦ï¼åˆ‡ç‰‡å¼•ç”¨çš„æ•°æ®å¿…é¡»æœ‰æ•ˆï¼Œå¼•ç”¨æ‰èƒ½æœ‰æ•ˆï¼›è‹¥ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å‡å®šæˆ‘ä»¬åˆ›å»ºçš„æ˜¯ query è€Œé contents çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œå…¶å®‰å…¨æ£€æŸ¥å°†å‡ºé”™ã€‚

If we forget the lifetime annotations and try to compile this function, weâ€™ll get this error:

å¦‚æœå¿˜è®°ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸæ³¨è§£å°è¯•ç¼–è¯‘æ­¤å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå°†å¾—åˆ°ä»¥ä¸‹é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo build
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> src/lib.rs:1:51
  |
1 | pub fn search(query: &str, contents: &str) -> Vec<&str> {
  |                      ----            ----         ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
  = help: this function's return type contains a borrowed value, but the signature does not say whether it is borrowed from `query` or `contents`
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
1 | pub fn search<'a>(query: &'a str, contents: &'a str) -> Vec<&'a str> {
  |              ++++         ++                 ++              ++

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0106`.
error: could not compile `minigrep` (lib) due to 1 previous error

Rust canâ€™t know which of the two parameters we need for the output, so we need to tell it explicitly. Note that the help text suggests specifying the same lifetime parameter for all the parameters and the output type, which is incorrect! Because contents is the parameter that contains all of our text and we want to return the parts of that text that match, we know contents is the only parameter that should be connected to the return value using the lifetime syntax.

Rust æ— æ³•ç¡®å®šè¾“å‡ºéœ€è¦å“ªä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼Œå› æ­¤éœ€è¦æ˜¾å¼å‘ŠçŸ¥ã€‚æ³¨æ„å¸®åŠ©æ–‡æœ¬å»ºè®®ä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰å‚æ•°å’Œè¾“å‡ºç±»å‹æŒ‡å®šç›¸åŒçš„ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸå‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯é”™è¯¯çš„ï¼ç”±äº contents æ˜¯åŒ…å«å…¨éƒ¨æ–‡æœ¬çš„å‚æ•°ï¼Œä¸”æˆ‘ä»¬è¦è¿”å›åŒ¹é…è¯¥æ–‡æœ¬çš„éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå› æ­¤åªæœ‰ contents åº”é€šè¿‡ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸè¯­æ³•ä¸è¿”å›å€¼å…³è”ã€‚

Other programming languages donâ€™t require you to connect arguments to return values in the signature, but this practice will get easier over time. You might want to compare this example with the examples in the â€œValidating References with Lifetimesâ€ section in Chapter 10.

å…¶ä»–ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ä¸è¦æ±‚åœ¨ç­¾åä¸­è¿æ¥å‚æ•°ä¸è¿”å›å€¼ï¼Œä½†è¿™ç§å®è·µä¼šéšæ—¶é—´æ¨ç§»å˜å¾—å®¹æ˜“ã€‚å»ºè®®å°†æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸ç¬¬10ç« â€œä½¿ç”¨ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸéªŒè¯å¼•ç”¨â€œéƒ¨åˆ†çš„ç¤ºä¾‹è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒã€‚

Writing Code to Pass the Test ç¼–å†™é€šè¿‡æµ‹è¯•çš„ä»£ç 

Currently, our test is failing because we always return an empty vector. To fix that and implement search, our program needs to follow these steps:

å½“å‰æµ‹è¯•å› å§‹ç»ˆè¿”å›ç©ºå‘é‡è€Œå¤±è´¥ã€‚ä¸ºå®ç° search åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œç¨‹åºéœ€éµå¾ªä»¥ä¸‹æ­¥éª¤ï¼š

  • Iterate through each line of the contents.
  • éå†å†…å®¹çš„æ¯ä¸€è¡Œã€‚
  • Check whether the line contains our query string.
  • æ£€æŸ¥è¡Œæ˜¯å¦åŒ…å«æŸ¥è¯¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚
  • If it does, add it to the list of values weâ€™re returning.
  • è‹¥åŒ…å«ï¼Œåˆ™å°†å…¶æ·»åŠ åˆ°è¿”å›çš„å€¼åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­ã€‚
  • If it doesnâ€™t, do nothing.
  • è‹¥ä¸åŒ…å«ï¼Œåˆ™ä¸æ‰§è¡Œæ“ä½œã€‚
  • Return the list of results that match.
  • è¿”å›åŒ¹é…çš„ç»“æœåˆ—è¡¨ã€‚

Letâ€™s work through each step, starting with iterating through lines.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€æ­¥å®ç°ï¼Œä»éå†è¡Œå¼€å§‹ã€‚

Iterating Through Lines with the lines Method ä½¿ç”¨ lines æ–¹æ³•é€è¡Œè¿­ä»£

Rust has a helpful method to handle line-by-line iteration of strings, conveniently named lines, that works as shown in Listing 12-17. Note that this wonâ€™t compile yet.

Rust æä¾›äº†ä¾¿æ·çš„ lines æ–¹æ³•å¤„ç†å­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„é€è¡Œè¿­ä»£ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-17æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚æ³¨æ„æ­¤ä»£ç å°šä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

The lines method returns an iterator. Weâ€™ll talk about iterators in depth in Chapter 13, but recall that you saw this way of using an iterator in Listing 3-5, where we used a for loop with an iterator to run some code on each item in a collection.

lines æ–¹æ³•è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªè¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬13ç« æ·±å…¥è®¨è®ºè¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼Œä½†å›å¿†ä¸€ä¸‹åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å•3-5ä¸­æ›¾ç”¨ for å¾ªç¯é…åˆè¿­ä»£å™¨å¯¹é›†åˆä¸­æ¯ä¸ªå…ƒç´ æ‰§è¡Œä»£ç ã€‚

Searching Each Line for the Query åœ¨æ¯è¡Œä¸­æœç´¢æŸ¥è¯¢è¯

Next, weâ€™ll check whether the current line contains our query string. Fortunately, strings have a helpful method named contains that does this for us! Add a call to the contains method in the search function, as shown in Listing 12-18. Note that this still wonâ€™t compile yet.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æ£€æŸ¥å½“å‰è¡Œæ˜¯å¦åŒ…å«æŸ¥è¯¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æä¾›äº† contains æ–¹æ³•ï¼å¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-18æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œåœ¨ search å‡½æ•°ä¸­æ·»åŠ å¯¹ contains çš„è°ƒç”¨ã€‚æ³¨æ„æ­¤ä»£ç ä»ä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

At the moment, weâ€™re building up functionality. To get the code to compile, we need to return a value from the body as we indicated we would in the function signature.

ç›®å‰æˆ‘ä»¬æ­£åœ¨æ„å»ºåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚ä¸ºä½¿ä»£ç ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œéœ€ä»å‡½æ•°ä½“è¿”å›ç­¾åä¸­å£°æ˜çš„å€¼ã€‚

Storing Matching Lines å­˜å‚¨åŒ¹é…è¡Œ

To finish this function, we need a way to store the matching lines that we want to return. For that, we can make a mutable vector before the for loop and call the push method to store a line in the vector. After the for loop, we return the vector, as shown in Listing 12-19.

è¦å®Œæˆæ­¤å‡½æ•°ï¼Œéœ€è¦å­˜å‚¨è¦è¿”å›çš„åŒ¹é…è¡Œã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨ for å¾ªç¯å‰åˆ›å»ºå¯å˜å‘é‡ï¼Œå¹¶è°ƒç”¨ push æ–¹æ³•å°† line å­˜å…¥å‘é‡ã€‚for å¾ªç¯åè¿”å›è¯¥å‘é‡ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-19æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Now the search function should return only the lines that contain query, and our test should pass. Letâ€™s run the test:

ç°åœ¨ search å‡½æ•°åº”ä»…è¿”å›åŒ…å« query çš„è¡Œï¼Œæµ‹è¯•åº”èƒ½é€šè¿‡ã€‚è¿è¡Œæµ‹è¯•ï¼š

$ cargo test
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `test` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 1.22s
     Running unittests src/lib.rs (target/debug/deps/minigrep-9cd200e5fac0fc94)

running 1 test
test tests::one_result ... ok

test result: ok. 1 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

     Running unittests src/main.rs (target/debug/deps/minigrep-9cd200e5fac0fc94)

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

   Doc-tests minigrep

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

Our test passed, so we know it works!

æµ‹è¯•é€šè¿‡ï¼Œç¡®è®¤åŠŸèƒ½æ­£å¸¸ï¼

At this point, we could consider opportunities for refactoring the implementation of the search function while keeping the tests passing to maintain the same functionality. The code in the search function isnâ€™t too bad, but it doesnâ€™t take advantage of some useful features of iterators. Weâ€™ll return to this example in Chapter 13, where weâ€™ll explore iterators in detail, and look at how to improve it.

æ­¤æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è€ƒè™‘é‡æ„ search å‡½æ•°çš„å®ç°ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¿æŒæµ‹è¯•é€šè¿‡ä»¥ç»´æŒç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚å½“å‰å®ç°å°šå¯ï¼Œä½†æœªå……åˆ†åˆ©ç”¨è¿­ä»£å™¨çš„ç‰¹æ€§ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬13ç« é‡æ–°æ¢è®¨æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼Œè¯¦ç»†ç ”ç©¶è¿­ä»£å™¨å¹¶æ”¹è¿›å®ç°ã€‚

Now the entire program should work! Letâ€™s try it out, first with a word that should return exactly one line from the Emily Dickinson poem: frog.

ç°åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªç¨‹åºåº”èƒ½å·¥ä½œï¼è®©æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ Emily Dickinson è¯—ä¸­åº”è¿”å›å•è¡Œçš„è¯æµ‹è¯•ï¼šfrogã€‚

$ cargo run -- frog poem.txt
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.38s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep frog poem.txt`
How public, like a frog

Cool! Now letâ€™s try a word that will match multiple lines, like body:

å¾ˆå¥½ï¼ç°åœ¨å°è¯•åŒ¹é…å¤šè¡Œçš„è¯ï¼Œå¦‚ bodyï¼š

$ cargo run -- body poem.txt
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep body poem.txt`
I'm nobody! Who are you?
Are you nobody, too?
How dreary to be somebody!

And finally, letâ€™s make sure that we donâ€™t get any lines when we search for a word that isnâ€™t anywhere in the poem, such as monomorphization:

æœ€åç¡®è®¤æœç´¢è¯—ä¸­ä¸å­˜åœ¨çš„è¯ï¼ˆå¦‚ monomorphizationï¼‰æ—¶ä¸è¿”å›ä»»ä½•è¡Œï¼š

$ cargo run -- monomorphization poem.txt
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep monomorphization poem.txt`

Excellent! Weâ€™ve built our own mini version of a classic tool and learned a lot about how to structure applications. Weâ€™ve also learned a bit about file input and output, lifetimes, testing, and command line parsing.

å®Œç¾ï¼æˆ‘ä»¬æ„å»ºäº†è‡ªå·±çš„ç»å…¸å·¥å…·ç®€åŒ–ç‰ˆï¼Œå¹¶å­¦ä¹ äº†åº”ç”¨ç»“æ„è®¾è®¡ã€‚åŒæ—¶è¿˜å­¦ä¹ äº†æ–‡ä»¶è¾“å…¥è¾“å‡ºã€ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸã€æµ‹è¯•å’Œå‘½ä»¤è¡Œè§£æã€‚

To round out this project, weâ€™ll briefly demonstrate how to work with environment variables and how to print to standard error, both of which are useful when youâ€™re writing command line programs.

ä½œä¸ºé¡¹ç›®æ”¶å°¾ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç®€è¦æ¼”ç¤ºå¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡åŠæ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµï¼Œè¿™ä¸¤è€…åœ¨ç¼–å†™å‘½ä»¤è¡Œç¨‹åºæ—¶éå¸¸å®ç”¨ã€‚

Working with Environment Variables ä½¿ç”¨ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡

Weâ€™ll improve the minigrep binary by adding an extra feature: an option for case-insensitive searching that the user can turn on via an environment variable. We could make this feature a command line option and require that users enter it each time they want it to apply, but by instead making it an environment variable, we allow our users to set the environment variable once and have all their searches be case insensitive in that terminal session.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é€šè¿‡é¢å¤–åŠŸèƒ½æ”¹è¿› minigrepï¼šå…è®¸ç”¨æˆ·é€šè¿‡ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å¼€å¯å¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ã€‚è™½ç„¶å¯ä»¥å°†å…¶è®¾ä¸ºå‘½ä»¤è¡Œé€‰é¡¹è¦æ±‚ç”¨æˆ·æ¯æ¬¡è¾“å…¥ï¼Œä½†æ”¹ç”¨ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å…è®¸ç”¨æˆ·è®¾ç½®ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œå³å¯åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªç»ˆç«¯ä¼šè¯ä¸­è¿›è¡Œå¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ã€‚

Writing a Failing Test for the Case-Insensitive search Function ä¸ºå¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿçš„ search å‡½æ•°ç¼–å†™å¤±è´¥æµ‹è¯•

We first add a new search_case_insensitive function to the minigrep library that will be called when the environment variable has a value. Weâ€™ll continue to follow the TDD process, so the first step is again to write a failing test. Weâ€™ll add a new test for the new search_case_insensitive function and rename our old test from one_result to case_sensitive to clarify the differences between the two tests, as shown in Listing 12-20.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ minigrep åº“ä¸­æ·»åŠ æ–°çš„ search_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå½“ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å­˜åœ¨æ—¶è°ƒç”¨å®ƒã€‚ç»§ç»­éµå¾ªTDDæµç¨‹ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ä»æ˜¯ç¼–å†™å¤±è´¥æµ‹è¯•ã€‚å¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-20æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œä¸ºæ–°å‡½æ•°æ·»åŠ æµ‹è¯•ï¼Œå¹¶å°†æ—§æµ‹è¯•ä» one_result é‡å‘½åä¸º case_sensitive ä»¥åŒºåˆ†ä¸¤è€…ã€‚

Note that weâ€™ve edited the old testâ€™s contents too. Weâ€™ve added a new line with the text "Duct tape." using a capital D that shouldnâ€™t match the query "duct" when weâ€™re searching in a case-sensitive manner. Changing the old test in this way helps ensure that we donâ€™t accidentally break the case-sensitive search functionality that weâ€™ve already implemented. This test should pass now and should continue to pass as we work on the case-insensitive search.

æ³¨æ„æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿä¿®æ”¹äº†æ—§æµ‹è¯•çš„ contentsï¼Œæ·»åŠ äº†å¸¦å¤§å†™ D çš„æ–°è¡Œ "Duct tape."ï¼Œå®ƒåœ¨å¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ä¸­ä¸åº”åŒ¹é…æŸ¥è¯¢ "duct"ã€‚è¿™æ ·ä¿®æ”¹æ—§æµ‹è¯•èƒ½ç¡®ä¿ä¸ç ´åå·²å®ç°çš„å¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚è¯¥æµ‹è¯•ç°åœ¨åº”é€šè¿‡ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨å¤„ç†å¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢æ—¶ä¿æŒé€šè¿‡ã€‚

The new test for the case-insensitive search uses "rUsT" as its query. In the search_case_insensitive function weâ€™re about to add, the query "rUsT" should match the line containing "Rust:" with a capital R and match the line "Trust me." even though both have different casing from the query. This is our failing test, and it will fail to compile because we havenâ€™t yet defined the search_case_insensitive function. Feel free to add a skeleton implementation that always returns an empty vector, similar to the way we did for the search function in Listing 12-16 to see the test compile and fail.

å¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæµ‹è¯•ä½¿ç”¨ "rUsT" ä½œä¸ºæŸ¥è¯¢ã€‚åœ¨å³å°†æ·»åŠ çš„ search_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°ä¸­ï¼ŒæŸ¥è¯¢ "rUsT" åº”åŒ¹é…åŒ…å«å¤§å†™ R çš„ "Rust:" è¡Œï¼Œä»¥åŠ "Trust me." è¡Œï¼Œå°½ç®¡å®ƒä»¬çš„å¤§å°å†™ä¸æŸ¥è¯¢ä¸åŒã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å¤±è´¥çš„æµ‹è¯•ï¼Œç”±äºå°šæœªå®šä¹‰ search_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å°†å¤±è´¥ã€‚å¯ä»¥æ·»åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªå§‹ç»ˆè¿”å›ç©ºå‘é‡çš„éª¨æ¶å®ç°ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-16ä¸­ search çš„åšæ³•ï¼‰æ¥è§‚å¯Ÿæµ‹è¯•ç¼–è¯‘å’Œå¤±è´¥ã€‚

Implementing the search_case_insensitive Function å®ç° search_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°

The search_case_insensitive function, shown in Listing 12-21, will be almost the same as the search function. The only difference is that weâ€™ll lowercase the query and each line so that whatever the case of the input arguments, theyâ€™ll be the same case when we check whether the line contains the query.

å¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-21æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œsearch_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°ä¸ search å‡ ä¹ç›¸åŒï¼Œå”¯ä¸€åŒºåˆ«æ˜¯å°† query å’Œæ¯è¡Œ line è½¬ä¸ºå°å†™ï¼Œä½¿å¾—æ— è®ºè¾“å…¥å‚æ•°å¤§å°å†™å¦‚ä½•ï¼Œæ£€æŸ¥è¡Œæ˜¯å¦åŒ…å«æŸ¥è¯¢æ—¶éƒ½ä¿æŒç›¸åŒå¤§å°å†™ã€‚

First we lowercase the query string and store it in a new variable with the same name, shadowing the original query. Calling to_lowercase on the query is necessary so that no matter whether the userâ€™s query is "rust", "RUST", "Rust", or "``rUsT``", weâ€™ll treat the query as if it were "rust" and be insensitive to the case. While to_lowercase will handle basic Unicode, it wonâ€™t be 100 percent accurate. If we were writing a real application, weâ€™d want to do a bit more work here, but this section is about environment variables, not Unicode, so weâ€™ll leave it at that here.

é¦–å…ˆå°† query å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è½¬ä¸ºå°å†™å¹¶å­˜å…¥åŒåæ–°å˜é‡ï¼ˆé®è”½åŸå§‹ queryï¼‰ã€‚è°ƒç”¨ to_lowercase æ˜¯å¿…è¦çš„ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ— è®ºç”¨æˆ·æŸ¥è¯¢æ˜¯ "rust"ã€"RUST"ã€"Rust" è¿˜æ˜¯ "rUsT"ï¼Œéƒ½ä¼šè§†ä¸º "rust" å¹¶å¿½ç•¥å¤§å°å†™ã€‚è™½ç„¶ to_lowercase èƒ½å¤„ç†åŸºç¡€ Unicodeï¼Œä½†å¹¶é 100% ç²¾ç¡®ã€‚åœ¨çœŸå®åº”ç”¨ä¸­éœ€æ›´å¤šå¤„ç†ï¼Œä½†æœ¬èŠ‚é‡ç‚¹åœ¨ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡è€Œé Unicodeï¼Œæ•…æš‚ä¸æ·±å…¥ã€‚

Note that query is now a String rather than a string slice because calling to_lowercase creates new data rather than referencing existing data. Say the query is "rUsT", as an example: that string slice doesnâ€™t contain a lowercase u or t for us to use, so we have to allocate a new String containing "rust". When we pass query as an argument to the contains method now, we need to add an ampersand because the signature of contains is defined to take a string slice.

æ³¨æ„ query ç°åœ¨æ˜¯ String è€Œéå­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè°ƒç”¨ to_lowercase ä¼šåˆ›å»ºæ–°æ•°æ®è€Œéå¼•ç”¨ç°æœ‰æ•°æ®ã€‚ä»¥æŸ¥è¯¢ "rUsT" ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼šè¯¥å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ä¸å«å°å†™ u æˆ– tï¼Œå› æ­¤éœ€åˆ†é…åŒ…å« "rust" çš„æ–° Stringã€‚ç°åœ¨å°† query ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°ä¼ é€’ç»™ contains æ—¶éœ€æ·»åŠ  &ï¼Œå› ä¸º contains ç­¾åå®šä¹‰ä¸ºæ¥æ”¶å­—ç¬¦ä¸²åˆ‡ç‰‡ã€‚

Next, we add a call to to_lowercase on each line to lowercase all characters. Now that weâ€™ve converted line and query to lowercase, weâ€™ll find matches no matter what the case of the query is.

æ¥ç€åœ¨æ¯è¡Œ line ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ to_lowercase è½¬ä¸ºå°å†™ã€‚ç°åœ¨æ— è®ºæŸ¥è¯¢å¤§å°å†™å¦‚ä½•ï¼Œéƒ½èƒ½æ‰¾åˆ°åŒ¹é…é¡¹ã€‚

Letâ€™s see if this implementation passes the tests:

æ£€æŸ¥å®ç°æ˜¯å¦é€šè¿‡æµ‹è¯•ï¼š

$ cargo test
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `test` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 1.33s
     Running unittests src/lib.rs (target/debug/deps/minigrep-9cd200e5fac0fc94)

running 2 tests
test tests::case_insensitive ... ok
test tests::case_sensitive ... ok

test result: ok. 2 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

     Running unittests src/main.rs (target/debug/deps/minigrep-9cd200e5fac0fc94)

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

   Doc-tests minigrep

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out; finished in 0.00s

Great! They passed. Now, letâ€™s call the new search_case_insensitive function from the run function. First weâ€™ll add a configuration option to the Config struct to switch between case-sensitive and case-insensitive search. Adding this field will cause compiler errors because we arenâ€™t initializing this field anywhere yet:

å¾ˆå¥½ï¼æµ‹è¯•é€šè¿‡ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä» run å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨æ–°çš„ search_case_insensitive å‡½æ•°ã€‚é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ Config ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸­æ·»åŠ é…ç½®é€‰é¡¹æ¥åˆ‡æ¢å¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ã€‚æ·»åŠ æ­¤å­—æ®µä¼šå¯¼è‡´ç¼–è¯‘é”™è¯¯ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå°šæœªåˆå§‹åŒ–è¯¥å­—æ®µï¼š

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::env;
use std::error::Error;
use std::fs;
use std::process;

use minigrep::{search, search_case_insensitive};

// --snip--


fn main() {
    let args: Vec<String> = env::args().collect();

    let config = Config::build(&args).unwrap_or_else(|err| {
        println!("Problem parsing arguments: {err}");
        process::exit(1);
    });

    if let Err(e) = run(config) {
        println!("Application error: {e}");
        process::exit(1);
    }
}

pub struct Config {
    pub query: String,
    pub file_path: String,
    pub ignore_case: bool,
}

impl Config {
    fn build(args: &[String]) -> Result<Config, &'static str> {
        if args.len() < 3 {
            return Err("not enough arguments");
        }

        let query = args[1].clone();
        let file_path = args[2].clone();

        Ok(Config { query, file_path })
    }
}

fn run(config: Config) -> Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> {
    let contents = fs::read_to_string(config.file_path)?;

    let results = if config.ignore_case {
        search_case_insensitive(&config.query, &contents)
    } else {
        search(&config.query, &contents)
    };

    for line in results {
        println!("{line}");
    }

    Ok(())
}

We added the ignore_case field that holds a Boolean. Next, we need the run function to check the ignore_case fieldâ€™s value and use that to decide whether to call the search function or the search_case_insensitive function, as shown in Listing 12-22. This still wonâ€™t compile yet.

æˆ‘ä»¬æ·»åŠ äº†å¸ƒå°”ç±»å‹å­—æ®µ ignore_caseã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥éœ€è¦ run å‡½æ•°æ£€æŸ¥ ignore_case å€¼ï¼Œå†³å®šè°ƒç”¨ search è¿˜æ˜¯ search_case_insensitiveï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-22æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚æ­¤ä»£ç ä»ä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

Finally, we need to check for the environment variable. The functions for working with environment variables are in the env module in the standard library, which is already in scope at the top of src/main.rs. Weâ€™ll use the var function from the env module to check to see if any value has been set for an environment variable named IGNORE_CASE, as shown in Listing 12-23.

æœ€åéœ€è¦æ£€æŸ¥ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡ã€‚æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ env æ¨¡å—åŒ…å«ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å¤„ç†å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆå·²é€šè¿‡ src/main.rs é¡¶éƒ¨ä½œç”¨åŸŸå¼•å…¥ï¼‰ã€‚å¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-23æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ env æ¨¡å—çš„ var å‡½æ•°æ£€æŸ¥åä¸º IGNORE_CASE çš„ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡æ˜¯å¦è¢«è®¾ç½®ã€‚

Here, we create a new variable, ignore_case. To set its value, we call the env::var function and pass it the name of the IGNORE_CASE environment variable. The env::var function returns a Result that will be the successful Ok variant that contains the value of the environment variable if the environment variable is set to any value. It will return the Err variant if the environment variable is not set.

è¿™é‡Œåˆ›å»ºæ–°å˜é‡ ignore_caseã€‚ä¸ºè®¾ç½®å…¶å€¼ï¼Œ[note]è°ƒç”¨ env::var å‡½æ•°å¹¶ä¼ å…¥ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å IGNORE_CASEã€‚env::var è¿”å› Resultï¼šè‹¥ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡è®¾ä¸ºä»»æ„å€¼ï¼Œåˆ™ä¸ºåŒ…å«å…¶å€¼çš„æˆåŠŸ Ok å˜ä½“ï¼›è‹¥æœªè®¾ç½®ï¼Œåˆ™ä¸º Err å˜ä½“ã€‚

Weâ€™re using the is_ok method on the Result to check whether the environment variable is set, which means the program should do a case-insensitive search. If the IGNORE_CASE environment variable isnâ€™t set to anything, is_ok will return false and the program will perform a case-sensitive search. We donâ€™t care about the value of the environment variable, just whether itâ€™s set or unset, so weâ€™re checking is_ok rather than using unwrap, expect, or any of the other methods weâ€™ve seen on Result.

æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ Result ä¸Šä½¿ç”¨ is_ok æ–¹æ³•æ£€æŸ¥ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡æ˜¯å¦è®¾ç½®ï¼ˆå³ç¨‹åºåº”æ‰§è¡Œå¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥ IGNORE_CASE æœªè®¾ç½®ï¼Œis_ok è¿”å› falseï¼Œç¨‹åºæ‰§è¡Œå¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸å…³å¿ƒç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡çš„å€¼ï¼Œåªå…³å¿ƒæ˜¯å¦è®¾ç½®ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ£€æŸ¥ is_ok è€Œé unwrapã€expect ç­‰ Result æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

We pass the value in the ignore_case variable to the Config instance so the run function can read that value and decide whether to call search_case_insensitive or search, as we implemented in Listing 12-22.

å°† ignore_case çš„å€¼ä¼ é€’ç»™ Config å®ä¾‹ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ run å‡½æ•°è¯»å–è¯¥å€¼å¹¶å†³å®šè°ƒç”¨ search_case_insensitive è¿˜æ˜¯ searchï¼ˆå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-22å®ç°ï¼‰ã€‚

Letâ€™s give it a try! First weâ€™ll run our program without the environment variable set and with the query to, which should match any line that contains the word to in all lowercase:

å°è¯•è¿è¡Œï¼é¦–å…ˆä¸è®¾ç½®ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡ï¼Œç”¨æŸ¥è¯¢è¯ to è¿è¡Œï¼ˆåº”åŒ¹é…æ‰€æœ‰å«å°å†™ to çš„è¡Œï¼‰ï¼š

$ cargo run -- to poem.txt
   Compiling minigrep v0.1.0 (file:///projects/minigrep)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0s
     Running `target/debug/minigrep to poem.txt`
Are you nobody, too?
How dreary to be somebody!

Looks like that still works! Now letâ€™s run the program with IGNORE_CASE set to 1 but with the same query to:

è¿è¡Œæ­£å¸¸ï¼ç°åœ¨è®¾ç½® IGNORE_CASE=1 å¹¶ç”¨ç›¸åŒæŸ¥è¯¢è¯ to è¿è¡Œï¼š

$ IGNORE_CASE=1 cargo run -- to poem.txt

If youâ€™re using PowerShell, you will need to set the environment variable and run the program as separate commands:

è‹¥ä½¿ç”¨ PowerShellï¼Œéœ€åˆ†è®¾ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å’Œè¿è¡Œå‘½ä»¤ï¼š

PS> $Env:IGNORE_CASE=1; cargo run -- to poem.txt

This will make IGNORE_CASE persist for the remainder of your shell session. It can be unset with the Remove-Item cmdlet:

è¿™å°†ä½¿ IGNORE_CASE åœ¨å‰©ä½™ shell ä¼šè¯ä¸­æŒç»­ç”Ÿæ•ˆã€‚å¯ç”¨ Remove-Item cmdlet å–æ¶ˆè®¾ç½®ï¼š

PS> Remove-Item Env:IGNORE_CASE

We should get lines that contain to that might have uppercase letters:

ç°åœ¨åº”å¾—åˆ°åŒ…å« to ä¸”å¯èƒ½æœ‰å¤§å†™å­—æ¯çš„è¡Œï¼š

Are you nobody, too?
How dreary to be somebody!
To tell your name the livelong day
To an admiring bog!

Excellent, we also got lines containing To! Our minigrep program can now do case-insensitive searching controlled by an environment variable. Now you know how to manage options set using either command line arguments or environment variables.

å¾ˆå¥½ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¾—åˆ°äº†åŒ…å« To çš„è¡Œï¼minigrep ç¨‹åºç°åœ¨å¯é€šè¿‡ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡æ§åˆ¶å¤§å°å†™ä¸æ•æ„Ÿæœç´¢ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä½ å·²æŒæ¡å¦‚ä½•ç®¡ç†å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°æˆ–ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡è®¾ç½®çš„é€‰é¡¹ã€‚

Some programs allow arguments and environment variables for the same configuration. In those cases, the programs decide that one or the other takes precedence. For another exercise on your own, try controlling case sensitivity through either a command line argument or an environment variable. Decide whether the command line argument or the environment variable should take precedence if the program is run with one set to case sensitive and one set to ignore case.

æŸäº›ç¨‹åºå…è®¸åŒæ—¶ä½¿ç”¨å‚æ•°å’Œç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡é…ç½®ç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ç¨‹åºéœ€å†³å®šä¼˜å…ˆçº§ã€‚ä½œä¸ºé¢å¤–ç»ƒä¹ ï¼Œå°è¯•é€šè¿‡å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°æˆ–ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡æ§åˆ¶å¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿæ€§ï¼Œå¹¶å†³å®šå½“ä¸¤è€…è®¾ç½®å†²çªï¼ˆä¸€ä¸ªå¤§å°å†™æ•æ„Ÿï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªå¿½ç•¥å¤§å°å†™ï¼‰æ—¶å“ªä¸ªä¼˜å…ˆçº§æ›´é«˜ã€‚

The std::env module contains many more useful features for dealing with environment variables: check out its documentation to see what is available.

std::env æ¨¡å—åŒ…å«æ›´å¤šå¤„ç†ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡çš„å®ç”¨åŠŸèƒ½ï¼šè¯·æŸ¥é˜…æ–‡æ¡£äº†è§£å¯ç”¨å†…å®¹ã€‚

Writing Error Messages to Standard Error Instead of Standard Output å°†é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯å†™å…¥æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµè€Œéæ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµ

At the moment, weâ€™re writing all of our output to the terminal using the println! macro. In most terminals, there are two kinds of output: standard output (stdout) for general information and standard error (stderr) for error messages. This distinction enables users to choose to direct the successful output of a program to a file but still print error messages to the screen.

ç›®å‰æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ println! å®å°†æ‰€æœ‰è¾“å‡ºå†™å…¥ç»ˆç«¯ã€‚å¤šæ•°ç»ˆç«¯æœ‰ä¸¤ç§è¾“å‡ºï¼šæ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµï¼ˆstdoutï¼‰ç”¨äºå¸¸è§„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œæ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµï¼ˆstderrï¼‰ç”¨äºé”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚è¿™ç§åŒºåˆ†ä½¿ç”¨æˆ·å¯å°†ç¨‹åºæˆåŠŸè¾“å‡ºé‡å®šå‘åˆ°æ–‡ä»¶ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶åœ¨å±å¹•æ˜¾ç¤ºé”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

The println! macro is only capable of printing to standard output, so we have to use something else to print to standard error.

println! å®ä»…èƒ½æ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµï¼Œå› æ­¤éœ€ä½¿ç”¨å…¶ä»–æ–¹å¼æ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµã€‚

Checking Where Errors Are Written æ£€æŸ¥é”™è¯¯å†™å…¥ä½ç½®

First letâ€™s observe how the content printed by minigrep is currently being written to standard output, including any error messages we want to write to standard error instead. Weâ€™ll do that by redirecting the standard output stream to a file while intentionally causing an error. We wonâ€™t redirect the standard error stream, so any content sent to standard error will continue to display on the screen.

é¦–å…ˆè§‚å¯Ÿ minigrep çš„å†…å®¹å¦‚ä½•è¢«å†™å…¥æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬æœ¬åº”å†™å…¥æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµçš„é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰ã€‚é€šè¿‡å°†æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµé‡å®šå‘åˆ°æ–‡ä»¶å¹¶æ•…æ„å¼•å‘é”™è¯¯æ¥æ¼”ç¤ºã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸é‡å®šå‘æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµï¼Œå› æ­¤å…¶å†…å®¹ä»ä¼šæ˜¾ç¤ºåœ¨å±å¹•ä¸Šã€‚

Command line programs are expected to send error messages to the standard error stream so we can still see error messages on the screen even if we redirect the standard output stream to a file. Our program is not currently well behaved: weâ€™re about to see that it saves the error message output to a file instead!

å‘½ä»¤è¡Œç¨‹åºåº”å°†é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯å‘é€åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµï¼Œè¿™æ ·å³ä½¿é‡å®šå‘æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµï¼Œä»èƒ½åœ¨å±å¹•ä¸Šçœ‹åˆ°é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚ä½†å½“å‰ç¨‹åºè¡Œä¸ºä¸ç¬¦åˆé¢„æœŸï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬å°†çœ‹åˆ°é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯è¢«ä¿å­˜åˆ°æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­ï¼

To demonstrate this behavior, weâ€™ll run the program with > and the file path, output.txt, that we want to redirect the standard output stream to. We wonâ€™t pass any arguments, which should cause an error:

ä¸ºæ¼”ç¤ºæ­¤è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä¸å¸¦å‚æ•°è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºï¼ˆè¿™ä¼šå¼•å‘é”™è¯¯ï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶ä½¿ç”¨ > å’Œæ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ output.txt é‡å®šå‘æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµï¼š

$ cargo run > output.txt

The > syntax tells the shell to write the contents of standard output to output.txt instead of the screen. We didnâ€™t see the error message we were expecting printed to the screen, so that means it must have ended up in the file. This is what output.txt contains:

> è¯­æ³•å‘Šè¯‰ shell å°†æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµå†…å®¹å†™å…¥ output.txt è€Œéå±å¹•ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æœªåœ¨å±å¹•çœ‹åˆ°é¢„æœŸçš„é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¯´æ˜å®ƒè¢«å†™å…¥æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ output.txt çš„å†…å®¹ï¼š

Problem parsing arguments: not enough arguments

Yup, our error message is being printed to standard output. Itâ€™s much more useful for error messages like this to be printed to standard error so only data from a successful run ends up in the file. Weâ€™ll change that.

æ˜¯çš„ï¼Œé”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯è¢«æ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµã€‚æ­¤ç±»é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯æ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµæ›´åˆç†ï¼Œè¿™æ ·åªæœ‰æˆåŠŸè¿è¡Œçš„æ•°æ®ä¼šè¿›å…¥æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä¿®æ”¹è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚

Printing Errors to Standard Error å°†é”™è¯¯æ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµ

Weâ€™ll use the code in Listing 12-24 to change how error messages are printed. Because of the refactoring we did earlier in this chapter, all the code that prints error messages is in one function, main. The standard library provides the eprintln! macro that prints to the standard error stream, so letâ€™s change the two places we were calling println! to print errors to use eprintln! instead.

ä½¿ç”¨ä»£ç æ¸…å•12-24çš„ä»£ç ä¿®æ”¹é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯æ‰“å°æ–¹å¼ã€‚å¾—ç›Šäºæœ¬ç« æ—©å‰çš„é‡æ„ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰é”™è¯¯æ‰“å°ä»£ç éƒ½åœ¨ main å‡½æ•°ä¸­ã€‚[note]æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾› eprintln! å®ç”¨äºæ‰“å°åˆ°æ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµï¼Œå› æ­¤å°†ä¸¤å¤„è°ƒç”¨ println! æ‰“å°é”™è¯¯çš„åœ°æ–¹æ”¹ä¸º eprintln!ã€‚

Letâ€™s now run the program again in the same way, without any arguments and redirecting standard output with >:

ç°åœ¨ä»¥ç›¸åŒæ–¹å¼å†æ¬¡è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºï¼ˆä¸å¸¦å‚æ•°å¹¶ç”¨ > é‡å®šå‘æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºï¼‰ï¼š

$ cargo run > output.txt
Problem parsing arguments: not enough arguments

Now we see the error onscreen and output.txt contains nothing, which is the behavior we expect of command line programs.

ç°åœ¨å±å¹•ä¸Šçœ‹åˆ°é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä¸” output.txt ä¸ºç©ºï¼Œç¬¦åˆå‘½ä»¤è¡Œç¨‹åºçš„é¢„æœŸè¡Œä¸ºã€‚

Letâ€™s run the program again with arguments that donâ€™t cause an error but still redirect standard output to a file, like so:

å†æ¬¡ç”¨ä¸ä¼šå¼•å‘é”™è¯¯çš„å‚æ•°è¿è¡Œç¨‹åºï¼Œä½†ä»é‡å®šå‘æ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºåˆ°æ–‡ä»¶ï¼š

$ cargo run -- to poem.txt > output.txt

We wonâ€™t see any output to the terminal, and output.txt will contain our results:

ç»ˆç«¯æ— è¾“å‡ºï¼Œä¸” output.txt åŒ…å«ç»“æœï¼š

Filename: output.txt

Are you nobody, too?
How dreary to be somebody!

This demonstrates that weâ€™re now using standard output for successful output and standard error for error output as appropriate.

è¿™è¡¨æ˜æˆ‘ä»¬å·²å°†æˆåŠŸè¾“å‡ºç”¨äºæ ‡å‡†è¾“å‡ºæµï¼Œé”™è¯¯è¾“å‡ºç”¨äºæ ‡å‡†é”™è¯¯æµã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

This chapter recapped some of the major concepts youâ€™ve learned so far and covered how to perform common I/O operations in Rust. By using command line arguments, files, environment variables, and the eprintln! macro for printing errors, youâ€™re now prepared to write command line applications. Combined with the concepts in previous chapters, your code will be well organized, store data effectively in the appropriate data structures, handle errors nicely, and be well tested.

æœ¬ç« å›é¡¾äº†ç›®å‰æ‰€å­¦çš„æ ¸å¿ƒæ¦‚å¿µï¼Œå¹¶ä»‹ç»äº†å¦‚ä½•åœ¨ Rust ä¸­æ‰§è¡Œå¸¸è§ I/O æ“ä½œã€‚é€šè¿‡ä½¿ç”¨å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°ã€æ–‡ä»¶ã€ç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡å’Œ eprintln! å®æ‰“å°é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä½ å·²ä¸ºç¼–å†™å‘½ä»¤è¡Œåº”ç”¨åšå¥½å‡†å¤‡ã€‚ç»“åˆå‰å‡ ç« çš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œä½ çš„ä»£ç å°†ç»„ç»‡è‰¯å¥½ã€é«˜æ•ˆå­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®ã€ä¼˜é›…å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯ä¸”ç»è¿‡å……åˆ†æµ‹è¯•ã€‚

Next, weâ€™ll explore some Rust features that were influenced by functional languages: closures and iterators.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢ç´¢å—å‡½æ•°å¼è¯­è¨€å½±å“çš„ Rust ç‰¹æ€§ï¼šé—­åŒ…å’Œè¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚

Functional Language Features: Iterators and Closures å‡½æ•°å¼è¯­è¨€ç‰¹æ€§ï¼šè¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸é—­åŒ…

Rustâ€™s design has taken inspiration from many existing languages and techniques, and one significant influence is functional programming. Programming in a functional style often includes using functions as values by passing them in arguments, returning them from other functions, assigning them to variables for later execution, and so forth.

Rust çš„è®¾è®¡ä»è®¸å¤šç°æœ‰è¯­è¨€å’ŒæŠ€æœ¯ä¸­æ±²å–äº†çµæ„Ÿï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªé‡è¦å½±å“æ¥è‡ªå‡½æ•°å¼ç¼–ç¨‹ã€‚å‡½æ•°å¼ç¼–ç¨‹é£æ ¼é€šå¸¸åŒ…æ‹¬å°†å‡½æ•°ä½œä¸ºå€¼ä½¿ç”¨ï¼šé€šè¿‡å‚æ•°ä¼ é€’å‡½æ•°ã€ä»å…¶ä»–å‡½æ•°è¿”å›å‡½æ•°ã€å°†å‡½æ•°èµ‹å€¼ç»™å˜é‡ä»¥ä¾¿åç»­æ‰§è¡Œç­‰ã€‚

In this chapter, we wonâ€™t debate the issue of what functional programming is or isnâ€™t but will instead discuss some features of Rust that are similar to features in many languages often referred to as functional.

æœ¬ç« ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä¼šæ¢è®¨å‡½æ•°å¼ç¼–ç¨‹çš„å…·ä½“å®šä¹‰ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è®¨è®º Rust ä¸­ä¸å¸¸è¢«ç§°ä¸ºå‡½æ•°å¼çš„è¯­è¨€ç›¸ä¼¼çš„ä¸€äº›ç‰¹æ€§ã€‚

More specifically, weâ€™ll cover:

å…·ä½“æ¥è¯´ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¶µç›–ï¼š

  • Closures, a function-like construct you can store in a variable
  • é—­åŒ…ï¼šä¸€ç§å¯å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å˜é‡ä¸­çš„ç±»å‡½æ•°ç»“æ„
  • Iterators, a way of processing a series of elements
  • è¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼šå¤„ç†å…ƒç´ åºåˆ—çš„æ–¹æ³•
  • How to use closures and iterators to improve the I/O project in Chapter 12
  • å¦‚ä½•åˆ©ç”¨é—­åŒ…å’Œè¿­ä»£å™¨æ”¹è¿›ç¬¬ 12 ç« çš„ I/O é¡¹ç›®
  • The performance of closures and iterators (spoiler alert: theyâ€™re faster than you might think!)
  • é—­åŒ…å’Œè¿­ä»£å™¨çš„æ€§èƒ½ï¼ˆå‰§é€è­¦å‘Šï¼šå®ƒä»¬æ¯”ä½ æƒ³è±¡çš„æ›´å¿«ï¼ï¼‰

Weâ€™ve already covered some other Rust features, such as pattern matching and enums, that are also influenced by the functional style. Because mastering closures and iterators is an important part of writing idiomatic, fast Rust code, weâ€™ll devote this entire chapter to them.

æˆ‘ä»¬å·²ç»ä»‹ç»è¿‡çš„å…¶ä»– Rust ç‰¹æ€§ï¼ˆå¦‚æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…å’Œæšä¸¾ï¼‰åŒæ ·å—åˆ°å‡½æ•°å¼é£æ ¼çš„å½±å“ã€‚ç”±äºæŒæ¡é—­åŒ…å’Œè¿­ä»£å™¨æ˜¯ç¼–å†™åœ°é“ã€é«˜æ•ˆ Rust ä»£ç çš„å…³é”®ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç”¨æ•´ç« ç¯‡å¹…æ·±å…¥æ¢è®¨å®ƒä»¬ã€‚

Closures: Anonymous Functions That Capture Their Environment é—­åŒ…ï¼šå¯æ•è·ç¯å¢ƒçš„åŒ¿åå‡½æ•°

Rustâ€™s closures are anonymous functions you can save in a variable or pass as arguments to other functions. You can create the closure in one place and then call the closure elsewhere to evaluate it in a different context. Unlike functions, closures can capture values from the scope in which theyâ€™re defined. Weâ€™ll demonstrate how these closure features allow for code reuse and behavior customization.

Rust çš„é—­åŒ…æ˜¯å¯å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å˜é‡ä¸­æˆ–ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°ä¼ é€’ç»™å…¶ä»–å‡½æ•°çš„åŒ¿åå‡½æ•°ã€‚ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨ä¸€å¤„åˆ›å»ºé—­åŒ…ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨å¦ä¸€å¤„è°ƒç”¨é—­åŒ…ä»¥åœ¨ä¸åŒä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­æ±‚å€¼ã€‚ä¸å‡½æ•°ä¸åŒï¼Œé—­åŒ…èƒ½æ•è·å…¶å®šä¹‰ä½œç”¨åŸŸä¸­çš„å€¼ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å±•ç¤ºè¿™äº›é—­åŒ…ç‰¹æ€§å¦‚ä½•å®ç°ä»£ç å¤ç”¨å’Œè¡Œä¸ºå®šåˆ¶ã€‚

Capturing the Environment with Closures ä½¿ç”¨é—­åŒ…æ•è·ç¯å¢ƒ

Weâ€™ll first examine how we can use closures to capture values from the environment theyâ€™re defined in for later use. Hereâ€™s the scenario: every so often, our T-shirt company gives away an exclusive, limited-edition shirt to someone on our mailing list as a promotion. People on the mailing list can optionally add their favorite color to their profile. If the person chosen for a free shirt has their favorite color set, they get that color shirt. If the person hasnâ€™t specified a favorite color, they get whatever color the company currently has the most of.

é¦–å…ˆæˆ‘ä»¬æ¢ç©¶å¦‚ä½•ç”¨é—­åŒ…æ•è·å…¶å®šä¹‰ç¯å¢ƒä¸­çš„å€¼ä»¥ä¾›åç»­ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚å‡è®¾åœºæ™¯ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬çš„ T æ¤å…¬å¸å®šæœŸå‘é‚®ä»¶åˆ—è¡¨ç”¨æˆ·èµ é€ç‹¬å®¶é™é‡ç‰ˆ T æ¤ä½œä¸ºä¿ƒé”€ã€‚é‚®ä»¶åˆ—è¡¨ç”¨æˆ·å¯é€‰æ‹©åœ¨ä¸ªäººèµ„æ–™ä¸­æ·»åŠ å–œçˆ±çš„é¢œè‰²ã€‚è‹¥ä¸­å¥–ç”¨æˆ·è®¾ç½®äº†å–œçˆ±é¢œè‰²ï¼Œå°†è·å¾—è¯¥é¢œè‰²çš„ T æ¤ï¼›è‹¥æœªæŒ‡å®šï¼Œåˆ™è·å¾—å…¬å¸å½“å‰åº“å­˜æœ€å¤šçš„é¢œè‰²ã€‚

There are many ways to implement this. For this example, weâ€™re going to use an enum called ShirtColor that has the variants Red and Blue (limiting the number of colors available for simplicity). We represent the companyâ€™s inventory with an Inventory struct that has a field named shirts that contains a Vec<ShirtColor> representing the shirt colors currently in stock. The method giveaway defined on Inventory gets the optional shirt color preference of the free-shirt winner, and returns the shirt color the person will get. This setup is shown in Listing 13-1.

å®ç°æ–¹å¼å¤šç§å¤šæ ·ã€‚æœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä½¿ç”¨åä¸º ShirtColor çš„æšä¸¾ï¼ŒåŒ…å« Red å’Œ Blue å˜ä½“ï¼ˆä¸ºç®€åŒ–é™åˆ¶å¯é€‰é¢œè‰²ï¼‰ã€‚ç”¨ Inventory ç»“æ„ä½“è¡¨ç¤ºå…¬å¸åº“å­˜ï¼Œå…¶ shirts å­—æ®µåŒ…å«è¡¨ç¤ºå½“å‰åº“å­˜é¢œè‰²çš„ Vec<ShirtColor>ã€‚Inventory ä¸Šå®šä¹‰çš„ giveaway æ–¹æ³•è·å–ä¸­å¥–è€…çš„å¯é€‰é¢œè‰²åå¥½ï¼Œå¹¶è¿”å›è¯¥ç”¨æˆ·å°†è·å¾—çš„é¢œè‰²ã€‚å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 13-1 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

The store defined in main has two blue shirts and one red shirt remaining to distribute for this limited-edition promotion. We call the giveaway method for a user with a preference for a red shirt and a user without any preference.

main ä¸­å®šä¹‰çš„ store æœ‰ä¸¤ä»¶è“ T æ¤å’Œä¸€ä»¶çº¢ T æ¤å¯ç”¨äºæ­¤æ¬¡é™é‡ä¿ƒé”€ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ºæœ‰çº¢ T æ¤åå¥½å’Œæ— åå¥½çš„ç”¨æˆ·è°ƒç”¨ giveaway æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Again, this code could be implemented in many ways, and here, to focus on closures, weâ€™ve stuck to concepts youâ€™ve already learned, except for the body of the giveaway method that uses a closure. In the giveaway method, we get the user preference as a parameter of type Option<ShirtColor> and call the unwrap_or_else method on user_preference. The is defined by the standard library. It takes one argument: a closure without any arguments that returns a value T (the same type stored in the Some variant of the Option<T>, in this case ShirtColor). If the Option<T> is the Some variant, unwrap_or_else returns the value from within the Some. If the Option<T> is the None variant, unwrap_or_else calls the closure and returns the value returned by the closure.

é‡ç”³ï¼šæ­¤ä»£ç æœ‰å¤šç§å®ç°æ–¹å¼ã€‚æ­¤å¤„ä¸ºèšç„¦é—­åŒ…ï¼Œé™¤ giveaway æ–¹æ³•ä½“å†…ä½¿ç”¨äº†é—­åŒ…å¤–ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»…ä½¿ç”¨å·²å­¦æ¦‚å¿µã€‚åœ¨ giveaway æ–¹æ³•ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è·å– Option<ShirtColor> ç±»å‹çš„ç”¨æˆ·åå¥½ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ user_preference ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ unwrap_or_else æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ç”±æ ‡å‡†åº“å®šä¹‰ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼šæ— å‚æ•°ä¸”è¿”å›å€¼ T çš„é—­åŒ…ï¼ˆä¸ Option<T> ä¸­ Some å˜ä½“å­˜å‚¨çš„ç±»å‹ç›¸åŒï¼Œæ­¤å¤„ä¸º ShirtColorï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥ Option<T> ä¸º Some å˜ä½“ï¼Œunwrap_or_else è¿”å›å…¶å†…éƒ¨å€¼ï¼›è‹¥ä¸º None å˜ä½“ï¼Œåˆ™è°ƒç”¨é—­åŒ…å¹¶è¿”å›å…¶ç»“æœã€‚

We specify the closure expression || self.most_stocked() as the argument to unwrap_or_else. This is a closure that takes no parameters itself (if the closure had parameters, they would appear between the two vertical pipes). The body of the closure calls self.most_stocked(). Weâ€™re defining the closure here, and the implementation of unwrap_or_else will evaluate the closure later if the result is needed.

æˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‡å®šé—­åŒ…è¡¨è¾¾å¼ || self.most_stocked() ä½œä¸º unwrap_or_else çš„å‚æ•°ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ— å‚é—­åŒ…ï¼ˆè‹¥æœ‰å‚æ•°ï¼Œå°†å‡ºç°åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªç«–çº¿ä¹‹é—´ï¼‰ã€‚é—­åŒ…ä½“è°ƒç”¨ self.most_stocked()ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æ­¤å®šä¹‰é—­åŒ…ï¼Œè€Œ unwrap_or_else çš„å®ç°ä¼šåœ¨éœ€è¦ç»“æœæ—¶æ±‚å€¼è¯¥é—­åŒ…ã€‚

Running this code prints the following:

è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç è¾“å‡ºï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling shirt-company v0.1.0 (file:///projects/shirt-company)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.27s
     Running `target/debug/shirt-company`
The user with preference Some(Red) gets Red
The user with preference None gets Blue

One interesting aspect here is that weâ€™ve passed a closure that calls self.most_stocked() on the current Inventory instance. The standard library didnâ€™t need to know anything about the Inventory or ShirtColor types we defined, or the logic we want to use in this scenario. The closure captures an immutable reference to the self Inventory instance and passes it with the code we specify to the unwrap_or_else method. Functions, on the other hand, are not able to capture their environment in this way.

æ­¤å¤„å€¼å¾—æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼ é€’äº†è°ƒç”¨å½“å‰ Inventory å®ä¾‹ä¸Š self.most_stocked() çš„é—­åŒ…ã€‚æ ‡å‡†åº“æ— éœ€çŸ¥æ™“æˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰çš„ Inventory æˆ– ShirtColor ç±»å‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ— éœ€çŸ¥æ™“æ­¤åœºæ™¯çš„ä¸šåŠ¡é€»è¾‘ã€‚é—­åŒ…æ•è·äº† selfï¼ˆå³ Inventory å®ä¾‹ï¼‰çš„ä¸å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‡å®šçš„ä»£ç ä¸€åŒä¼ é€’ç»™ unwrap_or_else æ–¹æ³•ã€‚è€Œæ™®é€šå‡½æ•°æ— æ³•ä»¥è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼æ•è·ç¯å¢ƒã€‚

Closure Type Inference and Annotation é—­åŒ…ç±»å‹æ¨æ–­ä¸æ³¨è§£

There are more differences between functions and closures. Closures donâ€™t usually require you to annotate the types of the parameters or the return value like fn functions do. Type annotations are required on functions because the types are part of an explicit interface exposed to your users. Defining this interface rigidly is important for ensuring that everyone agrees on what types of values a function uses and returns. Closures, on the other hand, arenâ€™t used in an exposed interface like this: theyâ€™re stored in variables and used without naming them and exposing them to users of our library.

å‡½æ•°ä¸é—­åŒ…è¿˜æœ‰æ›´å¤šå·®å¼‚ã€‚é—­åŒ…é€šå¸¸ä¸åƒ fn å‡½æ•°é‚£æ ·è¦æ±‚æ ‡æ³¨å‚æ•°æˆ–è¿”å›å€¼ç±»å‹ã€‚å‡½æ•°éœ€è¦ç±»å‹æ ‡æ³¨æ˜¯å› ä¸ºç±»å‹æ˜¯æš´éœ²ç»™ç”¨æˆ·çš„æ˜¾å¼æ¥å£çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œä¸¥æ ¼å®šä¹‰æ­¤æ¥å£å¯¹äºç¡®ä¿å‡½æ•°ä½¿ç”¨çš„å€¼ç±»å‹å’Œè¿”å›ç±»å‹è¾¾æˆå…±è¯†è‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚é—­åŒ…åˆ™ä¸ä¼šæš´éœ²åœ¨æ­¤ç±»æ¥å£ä¸­ï¼šå®ƒä»¬å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å˜é‡ä¸­ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ—¶æ— éœ€å‘½åæˆ–æš´éœ²ç»™åº“ç”¨æˆ·ã€‚

Closures are typically short and relevant only within a narrow context rather than in any arbitrary scenario. Within these limited contexts, the compiler can infer the types of the parameters and the return type, similar to how itâ€™s able to infer the types of most variables (there are rare cases where the compiler needs closure type annotations too).

é—­åŒ…é€šå¸¸ç®€çŸ­ä¸”ä»…é€‚ç”¨äºç‹­çª„çš„ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ã€‚åœ¨æ­¤æœ‰é™ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨å¯æ¨æ–­å‚æ•°å’Œè¿”å›ç±»å‹ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºæ¨æ–­å¤§å¤šæ•°å˜é‡ç±»å‹çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼ˆæå°‘æ•°æƒ…å†µä¹Ÿéœ€è¦é—­åŒ…ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£ï¼‰ã€‚

As with variables, we can add type annotations if we want to increase explicitness and clarity at the cost of being more verbose than is strictly necessary. Annotating the types for a closure would look like the definition shown in Listing 13-2. In this example, weâ€™re defining a closure and storing it in a variable rather than defining the closure in the spot we pass it as an argument, as we did in Listing 13-1.

ä¸å˜é‡ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬[note]å¯ä¸ºé—­åŒ…æ·»åŠ ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£ä»¥æå‡æ˜ç¡®æ€§ï¼Œä»£ä»·æ˜¯æ¯”ä¸¥æ ¼å¿…è¦çš„æ›´å†—é•¿ã€‚æ³¨è§£é—­åŒ…ç±»å‹å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 13-2 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰é—­åŒ…å¹¶å°†å…¶å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å˜é‡ä¸­ï¼Œè€Œéå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 13-1 åœ¨ä¼ å‚å¤„å®šä¹‰ã€‚

With type annotations added, the syntax of closures looks more similar to the syntax of functions. Here, we define a function that adds 1 to its parameter and a closure that has the same behavior, for comparison. Weâ€™ve added some spaces to line up the relevant parts. This illustrates how closure syntax is similar to function syntax except for the use of pipes and the amount of syntax that is optional:

æ·»åŠ ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£åï¼Œé—­åŒ…è¯­æ³•æ›´æ¥è¿‘å‡½æ•°è¯­æ³•ã€‚ä¸‹é¢å¯¹æ¯”äº†å‚æ•°åŠ  1 çš„å‡½æ•°å’Œç›¸åŒè¡Œä¸ºçš„é—­åŒ…ï¼ˆæ·»åŠ ç©ºæ ¼å¯¹é½ç›¸å…³éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™å±•ç¤ºäº†é—­åŒ…è¯­æ³•ä¸å‡½æ•°è¯­æ³•çš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§ï¼ˆé™¤ç®¡é“ç¬¦å’Œå¯é€‰è¯­æ³•é‡å¤–ï¼‰ï¼š

fn  add_one_v1   (x: u32) -> u32 { x + 1 }
let add_one_v2 = |x: u32| -> u32 { x + 1 };
let add_one_v3 = |x|             { x + 1 };
let add_one_v4 = |x|               x + 1  ;

The first line shows a function definition and the second line shows a fully annotated closure definition. In the third line, we remove the type annotations from the closure definition. In the fourth line, we remove the brackets, which are optional because the closure body has only one expression. These are all valid definitions that will produce the same behavior when theyâ€™re called.
