åœ¨å½“ä»Šå¤šæ•°æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¸­ï¼Œæ‰§è¡Œç¨‹åºçš„ä»£ç è¿è¡Œäºè¿›ç¨‹å†…ï¼Œæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¼šåŒæ—¶ç®¡ç†å¤šä¸ªè¿›ç¨‹ã€‚ç¨‹åºå†…éƒ¨ä¹Ÿå¯æœ‰ç‹¬ç«‹éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ—¶è¿è¡Œï¼Œè¿è¡Œè¿™äº›ç‹¬ç«‹éƒ¨åˆ†çš„ç‰¹æ€§ç§°ä¸ºçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼ŒWeb æœåŠ¡å™¨å¯ä½¿ç”¨å¤šçº¿ç¨‹åŒæ—¶å“åº”å¤šä¸ªè¯·æ±‚ã€‚

Splitting the computation in your program into multiple threads to run multiple tasks at the same time can improve performance, but it also adds complexity. Because threads can run simultaneously, thereâ€™s no inherent guarantee about the order in which parts of your code on different threads will run. This can lead to problems, such as:

å°†ç¨‹åºè®¡ç®—æ‹†åˆ†åˆ°å¤šä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ä»¥åŒæ—¶æ‰§è¡Œå¤šä»»åŠ¡å¯æå‡æ€§èƒ½ï¼Œä½†ä¹Ÿå¢åŠ å¤æ‚æ€§ã€‚ç”±äºçº¿ç¨‹å¯èƒ½åŒæ—¶è¿è¡Œï¼Œæ— æ³•ä¿è¯ä¸åŒçº¿ç¨‹ä¸Šä»£ç çš„æ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåºã€‚è¿™ä¼šå¯¼è‡´ä»¥ä¸‹é—®é¢˜ï¼š

  • Race conditions, in which threads are accessing data or resources in an inconsistent order

  • Deadlocks, in which two threads are waiting for each other, preventing both threads from continuing

  • Bugs that only happen in certain situations and are hard to reproduce and fix reliably

  • ç«æ€æ¡ä»¶ï¼šçº¿ç¨‹ä»¥ä¸ä¸€è‡´é¡ºåºè®¿é—®æ•°æ®æˆ–èµ„æº

  • æ­»é”ï¼šä¸¤ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ç›¸äº’ç­‰å¾…å¯¼è‡´éƒ½æ— æ³•ç»§ç»­

  • ä»…ç‰¹å®šåœºæ™¯å‡ºç°çš„ Bugï¼šéš¾ä»¥å¯é å¤ç°å’Œä¿®å¤

Rust attempts to mitigate the negative effects of using threads, but programming in a multithreaded context still takes careful thought and requires a code structure that is different from that in programs running in a single thread.

Rust è¯•å›¾å‡è½»ä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹çš„è´Ÿé¢å½±å“ï¼Œä½†å¤šçº¿ç¨‹ç¼–ç¨‹ä»éœ€è°¨æ…æ€è€ƒï¼Œä¸”ä»£ç ç»“æ„éœ€ä¸åŒäºå•çº¿ç¨‹ç¨‹åºã€‚

Programming languages implement threads in a few different ways, and many operating systems provide an API the programming language can call for creating new threads. The Rust standard library uses a 1:1 model of thread implementation, whereby a program uses one operating system thread per one language thread. There are crates that implement other models of threading that make different trade-offs to the 1:1 model. (Rustâ€™s async system, which we will see in the next chapter, provides another approach to concurrency as well.)

ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ä»¥å‡ ç§ä¸åŒæ–¹å¼å®ç°çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œè®¸å¤šæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿæä¾›åˆ›å»ºæ–°çº¿ç¨‹çš„ APIã€‚Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“é‡‡ç”¨ 1:1 çº¿ç¨‹æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œå³æ¯ä¸ªè¯­è¨€çº¿ç¨‹å¯¹åº”ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ä¹Ÿæœ‰ crate å®ç°å…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œæƒè¡¡ä¸åŒäº 1:1 æ¨¡å‹ï¼ˆRust çš„å¼‚æ­¥ç³»ç»Ÿæ˜¯å¦ä¸€ç§å¹¶å‘æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå°†åœ¨ä¸‹ä¸€ç« ä»‹ç»ï¼‰ã€‚

Creating a New Thread with spawn ä½¿ç”¨ spawn åˆ›å»ºæ–°çº¿ç¨‹

To create a new thread, we call the thread::spawn function and pass it a closure (we talked about closures in Chapter 13) containing the code we want to run in the new thread. The example in Listing 16-1 prints some text from a main thread and other text from a new thread.

[note]åˆ›å»ºæ–°çº¿ç¨‹éœ€è°ƒç”¨ thread::spawn å‡½æ•°å¹¶ä¼ é€’é—­åŒ…ï¼ˆç¬¬ 13 ç« è®¨è®ºè¿‡é—­åŒ…ï¼‰ï¼Œé—­åŒ…åŒ…å«è¦åœ¨æ–°çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­è¿è¡Œçš„ä»£ç ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-1 åœ¨ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹å’Œæ–°çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­åˆ†åˆ«æ‰“å°æ–‡æœ¬ã€‚

Note that when the main thread of a Rust program completes, all spawned threads are shut down, whether or not they have finished running. The output from this program might be a little different every time, but it will look similar to the following:

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå½“ Rust ç¨‹åºçš„ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ç»“æŸæ—¶ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹æ— è®ºæ˜¯å¦å®Œæˆéƒ½ä¼šè¢«å…³é—­ã€‚ç¨‹åºè¾“å‡ºå¯èƒ½ç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒï¼Œä½†ç±»ä¼¼å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

hi number 1 from the main thread!
hi number 1 from the spawned thread!
hi number 2 from the main thread!
hi number 2 from the spawned thread!
hi number 3 from the main thread!
hi number 3 from the spawned thread!
hi number 4 from the main thread!
hi number 4 from the spawned thread!
hi number 5 from the spawned thread!

The calls to thread::sleep force a thread to stop its execution for a short duration, allowing a different thread to run. The threads will probably take turns, but that isnâ€™t guaranteed: it depends on how your operating system schedules the threads. In this run, the main thread printed first, even though the print statement from the spawned thread appears first in the code. And even though we told the spawned thread to print until i is 9, it only got to 5 before the main thread shut down.

[note]thread::sleep è°ƒç”¨å¼ºåˆ¶çº¿ç¨‹çŸ­æš‚æš‚åœæ‰§è¡Œï¼Œå…è®¸å…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹è¿è¡Œã€‚çº¿ç¨‹å¯èƒ½è½®æµæ‰§è¡Œï¼Œä½†ä¸ä¿è¯ï¼šè¿™å–å†³äºæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿè°ƒåº¦ç­–ç•¥ã€‚æ­¤è¿è¡Œä¸­ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹å…ˆæ‰“å°ï¼Œå°½ç®¡æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹çš„æ‰“å°è¯­å¥åœ¨ä»£ç ä¸­æ›´é å‰ã€‚è™½ç„¶æˆ‘ä»¬è®©æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹æ‰“å°åˆ° i ä¸º 9ï¼Œä½†ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹å…³é—­æ—¶å®ƒåªæ‰“å°åˆ° 5ã€‚

If you run this code and only see output from the main thread, or donâ€™t see any overlap, try increasing the numbers in the ranges to create more opportunities for the operating system to switch between the threads.

è‹¥è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ä»…è§ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹è¾“å‡ºæˆ–æ— äº¤æ›¿è¾“å‡ºï¼Œå°è¯•å¢å¤§èŒƒå›´å€¼ä»¥å¢åŠ æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿåˆ‡æ¢çº¿ç¨‹çš„æœºä¼šã€‚

Waiting for All Threads to Finish Using join Handles ä½¿ç”¨ join å¥æŸ„ç­‰å¾…æ‰€æœ‰çº¿ç¨‹å®Œæˆ

The code in Listing 16-1 not only stops the spawned thread prematurely most of the time due to the main thread ending, but because there is no guarantee on the order in which threads run, we also canâ€™t guarantee that the spawned thread will get to run at all!

ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-1 çš„ä»£ç ä¸ä»…å¸¸å› ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ç»“æŸè€Œæå‰ç»ˆæ­¢æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œä¸”å› çº¿ç¨‹æ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåºæ— ä¿è¯ï¼Œç”šè‡³æ— æ³•ç¡®ä¿æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹èƒ½è¿è¡Œï¼

We can fix the problem of the spawned thread not running or of it ending prematurely by saving the return value of thread::spawn in a variable. The return type of thread::spawn is JoinHandle<T>. A JoinHandle<T> is an owned value that, when we call the join method on it, will wait for its thread to finish. Listing 16-2 shows how to use the JoinHandle<T> of the thread we created in Listing 16-1 and how to call join to make sure the spawned thread finishes before main exits.

é€šè¿‡å°† thread::spawn è¿”å›å€¼å­˜å…¥å˜é‡å¯è§£å†³æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹æœªè¿è¡Œæˆ–æå‰ç»“æŸçš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚[note]thread::spawn è¿”å› JoinHandle<T> ç±»å‹ã€‚JoinHandle<T> æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ‹¥æœ‰å€¼ï¼Œå¯¹å…¶è°ƒç”¨ join æ–¹æ³•ä¼šç­‰å¾…å…¶çº¿ç¨‹ç»“æŸã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-2 å±•ç¤ºå¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-1 ä¸­çº¿ç¨‹çš„ JoinHandle<T> å¹¶è°ƒç”¨ join ç¡®ä¿æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹åœ¨ main é€€å‡ºå‰å®Œæˆã€‚

Calling join on the handle blocks the thread currently running until the thread represented by the handle terminates. Blocking a thread means that thread is prevented from performing work or exiting. Because weâ€™ve put the call to join after the main threadâ€™s for loop, running Listing 16-2 should produce output similar to this:

å¯¹å¥æŸ„è°ƒç”¨ join ä¼šé˜»å¡å½“å‰çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œç›´åˆ°å¥æŸ„ä»£è¡¨çš„çº¿ç¨‹ç»ˆæ­¢ã€‚é˜»å¡çº¿ç¨‹æ„å‘³ç€é˜»æ­¢å…¶æ‰§è¡Œå·¥ä½œæˆ–é€€å‡ºã€‚å› å°† join è°ƒç”¨ç½®äºä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ for å¾ªç¯åï¼Œè¿è¡Œç¤ºä¾‹ 16-2 åº”äº§ç”Ÿç±»ä¼¼è¾“å‡ºï¼š

hi number 1 from the main thread!
hi number 2 from the main thread!
hi number 1 from the spawned thread!
hi number 3 from the main thread!
hi number 2 from the spawned thread!
hi number 4 from the main thread!
hi number 3 from the spawned thread!
hi number 4 from the spawned thread!
hi number 5 from the spawned thread!
hi number 6 from the spawned thread!
hi number 7 from the spawned thread!
hi number 8 from the spawned thread!
hi number 9 from the spawned thread!

The two threads continue alternating, but the main thread waits because of the call to handle.join() and does not end until the spawned thread is finished.

ä¸¤çº¿ç¨‹ç»§ç»­äº¤æ›¿æ‰§è¡Œï¼Œä½†ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹å›  handle.join() è°ƒç”¨è€Œç­‰å¾…ï¼Œç›´åˆ°æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ç»“æŸåæ‰é€€å‡ºã€‚

But letâ€™s see what happens when we instead move handle.join() before the for loop in main, like this:

ä½†è‹¥å°† handle.join() ç§»åˆ° main çš„ for å¾ªç¯ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

The main thread will wait for the spawned thread to finish and then run its for loop, so the output wonâ€™t be interleaved anymore, as shown here:

ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹å°†ç­‰å¾…æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å®Œæˆåå†è¿è¡Œå…¶ for å¾ªç¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¾“å‡ºä¸å†äº¤æ›¿ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

hi number 1 from the spawned thread!
hi number 2 from the spawned thread!
hi number 3 from the spawned thread!
hi number 4 from the spawned thread!
hi number 5 from the spawned thread!
hi number 6 from the spawned thread!
hi number 7 from the spawned thread!
hi number 8 from the spawned thread!
hi number 9 from the spawned thread!
hi number 1 from the main thread!
hi number 2 from the main thread!
hi number 3 from the main thread!
hi number 4 from the main thread!

Small details, such as where join is called, can affect whether or not your threads run at the same time.

ç»†å¾®ä¹‹å¤„ï¼ˆå¦‚ join çš„è°ƒç”¨ä½ç½®ï¼‰ä¼šå½±å“çº¿ç¨‹æ˜¯å¦åŒæ—¶è¿è¡Œã€‚

Using move Closures with Threads åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ move é—­åŒ…

Weâ€™ll often use the move keyword with closures passed to thread::spawn because the closure will then take ownership of the values it uses from the environment, thus transferring ownership of those values from one thread to another. In â€œCapturing References or Moving Ownershipâ€ in Chapter 13, we discussed move in the context of closures. Now weâ€™ll concentrate more on the interaction between move and thread::spawn.

ä¼ é€’ç»™ thread::spawn çš„é—­åŒ…å¸¸éœ€ä½¿ç”¨ move å…³é”®å­—ï¼Œå› ä¸ºé—­åŒ…ä¼šè·å–å…¶ä½¿ç”¨ç¯å¢ƒå€¼çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œä»è€Œå°†æ‰€æœ‰æƒä»ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹è½¬ç§»åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ç¬¬ 13 ç« â€œæ•è·å¼•ç”¨æˆ–ç§»åŠ¨æ‰€æœ‰æƒâ€ä¸­è®¨è®ºè¿‡é—­åŒ…çš„ moveã€‚ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ›´å…³æ³¨ move ä¸ thread::spawn çš„äº¤äº’ã€‚

Notice in Listing 16-1 that the closure we pass to thread::spawn takes no arguments: weâ€™re not using any data from the main thread in the spawned threadâ€™s code. To use data from the main thread in the spawned thread, the spawned threadâ€™s closure must capture the values it needs. Listing 16-3 shows an attempt to create a vector in the main thread and use it in the spawned thread. However, this wonâ€™t work yet, as youâ€™ll see in a moment.

æ³¨æ„ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-1 ä¸­ä¼ é€’ç»™ thread::spawn çš„é—­åŒ…æ— å‚æ•°ï¼šæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹æœªä½¿ç”¨ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­çš„ä»»ä½•æ•°æ®ã€‚[note]è¦åœ¨æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹æ•°æ®ï¼Œå…¶é—­åŒ…å¿…é¡»æ•è·æ‰€éœ€å€¼ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-3 å°è¯•åœ¨ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹åˆ›å»ºå‘é‡å¹¶åœ¨æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä½†ç›®å‰æ— æ³•å·¥ä½œï¼Œç¨åä¼šçœ‹åˆ°åŸå› ã€‚

The closure uses v, so it will capture v and make it part of the closureâ€™s environment. Because thread::spawn runs this closure in a new thread, we should be able to access v inside that new thread. But when we compile this example, we get the following error:

é—­åŒ…ä½¿ç”¨ vï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¼šæ•è· v å¹¶ä½¿å…¶æˆä¸ºé—­åŒ…ç¯å¢ƒçš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚å›  thread::spawn åœ¨æ–°çº¿ç¨‹è¿è¡Œé—­åŒ…ï¼Œåº”èƒ½åœ¨æ–°çº¿ç¨‹å†…è®¿é—® vã€‚ä½†ç¼–è¯‘æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹ä¼šæŠ¥é”™ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling threads v0.1.0 (file:///projects/threads)
error[E0373]: closure may outlive the current function, but it borrows `v`, which is owned by the current function
 --> src/main.rs:6:32
  |
6 |     let handle = thread::spawn(|| {
  |                                ^^ may outlive borrowed value `v`
7 |         println!("Here's a vector: {v:?}");
  |                                     - `v` is borrowed here
  |
note: function requires argument type to outlive `'static`
 --> src/main.rs:6:18
  |
6 |       let handle = thread::spawn(|| {
  |  __________________^
7 | |         println!("Here's a vector: {v:?}");
8 | |     });
  | |______^
help: to force the closure to take ownership of `v` (and any other referenced variables), use the `move` keyword
  |
6 |     let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
  |                                ++++

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0373`.
error: could not compile `threads` (bin "threads") due to 1 previous error

Rust infers how to capture v, and because println! only needs a reference to v, the closure tries to borrow v. However, thereâ€™s a problem: Rust canâ€™t tell how long the spawned thread will run, so it doesnâ€™t know whether the reference to v will always be valid.

Rust æ¨æ–­å¦‚ä½•æ•è· vï¼Œå›  println! åªéœ€ v çš„å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œé—­åŒ…å°è¯•å€Ÿç”¨ vã€‚ä½†å­˜åœ¨é—®é¢˜ï¼šRust æ— æ³•åˆ¤æ–­æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹è¿è¡Œå¤šä¹…ï¼Œæ•…ä¸çŸ¥ v çš„å¼•ç”¨æ˜¯å¦å§‹ç»ˆæœ‰æ•ˆã€‚

Listing 16-4 provides a scenario thatâ€™s more likely to have a reference to v that wonâ€™t be valid.

ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-4 å±•ç¤ºäº†æ›´å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´ v å¼•ç”¨æ— æ•ˆçš„åœºæ™¯ã€‚

If Rust allowed us to run this code, thereâ€™s a possibility that the spawned thread would be immediately put in the background without running at all. The spawned thread has a reference to v inside, but the main thread immediately drops v, using the drop function we discussed in Chapter 15. Then, when the spawned thread starts to execute, v is no longer valid, so a reference to it is also invalid. Oh no!

è‹¥ Rust å…è®¸æ­¤ä»£ç è¿è¡Œï¼Œæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å¯èƒ½è¢«ç«‹å³ç½®äºåå°è€Œä¸è¿è¡Œã€‚æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å†…å« v çš„å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œä½†ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ç«‹å³ç”¨ drop å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆç¬¬ 15 ç« è®¨è®ºè¿‡ï¼‰ä¸¢å¼ƒ vã€‚å½“æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å¼€å§‹æ‰§è¡Œæ—¶ï¼Œv å·²æ— æ•ˆï¼Œå…¶å¼•ç”¨ä¹Ÿæ— æ•ˆã€‚ç³Ÿç³•ï¼

To fix the compiler error in Listing 16-3, we can use the error messageâ€™s advice:

è¦ä¿®å¤ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-3 çš„ç¼–è¯‘é”™è¯¯ï¼Œå¯ä½¿ç”¨é”™è¯¯æç¤ºå»ºè®®ï¼š

help: to force the closure to take ownership of `v` (and any other referenced variables), use the `move` keyword
  |
6 |     let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
  |                                ++++

By adding the move keyword before the closure, we force the closure to take ownership of the values itâ€™s using rather than allowing Rust to infer that it should borrow the values. The modification to Listing 16-3 shown in Listing 16-5 will compile and run as we intend.

åœ¨é—­åŒ…å‰æ·»åŠ  move å…³é”®å­—ï¼Œå¼ºåˆ¶é—­åŒ…è·å–å…¶ä½¿ç”¨å€¼çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œè€Œéè®© Rust æ¨æ–­å€Ÿç”¨å€¼ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-5 å¯¹ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-3 çš„ä¿®æ”¹å¯æ­£å¸¸ç¼–è¯‘è¿è¡Œã€‚

We might be tempted to try the same thing to fix the code in Listing 16-4 where the main thread called drop by using a move closure. However, this fix will not work because what Listing 16-4 is trying to do is disallowed for a different reason. If we added move to the closure, we would move v into the closureâ€™s environment, and we could no longer call drop on it in the main thread. We would get this compiler error instead:

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½æƒ³ç”¨ç›¸åŒæ–¹æ³•ä¿®å¤ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-4ï¼ˆä¸»çº¿ç¨‹è°ƒç”¨ dropï¼‰ï¼Œä½†æ­¤ä¿®å¤æ— æ•ˆï¼Œå› ä¸ºç¤ºä¾‹ 16-4 çš„é—®é¢˜å¦æœ‰åŸå› ã€‚è‹¥å¯¹é—­åŒ…æ·»åŠ  moveï¼Œä¼šå°† v ç§»å…¥é—­åŒ…ç¯å¢ƒï¼Œä¸»çº¿ç¨‹æ— æ³•å†å¯¹å…¶è°ƒç”¨ dropã€‚ä¼šå¾—åˆ°ä»¥ä¸‹ç¼–è¯‘é”™è¯¯ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling threads v0.1.0 (file:///projects/threads)
error[E0382]: use of moved value: `v`
  --> src/main.rs:10:10
   |
4  |     let v = vec![1, 2, 3];
   |         - move occurs because `v` has type `Vec<i32>`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
5  |
6  |     let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
   |                                ------- value moved into closure here
7  |         println!("Here's a vector: {v:?}");
   |                                     - variable moved due to use in closure
...
10 |     drop(v); // oh no!
   |          ^ value used here after move

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0382`.
error: could not compile `threads` (bin "threads") due to 1 previous error

Rustâ€™s ownership rules have saved us again! We got an error from the code in Listing 16-3 because Rust was being conservative and only borrowing v for the thread, which meant the main thread could theoretically invalidate the spawned threadâ€™s reference. By telling Rust to move ownership of v to the spawned thread, weâ€™re guaranteeing to Rust that the main thread wonâ€™t use v anymore. If we change Listing 16-4 in the same way, weâ€™re then violating the ownership rules when we try to use v in the main thread. The move keyword overrides Rustâ€™s conservative default of borrowing; it doesnâ€™t let us violate the ownership rules.

Rust çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™å†æ¬¡æ‹¯æ•‘äº†æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-3 çš„é”™è¯¯æ˜¯å›  Rust ä¿å®ˆåœ°ä»…ä¸ºçº¿ç¨‹å€Ÿç”¨ vï¼Œæ„å‘³ç€ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ç†è®ºä¸Šå¯èƒ½ä½¿æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹çš„å¼•ç”¨å¤±æ•ˆã€‚é€šè¿‡å‘ŠçŸ¥ Rust å°† v æ‰€æœ‰æƒç§»è‡³æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å‘ Rust ä¿è¯ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ä¸å†ä½¿ç”¨ vã€‚è‹¥åŒæ ·ä¿®æ”¹ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-4ï¼Œåˆ™ä¼šåœ¨ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ä½¿ç”¨ v æ—¶è¿åæ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™ã€‚move å…³é”®å­—è¦†ç›–äº† Rust å€Ÿç”¨é»˜è®¤ä¿å®ˆæ€§ï¼Œä½†ä¸å…è®¸è¿åæ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™ã€‚

Now that weâ€™ve covered what threads are and the methods supplied by the thread API, letâ€™s look at some situations in which we can use threads.

ç°åœ¨ä»‹ç»äº†çº¿ç¨‹åŠçº¿ç¨‹ API çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæ¥çœ‹ä¸€äº›ä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹çš„åœºæ™¯ã€‚

Using Message Passing to Transfer Data Between Threads ä½¿ç”¨æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´ä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®

One increasingly popular approach to ensuring safe concurrency is message passing, where threads or actors communicate by sending each other messages containing data. Hereâ€™s the idea in a slogan from the Go language documentation: â€œDo not communicate by sharing memory; instead, share memory by communicating.â€

ç¡®ä¿å®‰å…¨å¹¶å‘æ—¥ç›Šæµè¡Œçš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’ï¼Œçº¿ç¨‹æˆ–å‚ä¸è€…é€šè¿‡ç›¸äº’å‘é€åŒ…å«æ•°æ®çš„æ¶ˆæ¯é€šä¿¡ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ Go è¯­è¨€æ–‡æ¡£ çš„å£å·ç²¾é«“ï¼šâ€œä¸è¦é€šè¿‡å…±äº«å†…å­˜æ¥é€šä¿¡ï¼›ç›¸åï¼Œé€šè¿‡é€šä¿¡æ¥å…±äº«å†…å­˜ã€‚â€

To accomplish message-sending concurrency, Rustâ€™s standard library provides an implementation of channels. A channel is a general programming concept by which data is sent from one thread to another.

ä¸ºå®ç°æ¶ˆæ¯å‘é€å¹¶å‘ï¼ŒRust æ ‡å‡†åº“æä¾›äº†é€šé“å®ç°ã€‚é€šé“æ˜¯é€šç”¨ç¼–ç¨‹æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œæ•°æ®é€šè¿‡å…¶ä»ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹å‘é€åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚

You can imagine a channel in programming as being like a directional channel of water, such as a stream or a river. If you put something like a rubber duck into a river, it will travel downstream to the end of the waterway.

å¯å°†ç¼–ç¨‹ä¸­çš„é€šé“æƒ³è±¡ä¸ºå•å‘æ°´é“ï¼ˆå¦‚æºªæµæˆ–æ²³æµï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥å°†æ©¡çš®é¸­æ”¾å…¥æ²³æµï¼Œå®ƒä¼šé¡ºæµè€Œä¸‹åˆ°æ°´é“ç»ˆç‚¹ã€‚

A channel has two halves: a transmitter and a receiver. The transmitter half is the upstream location where you put the rubber duck into the river, and the receiver half is where the rubber duck ends up downstream. One part of your code calls methods on the transmitter with the data you want to send, and another part checks the receiving end for arriving messages. A channel is said to be closed if either the transmitter or receiver half is dropped.

é€šé“æœ‰ä¸¤ç«¯ï¼šå‘é€ç«¯å’Œæ¥æ”¶ç«¯ã€‚å‘é€ç«¯æ˜¯ä¸Šæ¸¸ï¼ˆæ”¾å…¥æ©¡çš®é¸­å¤„ï¼‰ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶ç«¯æ˜¯ä¸‹æ¸¸ï¼ˆæ©¡çš®é¸­ç»ˆç‚¹ï¼‰ã€‚ä»£ç ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†è°ƒç”¨å‘é€ç«¯æ–¹æ³•å‘é€æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¦ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†æ£€æŸ¥æ¥æ”¶ç«¯åˆ°è¾¾çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚è‹¥å‘é€ç«¯æˆ–æ¥æ”¶ç«¯è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒï¼Œåˆ™ç§°é€šé“å…³é—­ã€‚

Here, weâ€™ll work up to a program that has one thread to generate values and send them down a channel, and another thread that will receive the values and print them out. Weâ€™ll be sending simple values between threads using a channel to illustrate the feature. Once youâ€™re familiar with the technique, you could use channels for any threads that need to communicate with each other, such as a chat system or a system where many threads perform parts of a calculation and send the parts to one thread that aggregates the results.

æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ç¼–å†™ä¸€ä¸ªç¨‹åºï¼šä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ç”Ÿæˆå€¼å¹¶é€šè¿‡é€šé“å‘é€ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹æ¥æ”¶å€¼å¹¶æ‰“å°ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨é€šé“å‘é€ç®€å•å€¼ä»¥æ¼”ç¤ºç‰¹æ€§ã€‚ç†Ÿæ‚‰æ­¤æŠ€æœ¯åï¼Œå¯å°†é€šé“ç”¨äºä»»ä½•éœ€ç›¸äº’é€šä¿¡çš„çº¿ç¨‹ï¼ˆå¦‚èŠå¤©ç³»ç»Ÿæˆ–å¤šçº¿ç¨‹æ‰§è¡Œéƒ¨åˆ†è®¡ç®—å¹¶å°†ç»“æœå‘é€åˆ°èšåˆçº¿ç¨‹çš„ç³»ç»Ÿï¼‰ã€‚

First, in Listing 16-6, weâ€™ll create a channel but not do anything with it. Note that this wonâ€™t compile yet because Rust canâ€™t tell what type of values we want to send over the channel.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-6 [note]åˆ›å»ºé€šé“ä½†ä¸æ“ä½œã€‚æ³¨æ„æ­¤ä»£ç å°šä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œå›  Rust æ— æ³•æ¨æ–­é€šé“è¦å‘é€çš„å€¼ç±»å‹ã€‚

We create a new channel using the mpsc::channel function; mpsc stands for multiple producer, single consumer. In short, the way Rustâ€™s standard library implements channels means a channel can have multiple sending ends that produce values but only one receiving end that consumes those values. Imagine multiple streams flowing together into one big river: everything sent down any of the streams will end up in one river at the end. Weâ€™ll start with a single producer for now, but weâ€™ll add multiple producers when we get this example working.

ç”¨ mpsc::channel å‡½æ•°åˆ›å»ºæ–°é€šé“ï¼›mpsc è¡¨ç¤ºå¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…ï¼Œå•æ¶ˆè´¹è€…ã€‚ç®€è¨€ä¹‹ï¼ŒRust æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„é€šé“å®ç°å…è®¸å¤šä¸ªå‘é€ç«¯äº§ç”Ÿå€¼ï¼Œä½†ä»…ä¸€ä¸ªæ¥æ”¶ç«¯æ¶ˆè´¹å€¼ã€‚æƒ³è±¡å¤šæ¡æºªæµæ±‡å…¥å¤§æ²³ï¼šä»»ä½•æºªæµå‘é€çš„å†…å®¹éƒ½ä¼šåœ¨ç»ˆç‚¹æ±‡å…¥åŒä¸€æ¡æ²³ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä»å•ç”Ÿäº§è€…å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå¾…æ­¤ä¾‹è¿è¡Œåå†æ·»åŠ å¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…ã€‚

The mpsc::channel function returns a tuple, the first element of which is the sending endâ€”the transmitterâ€”and the second element of which is the receiving endâ€”the receiver. The abbreviations tx and rx are traditionally used in many fields for transmitter and receiver, respectively, so we name our variables as such to indicate each end. Weâ€™re using a let statement with a pattern that destructures the tuples; weâ€™ll discuss the use of patterns in let statements and destructuring in Chapter 19. For now, know that using a let statement in this way is a convenient approach to extract the pieces of the tuple returned by mpsc::channel.

mpsc::channel è¿”å›å…ƒç»„ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€å…ƒç´ æ˜¯å‘é€ç«¯ï¼ˆå‘é€å™¨ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒå…ƒç´ æ˜¯æ¥æ”¶ç«¯ï¼ˆæ¥æ”¶å™¨ï¼‰ã€‚[note]ä¼ ç»Ÿä¸Š tx å’Œ rx åˆ†åˆ«ç¼©å†™è¡¨ç¤ºå‘é€å™¨å’Œæ¥æ”¶å™¨ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¦‚æ­¤å‘½åå˜é‡ä»¥åŒºåˆ†ä¸¤ç«¯ã€‚è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨ let è¯­å¥å’Œæ¨¡å¼è§£æ„å…ƒç»„ï¼ˆç¬¬ 19 ç« è®¨è®ºï¼‰ï¼›ç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥æ­¤æ–¹å¼å¯æ–¹ä¾¿æå– mpsc::channel è¿”å›å…ƒç»„çš„å„éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

Letâ€™s move the transmitting end into a spawned thread and have it send one string so the spawned thread is communicating with the main thread, as shown in Listing 16-7. This is like putting a rubber duck in the river upstream or sending a chat message from one thread to another.

å°†å‘é€ç«¯ç§»å…¥æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å¹¶å‘é€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œä½¿æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ä¸ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹é€šä¿¡ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-7 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚è¿™å¦‚åŒå°†æ©¡çš®é¸­æ”¾å…¥ä¸Šæ¸¸æˆ–çº¿ç¨‹é—´å‘é€èŠå¤©æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

Again, weâ€™re using thread::spawn to create a new thread and then using move to move tx into the closure so the spawned thread owns tx. The spawned thread needs to own the transmitter to be able to send messages through the channel.

å†æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨ thread::spawn åˆ›å»ºæ–°çº¿ç¨‹å¹¶ç”¨ move å°† tx ç§»å…¥é—­åŒ…ï¼Œä½¿æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹æ‹¥æœ‰ txã€‚æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹éœ€æ‹¥æœ‰å‘é€å™¨æ‰èƒ½é€šè¿‡é€šé“å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

The transmitter has a send method that takes the value we want to send. The send method returns a Result<T, E> type, so if the receiver has already been dropped and thereâ€™s nowhere to send a value, the send operation will return an error. In this example, weâ€™re calling unwrap to panic in case of an error. But in a real application, we would handle it properly: return to Chapter 9 to review strategies for proper error handling.

[note]å‘é€å™¨æœ‰ send æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶è¦å‘é€çš„å€¼ã€‚send è¿”å› Result<T, E> ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› æ­¤è‹¥æ¥æ”¶ç«¯å·²è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒä¸”æ— å¤„å‘é€å€¼ï¼Œå‘é€æ“ä½œå°†è¿”å›é”™è¯¯ã€‚æœ¬ä¾‹ä¸­è°ƒç”¨ unwrap åœ¨é”™è¯¯æ—¶ panicã€‚å®é™…åº”ç”¨ä¸­åº”æ­£ç¡®å¤„ç†ï¼šå›é¡¾ç¬¬ 9 ç« çš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†ç­–ç•¥ã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šsendä¸å› æ— æ¥æ”¶åŠ¨ä½œè€Œé˜»å¡ã€‚

In Listing 16-8, weâ€™ll get the value from the receiver in the main thread. This is like retrieving the rubber duck from the water at the end of the river or receiving a chat message.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-8ï¼Œä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ä»æ¥æ”¶ç«¯è·å–å€¼ã€‚è¿™å¦‚åŒä»ç»ˆç‚¹å–å‡ºæ©¡çš®é¸­æˆ–æ¥æ”¶èŠå¤©æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

The receiver has two useful methods: recv and try_recv. Weâ€™re using recv, short for receive, which will block the main threadâ€™s execution and wait until a value is sent down the channel. Once a value is sent, recv will return it in a Result<T, E>. When the transmitter closes, recv will return an error to signal that no more values will be coming.

[note]æ¥æ”¶ç«¯æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå®ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼šrecv å’Œ try_recvã€‚è¿™é‡Œç”¨ recvï¼ˆreceive ç¼©å†™ï¼‰ä¼šé˜»å¡ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ç›´åˆ°é€šé“å‘é€å€¼ã€‚å€¼å‘é€åï¼Œrecv è¿”å› Result<T, E>ã€‚å‘é€å™¨å…³é—­æ—¶ï¼Œrecv è¿”å›é”™è¯¯è¡¨ç¤ºä¸å†æœ‰å€¼ã€‚

The try_recv method doesnâ€™t block, but will instead return a Result<T, E> immediately: an Ok value holding a message if one is available and an Err value if there arenâ€™t any messages this time. Using try_recv is useful if this thread has other work to do while waiting for messages: we could write a loop that calls try_recv every so often, handles a message if one is available, and otherwise does other work for a little while until checking again.

[note]try_recv æ–¹æ³•ä¸é˜»å¡ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç«‹å³è¿”å› Result<T, E>ï¼šè‹¥æœ‰æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ™ä¸ºåŒ…å«æ¶ˆæ¯çš„ Okï¼Œè‹¥æ— åˆ™ä¸º Errã€‚è‹¥çº¿ç¨‹éœ€åœ¨ç­‰å¾…æ¶ˆæ¯æ—¶æ‰§è¡Œå…¶ä»–å·¥ä½œï¼Œtry_recv å¾ˆæœ‰ç”¨ï¼šå¯ç¼–å†™å¾ªç¯å®šæœŸè°ƒç”¨ try_recvï¼Œå¤„ç†æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼ˆè‹¥æœ‰ï¼‰ï¼Œå¦åˆ™æ‰§è¡Œå…¶ä»–å·¥ä½œç›´åˆ°ä¸‹æ¬¡æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚

Weâ€™ve used recv in this example for simplicity; we donâ€™t have any other work for the main thread to do other than wait for messages, so blocking the main thread is appropriate.

æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸ºç®€åŒ–ä½¿ç”¨ recvï¼›ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹é™¤ç­‰å¾…æ¶ˆæ¯å¤–æ— å…¶ä»–å·¥ä½œï¼Œå› æ­¤é˜»å¡ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹åˆé€‚ã€‚

When we run the code in Listing 16-8, weâ€™ll see the value printed from the main thread:

è¿è¡Œç¤ºä¾‹ 16-8 çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œä¸»çº¿ç¨‹æ‰“å°å€¼ï¼š

Got: hi

Perfect!

å®Œç¾ï¼

Channels and Ownership Transference é€šé“ä¸æ‰€æœ‰æƒè½¬ç§»

The ownership rules play a vital role in message sending because they help you write safe, concurrent code. Preventing errors in concurrent programming is the advantage of thinking about ownership throughout your Rust programs. Letâ€™s do an experiment to show how channels and ownership work together to prevent problems: weâ€™ll try to use a val value in the spawned thread after weâ€™ve sent it down the channel. Try compiling the code in Listing 16-9 to see why this code isnâ€™t allowed.

æ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™åœ¨æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’ä¸­è‡³å…³é‡è¦ï¼Œå› å…¶åŠ©ä½ ç¼–å†™å®‰å…¨çš„å¹¶å‘ä»£ç ã€‚åœ¨ Rust ç¨‹åºä¸­å…¨é¢è€ƒè™‘æ‰€æœ‰æƒå¯é˜²æ­¢å¹¶å‘é”™è¯¯ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡å®éªŒå±•ç¤ºé€šé“å’Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒå¦‚ä½•ååŒé˜²æ­¢é—®é¢˜ï¼šå°è¯•åœ¨å‘é€å€¼åäºæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ val å€¼ã€‚å°è¯•ç¼–è¯‘ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-9 çš„ä»£ç ä»¥è§£å…¶ä¸è¢«å…è®¸çš„åŸå› ã€‚

Here, we try to print val after weâ€™ve sent it down the channel via tx.send. Allowing this would be a bad idea: once the value has been sent to another thread, that thread could modify or drop it before we try to use the value again. Potentially, the other threadâ€™s modifications could cause errors or unexpected results due to inconsistent or nonexistent data. However, Rust gives us an error if we try to compile the code in Listing 16-9:

æ­¤å¤„å°è¯•åœ¨é€šè¿‡ tx.send å‘é€åæ‰“å° valã€‚å…è®¸æ­¤æ“ä½œæ˜¯åä¸»æ„ï¼šå› å€¼å‘é€åˆ°å¦ä¸€çº¿ç¨‹åï¼Œè¯¥çº¿ç¨‹å¯èƒ½åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬é‡ç”¨å‰ä¿®æ”¹æˆ–ä¸¢å¼ƒå®ƒã€‚å¦ä¸€çº¿ç¨‹çš„ä¿®æ”¹å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´æ•°æ®ä¸ä¸€è‡´æˆ–ä¸å­˜åœ¨è€Œäº§ç”Ÿé”™è¯¯æˆ–æ„å¤–ç»“æœã€‚ä½† Rust åœ¨ç¼–è¯‘ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-9 æ—¶ä¼šæŠ¥é”™ï¼š

$ cargo run
   Compiling message-passing v0.1.0 (file:///projects/message-passing)
error[E0382]: borrow of moved value: `val`
  --> src/main.rs:10:26
   |
8  |         let val = String::from("hi");
   |             --- move occurs because `val` has type `String`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
9  |         tx.send(val).unwrap();
   |                 --- value moved here
10 |         println!("val is {val}");
   |                          ^^^^^ value borrowed here after move
   |
   = note: this error originates in the macro `$crate::format_args_nl` which comes from the expansion of the macro `println` (in Nightly builds, run with -Z macro-backtrace for more info)

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0382`.
error: could not compile `message-passing` (bin "message-passing") due to 1 previous error

Our concurrency mistake has caused a compile-time error. The send function takes ownership of its parameter, and when the value is moved the receiver takes ownership of it. This stops us from accidentally using the value again after sending it; the ownership system checks that everything is okay.

å¹¶å‘é”™è¯¯å¯¼è‡´äº†ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶é”™è¯¯ã€‚send å‡½æ•°è·å–å‚æ•°çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œå€¼ç§»åŠ¨æ—¶æ¥æ”¶ç«¯è·å–æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚è¿™é˜²æ­¢æˆ‘ä»¬æ„å¤–é‡ç”¨å‘é€åçš„å€¼ï¼›æ‰€æœ‰æƒç³»ç»Ÿç¡®ä¿ä¸€åˆ‡æ­£å¸¸ã€‚

Sending Multiple Values and Seeing the Receiver Waiting å‘é€å¤šå€¼å¹¶è§‚å¯Ÿæ¥æ”¶ç«¯ç­‰å¾…

The code in Listing 16-8 compiled and ran, but it didnâ€™t clearly show us that two separate threads were talking to each other over the channel.

ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-8 çš„ä»£ç å¯ç¼–è¯‘è¿è¡Œï¼Œä½†æœªæ¸…æ™°å±•ç¤ºä¸¤çº¿ç¨‹é€šè¿‡é€šé“é€šä¿¡ã€‚

In Listing 16-10 weâ€™ve made some modifications that will prove the code in Listing 16-8 is running concurrently: the spawned thread will now send multiple messages and pause for a second between each message.

ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-10 çš„ä¿®æ”¹å°†è¯æ˜ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-8 å¹¶å‘è¿è¡Œï¼šæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ç°åœ¨å‘é€å¤šæ¡æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œæ¯æ¡é—´éš”ä¸€ç§’ã€‚

This time, the spawned thread has a vector of strings that we want to send to the main thread. We iterate over them, sending each individually, and pause between each by calling the thread::sleep function with a Duration value of one second.

æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ç°æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å‘é‡è¦å‘é€åˆ°ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬é€ä¸ªå‘é€ï¼Œæ¯æ¡é—´éš”ä¸€ç§’ï¼ˆé€šè¿‡ thread::sleep å’Œ Duration å€¼å®ç°ï¼‰ã€‚

In the main thread, weâ€™re not calling the recv function explicitly anymore: instead, weâ€™re treating rx as an iterator. For each value received, weâ€™re printing it. When the channel is closed, iteration will end.

ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ä¸å†æ˜¾å¼è°ƒç”¨ recvï¼šè€Œæ˜¯[note]å°† rx è§†ä¸ºè¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚å¯¹æ¯ä¸ªæ¥æ”¶å€¼æ‰“å°ã€‚é€šé“å…³é—­æ—¶è¿­ä»£ç»“æŸã€‚

When running the code in Listing 16-10, you should see the following output with a one-second pause in between each line:

è¿è¡Œç¤ºä¾‹ 16-10 çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œåº”åœ¨æ¯è¡Œè¾“å‡ºé—´çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€ç§’åœé¡¿ï¼š

Got: hi
Got: from
Got: the
Got: thread

Because we donâ€™t have any code that pauses or delays in the for loop in the main thread, we can tell that the main thread is waiting to receive values from the spawned thread.

å› ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹çš„ for å¾ªç¯æ— æš‚åœæˆ–å»¶è¿Ÿä»£ç ï¼Œå¯çŸ¥ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹åœ¨ç­‰å¾…æ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å‘é€å€¼ã€‚

Creating Multiple Producers by Cloning the Transmitter å…‹éš†å‘é€ç«¯ä»¥åˆ›å»ºå¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…

Earlier we mentioned that mpsc was an acronym for multiple producer, single consumer. Letâ€™s put mpsc to use and expand the code in Listing 16-10 to create multiple threads that all send values to the same receiver. We can do so by cloning the transmitter, as shown in Listing 16-11.

å‰æ–‡æåˆ° mpsc è¡¨ç¤ºå¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…ï¼Œå•æ¶ˆè´¹è€…ã€‚ç°ä½¿ç”¨ mpsc æ‰©å±•ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-10 çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå¤šçº¿ç¨‹å‘åŒä¸€æ¥æ”¶ç«¯å‘é€å€¼ã€‚å¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-11 æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œé€šè¿‡å…‹éš†å‘é€ç«¯å®ç°ã€‚

This time, before we create the first spawned thread, we call clone on the transmitter. This will give us a new transmitter we can pass to the first spawned thread. We pass the original transmitter to a second spawned thread. This gives us two threads, each sending different messages to the one receiver.

æ­¤æ¬¡åœ¨åˆ›å»ºç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹å‰ï¼Œ[note]å¯¹å‘é€ç«¯è°ƒç”¨ cloneã€‚è¿™æä¾›æ–°å‘é€ç«¯ä¼ é€’ç»™ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚åŸå§‹å‘é€ç«¯ä¼ é€’ç»™ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªæ´¾ç”Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚è¿™äº§ç”Ÿä¸¤ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œå„è‡ªå‘åŒä¸€æ¥æ”¶ç«¯å‘é€ä¸åŒæ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

When you run the code, your output should look something like this:

è¿è¡Œä»£ç ï¼Œè¾“å‡ºç±»ä¼¼å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

Got: hi
Got: more
Got: from
Got: messages
Got: for
Got: the
Got: thread
Got: you

You might see the values in another order, depending on your system. This is what makes concurrency interesting as well as difficult. If you experiment with thread::sleep, giving it various values in the different threads, each run will be more nondeterministic and create different output each time.

å€¼é¡ºåºå¯èƒ½å› ç³»ç»Ÿè€Œå¼‚ã€‚è¿™æ­£æ˜¯å¹¶å‘æœ‰è¶£ä¸”å›°éš¾ä¹‹å¤„ã€‚è‹¥ç”¨ thread::sleep åœ¨ä¸åŒçº¿ç¨‹è®¾ç½®ä¸åŒå€¼ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡è¿è¡Œå°†æ›´ä¸ç¡®å®šä¸”è¾“å‡ºä¸åŒã€‚

Now that weâ€™ve looked at how channels work, letâ€™s look at a different method of concurrency.

äº†è§£é€šé“å·¥ä½œåŸç†åï¼Œå†çœ‹å¦ä¸€ç§å¹¶å‘æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Shared-State Concurrency å…±äº«çŠ¶æ€å¹¶å‘

Message passing is a fine way to handle concurrency, but itâ€™s not the only way. Another method would be for multiple threads to access the same shared data. Consider this part of the slogan from the Go language documentation again: â€œDo not communicate by sharing memory.â€

æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’æ˜¯å¤„ç†å¹¶å‘çš„è‰¯æ–¹ï¼Œä½†éå”¯ä¸€æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å¦ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯å¤šçº¿ç¨‹è®¿é—®åŒä¸€å…±äº«æ•°æ®ã€‚å†æ€è€ƒ Go æ–‡æ¡£çš„å£å·ï¼šâ€œä¸è¦é€šè¿‡å…±äº«å†…å­˜æ¥é€šä¿¡ã€‚â€

What would communicating by sharing memory look like? In addition, why would message-passing enthusiasts caution not to use memory sharing?

å…±äº«å†…å­˜é€šä¿¡æ˜¯ä½•ç§å½¢å¼ï¼Ÿä¸ºä½•æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’å€¡å¯¼è€…è­¦å‘Šå‹¿ç”¨å…±äº«å†…å­˜ï¼Ÿ

In a way, channels in any programming language are similar to single ownership because once you transfer a value down a channel, you should no longer use that value. Shared-memory concurrency is like multiple ownership: multiple threads can access the same memory location at the same time. As you saw in Chapter 15, where smart pointers made multiple ownership possible, multiple ownership can add complexity because these different owners need managing. Rustâ€™s type system and ownership rules greatly assist in getting this management correct. For an example, letâ€™s look at mutexes, one of the more common concurrency primitives for shared memory.

æŸç§ç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šï¼Œä»»ä½•è¯­è¨€çš„é€šé“éƒ½ç±»ä¼¼å•ä¸€æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼Œå› å€¼ä¼ è¾“åä¸åº”å†ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚å…±äº«å†…å­˜å¹¶å‘ç±»ä¼¼å¤šæ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼šå¤šçº¿ç¨‹å¯åŒæ—¶è®¿é—®åŒä¸€å†…å­˜ä½ç½®ã€‚å¦‚ç¬¬ 15 ç« æ‰€è¿°ï¼Œæ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆä½¿å¤šæ‰€æœ‰æƒæˆä¸ºå¯èƒ½ï¼Œä½†ç®¡ç†ä¸åŒæ‰€æœ‰è€…ä¼šå¢åŠ å¤æ‚æ€§ã€‚Rust çš„ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿå’Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™æå¤§åŠ©åŠ›æ­¤ç®¡ç†çš„æ­£ç¡®æ€§ã€‚ä»¥äº’æ–¥é”ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯å…±äº«å†…å­˜çš„å¸¸è§å¹¶å‘åŸè¯­ã€‚

Using Mutexes to Allow Access to Data from One Thread at a Time ä½¿ç”¨äº’æ–¥é”ç¡®ä¿çº¿ç¨‹ç‹¬å è®¿é—®æ•°æ®

Mutex is an abbreviation for mutual exclusion, as in a mutex allows only one thread to access some data at any given time. To access the data in a mutex, a thread must first signal that it wants access by asking to acquire the mutexâ€™s lock. The lock is a data structure that is part of the mutex that keeps track of who currently has exclusive access to the data. Therefore, the mutex is described as guarding the data it holds via the locking system.

äº’æ–¥é”ï¼ˆMutexï¼‰æ˜¯â€œç›¸äº’æ’æ–¥â€çš„ç¼©å†™ï¼Œå› å…¶ä¸€æ¬¡ä»…å…è®¸ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹è®¿é—®æ•°æ®ã€‚è¦è®¿é—®äº’æ–¥é”æ•°æ®ï¼Œçº¿ç¨‹éœ€å…ˆè¯·æ±‚è·å–é”æ¥å‘å‡ºè®¿é—®ä¿¡å·ã€‚é”æ˜¯äº’æ–¥é”çš„æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼Œè·Ÿè¸ªå½“å‰è°ç‹¬å è®¿é—®æ•°æ®ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œäº’æ–¥é”é€šè¿‡é”å®šç³»ç»Ÿå®ˆæŠ¤å…¶æ•°æ®ã€‚

Mutexes have a reputation for being difficult to use because you have to remember two rules:

äº’æ–¥é”å› éš¾ç”¨è€Œé—»åï¼Œå› éœ€è®°ä½ä¸¤æ¡è§„åˆ™ï¼š

  1. You must attempt to acquire the lock before using the data.

  2. When youâ€™re done with the data that the mutex guards, you must unlock the data so other threads can acquire the lock.

  3. ä½¿ç”¨æ•°æ®å‰å¿…é¡»å°è¯•è·å–é”

  4. ä½¿ç”¨å®Œäº’æ–¥é”å®ˆæŠ¤çš„æ•°æ®åå¿…é¡»è§£é”ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿å…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹è·å–é”

For a real-world metaphor for a mutex, imagine a panel discussion at a conference with only one microphone. Before a panelist can speak, they have to ask or signal that they want to use the microphone. When they get the microphone, they can talk for as long as they want to and then hand the microphone to the next panelist who requests to speak. If a panelist forgets to hand the microphone off when theyâ€™re finished with it, no one else is able to speak. If management of the shared microphone goes wrong, the panel wonâ€™t work as planned!

äº’æ–¥é”çš„ç°å®éšå–»ï¼šä¼šè®®å°ç»„è®¨è®ºä»…æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªéº¦å…‹é£ã€‚å‘è¨€å‰éœ€è¯·æ±‚ä½¿ç”¨éº¦å…‹é£ã€‚è·å¾—åå‘è¨€æ—¶é•¿ä¸é™ï¼Œç»“æŸåä¼ é€’ç»™ä¸‹ä¸€ä½è¯·æ±‚å‘è¨€è€…ã€‚è‹¥å‘è¨€åæœªä¼ é€’éº¦å…‹é£ï¼Œå…¶ä»–äººå°†æ— æ³•å‘è¨€ã€‚å…±äº«éº¦å…‹é£ç®¡ç†å‡ºé”™å°†å¯¼è‡´è®¨è®ºæ··ä¹±ï¼

Management of mutexes can be incredibly tricky to get right, which is why so many people are enthusiastic about channels. However, thanks to Rustâ€™s type system and ownership rules, you canâ€™t get locking and unlocking wrong.

äº’æ–¥é”ç®¡ç†å¯èƒ½æå…¶å¤æ‚ï¼Œå› æ­¤è®¸å¤šäººçƒ­è¡·é€šé“ã€‚ä½†å¾—ç›Šäº Rust çš„ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿå’Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™ï¼Œé”å®šå’Œè§£é”ä¸ä¼šå‡ºé”™ã€‚

The API of Mutex<T> Mutex<T> çš„ API

As an example of how to use a mutex, letâ€™s start by using a mutex in a single-threaded context, as shown in Listing 16-12.

ä»¥å•çº¿ç¨‹ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä½¿ç”¨äº’æ–¥é”ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-12ã€‚

As with many types, we create a Mutex<T> using the associated function new. To access the data inside the mutex, we use the lock method to acquire the lock. This call will block the current thread so it canâ€™t do any work until itâ€™s our turn to have the lock.

ä¸è®¸å¤šç±»å‹ç›¸åŒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨[note]å…³è”å‡½æ•° new åˆ›å»º Mutex<T>ã€‚è¦è®¿é—®äº’æ–¥é”å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®ï¼Œéœ€ç”¨ lock æ–¹æ³•è·å–é”ã€‚æ­¤è°ƒç”¨é˜»å¡å½“å‰çº¿ç¨‹ç›´åˆ°è½®åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬æŒæœ‰é”ã€‚

The call to lock would fail if another thread holding the lock panicked. In that case, no one would ever be able to get the lock, so weâ€™ve chosen to unwrap and have this thread panic if weâ€™re in that situation.

[note]è‹¥æŒæœ‰é”çš„çº¿ç¨‹ panicï¼Œlock è°ƒç”¨ä¼šå¤±è´¥ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶æ— äººèƒ½è·å–é”ï¼Œæ•…é€‰æ‹© unwrap è®©æ­¤çº¿ç¨‹ panicã€‚

After weâ€™ve acquired the lock, we can treat the return value, named num in this case, as a mutable reference to the data inside. The type system ensures that we acquire a lock before using the value in m. The type of m is Mutex<i32>, not i32, so we must call lock to be able to use the i32 value. We canâ€™t forget; the type system wonâ€™t let us access the inner i32 otherwise.

[note]è·å–é”åï¼Œå¯å°†è¿”å›å€¼ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸º numï¼‰è§†ä¸ºå†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ã€‚ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿç¡®ä¿ä½¿ç”¨æ•°æ®å‰å…ˆè·å–é”ã€‚m ç±»å‹ä¸º Mutex<i32> è€Œé i32ï¼Œæ•…å¿…é¡»è°ƒç”¨ lock æ‰èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ i32 å€¼ã€‚ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿé˜²æ­¢æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥å…¶ä»–æ–¹å¼è®¿é—®å†…éƒ¨ i32ã€‚

The call to lock returns a type called MutexGuard, wrapped in a LockResult that we handled with the call to unwrap. The MutexGuard type implements Deref to point at our inner data; the type also has a Drop implementation that releases the lock automatically when a MutexGuard goes out of scope, which happens at the end of the inner scope. As a result, we donâ€™t risk forgetting to release the lock and blocking the mutex from being used by other threads because the lock release happens automatically.

[note]lock è°ƒç”¨è¿”å›åä¸º MutexGuard çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ŒåŒ…è£…åœ¨ LockResult ä¸­ï¼ˆé€šè¿‡ unwrap å¤„ç†ï¼‰ã€‚MutexGuard å®ç° Deref æŒ‡å‘å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®ï¼›å…¶è¿˜æœ‰ Drop å®ç°ï¼Œåœ¨ MutexGuard ç¦»å¼€ä½œç”¨åŸŸæ—¶è‡ªåŠ¨é‡Šæ”¾é”ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä¼šå¿˜è®°é‡Šæ”¾é”å¯¼è‡´äº’æ–¥é”è¢«å…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹é˜»å¡ã€‚

After dropping the lock, we can print the mutex value and see that we were able to change the inner i32 to 6.

é‡Šæ”¾é”åï¼Œå¯æ‰“å°äº’æ–¥é”å€¼ï¼Œå¯è§å†…éƒ¨ i32 æˆåŠŸæ”¹ä¸º 6ã€‚

Sharing a Mutex<T> Between Multiple Threads å¤šçº¿ç¨‹é—´å…±äº« Mutex<T>

Now letâ€™s try to share a value between multiple threads using Mutex<T>. Weâ€™ll spin up 10 threads and have them each increment a counter value by 1, so the counter goes from 0 to 10. The example in Listing 16-13 will have a compiler error, and weâ€™ll use that error to learn more about using Mutex<T> and how Rust helps us use it correctly.

ç°å°è¯•ç”¨ Mutex<T> åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´å…±äº«å€¼ã€‚å¯åŠ¨ 10 ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªå°†è®¡æ•°å™¨å€¼å¢åŠ  1ï¼Œä½¿è®¡æ•°å™¨ä» 0 åˆ° 10ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-13 å°†äº§ç”Ÿç¼–è¯‘é”™è¯¯ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†å€Ÿæ­¤å­¦ä¹  Mutex<T> çš„ä½¿ç”¨åŠ Rust å¦‚ä½•åŠ©å…¶æ­£ç¡®ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚

We create a counter variable to hold an i32 inside a Mutex<T>, as we did in Listing 16-12. Next, we create 10 threads by iterating over a range of numbers. We use thread::spawn and give all the threads the same closure: one that moves the counter into the thread, acquires a lock on the Mutex<T> by calling the lock method, and then adds 1 to the value in the mutex. When a thread finishes running its closure, num will go out of scope and release the lock so another thread can acquire it.

åˆ›å»º counter å˜é‡æŒæœ‰ Mutex<T> å†…çš„ i32ï¼ˆåŒç¤ºä¾‹ 16-12ï¼‰ã€‚æ¥ç€é€šè¿‡æ•°å­—èŒƒå›´è¿­ä»£åˆ›å»º 10 ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ thread::spawn å¹¶ä¼ é€’ç›¸åŒé—­åŒ…ï¼šç§»åŠ¨ counter åˆ°çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨ lock æ–¹æ³•è·å– Mutex<T> çš„é”ï¼Œç„¶åå°†äº’æ–¥é”å€¼åŠ  1ã€‚çº¿ç¨‹è¿è¡Œå®Œé—­åŒ…åï¼Œnum ç¦»å¼€ä½œç”¨åŸŸå¹¶é‡Šæ”¾é”ï¼Œå…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹å¯è·å–ã€‚

In the main thread, we collect all the join handles. Then, as we did in Listing 16-2, we call join on each handle to make sure all the threads finish. At that point, the main thread will acquire the lock and print the result of this program.

ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹æ”¶é›†æ‰€æœ‰è¿æ¥å¥æŸ„ã€‚ç„¶ååŒç¤ºä¾‹ 16-2ï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå¥æŸ„è°ƒç”¨ join ç¡®ä¿æ‰€æœ‰çº¿ç¨‹å®Œæˆã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹è·å–é”å¹¶æ‰“å°ç»“æœã€‚

We hinted that this example wouldnâ€™t compile. Now letâ€™s find out why!

æ­¤ä¾‹æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚ç°åœ¨æ‰¾å‡ºåŸå› ï¼

$ cargo run
   Compiling shared-state v0.1.0 (file:///projects/shared-state)
error[E0382]: borrow of moved value: `counter`
  --> src/main.rs:21:29
   |
5  |     let counter = Mutex::new(0);
   |         ------- move occurs because `counter` has type `Mutex<i32>`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
...
8  |     for _ in 0..10 {
   |     -------------- inside of this loop
9  |         let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
   |                                    ------- value moved into closure here, in previous iteration of loop
...
21 |     println!("Result: {}", *counter.lock().unwrap());
   |                             ^^^^^^^ value borrowed here after move
   |
help: consider moving the expression out of the loop so it is only moved once
   |
8  ~     let mut value = counter.lock();
9  ~     for _ in 0..10 {
10 |         let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
11 ~             let mut num = value.unwrap();
   |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0382`.
error: could not compile `shared-state` (bin "shared-state") due to 1 previous error

The error message states that the counter value was moved in the previous iteration of the loop. Rust is telling us that we canâ€™t move the ownership of lock counter into multiple threads. Letâ€™s fix the compiler error with the multiple-ownership method we discussed in Chapter 15.

é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯è¡¨æ˜ counter å€¼åœ¨ä¸Šæ¬¡å¾ªç¯è¿­ä»£ä¸­è¢«ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚Rust æç¤ºæ— æ³•å°†é” counter çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒç§»å…¥å¤šä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ç”¨ç¬¬ 15 ç« çš„å¤šæ‰€æœ‰æƒæ–¹æ³•ä¿®å¤æ­¤é”™è¯¯ã€‚

Multiple Ownership with Multiple Threads å¤šçº¿ç¨‹çš„å¤šæ‰€æœ‰æƒ

In Chapter 15, we gave a value to multiple owners by using the smart pointer Rc<T> to create a reference counted value. Letâ€™s do the same here and see what happens. Weâ€™ll wrap the Mutex<T> in Rc<T> in Listing 16-14 and clone the Rc<T> before moving ownership to the thread.

ç¬¬ 15 ç« ç”¨æ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆ Rc<T> åˆ›å»ºå¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°å€¼å®ç°å¤šæ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚ç°å°è¯•ç›¸åŒæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-14 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Once again, we compile and getâ€¦ different errors! The compiler is teaching us a lot.

å†æ¬¡ç¼–è¯‘åâ€¦å‡ºç°ä¸åŒé”™è¯¯ï¼ç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ•™ä¼šæˆ‘ä»¬è®¸å¤šã€‚

$ cargo run
   Compiling shared-state v0.1.0 (file:///projects/shared-state)
error[E0277]: `Rc<Mutex<i32>>` cannot be sent between threads safely
  --> src/main.rs:11:36
   |
11 |           let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
   |                        ------------- ^------
   |                        |             |
   |  ______________________|_____________within this `{closure@src/main.rs:11:36: 11:43}`
   | |                      |
   | |                      required by a bound introduced by this call
12 | |             let mut num = counter.lock().unwrap();
13 | |
14 | |             *num += 1;
15 | |         });
   | |_________^ `Rc<Mutex<i32>>` cannot be sent between threads safely
   |
   = help: within `{closure@src/main.rs:11:36: 11:43}`, the trait `Send` is not implemented for `Rc<Mutex<i32>>`
note: required because it's used within this closure
  --> src/main.rs:11:36
   |
11 |         let handle = thread::spawn(move || {
   |                                    ^^^^^^^
note: required by a bound in `spawn`
  --> /rustc/4eb161250e340c8f48f66e2b929ef4a5bed7c181/library/std/src/thread/mod.rs:728:1

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `shared-state` (bin "shared-state") due to 1 previous error

Wow, that error message is very wordy! Hereâ€™s the important part to focus on: `Rc<Mutex<i32>>` cannot be sent between threads safely. The compiler is also telling us the reason why: the trait `Send` is not implemented for `Rc<Mutex<i32>>`. Weâ€™ll talk about Send in the next section: itâ€™s one of the traits that ensures the types we use with threads are meant for use in concurrent situations.

é‡ç‚¹åœ¨äºï¼š`Rc<Mutex<i32>>` cannot be sent between threads safelyã€‚ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¹Ÿç»™å‡ºåŸå› ï¼šthe trait `Send` is not implemented for `Rc<Mutex<i32>>`ã€‚ä¸‹èŠ‚è®¨è®º Sendï¼šå®ƒæ˜¯ç¡®ä¿ç±»å‹ç”¨äºå¹¶å‘åœºæ™¯çš„ç‰¹å¾ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚

Unfortunately, Rc<T> is not safe to share across threads. When Rc<T> manages the reference count, it adds to the count for each call to clone and subtracts from the count when each clone is dropped. But it doesnâ€™t use any concurrency primitives to make sure that changes to the count canâ€™t be interrupted by another thread. This could lead to wrong countsâ€”subtle bugs that could in turn lead to memory leaks or a value being dropped before weâ€™re done with it. What we need is a type that is exactly like Rc<T>, but that makes changes to the reference count in a thread-safe way.

ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œ[note]Rc<T> ä¸èƒ½å®‰å…¨è·¨çº¿ç¨‹å…±äº«ã€‚å½“ Rc<T> ç®¡ç†å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œclone è°ƒç”¨å¢åŠ è®¡æ•°ï¼Œdrop è°ƒç”¨å‡å°‘è®¡æ•°ã€‚ä½†æœªä½¿ç”¨ä»»ä½•å¹¶å‘åŸè¯­ç¡®ä¿è®¡æ•°æ›´æ”¹ä¸è¢«å…¶ä»–çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­æ–­ã€‚è¿™å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´è®¡æ•°é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆè¿›è€Œå¯¼è‡´å†…å­˜æ³„æ¼æˆ–å€¼æå‰ä¸¢å¼ƒï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ç±»ä¼¼ Rc<T> ä½†çº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨æ›´æ”¹å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚

Atomic Reference Counting with Arc<T> åŸå­å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•° Arc<T>

Fortunately, Arc<T> is a type like Rc<T> that is safe to use in concurrent situations. The a stands for atomic, meaning itâ€™s an atomically reference-counted type. Atomics are an additional kind of concurrency primitive that we wonâ€™t cover in detail here: see the standard library documentation for std::sync::atomic for more details. At this point, you just need to know that atomics work like primitive types but are safe to share across threads.

å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œ[note]Arc<T> æ­£æ˜¯ç±»ä¼¼ Rc<T> ä½†çº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚a ä»£è¡¨åŸå­æ€§ï¼ˆatomicï¼‰ï¼Œå³åŸå­å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°ç±»å‹ã€‚åŸå­æ˜¯å¦ä¸€ç§å¹¶å‘åŸè¯­ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸èµ˜è¿°ï¼‰ï¼Œè¯¦è§æ ‡å‡†åº“æ–‡æ¡£ std::sync::atomicã€‚ç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥åŸå­ç±»å‹ç±»ä¼¼åŸå§‹ç±»å‹ä½†å¯å®‰å…¨è·¨çº¿ç¨‹å…±äº«ã€‚

You might then wonder why all primitive types arenâ€™t atomic and why standard library types arenâ€™t implemented to use Arc<T> by default. The reason is that thread safety comes with a performance penalty that you only want to pay when you really need to. If youâ€™re just performing operations on values within a single thread, your code can run faster if it doesnâ€™t have to enforce the guarantees atomics provide.

ä½ å¯èƒ½å¥½å¥‡ä¸ºä½•æ‰€æœ‰åŸå§‹ç±»å‹éåŸå­ï¼Œä»¥åŠæ ‡å‡†åº“ç±»å‹ä¸ºä½•ä¸é»˜è®¤ç”¨ Arc<T>ã€‚åŸå› æ˜¯[note]çº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨éœ€æ€§èƒ½ä»£ä»·ï¼Œä»…å½“çœŸæ­£éœ€è¦æ—¶æ‰åº”æ”¯ä»˜ã€‚è‹¥ä»…åœ¨å•çº¿ç¨‹æ“ä½œå€¼ï¼Œä¸å¼ºåˆ¶åŸå­ä¿è¯å¯ä½¿ä»£ç æ›´å¿«ã€‚

Letâ€™s return to our example: Arc<T> and Rc<T> have the same API, so we fix our program by changing the use line, the call to new, and the call to clone. The code in Listing 16-15 will finally compile and run.

å›åˆ°ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼šArc<T> å’Œ Rc<T> API ç›¸åŒï¼Œæ•…ä¿®æ”¹ use è¡Œã€new å’Œ clone è°ƒç”¨å³å¯ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-15 æœ€ç»ˆå¯ç¼–è¯‘è¿è¡Œã€‚

This code will print the following:

ä»£ç å°†æ‰“å°ï¼š

Result: 10

We did it! We counted from 0 to 10, which may not seem very impressive, but it did teach us a lot about Mutex<T> and thread safety. You could also use this programâ€™s structure to do more complicated operations than just incrementing a counter. Using this strategy, you can divide a calculation into independent parts, split those parts across threads, and then use a Mutex<T> to have each thread update the final result with its part.

æˆåŠŸäº†ï¼ä» 0 è®¡æ•°åˆ° 10 å¯èƒ½ä¸æƒŠäººï¼Œä½†æ•™ä¼šæˆ‘ä»¬è®¸å¤š Mutex<T> å’Œçº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨çŸ¥è¯†ã€‚ä½ ä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨æ­¤ç¨‹åºç»“æ„æ‰§è¡Œæ¯”é€’å¢è®¡æ•°å™¨æ›´å¤æ‚çš„æ“ä½œã€‚ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤ç­–ç•¥ï¼Œå¯å°†è®¡ç®—æ‹†åˆ†ä¸ºç‹¬ç«‹éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œåˆ†é…åˆ°ä¸åŒçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œç„¶åç”¨ Mutex<T> è®©æ¯ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹æ›´æ–°å…¶éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æœ€ç»ˆç»“æœã€‚

Note that if you are doing simple numerical operations, there are types simpler than Mutex<T> types provided by the std::sync::atomic module of the standard library. These types provide safe, concurrent, atomic access to primitive types. We chose to use Mutex<T> with a primitive type for this example so we could concentrate on how Mutex<T> works.

æ³¨æ„ï¼š[note]è‹¥è¿›è¡Œç®€å•æ•°å€¼æ“ä½œï¼Œæ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ std::sync::atomic æ¨¡å—æä¾›æ¯” Mutex<T> æ›´ç®€å•çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚è¿™äº›ç±»å‹æä¾›å¯¹åŸå§‹ç±»å‹çš„å®‰å…¨å¹¶å‘åŸå­è®¿é—®ã€‚æ­¤ä¾‹é€‰æ‹©å¯¹åŸå§‹ç±»å‹ç”¨ Mutex<T> æ˜¯ä¸ºä¸“æ³¨äº Mutex<T> å·¥ä½œåŸç†ã€‚

Similarities Between RefCell<T>/Rc<T> and Mutex<T>/Arc<T> RefCell<T>/Rc<T> ä¸ Mutex<T>/Arc<T> çš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§

You might have noticed that counter is immutable but we could get a mutable reference to the value inside it; this means Mutex<T> provides interior mutability, as the Cell family does. In the same way we used RefCell<T> in Chapter 15 to allow us to mutate contents inside an Rc<T>, we use Mutex<T> to mutate contents inside an Arc<T>.

ä½ å¯èƒ½æ³¨æ„åˆ° counter ä¸å¯å˜ä½†èƒ½è·å–å†…éƒ¨å€¼çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼›è¿™æ„å‘³ç€ Mutex<T> æä¾›å†…éƒ¨å¯å˜æ€§ï¼ˆåŒ Cell ç³»åˆ—ï¼‰ã€‚ç±»ä¼¼ç¬¬ 15 ç« ç”¨ RefCell<T> åœ¨ Rc<T> å†…éƒ¨å¯å˜å†…å®¹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ Mutex<T> åœ¨ Arc<T> å†…éƒ¨å¯å˜å†…å®¹ã€‚

Another detail to note is that Rust canâ€™t protect you from all kinds of logic errors when you use Mutex<T>. Recall from Chapter 15 that using Rc<T> came with the risk of creating reference cycles, where two Rc<T> values refer to each other, causing memory leaks. Similarly, Mutex<T> comes with the risk of creating deadlocks. These occur when an operation needs to lock two resources and two threads have each acquired one of the locks, causing them to wait for each other forever. If youâ€™re interested in deadlocks, try creating a Rust program that has a deadlock; then research deadlock mitigation strategies for mutexes in any language and have a go at implementing them in Rust. The standard library API documentation for Mutex<T> and MutexGuard offers useful information.

å¦éœ€æ³¨æ„ï¼šä½¿ç”¨ Mutex<T> æ—¶ï¼ŒRust æ— æ³•é˜²æ­¢æ‰€æœ‰é€»è¾‘é”™è¯¯ã€‚å›é¡¾ç¬¬ 15 ç« ï¼Œ[note]ä½¿ç”¨ Rc<T> æœ‰åˆ›å»ºå¼•ç”¨å¾ªç¯çš„é£é™©ï¼ˆä¸¤ä¸ª Rc<T> ç›¸äº’å¼•ç”¨å¯¼è‡´å†…å­˜æ³„æ¼ï¼‰ã€‚ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼ŒMutex<T> æœ‰åˆ›å»ºæ­»é”çš„é£é™©ã€‚æ­»é”å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨æ“ä½œéœ€é”ä¸¤ä¸ªèµ„æºï¼Œè€Œä¸¤çº¿ç¨‹å„æŒæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªé”æ—¶ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´å½¼æ­¤æ°¸ä¹…ç­‰å¾…ã€‚è‹¥å¯¹æ­»é”æ„Ÿå…´è¶£ï¼Œå¯å°è¯•ç”¨ Rust ç¼–å†™æ­»é”ç¨‹åºï¼Œç ”ç©¶ä»»æ„è¯­è¨€çš„äº’æ–¥é”æ­»é”ç¼“è§£ç­–ç•¥å¹¶åœ¨ Rust ä¸­å®ç°ã€‚Mutex<T> å’Œ MutexGuard çš„æ ‡å‡†åº“ API æ–‡æ¡£æä¾›äº†æœ‰ç”¨ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Weâ€™ll round out this chapter by talking about the Send and Sync traits and how we can use them with custom types.

æœ€åè®¨è®º Send å’Œ Sync ç‰¹å¾åŠå…¶åœ¨è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ä¸­çš„åº”ç”¨ã€‚

Extensible Concurrency with the Send and Sync Traits é€šè¿‡ Send å’Œ Sync ç‰¹å¾æ‰©å±•å¹¶å‘

Interestingly, almost every concurrency feature weâ€™ve talked about so far in this chapter has been part of the standard library, not the language. Your options for handling concurrency are not limited to the language or the standard library; you can write your own concurrency features or use those written by others.

æœ‰è¶£çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæœ¬ç« è®¨è®ºçš„å¤šæ•°å¹¶å‘ç‰¹æ€§å±äºæ ‡å‡†åº“è€Œéè¯­è¨€æœ¬èº«ã€‚å¤„ç†å¹¶å‘çš„é€‰æ‹©ä¸é™äºè¯­è¨€æˆ–æ ‡å‡†åº“ï¼›å¯ç¼–å†™è‡ªå·±çš„å¹¶å‘ç‰¹æ€§æˆ–ä½¿ç”¨ä»–äººç¼–å†™çš„ã€‚

However, among the key concurrency concepts that are embedded in the language rather than the standard library are the std::marker traits Send and Sync.

ä½†[note]è¯­è¨€æœ¬èº«ï¼ˆè€Œéæ ‡å‡†åº“ï¼‰çš„å…³é”®å¹¶å‘æ¦‚å¿µæ˜¯ std::marker ç‰¹å¾ Send å’Œ Syncã€‚

Allowing Transference of Ownership Between Threads with Send ç”¨ Send å…è®¸æ‰€æœ‰æƒåœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´è½¬ç§»

The Send marker trait indicates that ownership of values of the type implementing Send can be transferred between threads. Almost every Rust type implements Send, but there are some exceptions, including Rc<T>: this cannot implement Send because if you cloned an Rc<T> value and tried to transfer ownership of the clone to another thread, both threads might update the reference count at the same time. For this reason, Rc<T> is implemented for use in single-threaded situations where you donâ€™t want to pay the thread-safe performance penalty.

[note]Send æ ‡è®°ç‰¹å¾è¡¨ç¤ºå®ç° Send çš„ç±»å‹å€¼å¯è·¨çº¿ç¨‹è½¬ç§»æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰ Rust ç±»å‹éƒ½å®ç° Sendï¼Œä½†ä¾‹å¤–åŒ…æ‹¬ Rc<T>ï¼šè‹¥å…‹éš† Rc<T> å€¼å¹¶å°è¯•å°†å…‹éš†æ‰€æœ‰æƒè½¬ç§»åˆ°å¦ä¸€çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œä¸¤çº¿ç¨‹å¯èƒ½åŒæ—¶æ›´æ–°å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°ã€‚å› æ­¤ Rc<T> ä»…ç”¨äºå•çº¿ç¨‹åœºæ™¯ï¼ˆé¿å…çº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨æ€§èƒ½ä»£ä»·ï¼‰ã€‚

Therefore, Rustâ€™s type system and trait bounds ensure that you can never accidentally send an Rc<T> value across threads unsafely. When we tried to do this in Listing 16-14, we got the error the trait `Send` is not implemented for `Rc<Mutex<i32>>`. When we switched to Arc<T>, which does implement Send, the code compiled.

å› æ­¤ï¼ŒRust çš„ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿå’Œç‰¹å¾è¾¹ç•Œç¡®ä¿ä¸ä¼šæ„å¤–ä¸å®‰å…¨åœ°è·¨çº¿ç¨‹å‘é€ Rc<T> å€¼ã€‚å°è¯•åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 16-14 ä¸­æ“ä½œæ—¶ï¼Œå‡ºç°é”™è¯¯ the trait `Send` is not implemented for `Rc<Mutex<i32>>`ã€‚æ”¹ç”¨å®ç° Send çš„ Arc<T> åï¼Œä»£ç æˆåŠŸç¼–è¯‘ã€‚

Any type composed entirely of Send types is automatically marked as Send as well. Almost all primitive types are Send, aside from raw pointers, which weâ€™ll discuss in Chapter 20.

[note]å®Œå…¨ç”± Send ç±»å‹ç»„æˆçš„ç±»å‹è‡ªåŠ¨æ ‡è®°ä¸º Sendã€‚é™¤åŸå§‹æŒ‡é’ˆï¼ˆç¬¬ 20 ç« è®¨è®ºï¼‰å¤–ï¼Œå‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰åŸå§‹ç±»å‹éƒ½æ˜¯ Sendã€‚

Allowing Access from Multiple Threads with Sync ç”¨ Sync å…è®¸å¤šçº¿ç¨‹è®¿é—®

The Sync marker trait indicates that it is safe for the type implementing Sync to be referenced from multiple threads. In other words, any type T implements Sync if &T (an immutable reference to T) implements Send, meaning the reference can be sent safely to another thread. Similar to Send, primitive types all implement Sync, and types composed entirely of types that implement Sync also implement Sync.

[note]Sync æ ‡è®°ç‰¹å¾è¡¨ç¤ºå®ç° Sync çš„ç±»å‹å¯å®‰å…¨åœ°è¢«å¤šçº¿ç¨‹å¼•ç”¨ã€‚æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼Œè‹¥ &Tï¼ˆT çš„ä¸å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼‰å®ç° Sendï¼ˆå³å¼•ç”¨å¯å®‰å…¨å‘é€åˆ°å¦ä¸€çº¿ç¨‹ï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™ç±»å‹ T å®ç° Syncã€‚ä¸ Send ç±»ä¼¼ï¼ŒåŸå§‹ç±»å‹éƒ½å®ç° Syncï¼Œå®Œå…¨ç”± Sync ç±»å‹ç»„æˆçš„ç±»å‹ä¹Ÿå®ç° Syncã€‚

The smart pointer Rc<T> also doesnâ€™t implement Sync for the same reasons that it doesnâ€™t implement Send. The RefCell<T> type (which we talked about in Chapter 15) and the family of related Cell<T> types donâ€™t implement Sync. The implementation of borrow checking that RefCell<T> does at runtime is not thread-safe. The smart pointer Mutex<T> implements Sync and can be used to share access with multiple threads, as you saw in â€œSharing a Mutex<T> Between Multiple Threadsâ€.

æ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆ Rc<T> åŒæ ·å›  Send çš„ç›¸åŒåŸå› ä¸å®ç° Syncã€‚RefCell<T> ç±»å‹ï¼ˆç¬¬ 15 ç« è®¨è®ºï¼‰åŠç›¸å…³ Cell<T> ç±»å‹ä¸å®ç° Syncã€‚RefCell<T> çš„è¿è¡Œæ—¶å€Ÿç”¨æ£€æŸ¥éçº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨ã€‚æ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆ Mutex<T> å®ç° Sync ä¸”å¯å…±äº«è®¿é—®å¤šçº¿ç¨‹ï¼ˆå¦‚â€œå¤šçº¿ç¨‹é—´å…±äº« Mutex<T>â€æ‰€ç¤ºï¼‰ã€‚

Implementing Send and Sync Manually Is Unsafe æ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç° Send å’Œ Sync ä¸å®‰å…¨

Because types composed entirely of other types that implement the Send and Sync traits also automatically implement Send and Sync, we donâ€™t have to implement those traits manually. As marker traits, they donâ€™t even have any methods to implement. Theyâ€™re just useful for enforcing invariants related to concurrency.

å› å®Œå…¨ç”±å®ç° Send å’Œ Sync ç‰¹å¾çš„ç±»å‹ç»„æˆçš„ç±»å‹è‡ªåŠ¨å®ç°è¿™äº›ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œæ•…æ— éœ€æ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°ã€‚ä½œä¸ºæ ‡è®°ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬ç”šè‡³æ— éœ€å®ç°æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å®ƒä»¬ä»…ç”¨äºå¼ºåˆ¶å¹¶å‘ç›¸å…³çš„ä¸å˜æ€§ã€‚

Manually implementing these traits involves implementing unsafe Rust code. Weâ€™ll talk about using unsafe Rust code in Chapter 20; for now, the important information is that building new concurrent types not made up of Send and Sync parts requires careful thought to uphold the safety guarantees. â€œThe Rustonomiconâ€ has more information about these guarantees and how to uphold them.

æ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°è¿™äº›ç‰¹å¾æ¶‰åŠä¸å®‰å…¨ Rust ä»£ç ï¼ˆç¬¬ 20 ç« è®¨è®ºï¼‰ã€‚ç›®å‰éœ€çŸ¥ï¼šæ„å»ºéç”± Send å’Œ Sync éƒ¨åˆ†ç»„æˆçš„å¹¶å‘æ–°ç±»å‹éœ€è°¨æ…æ€è€ƒä»¥ä¿è¯å®‰å…¨ã€‚ã€ŠRust ç§˜å…¸ã€‹æœ‰æ›´å¤šå…³äºè¿™äº›ä¿è¯åŠå¦‚ä½•ç»´æŠ¤çš„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

This isnâ€™t the last youâ€™ll see of concurrency in this book: the next chapter focuses on async programming, and the project in Chapter 21 will use the concepts in this chapter in a more realistic situation than the smaller examples discussed here.

æœ¬ä¹¦åç»­ç« èŠ‚ä»æ¶‰åŠå¹¶å‘ï¼šä¸‹ä¸€ç« èšç„¦å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼Œç¬¬ 21 ç« é¡¹ç›®å°†åœ¨æ¯”å°ç¤ºä¾‹æ›´çœŸå®çš„åœºæ™¯ä½¿ç”¨æœ¬ç« æ¦‚å¿µã€‚

As mentioned earlier, because very little of how Rust handles concurrency is part of the language, many concurrency solutions are implemented as crates. These evolve more quickly than the standard library, so be sure to search online for the current, state-of-the-art crates to use in multithreaded situations.

å¦‚å‰æ‰€è¿°ï¼ŒRust å¤„ç†å¹¶å‘çš„æ–¹å¼æå°‘å±äºè¯­è¨€æœ¬èº«ï¼Œæ•…è®¸å¤šå¹¶å‘æ–¹æ¡ˆä»¥ crate å½¢å¼å®ç°ã€‚è¿™äº› crate æ¯”æ ‡å‡†åº“å‘å±•æ›´å¿«ï¼Œå› æ­¤åŠ¡å¿…åœ¨çº¿æœç´¢å½“å‰å¤šçº¿ç¨‹åœºæ™¯çš„æœ€æ–° crateã€‚

The Rust standard library provides channels for message passing and smart pointer types, such as Mutex<T> and Arc<T>, that are safe to use in concurrent contexts. The type system and the borrow checker ensure that the code using these solutions wonâ€™t end up with data races or invalid references. Once you get your code to compile, you can rest assured that it will happily run on multiple threads without the kinds of hard-to-track-down bugs common in other languages. Concurrent programming is no longer a concept to be afraid of: go forth and make your programs concurrent, fearlessly!

Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸ºå¹¶å‘åœºæ™¯æä¾›é€šé“æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’å’Œæ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ Mutex<T> å’Œ Arc<T>ï¼‰ã€‚ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿå’Œå€Ÿç”¨æ£€æŸ¥å™¨ç¡®ä¿ä½¿ç”¨è¿™äº›æ–¹æ¡ˆçš„ä»£ç ä¸ä¼šå‡ºç°æ•°æ®ç«äº‰æˆ–æ— æ•ˆå¼•ç”¨ã€‚ä¸€æ—¦ä»£ç ç¼–è¯‘é€šè¿‡ï¼Œå¯ç¡®ä¿¡å…¶èƒ½æ— å¿§è¿è¡Œäºå¤šçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚å¹¶å‘ç¼–ç¨‹ä¸å†å¯æ€•ï¼šæ— ç•åœ°å‰è¿›ï¼Œè®©ä½ çš„ç¨‹åºå¹¶å‘å§ï¼

Fundamentals of Asynchronous Programming: Async, Await, Futures, and Streams å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹åŸºç¡€

Many operations we ask the computer to do can take a while to finish. It would be nice if we could do something else while we are waiting for those long-running processes to complete. Modern computers offer two techniques for working on more than one operation at a time: parallelism and concurrency. Once we start writing programs that involve parallel or concurrent operations, though, we quickly encounter new challenges inherent to asynchronous programming, where operations may not finish sequentially in the order they were started. This chapter builds on Chapter 16â€™s use of threads for parallelism and concurrency by introducing an alternative approach to asynchronous programming: Rustâ€™s Futures, Streams, the async and await syntax that supports them, and the tools for managing and coordinating between asynchronous operations.

æˆ‘ä»¬è¦æ±‚è®¡ç®—æœºæ‰§è¡Œçš„è®¸å¤šæ“ä½œå¯èƒ½éœ€è¦ä¸€æ®µæ—¶é—´æ‰èƒ½å®Œæˆã€‚å¦‚æœåœ¨ç­‰å¾…è¿™äº›é•¿æ—¶é—´è¿è¡Œçš„è¿‡ç¨‹å®Œæˆæ—¶èƒ½åšå…¶ä»–äº‹æƒ…å°±å¥½äº†ã€‚ç°ä»£è®¡ç®—æœºæä¾›äº†ä¸¤ç§åŒæ—¶å¤„ç†å¤šä¸ªæ“ä½œçš„æŠ€æœ¯ï¼šå¹¶è¡Œå’Œå¹¶å‘ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œä¸€æ—¦æˆ‘ä»¬å¼€å§‹ç¼–å†™æ¶‰åŠå¹¶è¡Œæˆ–å¹¶å‘æ“ä½œçš„ç¨‹åºï¼Œå¾ˆå¿«å°±ä¼šé‡åˆ°å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹å›ºæœ‰çš„æ–°æŒ‘æˆ˜â€”â€”æ“ä½œå¯èƒ½ä¸ä¼šæŒ‰ç…§å¯åŠ¨é¡ºåºä¾æ¬¡å®Œæˆã€‚æœ¬ç« åœ¨ç¬¬16ç« ä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹å®ç°å¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘çš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šï¼Œä»‹ç»å¦ä¸€ç§å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹æ–¹æ³•ï¼šRust çš„ Futureã€Streamã€æ”¯æŒå®ƒä»¬çš„ async å’Œ await è¯­æ³•ï¼Œä»¥åŠç®¡ç†å’Œåè°ƒå¼‚æ­¥æ“ä½œçš„å·¥å…·ã€‚

Letâ€™s consider an example. Say youâ€™re exporting a video youâ€™ve created of a family celebration, an operation that could take anywhere from minutes to hours. The video export will use as much CPU and GPU power as it can. If you had only one CPU core and your operating system didnâ€™t pause that export until it completedâ€”that is, if it executed the export synchronouslyâ€”you couldnâ€™t do anything else on your computer while that task was running. That would be a pretty frustrating experience. Fortunately, your computerâ€™s operating system can, and does, invisibly interrupt the export often enough to let you get other work done simultaneously.

è€ƒè™‘ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­ã€‚å‡è®¾ä½ æ­£åœ¨å¯¼å‡ºå®¶åº­åº†ç¥æ´»åŠ¨çš„è§†é¢‘ï¼Œè¯¥æ“ä½œå¯èƒ½éœ€è¦å‡ åˆ†é’Ÿåˆ°å‡ å°æ—¶ã€‚è§†é¢‘å¯¼å‡ºä¼šå°½å¯èƒ½å ç”¨ CPU å’Œ GPU èµ„æºã€‚å¦‚æœåªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª CPU æ ¸å¿ƒï¼Œä¸”æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿåœ¨å¯¼å‡ºå®Œæˆå‰ä¸æš‚åœï¼ˆå³åŒæ­¥æ‰§è¡Œå¯¼å‡ºï¼‰ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä»»åŠ¡è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä½ å°†æ— æ³•åœ¨è®¡ç®—æœºä¸Šæ‰§è¡Œå…¶ä»–æ“ä½œã€‚è¿™ç§ä½“éªŒç›¸å½“ä»¤äººæ²®ä¸§ã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè®¡ç®—æœºæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿèƒ½å¤Ÿï¼ˆä¸”ç¡®å®ï¼‰é¢‘ç¹åœ°é€æ˜ä¸­æ–­å¯¼å‡ºï¼Œè®©ä½ åŒæ—¶å®Œæˆå…¶ä»–å·¥ä½œã€‚

Now say youâ€™re downloading a video shared by someone else, which can also take a while but does not take up as much CPU time. In this case, the CPU has to wait for data to arrive from the network. While you can start reading the data once it starts to arrive, it might take some time for all of it to show up. Even once the data is all present, if the video is quite large, it could take at least a second or two to load it all. That might not sound like much, but itâ€™s a very long time for a modern processor, which can perform billions of operations every second. Again, your operating system will invisibly interrupt your program to allow the CPU to perform other work while waiting for the network call to finish.

å†å‡è®¾ä½ æ­£åœ¨ä¸‹è½½ä»–äººåˆ†äº«çš„è§†é¢‘ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿéœ€è¦æ—¶é—´ä½†å ç”¨è¾ƒå°‘ CPU æ—¶é—´ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ CPU éœ€ç­‰å¾…ç½‘ç»œæ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“ã€‚è™½ç„¶æ•°æ®å¼€å§‹åˆ°è¾¾åå³å¯è¯»å–ï¼Œä½†å…¨éƒ¨æ•°æ®åˆ°è¾¾å¯èƒ½éœ€è¦æ—¶é—´ã€‚å³ä½¿æ•°æ®å…¨éƒ¨åˆ°ä½ï¼Œè‹¥è§†é¢‘å¾ˆå¤§ï¼ŒåŠ è½½ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½è€—æ—¶ä¸€ä¸¤ç§’ã€‚è¿™å¯¹ç°ä»£å¤„ç†å™¨æ¥è¯´å¾ˆé•¿ï¼ˆæ¯ç§’å¯æ‰§è¡Œæ•°åäº¿æ¬¡æ“ä½œï¼‰ã€‚åŒæ ·ï¼Œæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¼šé€æ˜ä¸­æ–­ç¨‹åºï¼Œè®© CPU åœ¨ç­‰å¾…ç½‘ç»œè°ƒç”¨å®Œæˆæ—¶æ‰§è¡Œå…¶ä»–å·¥ä½œã€‚

The video export is an example of a CPU-bound or compute-bound operation. Itâ€™s limited by the computerâ€™s potential data processing speed within the CPU or GPU, and how much of that speed it can dedicate to the operation. The video download is an example of an IO-bound operation, because itâ€™s limited by the speed of the computerâ€™s input and output; it can only go as fast as the data can be sent across the network.

è§†é¢‘å¯¼å‡ºæ˜¯ CPU å¯†é›†å‹ï¼ˆæˆ–è®¡ç®—å¯†é›†å‹ï¼‰æ“ä½œçš„ä¾‹å­ï¼Œå…¶æ€§èƒ½å—é™äº CPU/GPU çš„æ•°æ®å¤„ç†èƒ½åŠ›åŠåˆ†é…ç»™è¯¥æ“ä½œçš„èµ„æºã€‚è§†é¢‘ä¸‹è½½åˆ™æ˜¯ I/O å¯†é›†å‹æ“ä½œçš„ä¾‹å­ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒå—é™äºè®¡ç®—æœºçš„è¾“å…¥/è¾“å‡ºé€Ÿåº¦ï¼Œåªèƒ½ä»¥ç½‘ç»œä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®çš„é€Ÿåº¦è¿›è¡Œã€‚

In both of these examples, the operating systemâ€™s invisible interrupts provide a form of concurrency. That concurrency happens only at the level of the entire program, though: the operating system interrupts one program to let other programs get work done. In many cases, because we understand our programs at a much more granular level than the operating system does, we can spot opportunities for concurrency that the operating system canâ€™t see.

è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªä¾‹å­ä¸­ï¼Œæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿçš„é€æ˜ä¸­æ–­æä¾›äº†å¹¶å‘æ€§ã€‚ä½†è¿™ç§å¹¶å‘ä»…åœ¨ç¨‹åºçº§åˆ«å‘ç”Ÿï¼šæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¸­æ–­ä¸€ä¸ªç¨‹åºä»¥è®©å…¶ä»–ç¨‹åºå·¥ä½œã€‚é€šå¸¸ï¼Œç”±äºæˆ‘ä»¬æ¯”æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿæ›´ç»†è‡´åœ°ç†è§£ç¨‹åºï¼Œèƒ½å‘ç°æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿæ— æ³•å¯Ÿè§‰çš„å¹¶å‘æœºä¼šã€‚

For example, if weâ€™re building a tool to manage file downloads, we should be able to write our program so that starting one download wonâ€™t lock up the UI, and users should be able to start multiple downloads at the same time. Many operating system APIs for interacting with the network are blocking, though; that is, they block the programâ€™s progress until the data theyâ€™re processing is completely ready.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæ„å»ºæ–‡ä»¶ä¸‹è½½ç®¡ç†å·¥å…·æ—¶ï¼Œç¨‹åºåº”æ”¯æŒå¯åŠ¨ä¸‹è½½æ—¶ä¸é”å®š UIï¼Œä¸”ç”¨æˆ·åº”èƒ½åŒæ—¶å¯åŠ¨å¤šä¸ªä¸‹è½½ã€‚ä½†è®¸å¤šä¸ç½‘ç»œäº¤äº’çš„æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿ API æ˜¯é˜»å¡çš„â€”â€”å³å®ƒä»¬ä¼šé˜»å¡ç¨‹åºè¿›åº¦ï¼Œç›´åˆ°å¤„ç†çš„æ•°æ®å®Œå…¨å°±ç»ªã€‚

Note: This is how most function calls work, if you think about it. However, the term blocking is usually reserved for function calls that interact with files, the network, or other resources on the computer, because those are the cases where an individual program would benefit from the operation being non-blocking.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šç»†æƒ³ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œå¤§å¤šæ•°å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨éƒ½æ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ã€‚ä½†æœ¯è¯­é˜»å¡é€šå¸¸ä¸“ç”¨äºä¸æ–‡ä»¶ã€ç½‘ç»œæˆ–å…¶ä»–è®¡ç®—æœºèµ„æºäº¤äº’çš„å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™äº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹å•ä¸ªç¨‹åºä¼šå—ç›Šäºéé˜»å¡æ“ä½œã€‚

We could avoid blocking our main thread by spawning a dedicated thread to download each file. However, the overhead of those threads would eventually become a problem. It would be preferable if the call didnâ€™t block in the first place. It would also be better if we could write in the same direct style we use in blocking code, similar to this:

å¯é€šè¿‡ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶ä¸‹è½½ç”Ÿæˆä¸“ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹æ¥é¿å…é˜»å¡ä¸»çº¿ç¨‹ã€‚ä½†çº¿ç¨‹å¼€é”€æœ€ç»ˆä¼šæˆä¸ºé—®é¢˜ã€‚ç†æƒ³æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æœ¬èº«åº”æ˜¯éé˜»å¡çš„ï¼Œä¸”èƒ½ä»¥ç±»ä¼¼é˜»å¡ä»£ç çš„ç›´æ¥é£æ ¼ç¼–å†™ï¼š

let data = fetch_data_from(url).await;
println!("{data}");

That is exactly what Rustâ€™s async (short for asynchronous) abstraction gives us. In this chapter, youâ€™ll learn all about async as we cover the following topics:

è¿™æ­£æ˜¯ Rust çš„å¼‚æ­¥ï¼ˆasyncï¼‰æŠ½è±¡æä¾›çš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æœ¬ç« å°†æ¶µç›–ä»¥ä¸‹ä¸»é¢˜ï¼š

  • How to use Rustâ€™s async and await syntax

  • How to use the async model to solve some of the same challenges we looked at in Chapter 16

  • How multithreading and async provide complementary solutions, that you can combine in many cases

  • å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ Rust çš„ async å’Œ await è¯­æ³•

  • å¦‚ä½•ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥æ¨¡å‹è§£å†³ç¬¬16ç« ä¸­çš„ç›¸åŒæŒ‘æˆ˜

  • å¤šçº¿ç¨‹ä¸å¼‚æ­¥å¦‚ä½•æä¾›äº’è¡¥è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå¹¶å¯åœ¨è®¸å¤šæƒ…å†µä¸‹ç»“åˆä½¿ç”¨

Before we see how async works in practice, though, we need to take a short detour to discuss the differences between parallelism and concurrency.

åœ¨å®è·µå¼‚æ­¥ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œéœ€ç®€è¦è®¨è®ºå¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘çš„åŒºåˆ«ã€‚

Parallelism and Concurrency å¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘

Weâ€™ve treated parallelism and concurrency as mostly interchangeable so far. Now we need to distinguish between them more precisely, because the differences will show up as we start working.

æ­¤å‰æˆ‘ä»¬å‡ ä¹å°†å¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘è§†ä¸ºåŒä¹‰è¯ã€‚ç°åœ¨éœ€è¦æ›´ç²¾ç¡®åŒºåˆ†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå·®å¼‚ä¼šåœ¨å®é™…å·¥ä½œä¸­æ˜¾ç°ã€‚

Consider the different ways a team could split up work on a software project. You could assign a single member multiple tasks, assign each member one task, or use a mix of the two approaches.

è€ƒè™‘å›¢é˜Ÿåˆ†å·¥çš„ä¸åŒæ–¹å¼ï¼šå¯åˆ†é…å•äººå¤šä»»åŠ¡ã€æ¯äººå•ä»»åŠ¡æˆ–æ··åˆæ¨¡å¼ã€‚ä¸ªäººåœ¨ä»»åŠ¡å®Œæˆå‰å¤„ç†å¤šä¸ªä¸åŒä»»åŠ¡æ˜¯å¹¶å‘ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ä½ åœ¨è®¡ç®—æœºä¸Šæ£€å‡ºä¸¤ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®ï¼Œå½“å¯¹ä¸€ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®æ„Ÿåˆ°åŒå€¦æˆ–å¡ä½æ—¶åˆ‡æ¢åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªã€‚ä½œä¸ºä¸ªä½“ï¼Œä½ æ— æ³•åŒæ—¶æ¨è¿›ä¸¤é¡¹ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä½†å¯é€šè¿‡åˆ‡æ¢è¿›è¡Œå¤šä»»åŠ¡å¤„ç†ï¼ˆè§å›¾17-1ï¼‰ã€‚

When an individual works on several different tasks before any of them is complete, this is concurrency. Maybe you have two different projects checked out on your computer, and when you get bored or stuck on one project, you switch to the other. Youâ€™re just one person, so you canâ€™t make progress on both tasks at the exact same time, but you can multi-task, making progress on one at a time by switching between them (see Figure 17-1).

When the team splits up a group of tasks by having each member take one task and work on it alone, this is parallelism. Each person on the team can make progress at the exact same time (see Figure 17-2).

å›¢é˜Ÿé€šè¿‡æ¯äººç‹¬ç«‹å¤„ç†å•ä¸€ä»»åŠ¡æ¥åˆ†é…å·¥ä½œæ˜¯å¹¶è¡Œã€‚å›¢é˜Ÿæˆå‘˜å¯åŒæ—¶æ¨è¿›å·¥ä½œï¼ˆè§å›¾17-2ï¼‰ã€‚

In both of these workflows, you might have to coordinate between different tasks. Maybe you thought the task assigned to one person was totally independent from everyone elseâ€™s work, but it actually requires another person on the team to finish their task first. Some of the work could be done in parallel, but some of it was actually serial: it could only happen in a series, one task after the other, as in Figure 17-3.

è¿™ä¸¤ç§å·¥ä½œæµå‡éœ€ä»»åŠ¡é—´åè°ƒã€‚å¯èƒ½ä½ ä»¥ä¸ºåˆ†é…ç»™æŸäººçš„ä»»åŠ¡å®Œå…¨ç‹¬ç«‹ï¼Œå®åˆ™éœ€ç­‰å¾…ä»–äººå®Œæˆä»»åŠ¡ã€‚éƒ¨åˆ†å·¥ä½œå¯å¹¶è¡Œï¼Œä½†éƒ¨åˆ†å®é™…æ˜¯ä¸²è¡Œçš„â€”â€”åªèƒ½æŒ‰é¡ºåºä¾æ¬¡æ‰§è¡Œï¼ˆè§å›¾17-3ï¼‰ã€‚

Likewise, you might realize that one of your own tasks depends on another of your tasks. Now your concurrent work has also become serial.

åŒç†ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½å‘ç°è‡ªå·±çš„æŸä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ä¾èµ–äºå¦ä¸€ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶å¹¶å‘å·¥ä½œä¹Ÿå˜ä¸ºä¸²è¡Œã€‚

Parallelism and concurrency can intersect with each other, too. If you learn that a colleague is stuck until you finish one of your tasks, youâ€™ll probably focus all your efforts on that task to â€œunblockâ€ your colleague. You and your coworker are no longer able to work in parallel, and youâ€™re also no longer able to work concurrently on your own tasks.

å¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘ä¹Ÿä¼šäº¤ç»‡ã€‚è‹¥å¾—çŸ¥åŒäº‹å› ç­‰å¾…ä½ çš„æŸé¡¹ä»»åŠ¡è€Œå—é˜»ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½ä¼šå…¨åŠ›å®Œæˆè¯¥ä»»åŠ¡ä»¥â€œè§£é”â€œåŒäº‹ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶ä½ ä¸åŒäº‹æ— æ³•å¹¶è¡Œå·¥ä½œï¼Œä½ è‡ªèº«ä¹Ÿæ— æ³•å¹¶å‘å¤„ç†ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚

The same basic dynamics come into play with software and hardware. On a machine with a single CPU core, the CPU can perform only one operation at a time, but it can still work concurrently. Using tools such as threads, processes, and async, the computer can pause one activity and switch to others before eventually cycling back to that first activity again. On a machine with multiple CPU cores, it can also do work in parallel. One core can be performing one task while another core performs a completely unrelated one, and those operations actually happen at the same time.

è½¯ä»¶å’Œç¡¬ä»¶éµå¾ªç›¸åŒåŸç†ã€‚å•æ ¸æœºå™¨ä¸Šï¼ŒCPU ä¸€æ¬¡åªèƒ½æ‰§è¡Œä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œï¼Œä½†ä»å¯å¹¶å‘å·¥ä½œã€‚é€šè¿‡çº¿ç¨‹ã€è¿›ç¨‹å’Œå¼‚æ­¥ç­‰å·¥å…·ï¼Œè®¡ç®—æœºå¯æš‚åœæ´»åŠ¨å¹¶åˆ‡æ¢åˆ°å…¶ä»–ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆå†åˆ‡å›ã€‚å¤šæ ¸æœºå™¨ä¸Šè¿˜èƒ½å¹¶è¡Œå·¥ä½œâ€”â€”ä¸€ä¸ªæ ¸å¿ƒæ‰§è¡Œä»»åŠ¡æ—¶ï¼Œå¦ä¸€æ ¸å¿ƒå¯æ‰§è¡Œå®Œå…¨ä¸ç›¸å…³çš„ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ“ä½œçœŸæ­£åŒæ—¶å‘ç”Ÿã€‚

When working with async in Rust, weâ€™re always dealing with concurrency. Depending on the hardware, the operating system, and the async runtime we are using (more on async runtimes shortly), that concurrency may also use parallelism under the hood.

åœ¨ Rust ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å§‹ç»ˆå¤„ç†å¹¶å‘ã€‚æ ¹æ®ç¡¬ä»¶ã€æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿå’Œä½¿ç”¨çš„å¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆç¨åè¯¦è¿°ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ç§å¹¶å‘åœ¨åº•å±‚ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½åˆ©ç”¨å¹¶è¡Œæ€§ã€‚

Now, letâ€™s dive into how async programming in Rust actually works.

ç°åœ¨æ·±å…¥æ¢è®¨ Rust å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹çš„å®é™…å·¥ä½œåŸç†ã€‚

Futures and the Async Syntax Future ä¸å¼‚æ­¥è¯­æ³•

The key elements of asynchronous programming in Rust are futures and Rustâ€™s async and await keywords.

Rust å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹çš„æ ¸å¿ƒè¦ç´ æ˜¯ Future åŠ async/await å…³é”®å­—ã€‚

A future is a value that may not be ready now but will become ready at some point in the future. (This same concept shows up in many languages, sometimes under other names such as task or promise.) Rust provides a Future trait as a building block so that different async operations can be implemented with different data structures but with a common interface. In Rust, futures are types that implement the Future trait. Each future holds its own information about the progress that has been made and what â€œreadyâ€ means.

Future æ˜¯å¯èƒ½å°šæœªå°±ç»ªä½†å°†åœ¨æœªæ¥æŸæ—¶åˆ»å°±ç»ªçš„å€¼ï¼ˆå…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€ä¸­å¯èƒ½ç§°ä¸ºä»»åŠ¡æˆ–æ‰¿è¯ºï¼‰ã€‚[note]Rust æä¾› Future trait ä½œä¸ºåŸºç¡€æ„å»ºå—ï¼Œä½¿ä¸åŒå¼‚æ­¥æ“ä½œå¯é€šè¿‡ä¸åŒæ•°æ®ç»“æ„å®ç°ç»Ÿä¸€æ¥å£ã€‚åœ¨ Rust ä¸­ï¼ŒFuture æ˜¯å®ç° Future trait çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚[note]æ¯ä¸ª Future æŒæœ‰è‡ªèº«è¿›å±•ä¿¡æ¯åŠâ€œå°±ç»ªâ€œçš„å«ä¹‰ã€‚

You can apply the async keyword to blocks and functions to specify that they can be interrupted and resumed. Within an async block or async function, you can use the await keyword to await a future (that is, wait for it to become ready). Any point where you await a future within an async block or function is a potential spot for that async block or function to pause and resume. The process of checking with a future to see if its value is available yet is called polling.

[note]async å…³é”®å­—å¯åº”ç”¨äºä»£ç å—å’Œå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºå®ƒä»¬å¯è¢«ä¸­æ–­å’Œæ¢å¤ã€‚åœ¨å¼‚æ­¥å—æˆ–å‡½æ•°å†…ï¼Œå¯ç”¨ await å…³é”®å­—ç­‰å¾… Futureï¼ˆå³ç­‰å¾…å…¶å°±ç»ªï¼‰ã€‚å¼‚æ­¥å—/å‡½æ•°å†…ä»»ä½•ç­‰å¾… Future çš„ç‚¹éƒ½æ˜¯æ½œåœ¨çš„æš‚åœ/æ¢å¤ç‚¹ã€‚æ£€æŸ¥ Future å€¼æ˜¯å¦å°±ç»ªçš„è¿‡ç¨‹ç§°ä¸ºè½®è¯¢ã€‚

Some other languages, such as C# and JavaScript, also use async and await keywords for async programming. If youâ€™re familiar with those languages, you may notice some significant differences in how Rust does things, including how it handles the syntax. Thatâ€™s for good reason, as weâ€™ll see!

C# å’Œ JavaScript ç­‰è¯­è¨€ä¹Ÿç”¨ async/await å¤„ç†å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹ã€‚è‹¥ç†Ÿæ‚‰è¿™äº›è¯­è¨€ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šæ³¨æ„åˆ° Rust çš„æ˜¾è‘—å·®å¼‚ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬è¯­æ³•å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯æœ‰æ„ä¸ºä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç¨åä¼šçœ‹åˆ°ï¼

When writing async Rust, we use the async and await keywords most of the time. Rust compiles them into equivalent code using the Future trait, much as it compiles for loops into equivalent code using the Iterator trait. Because Rust provides the Future trait, though, you can also implement it for your own data types when you need to. Many of the functions weâ€™ll see throughout this chapter return types with their own implementations of Future. Weâ€™ll return to the definition of the trait at the end of the chapter and dig into more of how it works, but this is enough detail to keep us moving forward.

ç¼–å†™å¼‚æ­¥ Rust æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸»è¦[note]ä½¿ç”¨ async/awaitã€‚Rust å°†å…¶ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºåŸºäº Future trait çš„ç­‰æ•ˆä»£ç ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼å°† for å¾ªç¯ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºåŸºäº Iterator trait çš„ä»£ç ã€‚ç”±äº Rust æä¾›äº† Future traitï¼Œä½ ä¹Ÿå¯åœ¨éœ€è¦æ—¶ä¸ºè‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹å®ç°å®ƒã€‚æœ¬ç« å¤šæ•°å‡½æ•°è¿”å›å®ç° Future çš„è‡ªå®šä¹‰ç±»å‹ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç« æœ«å›é¡¾è¯¥ trait å®šä¹‰å¹¶æ·±å…¥å…¶å·¥ä½œåŸç†ï¼Œç›®å‰è¿™äº›ç»†èŠ‚å·²è¶³å¤Ÿæ¨è¿›ã€‚

This may all feel a bit abstract, so letâ€™s write our first async program: a little web scraper. Weâ€™ll pass in two URLs from the command line, fetch both of them concurrently, and return the result of whichever one finishes first. This example will have a fair bit of new syntax, but donâ€™t worryâ€”weâ€™ll explain everything you need to know as we go.

è¿™äº›æ¦‚å¿µå¯èƒ½è¾ƒæŠ½è±¡ï¼Œå› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬ç¼–å†™ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç¨‹åºï¼šç®€æ˜“ç½‘é¡µæŠ“å–å·¥å…·ã€‚é€šè¿‡å‘½ä»¤è¡Œä¼ å…¥ä¸¤ä¸ª URLï¼Œå¹¶å‘è·å–ä¸¤è€…ï¼Œå¹¶è¿”å›å…ˆå®Œæˆçš„ç»“æœã€‚æ­¤ä¾‹ä¼šæœ‰æ–°è¯­æ³•ï¼Œä½†è¯·æ”¾å¿ƒâ€”â€”æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é€æ­¥è§£é‡Šã€‚

Our First Async Program é¦–ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç¨‹åº

To keep the focus of this chapter on learning async rather than juggling parts of the ecosystem, weâ€™ve created the trpl crate (trpl is short for â€œThe Rust Programming Languageâ€). It re-exports all the types, traits, and functions youâ€™ll need, primarily from the futures and tokio crates. The futures crate is an official home for Rust experimentation for async code, and itâ€™s actually where the Future trait was originally designed. Tokio is the most widely used async runtime in Rust today, especially for web applications. There are other great runtimes out there, and they may be more suitable for your purposes. We use the tokio crate under the hood for trpl because itâ€™s well tested and widely used.

ä¸ºèšç„¦å¼‚æ­¥å­¦ä¹ è€Œéç”Ÿæ€åº“ç»†èŠ‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åˆ›å»ºäº† trpl crateï¼ˆâ€œThe Rust Programming Languageâ€œç¼©å†™ï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒé‡æ–°å¯¼å‡ºäº†æ‰€éœ€ç±»å‹ã€trait å’Œå‡½æ•°ï¼ˆä¸»è¦æ¥è‡ª futures å’Œ tokio crateï¼‰ã€‚[note]futures crate æ˜¯ Rust å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç çš„å®˜æ–¹å®éªŒåŸºåœ°ï¼ŒFuture trait æœ€åˆåœ¨æ­¤è®¾è®¡ã€‚Tokio æ˜¯å½“å‰ Rust æœ€å¹¿æ³›ä½¿ç”¨çš„å¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆå°¤å…¶é€‚ç”¨äº Web åº”ç”¨ï¼‰ã€‚è¿˜æœ‰å…¶ä»–ä¼˜ç§€è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¯èƒ½æ›´é€‚åˆä½ çš„éœ€æ±‚ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åº•å±‚ä½¿ç”¨ tokio æ˜¯å› ä¸ºå®ƒç»è¿‡å……åˆ†æµ‹è¯•ä¸”åº”ç”¨å¹¿æ³›ã€‚

In some cases, trpl also renames or wraps the original APIs to keep you focused on the details relevant to this chapter. If you want to understand what the crate does, we encourage you to check out its source code. Youâ€™ll be able to see what crate each re-export comes from, and weâ€™ve left extensive comments explaining what the crate does.

æœ‰æ—¶ trpl ä¼šé‡å‘½åæˆ–åŒ…è£…åŸå§‹ API ä»¥èšç„¦æœ¬ç« ç›¸å…³ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚è‹¥æƒ³äº†è§£è¯¥ crate çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå»ºè®®æŸ¥çœ‹å…¶æºä»£ç ã€‚ä½ å¯æŸ¥çœ‹æ¯ä¸ªé‡å¯¼å‡ºé¡¹çš„æ¥æºï¼Œä¸”æˆ‘ä»¬ç•™æœ‰è¯¦ç»†æ³¨é‡Šè¯´æ˜åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Create a new binary project named hello-async and add the trpl crate as a dependency:

åˆ›å»ºåä¸º hello-async çš„äºŒè¿›åˆ¶é¡¹ç›®å¹¶æ·»åŠ  trpl ä¾èµ–ï¼š

$ cargo new hello-async
$ cd hello-async
$ cargo add trpl

Now we can use the various pieces provided by trpl to write our first async program. Weâ€™ll build a little command line tool that fetches two web pages, pulls the <title> element from each, and prints out the title of whichever page finishes that whole process first.

ç°åœ¨å¯ç”¨ trpl æä¾›çš„ç»„ä»¶ç¼–å†™é¦–ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç¨‹åºã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ„å»ºå‘½ä»¤è¡Œå·¥å…·ï¼šè·å–ä¸¤ä¸ªç½‘é¡µï¼Œæå–å„è‡ªçš„ <title> å…ƒç´ ï¼Œå¹¶æ‰“å°å…ˆå®Œæˆæ•´ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹çš„é¡µé¢æ ‡é¢˜ã€‚

Defining the page_title Function å®šä¹‰ page_title å‡½æ•°

Letâ€™s start by writing a function that takes one page URL as a parameter, makes a request to it, and returns the text of the title element (see Listing 17-1).

é¦–å…ˆç¼–å†™å‡½æ•°ï¼šæ¥æ”¶é¡µé¢ URL å‚æ•°ï¼Œå‘èµ·è¯·æ±‚ï¼Œè¿”å›æ ‡é¢˜å…ƒç´ æ–‡æœ¬ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-1ï¼‰ã€‚

First, we define a function named page_title and mark it with the async keyword. Then we use the trpl::get function to fetch whatever URL is passed in and add the await keyword to await the response. To get the text of the response, we call its text method, and once again await it with the await keyword. Both of these steps are asynchronous. For the get function, we have to wait for the server to send back the first part of its response, which will include HTTP headers, cookies, and so on, and can be delivered separately from the response body. Especially if the body is very large, it can take some time for it all to arrive. Because we have to wait for the entirety of the response to arrive, the text method is also async.

é¦–å…ˆç”¨ async å…³é”®å­—å®šä¹‰ page_title å‡½æ•°ã€‚ç„¶åç”¨ trpl::get è·å–ä¼ å…¥çš„ URLï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨ await ç­‰å¾…å“åº”ã€‚ä¸ºè·å–å“åº”æ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨å…¶ text æ–¹æ³•å¹¶å†æ¬¡ç”¨ await ç­‰å¾…ã€‚è¿™ä¸¤æ­¥éƒ½æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥çš„ï¼šget éœ€ç­‰å¾…æœåŠ¡å™¨è¿”å›å“åº”ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼ˆå« HTTP å¤´ã€Cookie ç­‰ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¸å“åº”ä½“åˆ†å¼€å‘é€ï¼›è‹¥å“åº”ä½“å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œå®Œå…¨åˆ°è¾¾å¯èƒ½è€—æ—¶ã€‚å› éœ€ç­‰å¾…æ•´ä¸ªå“åº”åˆ°è¾¾ï¼Œtext æ–¹æ³•ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥çš„ã€‚

We have to explicitly await both of these futures, because futures in Rust are lazy: they donâ€™t do anything until you ask them to with the await keyword. (In fact, Rust will show a compiler warning if you donâ€™t use a future.) This might remind you of Chapter 13â€™s discussion of iterators in the section Processing a Series of Items With Iterators. Iterators do nothing unless you call their next methodâ€”whether directly or by using for loops or methods such as map that use next under the hood. Likewise, futures do nothing unless you explicitly ask them to. This laziness allows Rust to avoid running async code until itâ€™s actually needed.
