å¿…é¡»æ˜¾å¼ç­‰å¾…è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ª Futureï¼Œå› ä¸º Rust çš„ Future æ˜¯æƒ°æ€§çš„ï¼š[note]é™¤éç”¨ await æ˜¾å¼è¯·æ±‚ï¼Œå¦åˆ™ä¸æ‰§è¡Œä»»ä½•æ“ä½œï¼ˆå®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œæœªä½¿ç”¨çš„ Future ä¼šè§¦å‘ç¼–è¯‘å™¨è­¦å‘Šï¼‰ã€‚è¿™ç±»ä¼¼äºç¬¬13ç« è¿­ä»£å™¨çš„å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ï¼šé™¤éè°ƒç”¨ next æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆç›´æ¥æˆ–é€šè¿‡ for å¾ªç¯/map ç­‰æ–¹æ³•ï¼‰ï¼Œå¦åˆ™è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸å·¥ä½œã€‚åŒç†ï¼ŒFuture é™¤éæ˜¾å¼è¯·æ±‚å¦åˆ™ä¸æ‰§è¡Œã€‚è¿™ç§æƒ°æ€§è®© Rust é¿å…åœ¨çœŸæ­£éœ€è¦å‰è¿è¡Œå¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç ã€‚

Note: This is different from the behavior we saw in the previous chapter when using thread::spawn in Creating a New Thread with spawn, where the closure we passed to another thread started running immediately. Itâ€™s also different from how many other languages approach async. But itâ€™s important for Rust to be able to provide its performance guarantees, just as it is with iterators.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šè¿™ä¸ç¬¬16ç« ä½¿ç”¨ thread::spawn çš„è¡Œä¸ºä¸åŒï¼ˆçº¿ç¨‹é—­åŒ…ç«‹å³è¿è¡Œï¼‰ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸åŒäºè®¸å¤šå…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€çš„å¼‚æ­¥å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ã€‚ä½†å¯¹ Rust æä¾›æ€§èƒ½ä¿è¯è‡³å…³é‡è¦ï¼ˆä¸è¿­ä»£å™¨ç±»ä¼¼ï¼‰ã€‚

Once we have response_text, we can parse it into an instance of the Html type using Html::parse. Instead of a raw string, we now have a data type we can use to work with the HTML as a richer data structure. In particular, we can use the select_first method to find the first instance of a given CSS selector. By passing the string "title", weâ€™ll get the first <title> element in the document, if there is one. Because there may not be any matching element, select_first returns an Option<ElementRef>. Finally, we use the Option::map method, which lets us work with the item in the Option if itâ€™s present, and do nothing if it isnâ€™t. (We could also use a match expression here, but map is more idiomatic.) In the body of the function we supply to map, we call inner_html on the title to get its content, which is a String. When all is said and done, we have an Option<String>.

è·å¾— response_text åï¼Œç”¨ Html::parse è§£æä¸º Html ç±»å‹å®ä¾‹ã€‚ç°åœ¨æœ‰äº†å¯æ“ä½œ HTML çš„ä¸°å¯Œæ•°æ®ç»“æ„ã€‚ç‰¹åˆ«æ˜¯å¯ç”¨ select_first æ–¹æ³•æŸ¥æ‰¾ç»™å®š CSS é€‰æ‹©å™¨çš„é¦–ä¸ªå®ä¾‹ã€‚ä¼ å…¥å­—ç¬¦ä¸² "title" å°†è·å–æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­é¦–ä¸ª <title> å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆè‹¥å­˜åœ¨ï¼‰ã€‚å› å¯èƒ½æ— åŒ¹é…å…ƒç´ ï¼Œselect_first è¿”å› Option<ElementRef>ã€‚æœ€åç”¨ Option::map å¤„ç† Option ä¸­çš„å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆè‹¥å­˜åœ¨ï¼‰ï¼Œå¦åˆ™æ— æ“ä½œï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨ matchï¼Œä½† map æ›´ç¬¦åˆä¹ æƒ¯ï¼‰ã€‚åœ¨ä¼ ç»™ map çš„å‡½æ•°ä¸­ï¼Œå¯¹ title è°ƒç”¨ inner_html è·å–å…¶å†…å®¹ï¼ˆå³ Stringï¼‰ã€‚æœ€ç»ˆå¾—åˆ° Option<String>ã€‚

Notice that Rustâ€™s await keyword goes after the expression youâ€™re awaiting, not before it. That is, itâ€™s a postfix keyword. This may differ from what youâ€™re used to if youâ€™ve used async in other languages, but in Rust it makes chains of methods much nicer to work with. As a result, we can change the body of page_title to chain the trpl::get and text function calls together with await between them, as shown in Listing 17-2.

æ³¨æ„ Rust çš„ await å…³é”®å­—ä½äºè¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¹‹åè€Œéä¹‹å‰ï¼Œæ˜¯åç¼€å…³é”®å­—ã€‚è‹¥ç†Ÿæ‚‰å…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€çš„å¼‚æ­¥ï¼Œè¿™å¯èƒ½æœ‰åˆ«ï¼Œä½†åœ¨ Rust ä¸­å®ƒä½¿æ–¹æ³•é“¾æ›´æ¸…æ™°ã€‚å› æ­¤å¯å°† page_title å‡½æ•°ä½“æ”¹ä¸ºé“¾å¼è°ƒç”¨ trpl::get å’Œ text æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¸­é—´ç”¨ await è¿æ¥ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-2ï¼‰ã€‚

With that, we have successfully written our first async function! Before we add some code in main to call it, letâ€™s talk a little more about what weâ€™ve written and what it means.

è‡³æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬æˆåŠŸç¼–å†™äº†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼åœ¨ main ä¸­æ·»åŠ è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç å‰ï¼Œå†è®¨è®ºå·²å†™å†…å®¹åŠå…¶å«ä¹‰ã€‚

When Rust sees a block marked with the async keyword, it compiles it into a unique, anonymous data type that implements the Future trait. When Rust sees a function marked with async, it compiles it into a non-async function whose body is an async block. An async functionâ€™s return type is the type of the anonymous data type the compiler creates for that async block.

[note]Rust é‡åˆ° async æ ‡è®°çš„ä»£ç å—æ—¶ï¼Œä¼šå°†å…¶ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºå®ç° Future trait çš„å”¯ä¸€åŒ¿åæ•°æ®ç±»å‹ã€‚é‡åˆ° async æ ‡è®°çš„å‡½æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œä¼šå°†å…¶ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºè¿”å›å¼‚æ­¥å—çš„éå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ã€‚å¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹æ˜¯ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¸ºè¯¥å¼‚æ­¥å—åˆ›å»ºçš„åŒ¿åæ•°æ®ç±»å‹ã€‚

Thus, writing async fn is equivalent to writing a function that returns a future of the return type. To the compiler, a function definition such as the async fn page_title in Listing 17-1 is equivalent to a non-async function defined like this:

å› æ­¤ï¼Œç¼–å†™ async fn ç­‰æ•ˆäºè¿”å›è¯¥è¿”å›ç±»å‹çš„ Future çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚å¯¹ç¼–è¯‘å™¨è€Œè¨€ï¼Œç¤ºä¾‹17-1ä¸­çš„ async fn page_title å®šä¹‰ç­‰æ•ˆäºå¦‚ä¸‹éå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
extern crate trpl; // required for mdbook test
use std::future::Future;
use trpl::Html;

fn page_title(url: &str) -> impl Future<Output = Option<String>> {
    async move {
        let text = trpl::get(url).await.text().await;
        Html::parse(&text)
            .select_first("title")
            .map(|title| title.inner_html())
    }
}
}

Letâ€™s walk through each part of the transformed version:

é€æ­¥è§£æè½¬æ¢ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š

  • It uses the impl Trait syntax we discussed back in Chapter 10 in the â€œTraits as Parametersâ€ section.
  • ä½¿ç”¨ç¬¬10ç« â€œå°† trait ä½œä¸ºå‚æ•°â€œæ‰€è¿°çš„ impl Trait è¯­æ³•
  • The returned trait is a Future with an associated type of Output. Notice that the Output type is Option<String>, which is the same as the original return type from the async fn version of page_title.
  • è¿”å›çš„ trait æ˜¯ Futureï¼Œå…³è”ç±»å‹ä¸º Outputï¼ˆæ³¨æ„ Output ç±»å‹æ˜¯ Option<String>ï¼Œä¸åŸ async fn ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„è¿”å›ç±»å‹ç›¸åŒï¼‰
  • All of the code called in the body of the original function is wrapped in an async move block. Remember that blocks are expressions. This whole block is the expression returned from the function.
  • åŸå‡½æ•°ä½“å†…æ‰€æœ‰ä»£ç è¢«åŒ…è£…åœ¨ async move å—ä¸­ï¼ˆå—æ˜¯è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼Œæ•´ä¸ªå—æ˜¯å‡½æ•°çš„è¿”å›è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼‰
  • This async block produces a value with the type Option<String>, as just described. That value matches the Output type in the return type. This is just like other blocks you have seen.
  • è¯¥å¼‚æ­¥å—ç”Ÿæˆ Option<String> ç±»å‹çš„å€¼ï¼ŒåŒ¹é…è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸­çš„ Output
  • The new function body is an async move block because of how it uses the url parameter. (Weâ€™ll talk much more about async versus async move later in the chapter.)
  • æ–°å‡½æ•°ä½“æ˜¯ async move å—ï¼Œå› å…¶ä½¿ç”¨äº† url å‚æ•°ï¼ˆæœ¬ç« ç¨åå°†è¯¦è¿° async ä¸ async moveï¼‰

Now we can call page_title in main.

ç°åœ¨å¯åœ¨ main ä¸­è°ƒç”¨ page_titleã€‚

Determining a Single Pageâ€™s Title è·å–å•ä¸ªé¡µé¢æ ‡é¢˜

To start, weâ€™ll just get the title for a single page. In Listing 17-3, we follow the same pattern we used in Chapter 12 to get command line arguments in the Accepting Command Line Arguments section. Then we pass the first URL page_title and await the result. Because the value produced by the future is an Option<String>, we use a match expression to print different messages to account for whether the page had a <title>.

é¦–å…ˆä»…è·å–å•ä¸ªé¡µé¢æ ‡é¢˜ã€‚ç¤ºä¾‹17-3æ²¿ç”¨ç¬¬12ç« è·å–å‘½ä»¤è¡Œå‚æ•°çš„æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå°†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª URL ä¼ ç»™ page_title å¹¶ç­‰å¾…ç»“æœã€‚å›  Future äº§ç”Ÿ Option<String>ï¼Œç”¨ match è¡¨è¾¾å¼æ ¹æ®é¡µé¢æ˜¯å¦æœ‰ <title> æ‰“å°ä¸åŒä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Unfortunately, this code doesnâ€™t compile. The only place we can use the await keyword is in async functions or blocks, and Rust wonâ€™t let us mark the special main function as async.

ä½†æ­¤ä»£ç æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼šawait å…³é”®å­—åªèƒ½åœ¨å¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°æˆ–å—ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œè€Œ Rust ä¸å…è®¸å°†ç‰¹æ®Šçš„ main å‡½æ•°æ ‡è®°ä¸º asyncã€‚

error[E0752]: `main` function is not allowed to be `async`
 --> src/main.rs:6:1
  |
6 | async fn main() {
  | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ `main` function is not allowed to be `async`

The reason main canâ€™t be marked async is that async code needs a runtime: a Rust crate that manages the details of executing asynchronous code. A programâ€™s main function can initialize a runtime, but itâ€™s not a runtime itself. (Weâ€™ll see more about why this is the case in a bit.) Every Rust program that executes async code has at least one place where it sets up a runtime and executes the futures.

main ä¸èƒ½æ ‡è®° async çš„åŸå› æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç éœ€è¦è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆç®¡ç†å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œç»†èŠ‚çš„ Rust crateï¼‰ã€‚ç¨‹åºçš„ main å‡½æ•°å¯åˆå§‹åŒ–è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼Œä½†å…¶æœ¬èº«ä¸æ˜¯è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆç¨åè¯¦è¿°åŸå› ï¼‰ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªæ‰§è¡Œå¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç çš„ Rust ç¨‹åºè‡³å°‘æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªè®¾ç½®è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¹¶æ‰§è¡Œ Future çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚

Most languages that support async bundle a runtime, but Rust does not. Instead, there are many different async runtimes available, each of which makes different tradeoffs suitable to the use case it targets. For example, a high-throughput web server with many CPU cores and a large amount of RAM has very different needs than a microcontroller with a single core, a small amount of RAM, and no heap allocation ability. The crates that provide those runtimes also often supply async versions of common functionality such as file or network I/O.

å¤šæ•°æ”¯æŒå¼‚æ­¥çš„è¯­è¨€æ†ç»‘è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼Œä½† Rust æ²¡æœ‰ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œæœ‰è®¸å¤šå¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¯ç”¨ï¼Œå„è‡ªé’ˆå¯¹ç›®æ ‡ç”¨ä¾‹åšå‡ºä¸åŒæƒè¡¡ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œå…·æœ‰å¤š CPU æ ¸å¿ƒå’Œå¤§å†…å­˜çš„é«˜ååé‡ Web æœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œä¸å•æ ¸ã€å°å†…å­˜ä¸”æ— å †åˆ†é…èƒ½åŠ›çš„å¾®æ§åˆ¶å™¨éœ€æ±‚è¿¥å¼‚ã€‚[note]æä¾›è¿™äº›è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„ crate é€šå¸¸ä¹ŸåŒ…å«å¸¸è§åŠŸèƒ½ï¼ˆå¦‚æ–‡ä»¶/ç½‘ç»œ I/Oï¼‰çš„å¼‚æ­¥ç‰ˆæœ¬ã€‚

Here, and throughout the rest of this chapter, weâ€™ll use the run function from the trpl crate, which takes a future as an argument and runs it to completion. Behind the scenes, calling run sets up a runtime thatâ€™s used to run the future passed in. Once the future completes, run returns whatever value the future produced.

æœ¬ç« å°†ä½¿ç”¨ trpl crate çš„ run å‡½æ•°ï¼šæ¥æ”¶ Future å‚æ•°å¹¶è¿è¡Œè‡³å®Œæˆã€‚è°ƒç”¨ run ä¼šè®¾ç½®è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä»¥è¿è¡Œä¼ å…¥çš„ Futureã€‚Future å®Œæˆåï¼Œrun è¿”å›å…¶äº§ç”Ÿçš„å€¼ã€‚

We could pass the future returned by page_title directly to run, and once it completed, we could match on the resulting Option<String>, as we tried to do in Listing 17-3. However, for most of the examples in the chapter (and most async code in the real world), weâ€™ll be doing more than just one async function call, so instead weâ€™ll pass an async block and explicitly await the result of the page_title call, as in Listing 17-4.

å¯å°† page_title è¿”å›çš„ Future ç›´æ¥ä¼ ç»™ runï¼Œå®Œæˆåå¯¹ç»“æœ Option<String> è¿›è¡ŒåŒ¹é…ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¤ºä¾‹17-3å°è¯•ï¼‰ã€‚ä½†æœ¬ç« å¤šæ•°ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼ˆåŠç°å®ä¸­çš„å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç ï¼‰ä¸åªæœ‰å•ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œå› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä¼ é€’ async å—å¹¶æ˜¾å¼ç­‰å¾… page_title è°ƒç”¨çš„ç»“æœï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-4ï¼‰ã€‚

When we run this code, we get the behavior we expected initially:

è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç å°†è·å¾—é¢„æœŸè¡Œä¸ºï¼š

$ cargo run -- https://www.rust-lang.org
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.05s
     Running `target/debug/async_await 'https://www.rust-lang.org'`
The title for https://www.rust-lang.org was
            Rust Programming Language

Phewâ€”we finally have some working async code! But before we add the code to race the two sites against each other, letâ€™s briefly turn our attention back to how futures work.

ç»ˆäºæœ‰äº†å¯å·¥ä½œçš„å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç ï¼ä½†åœ¨æ·»åŠ ç«é€Ÿä¸¤ä¸ªç«™ç‚¹çš„ä»£ç å‰ï¼Œå…ˆç®€è¦å›é¡¾ Future çš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†ã€‚

Each await pointâ€”that is, every place where the code uses the await keywordâ€”represents a place where control is handed back to the runtime. To make that work, Rust needs to keep track of the state involved in the async block so that the runtime can kick off some other work and then come back when itâ€™s ready to try advancing the first one again. This is an invisible state machine, as if youâ€™d written an enum like this to save the current state at each await point:

[note]æ¯ä¸ªç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ï¼ˆå³ä½¿ç”¨ await å…³é”®å­—çš„ä½ç½®ï¼‰ä»£è¡¨å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤å›è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼ŒRust éœ€è·Ÿè¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—æ¶‰åŠçš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿è¿è¡Œæ—¶æš‚åœæŸæ´»åŠ¨å¹¶åˆ‡æ¢åˆ°å…¶ä»–æ´»åŠ¨ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆå†åˆ‡å›æ¨è¿›ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ´»åŠ¨ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯éšå½¢çŠ¶æ€æœºï¼Œå¦‚åŒæ‰‹åŠ¨ç¼–å†™æšä¸¾ä¿å­˜æ¯ä¸ªç­‰å¾…ç‚¹çš„å½“å‰çŠ¶æ€ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
extern crate trpl; // required for mdbook test

enum PageTitleFuture<'a> {
    Initial { url: &'a str },
    GetAwaitPoint { url: &'a str },
    TextAwaitPoint { response: trpl::Response },
}
}

Writing the code to transition between each state by hand would be tedious and error-prone, however, especially when you need to add more functionality and more states to the code later. Fortunately, the Rust compiler creates and manages the state machine data structures for async code automatically. The normal borrowing and ownership rules around data structures all still apply, and happily, the compiler also handles checking those for us and provides useful error messages. Weâ€™ll work through a few of those later in the chapter.

æ‰‹åŠ¨ç¼–å†™çŠ¶æ€é—´è½¬æ¢ä»£ç å†—é•¿æ˜“é”™ï¼ˆå°¤å…¶éœ€æ·»åŠ åŠŸèƒ½å’ŒçŠ¶æ€æ—¶ï¼‰ã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼ŒRust ç¼–è¯‘å™¨è‡ªåŠ¨ä¸ºå¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç åˆ›å»ºå’Œç®¡ç†çŠ¶æ€æœºæ•°æ®ç»“æ„ã€‚å›´ç»•æ•°æ®ç»“æ„çš„å¸¸è§„å€Ÿç”¨å’Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒè§„åˆ™ä»é€‚ç”¨ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¹Ÿå¤„ç†è¿™äº›æ£€æŸ¥å¹¶æä¾›æœ‰ç”¨é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆæœ¬ç« ç¨åå°†æ¶‰åŠï¼‰ã€‚

Ultimately, something has to execute this state machine, and that something is a runtime. (This is why you may come across references to executors when looking into runtimes: an executor is the part of a runtime responsible for executing the async code.)

æœ€ç»ˆéœ€æœ‰æ‰§è¡Œæ­¤çŠ¶æ€æœºçš„å®ä½“ï¼Œå³è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆå› æ­¤ç ”ç©¶è¿è¡Œæ—¶æ—¶å¯èƒ½é‡åˆ°æ‰§è¡Œå™¨çš„ææ³•ï¼šæ‰§è¡Œå™¨æ˜¯è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¸­è´Ÿè´£æ‰§è¡Œå¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç çš„éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼‰ã€‚

Now you can see why the compiler stopped us from making main itself an async function back in Listing 17-3. If main were an async function, something else would need to manage the state machine for whatever future main returned, but main is the starting point for the program! Instead, we called the trpl::run function in main to set up a runtime and run the future returned by the async block until it is done.

ç°åœ¨æ˜ç™½ä¸ºä½•ç¼–è¯‘å™¨åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹17-3ä¸­é˜»æ­¢æˆ‘ä»¬å°† main è®¾ä¸ºå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼šè‹¥ main æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼Œéœ€æœ‰å…¶ä»–å®ä½“ç®¡ç†å…¶è¿”å›çš„ Future çŠ¶æ€æœºï¼Œä½† main æ˜¯ç¨‹åºçš„èµ·ç‚¹ï¼æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ main ä¸­è°ƒç”¨ trpl::run æ¥è®¾ç½®è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¹¶è¿è¡Œ async å—è¿”å›çš„ Future ç›´è‡³å®Œæˆã€‚

Note: Some runtimes provide macros so you can write an async main function. Those macros rewrite async fn main() { ... } to be a normal fn main, which does the same thing we did by hand in Listing 17-4: call a function that runs a future to completion the way trpl::run does.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šæŸäº›è¿è¡Œæ—¶æä¾›å®æ”¯æŒç¼–å†™å¼‚æ­¥ main å‡½æ•°ã€‚è¿™äº›å®å°† async fn main() { ... } é‡å†™ä¸ºæ™®é€š fn mainï¼Œå…¶åŠŸèƒ½ä¸ç¤ºä¾‹17-4æ‰‹åŠ¨æ“ä½œç›¸åŒï¼šè°ƒç”¨è¿è¡Œ Future è‡³å®Œæˆçš„å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ trpl::runï¼‰ã€‚

Now letâ€™s put these pieces together and see how we can write concurrent code.

ç°åœ¨æ•´åˆè¿™äº›éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œçœ‹çœ‹å¦‚ä½•ç¼–å†™å¹¶å‘ä»£ç ã€‚

Racing Our Two URLs Against Each Other ç«é€Ÿä¸¤ä¸ª URL

In Listing 17-5, we call page_title with two different URLs passed in from the command line and race them.

ç¤ºä¾‹17-5ç”¨å‘½ä»¤è¡Œä¼ å…¥çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒ URL è°ƒç”¨ page_title å¹¶ç«é€Ÿå®ƒä»¬ã€‚

We begin by calling page_title for each of the user-supplied URLs. We save the resulting futures as title_fut_1 and title_fut_2. Remember, these donâ€™t do anything yet, because futures are lazy and we havenâ€™t yet awaited them. Then we pass the futures to trpl::race, which returns a value to indicate which of the futures passed to it finishes first.

é¦–å…ˆä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªç”¨æˆ·æä¾›çš„ URL è°ƒç”¨ page_titleï¼Œå°†ç»“æœ Future ä¿å­˜ä¸º title_fut_1 å’Œ title_fut_2ã€‚è®°ä½ï¼šè¿™äº›è°ƒç”¨å°šæœªæ‰§è¡Œä»»ä½•æ“ä½œï¼ˆå›  Future æ˜¯æƒ°æ€§çš„ä¸”å°šæœªç­‰å¾…ï¼‰ã€‚ç„¶åå°† Future ä¼ ç»™ trpl::raceï¼ˆè¿”å›æŒ‡ç¤ºå“ªä¸ª Future å…ˆå®Œæˆçš„å€¼ï¼‰ã€‚

Note: Under the hood, race is built on a more general function, select, which you will encounter more often in real-world Rust code. A select function can do a lot of things that the trpl::race function canâ€™t, but it also has some additional complexity that we can skip over for now.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šåº•å±‚ race [note]åŸºäºæ›´é€šç”¨çš„ select å‡½æ•°æ„å»ºï¼ˆå®é™… Rust ä»£ç ä¸­æ›´å¸¸è§ï¼‰ã€‚select å‡½æ•°èƒ½å®Œæˆ trpl::race æ— æ³•å®ç°çš„è®¸å¤šåŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œä½†ä¹Ÿå¸¦æ¥é¢å¤–å¤æ‚æ€§ï¼ˆç›®å‰å¯è·³è¿‡ï¼‰ã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse futures::future::select;

Either future can legitimately â€œwin,â€ so it doesnâ€™t make sense to return a Result. Instead, race returns a type we havenâ€™t seen before, trpl::Either. The Either type is somewhat similar to a Result in that it has two cases. Unlike Result, though, there is no notion of success or failure baked into Either. Instead, it uses Left and Right to indicate â€œone or the otherâ€:

ä»»ä¸€ Future éƒ½å¯èƒ½â€œè·èƒœâ€œï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿”å› Result ä¸åˆç†ã€‚race è¿”å›æ–°ç±»å‹ trpl::Eitherã€‚Either ç±»å‹ç±»ä¼¼äº Resultï¼ˆæœ‰ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µï¼‰ï¼Œä½†ä¸å†…å»ºæˆåŠŸ/å¤±è´¥æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç”¨ Left å’Œ Right è¡¨ç¤ºâ€œäºŒè€…ä¹‹ä¸€â€œï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Either<A, B> {
    Left(A),
    Right(B),
}
}

The race function returns Left with the output from the first future argument it finishes first, or Right with the output of the second future argument if that one finishes first. This matches the order the arguments appear in when calling the function: the first argument is to the left of the second argument.

race å‡½æ•°è¿”å› Leftï¼ˆå«ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼Œè‹¥å…¶å…ˆå®Œæˆï¼‰æˆ– Rightï¼ˆå«ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå‚æ•°çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼Œè‹¥å…¶å…ˆå®Œæˆï¼‰ã€‚è¿™åŒ¹é…å‚æ•°é¡ºåºï¼šç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°åœ¨å·¦ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒä¸ªåœ¨å³ã€‚

We also update page_title to return the same URL passed in. That way, if the page that returns first does not have a <title> we can resolve, we can still print a meaningful message. With that information available, we wrap up by updating our println! output to indicate both which URL finished first and what, if any, the <title> is for the web page at that URL.

æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜æ›´æ–° page_title ä»¥è¿”å›ä¼ å…¥çš„ URLã€‚è¿™æ ·å³ä½¿å…ˆè¿”å›çš„é¡µé¢æ—  <title>ï¼Œä»èƒ½æ‰“å°æœ‰æ„ä¹‰çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚åˆ©ç”¨è¿™äº›ä¿¡æ¯æ›´æ–° println! è¾“å‡ºï¼ŒæŒ‡ç¤ºå“ªä¸ª URL å…ˆå®ŒæˆåŠå…¶ç½‘é¡µæ ‡é¢˜ï¼ˆè‹¥æœ‰ï¼‰ã€‚

You have built a small working web scraper now! Pick a couple URLs and run the command line tool. You may discover that some sites are consistently faster than others, while in other cases the faster site varies from run to run. More importantly, youâ€™ve learned the basics of working with futures, so now we can dig deeper into what we can do with async.

ç°åœ¨ä½ å·²æ„å»ºäº†ç®€æ˜“ç½‘é¡µæŠ“å–å·¥å…·ï¼é€‰æ‹©å‡ ä¸ª URL è¿è¡Œå‘½ä»¤è¡Œå·¥å…·ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šå‘ç°æŸäº›ç«™ç‚¹å§‹ç»ˆæ›´å¿«ï¼Œè€Œå…¶ä»–æƒ…å†µä¸‹è¾ƒå¿«çš„ç«™ç‚¹å› è¿è¡Œè€Œå¼‚ã€‚æ›´é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œä½ å·²æŒæ¡ä½¿ç”¨ Future çš„åŸºç¡€çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œç°åœ¨å¯æ·±å…¥æ¢ç´¢å¼‚æ­¥çš„æ›´å¤šåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Applying Concurrency with Async åº”ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥å®ç°å¹¶å‘

In this section, weâ€™ll apply async to some of the same concurrency challenges we tackled with threads in chapter 16. Because we already talked about a lot of the key ideas there, in this section weâ€™ll focus on whatâ€™s different between threads and futures.

æœ¬èŠ‚å°†å¼‚æ­¥åº”ç”¨äºç¬¬16ç« ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹è§£å†³çš„å¹¶å‘æŒ‘æˆ˜ã€‚å› å·²è®¨è®ºè®¸å¤šå…³é”®æ€æƒ³ï¼Œæœ¬èŠ‚èšç„¦çº¿ç¨‹ä¸ Future çš„å·®å¼‚ã€‚

In many cases, the APIs for working with concurrency using async are very similar to those for using threads. In other cases, they end up being quite different. Even when the APIs look similar between threads and async, they often have different behaviorâ€”and they nearly always have different performance characteristics.

è®¸å¤šæƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå¼‚æ­¥å¹¶å‘çš„ API ä¸çº¿ç¨‹éå¸¸ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œä½†æœ‰æ—¶å·®å¼‚æ˜¾è‘—ã€‚å³ä½¿ API çœ‹ä¼¼ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬çš„è¡Œä¸ºé€šå¸¸ä¸åŒï¼Œä¸”å‡ ä¹æ€»æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„æ€§èƒ½ç‰¹å¾ã€‚

Creating a New Task with spawn_task ç”¨ spawn_task åˆ›å»ºæ–°ä»»åŠ¡

The first operation we tackled in Creating a New Thread with Spawn was counting up on two separate threads. Letâ€™s do the same using async. The trpl crate supplies a spawn_task function that looks very similar to the thread::spawn API, and a sleep function that is an async version of the thread::sleep API. We can use these together to implement the counting example, as shown in Listing 17-6.

åœ¨â€œç”¨ spawn åˆ›å»ºæ–°çº¿ç¨‹â€œä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªç‹¬ç«‹çº¿ç¨‹ä¸Šè®¡æ•°ã€‚ç°åœ¨ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥å®ç°ç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚trpl crate æä¾›ä¸ thread::spawn API éå¸¸ç›¸ä¼¼çš„ spawn_task å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä»¥åŠå¼‚æ­¥ç‰ˆçš„ sleep å‡½æ•°ã€‚ç»“åˆä¸¤è€…å¯å®ç°è®¡æ•°ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-6ï¼‰ã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse tokio::task::spawn; use tokio::time::sleep;

As our starting point, we set up our main function with trpl::run so that our top-level function can be async.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ main ä¸­è®¾ç½® trpl::runï¼Œä½¿é¡¶å±‚å‡½æ•°å¯ä¸ºå¼‚æ­¥ã€‚

Note: From this point forward in the chapter, every example will include this exact same wrapping code with trpl::run in main, so weâ€™ll often skip it just as we do with main. Donâ€™t forget to include it in your code!

æ³¨æ„ï¼šæœ¬ç« åç»­ç¤ºä¾‹å‡åŒ…å« trpl::run çš„ç›¸åŒåŒ…è£…ä»£ç ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¸¸ä¼šçœç•¥ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ mainï¼‰ã€‚ä½†ä½ çš„ä»£ç ä¸­å‹¿å¿˜åŒ…å«ï¼

Then we write two loops within that block, each containing a trpl::sleep call, which waits for half a second (500 milliseconds) before sending the next message. We put one loop in the body of a trpl::spawn_task and the other in a top-level for loop. We also add an await after the sleep calls.

ç„¶ååœ¨å¼‚æ­¥å—å†…ç¼–å†™ä¸¤ä¸ªå¾ªç¯ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªå¾ªç¯å« trpl::sleep è°ƒç”¨ï¼ˆç­‰å¾…åŠç§’åå‘é€ä¸‹æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªå¾ªç¯æ”¾åœ¨ trpl::spawn_task ä½“å†…ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ”¾åœ¨é¡¶å±‚ for å¾ªç¯ä¸­ã€‚è¿˜åœ¨ sleep è°ƒç”¨åæ·»åŠ  awaitã€‚

This code behaves similarly to the thread-based implementationâ€”including the fact that you may see the messages appear in a different order in your own terminal when you run it:

æ­¤ä»£ç è¡Œä¸ºç±»ä¼¼äºåŸºäºçº¿ç¨‹çš„å®ç°ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬ç»ˆç«¯ä¸­æ¶ˆæ¯é¡ºåºå¯èƒ½ä¸åŒï¼‰ï¼š

hi number 1 from the second task!
hi number 1 from the first task!
hi number 2 from the first task!
hi number 2 from the second task!
hi number 3 from the first task!
hi number 3 from the second task!
hi number 4 from the first task!
hi number 4 from the second task!
hi number 5 from the first task!

This version stops as soon as the for loop in the body of the main async block finishes, because the task spawned by spawn_task is shut down when the main function ends. If you want it to run all the way to the taskâ€™s completion, you will need to use a join handle to wait for the first task to complete. With threads, we used the join method to â€œblockâ€ until the thread was done running. In Listing 17-7, we can use await to do the same thing, because the task handle itself is a future. Its Output type is a Result, so we also unwrap it after awaiting it.

ä¸»å¼‚æ­¥å—ä¸­çš„ for å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸåç«‹å³åœæ­¢ï¼ˆå›  spawn_task ç”Ÿæˆçš„ä»»åŠ¡åœ¨ main ç»“æŸæ—¶å…³é—­ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥è¦è®©ä»»åŠ¡å®Œå…¨å®Œæˆï¼Œéœ€ä½¿ç”¨ join å¥æŸ„[note]ç­‰å¾…ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡å®Œæˆã€‚çº¿ç¨‹ä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ join æ–¹æ³•â€œé˜»å¡â€œè‡³çº¿ç¨‹å®Œæˆã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹17-7ä¸­ï¼Œå› [note]ä»»åŠ¡å¥æŸ„æœ¬èº«æ˜¯ Futureï¼Œå¯ç”¨ await å®ç°ç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚å…¶ Output ç±»å‹æ˜¯ Resultï¼Œå› æ­¤åœ¨ç­‰å¾…åè§£åŒ…å®ƒã€‚

This updated version runs until both loops finish.

æ­¤æ›´æ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬å°†è¿è¡Œè‡³ä¸¤ä¸ªå¾ªç¯å‡å®Œæˆã€‚

hi number 1 from the second task!
hi number 1 from the first task!
hi number 2 from the first task!
hi number 2 from the second task!
hi number 3 from the first task!
hi number 3 from the second task!
hi number 4 from the first task!
hi number 4 from the second task!
hi number 5 from the first task!
hi number 6 from the first task!
hi number 7 from the first task!
hi number 8 from the first task!
hi number 9 from the first task!

So far, it looks like async and threads give us the same basic outcomes, just with different syntax: using await instead of calling join on the join handle, and awaiting the sleep calls.

ç›®å‰çœ‹æ¥ï¼Œå¼‚æ­¥å’Œçº¿ç¨‹æä¾›äº†ç›¸åŒçš„åŸºæœ¬ç»“æœï¼ˆä»…è¯­æ³•ä¸åŒï¼‰ï¼šç”¨ await æ›¿ä»£å¯¹ join å¥æŸ„è°ƒç”¨ joinï¼Œå¹¶ç­‰å¾… sleep è°ƒç”¨ã€‚

The bigger difference is that we didnâ€™t need to spawn another operating system thread to do this. In fact, we donâ€™t even need to spawn a task here. Because async blocks compile to anonymous futures, we can put each loop in an async block and have the runtime run them both to completion using the trpl::join function.

æ›´å¤§åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºæˆ‘ä»¬æ— éœ€ç”Ÿæˆå¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ã€‚å®é™…ä¸Šç”šè‡³æ— éœ€ç”Ÿæˆä»»åŠ¡ã€‚å› å¼‚æ­¥å—ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºåŒ¿å Futureï¼Œå¯å°†æ¯ä¸ªå¾ªç¯æ”¾å…¥å¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨ trpl::join å‡½æ•°è®©è¿è¡Œæ—¶è¿è¡Œä¸¤è€…è‡³å®Œæˆã€‚

In the section Waiting for All Threads to Finishing Using join Handles, we showed how to use the join method on the JoinHandle type returned when you call std::thread::spawn. The trpl::join function is similar, but for futures. When you give it two futures, it produces a single new future whose output is a tuple containing the output of each future you passed in once they both complete. Thus, in Listing 17-8, we use trpl::join to wait for both fut1 and fut2 to finish. We do not await fut1 and fut2 but instead the new future produced by trpl::join. We ignore the output, because itâ€™s just a tuple containing two unit values.

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse futures::future::join

åœ¨â€œä½¿ç”¨ join å¥æŸ„ç­‰å¾…æ‰€æœ‰çº¿ç¨‹å®Œæˆâ€œä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å±•ç¤ºäº†å¦‚ä½•å¯¹ std::thread::spawn è¿”å›çš„ JoinHandle ç±»å‹ä½¿ç”¨ join æ–¹æ³•ã€‚trpl::join å‡½æ•°ç±»ä¼¼ï¼ˆä½†ç”¨äº Futureï¼‰ã€‚[note]ä¼ å…¥ä¸¤ä¸ª Future æ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒç”Ÿæˆæ–°çš„ Futureï¼ˆå…¶è¾“å‡ºæ˜¯åŒ…å«ä¸¤ä¸ª Future è¾“å‡ºçš„å…ƒç»„ï¼Œå½“å®ƒä»¬å‡å®Œæˆåï¼‰ã€‚å› æ­¤åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹17-8ä¸­ï¼Œç”¨ trpl::join ç­‰å¾… fut1 å’Œ fut2 å®Œæˆã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ç­‰å¾… fut1 å’Œ fut2ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç­‰å¾… trpl::join äº§ç”Ÿçš„æ–° Futureã€‚å› è¾“å‡ºä»…ä¸ºåŒ…å«ä¸¤ä¸ªå•å…ƒå€¼çš„å…ƒç»„ï¼Œæ•…å¿½ç•¥å®ƒã€‚

When we run this, we see both futures run to completion:

è¿è¡Œåå°†çœ‹åˆ°ä¸¤ä¸ª Future å‡è¿è¡Œè‡³å®Œæˆï¼š

hi number 1 from the first task!
hi number 1 from the second task!
hi number 2 from the first task!
hi number 2 from the second task!
hi number 3 from the first task!
hi number 3 from the second task!
hi number 4 from the first task!
hi number 4 from the second task!
hi number 5 from the first task!
hi number 6 from the first task!
hi number 7 from the first task!
hi number 8 from the first task!
hi number 9 from the first task!

Now, youâ€™ll see the exact same order every time, which is very different from what we saw with threads. That is because the trpl::join function is fair, meaning it checks each future equally often, alternating between them, and never lets one race ahead if the other is ready. With threads, the operating system decides which thread to check and how long to let it run. With async Rust, the runtime decides which task to check. (In practice, the details get complicated because an async runtime might use operating system threads under the hood as part of how it manages concurrency, so guaranteeing fairness can be more work for a runtimeâ€”but itâ€™s still possible!) Runtimes donâ€™t have to guarantee fairness for any given operation, and they often offer different APIs to let you choose whether or not you want fairness.

ç°åœ¨æ¯æ¬¡çœ‹åˆ°çš„é¡ºåºå®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒï¼ˆä¸çº¿ç¨‹æ–¹å¼æˆªç„¶ä¸åŒï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸º [note]trpl::join å‡½æ•°æ˜¯å…¬å¹³çš„â€”â€”å®ƒå¹³ç­‰æ£€æŸ¥æ¯ä¸ª Futureï¼Œåœ¨å®ƒä»¬ä¹‹é—´äº¤æ›¿ï¼Œä¸”è‹¥å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå·²å°±ç»ªåˆ™ä¸è®©ä¸€ä¸ªè¶…å‰ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹æ—¶ï¼Œæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿå†³å®šæ£€æŸ¥å“ªä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹åŠå…è®¸å…¶è¿è¡Œå¤šä¹…ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥ Rust æ—¶ï¼Œè¿è¡Œæ—¶å†³å®šæ£€æŸ¥å“ªä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ï¼ˆå®è·µä¸­ï¼Œå› å¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¯èƒ½åœ¨åº•å±‚ä½¿ç”¨æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿçº¿ç¨‹ç®¡ç†å¹¶å‘ï¼Œä¿è¯å…¬å¹³æ€§å¯èƒ½éœ€è¦æ›´å¤šå·¥ä½œï¼Œä½†ä»æœ‰å¯èƒ½ï¼‰ã€‚[note]è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¸å¿…ä¿è¯ç»™å®šæ“ä½œçš„å…¬å¹³æ€§ï¼Œä¸”é€šå¸¸æä¾›ä¸åŒ API ä¾›é€‰æ‹©æ˜¯å¦è¦æ±‚å…¬å¹³æ€§ã€‚

Try some of these variations on awaiting the futures and see what they do:

å°è¯•ä»¥ä¸‹å˜ä½“å¹¶è§‚å¯Ÿè¡Œä¸ºï¼š

  • Remove the async block from around either or both of the loops.

  • Await each async block immediately after defining it.

  • Wrap only the first loop in an async block, and await the resulting future after the body of second loop.

  • ç§»é™¤ä»»ä¸€æˆ–ä¸¤ä¸ªå¾ªç¯çš„ async å—

  • å®šä¹‰åç«‹å³ç­‰å¾…æ¯ä¸ª async å—

  • ä»…å°†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¾ªç¯åŒ…è£…åœ¨ async å—ä¸­ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå¾ªç¯ä½“åç­‰å¾…ç”Ÿæˆçš„ Future

For an extra challenge, see if you can figure out what the output will be in each case before running the code!

è¿›é˜¶æŒ‘æˆ˜ï¼šåœ¨è¿è¡Œä»£ç å‰é¢„æµ‹æ¯ç§æƒ…å†µçš„è¾“å‡ºï¼

Counting Up on Two Tasks Using Message Passing é€šè¿‡æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ä¸Šè®¡æ•°

Sharing data between futures will also be familiar: weâ€™ll use message passing again, but this time with async versions of the types and functions. Weâ€™ll take a slightly different path than we did in Using Message Passing to Transfer Data Between Threads to illustrate some of the key differences between thread-based and futures-based concurrency. In Listing 17-9, weâ€™ll begin with just a single async blockâ€”not spawning a separate task as we spawned a separate thread.

Future é—´å…±äº«æ•°æ®çš„æ–¹å¼ä¹Ÿç±»ä¼¼ï¼šå†æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’ï¼Œä½†è¿™æ¬¡ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„ç±»å‹å’Œå‡½æ•°ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é‡‡å–ä¸â€œä½¿ç”¨æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´ä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®â€œç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„è·¯å¾„ï¼Œä»¥è¯´æ˜çº¿ç¨‹ä¸ Future å¹¶å‘çš„å…³é”®å·®å¼‚ã€‚åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹17-9ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»…ä»ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—å¼€å§‹ï¼ˆä¸ç”Ÿæˆå•ç‹¬ä»»åŠ¡ï¼‰ã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse tokio::sync::mpsc::unbounded_channel;

Here, we use trpl::channel, an async version of the multiple-producer, single-consumer channel API we used with threads back in Chapter 16. The async version of the API is only a little different from the thread-based version: it uses a mutable rather than an immutable receiver rx, and its recv method produces a future we need to await rather than producing the value directly. Now we can send messages from the sender to the receiver. Notice that we donâ€™t have to spawn a separate thread or even a task; we merely need to await the rx.recv call.

è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨ trpl::channelï¼ˆç¬¬16ç« æ‰€ç”¨å¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…å•æ¶ˆè´¹è€…é€šé“ API çš„å¼‚æ­¥ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼‰ã€‚å¼‚æ­¥ API ä¸çº¿ç¨‹ç‰ˆç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒï¼š[note]æ¥æ”¶ç«¯ rx éœ€å¯å˜è€Œéä¸å¯å˜ï¼Œä¸”å…¶ recv æ–¹æ³•ç”Ÿæˆéœ€ç­‰å¾…çš„ Futureï¼ˆè€Œéç›´æ¥ç”Ÿæˆå€¼ï¼‰ã€‚ç°åœ¨å¯é€šè¿‡å‘é€ç«¯å‘æ¥æ”¶ç«¯å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚æ³¨æ„ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬æ— éœ€ç”Ÿæˆå•ç‹¬çº¿ç¨‹ç”šè‡³ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä»…éœ€ç­‰å¾… rx.recv è°ƒç”¨ã€‚

The synchronous Receiver::recv method in std::mpsc::channel blocks until it receives a message. The trpl::Receiver::recv method does not, because it is async. Instead of blocking, it hands control back to the runtime until either a message is received or the send side of the channel closes. By contrast, we donâ€™t await the send call, because it doesnâ€™t block. It doesnâ€™t need to, because the channel weâ€™re sending it into is unbounded.

åŒæ­¥çš„ std::mpsc::channel ä¸­çš„ Receiver::recv æ–¹æ³•é˜»å¡ç›´è‡³æ”¶åˆ°æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚è€Œ trpl::Receiver::recv æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥çš„ï¼ˆä¸é˜»å¡ï¼‰ï¼Œå®ƒå°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆç›´åˆ°æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ°è¾¾æˆ–é€šé“å‘é€ç«¯å…³é—­ï¼‰ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬[note]ä¸ç­‰å¾… send è°ƒç”¨ï¼ˆå› å…¶ä¸é˜»å¡ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸ºå®ƒå‘é€åˆ°çš„é€šé“æ˜¯æ— ç•Œçš„ã€‚

Note: Because all of this async code runs in an async block in a trpl::run call, everything within it can avoid blocking. However, the code outside it will block on the run function returning. Thatâ€™s the whole point of the trpl::run function: it lets you choose where to block on some set of async code, and thus where to transition between sync and async code. In most async runtimes, run is actually named block_on for exactly this reason.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå› æ‰€æœ‰å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç åœ¨ trpl::run è°ƒç”¨çš„å¼‚æ­¥å—ä¸­è¿è¡Œï¼Œå…¶å†…éƒ¨å¯é¿å…é˜»å¡ã€‚ä½†å¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç å°†åœ¨ run å‡½æ•°è¿”å›æ—¶é˜»å¡ã€‚è¿™æ­£æ˜¯ trpl::run å‡½æ•°çš„æ„ä¹‰ï¼šè®©ä½ é€‰æ‹©åœ¨ä½•å¤„é˜»å¡ä¸€ç»„å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç ï¼Œä»è€Œåœ¨åŒæ­¥ä¸å¼‚æ­¥ä»£ç é—´è¿‡æ¸¡ã€‚å¤šæ•°å¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¸­ï¼Œrun å®é™…åä¸º block_onï¼ˆåŸå› å³æ­¤ï¼‰ã€‚

Notice two things about this example. First, the message will arrive right away. Second, although we use a future here, thereâ€™s no concurrency yet. Everything in the listing happens in sequence, just as it would if there were no futures involved.

æ³¨æ„æ­¤ä¾‹ä¸¤ç‚¹ï¼šæ¶ˆæ¯ç«‹å³åˆ°è¾¾ï¼›è™½æœ‰ Future ä½†å°šæ— å¹¶å‘æ€§ã€‚è¯¥ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­çš„ä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½æ˜¯é¡ºåºå‘ç”Ÿçš„ï¼ˆå¦‚åŒæœªæ¶‰åŠ Futureï¼‰ã€‚

Letâ€™s address the first part by sending a series of messages and sleeping in between them, as shown in Listing 17-10.

é€šè¿‡å‘é€å¤šæ¡æ¶ˆæ¯å¹¶åœ¨å…¶é—´ä¼‘çœ æ¥è§£å†³ç¬¬ä¸€ç‚¹ï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-10ï¼‰ã€‚

In addition to sending the messages, we need to receive them. In this case, because we know how many messages are coming in, we could do that manually by calling rx.recv().await four times. In the real world, though, weâ€™ll generally be waiting on some unknown number of messages, so we need to keep waiting until we determine that there are no more messages.

é™¤å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯å¤–ï¼Œè¿˜éœ€æ¥æ”¶å®ƒä»¬ã€‚å·²çŸ¥æ¶ˆæ¯æ•°é‡æ—¶å¯æ‰‹åŠ¨è°ƒç”¨ rx.recv().await å››æ¬¡ã€‚ä½†ç°å®ä¸­é€šå¸¸ç­‰å¾…æœªçŸ¥æ•°é‡çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤éœ€æŒç»­ç­‰å¾…ç›´è‡³ç¡®è®¤æ— æ›´å¤šæ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

In Listing 16-10, we used a for loop to process all the items received from a synchronous channel. Rust doesnâ€™t yet have a way to write a for loop over an asynchronous series of items, however, so we need to use a loop we havenâ€™t seen before: the while let conditional loop. This is the loop version of the if let construct we saw back in the section Concise Control Flow with if let and let else. The loop will continue executing as long as the pattern it specifies continues to match the value.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹16-10ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ for å¾ªç¯å¤„ç†åŒæ­¥é€šé“çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ¥æ”¶é¡¹ã€‚ä½† Rust å°šæ— å¯¹å¼‚æ­¥åºåˆ—é¡¹å†™ for å¾ªç¯çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼Œå› æ­¤[note]éœ€ä½¿ç”¨ while let æ¡ä»¶å¾ªç¯ï¼ˆè¿™æ˜¯ç¬¬6ç« â€œç”¨ if let å’Œ let else ç®€æ´æ§åˆ¶æµâ€œä¸­ if let çš„å¾ªç¯ç‰ˆï¼‰ã€‚åªè¦æŒ‡å®šæ¨¡å¼ç»§ç»­åŒ¹é…å€¼ï¼Œå¾ªç¯å°±ä¼šæŒç»­æ‰§è¡Œã€‚

The rx.recv call produces a future, which we await. The runtime will pause the future until it is ready. Once a message arrives, the future will resolve to Some(message) as many times as a message arrives. When the channel closes, regardless of whether any messages have arrived, the future will instead resolve to None to indicate that there are no more values and thus we should stop pollingâ€”that is, stop awaiting.

rx.recv è°ƒç”¨ç”Ÿæˆ Futureï¼ˆæˆ‘ä»¬ç­‰å¾…å®ƒï¼‰ã€‚è¿è¡Œæ—¶å°†æš‚åœè¯¥ Future ç›´è‡³å…¶å°±ç»ªã€‚æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ°è¾¾åï¼ŒFuture å°†è§£æä¸º Some(message)ï¼ˆå¤šæ¬¡åˆ°è¾¾åˆ™å¤šæ¬¡è§£æï¼‰ã€‚é€šé“å…³é—­æ—¶ï¼ˆæ— è®ºæ˜¯å¦åˆ°è¾¾æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ï¼ŒFuture å°†è§£æä¸º Noneï¼ˆè¡¨ç¤ºæ— æ›´å¤šå€¼ä¸”åº”åœæ­¢è½®è¯¢â€”â€”å³åœæ­¢ç­‰å¾…ï¼‰ã€‚

The while let loop pulls all of this together. If the result of calling rx.recv().await is Some(message), we get access to the message and we can use it in the loop body, just as we could with if let. If the result is None, the loop ends. Every time the loop completes, it hits the await point again, so the runtime pauses it again until another message arrives.

while let å¾ªç¯æ•´åˆäº†è¿™äº›ï¼šè‹¥ rx.recv().await ç»“æœæ˜¯ Some(message)ï¼Œåˆ™åœ¨å¾ªç¯ä½“å†…è®¿é—®æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼›è‹¥ä¸º None åˆ™å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸã€‚æ¯æ¬¡å¾ªç¯å®Œæˆæ—¶ï¼Œä¼šå†æ¬¡åˆ°è¾¾ç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿è¡Œæ—¶å†æ¬¡æš‚åœå®ƒç›´åˆ°ä¸‹æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ°è¾¾ã€‚

The code now successfully sends and receives all of the messages. Unfortunately, there are still a couple of problems. For one thing, the messages do not arrive at half-second intervals. They arrive all at once, 2 seconds (2,000 milliseconds) after we start the program. For another, this program never exits! Instead, it waits forever for new messages. You will need to shut it down using ctrl-c.

æ­¤ä»£ç æˆåŠŸå‘é€å¹¶æ¥æ”¶æ‰€æœ‰æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚ä½†ä»æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼šæ¶ˆæ¯éåŠç§’é—´éš”åˆ°è¾¾ï¼ˆå¯åŠ¨ç¨‹åº2ç§’ååŒæ—¶åˆ°è¾¾ï¼‰ï¼›ç¨‹åºæ°¸ä¸é€€å‡ºï¼ˆæ°¸è¿œç­‰å¾…æ–°æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œéœ€æŒ‰ ctrl-c å…³é—­ï¼‰ã€‚

Letâ€™s start by examining why the messages come in all at once after the full delay, rather than coming in with delays between each one. Within a given async block, the order in which await keywords appear in the code is also the order in which theyâ€™re executed when the program runs.

é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¥æ¢ç©¶ä¸€ä¸‹ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæ¶ˆæ¯ä¼šåœ¨æ•´ä¸ªå»¶è¿Ÿä¹‹åä¸€æ¬¡æ€§å…¨éƒ¨æ”¶åˆ°ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæ¶ˆæ¯ä¹‹é—´äº§ç”Ÿå»¶è¿Ÿã€‚åœ¨ç»™å®šçš„å¼‚æ­¥å—ä¸­ï¼Œä»£ç ä¸­awaitå…³é”®å­—å‡ºç°çš„é¡ºåºï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯å®ƒä»¬åœ¨ç¨‹åºè¿è¡Œæ—¶æ‰§è¡Œçš„é¡ºåºã€‚

Thereâ€™s only one async block in Listing 17-10, so everything in it runs linearly. Thereâ€™s still no concurrency. All the tx.send calls happen, interspersed with all of the trpl::sleep calls and their associated await points. Only then does the while let loop get to go through any of the await points on the recv calls.

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å•17-10ä¸­åªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼Œå› æ­¤å…¶ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰å†…å®¹éƒ½æ˜¯çº¿æ€§è¿è¡Œçš„ã€‚è¿™ä»ç„¶æ²¡æœ‰å¹¶å‘æ€§ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰çš„tx.sendè°ƒç”¨éƒ½ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿï¼Œå…¶é—´å¤¹æ‚ç€æ‰€æœ‰çš„trpl::sleepè°ƒç”¨åŠå…¶ç›¸å…³çš„ç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ã€‚åªæœ‰åœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹åï¼Œwhile letå¾ªç¯æ‰èƒ½å¼€å§‹å¤„ç†recvè°ƒç”¨ä¸Šçš„ä»»ä½•ç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ã€‚

To get the behavior we want, where the sleep delay happens between each message, we need to put the tx and rx operations in their own async blocks, as shown in Listing 17-11. Then the runtime can execute each of them separately using trpl::join, just as in the counting example. Once again, we await the result of calling trpl::join, not the individual futures. If we awaited the individual futures in sequence, we would just end up back in a sequential flowâ€”exactly what weâ€™re trying not to do.

ä¸ºäº†å®ç°æˆ‘ä»¬æœŸæœ›çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œå³æ¯ä¸ªæ¶ˆæ¯ä¹‹é—´äº§ç”Ÿç¡çœ å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å°†txå’Œrxæ“ä½œæ”¾å…¥å®ƒä»¬å„è‡ªçš„å¼‚æ­¥å—ä¸­ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å•17-11æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚è¿™æ ·ï¼Œè¿è¡Œæ—¶å°±å¯ä»¥åƒåœ¨è®¡æ•°ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨trpl::joinåˆ†åˆ«æ‰§è¡Œå®ƒä»¬ã€‚å†æ¬¡å¼ºè°ƒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç­‰å¾…çš„æ˜¯è°ƒç”¨trpl::joinçš„ç»“æœï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å„ä¸ªFutureæœ¬èº«ã€‚å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬æŒ‰é¡ºåºç­‰å¾…å„ä¸ªFutureï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆåªä¼šå›åˆ°é¡ºåºæµç¨‹â€”â€”è€Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬è¯•å›¾é¿å…çš„åšæ³•ã€‚

With the updated code in Listing 17-11, the messages get printed at 500-millisecond intervals, rather than all in a rush after 2 seconds.

æ›´æ–°åï¼ˆç¤ºä¾‹17-11ï¼‰çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ä»¥500æ¯«ç§’é—´éš”æ‰“å°ï¼ˆè€Œé2ç§’åé›†ä¸­åˆ°è¾¾ï¼‰ã€‚

The program still never exits, though, because of the way the while let loop interacts with trpl::join:

ç¨‹åºä»ä¸é€€å‡ºï¼ˆå›  while let å¾ªç¯ä¸ trpl::join çš„äº¤äº’æ–¹å¼ï¼‰ï¼š

  • The future returned from trpl::join completes only once both futures passed to it have completed.

  • The tx future completes once it finishes sleeping after sending the last message in vals.

  • The rx future wonâ€™t complete until the while let loop ends.

  • The while let loop wonâ€™t end until awaiting rx.recv produces None.

  • Awaiting rx.recv will return None only once the other end of the channel is closed.

  • The channel will close only if we call rx.close or when the sender side, tx, is dropped.

  • We donâ€™t call rx.close anywhere, and tx wonâ€™t be dropped until the outermost async block passed to trpl::run ends.

  • The block canâ€™t end because it is blocked on trpl::join completing, which takes us back to the top of this list.

  • trpl::join è¿”å›çš„ Future ä»…åœ¨ä¼ å…¥çš„ä¸¤ä¸ª Future å‡å®Œæˆåå®Œæˆ

  • tx Future åœ¨ vals ä¸­å‘é€æœ€åä¸€æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯å¹¶ä¼‘çœ åå®Œæˆ

  • rx Future åœ¨ while let å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸå‰ä¸ä¼šå®Œæˆ

  • while let å¾ªç¯ä»…åœ¨ç­‰å¾… rx.recv äº§ç”Ÿ None æ—¶ç»“æŸ

  • ä»…å½“é€šé“å¦ä¸€ç«¯å…³é—­æ—¶ï¼Œç­‰å¾… rx.recv æ‰ä¼šè¿”å› None

  • [note]ä»…å½“è°ƒç”¨ rx.close æˆ–å‘é€ç«¯ tx è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒæ—¶é€šé“æ‰å…³é—­

  • æˆ‘ä»¬æœªè°ƒç”¨ rx.closeï¼Œä¸” tx åœ¨æœ€å¤–å±‚å¼‚æ­¥å—ç»“æŸå‰ä¸ä¼šè¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒ

  • è¯¥å—å› é˜»å¡åœ¨ trpl::join å®Œæˆä¸Šè€Œæ— æ³•ç»“æŸï¼ˆå›åˆ°æœ¬åˆ—è¡¨å¼€å¤´ï¼‰

We could manually close rx by calling rx.close somewhere, but that doesnâ€™t make much sense. Stopping after handling some arbitrary number of messages would make the program shut down, but we could miss messages. We need some other way to make sure that tx gets dropped before the end of the function.

å¯æ‰‹åŠ¨è°ƒç”¨ rx.close å…³é—­ï¼Œä½†è¿™ä¸åˆç†ï¼ˆå¤„ç†ä»»æ„æ•°é‡æ¶ˆæ¯ååœæ­¢ç¨‹åºå¯èƒ½é—æ¼æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚éœ€è¦å…¶ä»–æ–¹å¼ç¡®ä¿ tx åœ¨å‡½æ•°ç»“æŸå‰è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒã€‚

Right now, the async block where we send the messages only borrows tx because sending a message doesnâ€™t require ownership, but if we could move tx into that async block, it would be dropped once that block ends. In the Chapter 13 section Capturing References or Moving Ownership, you learned how to use the move keyword with closures, and, as discussed in the Chapter 16 section Using move Closures with Threads, we often need to move data into closures when working with threads. The same basic dynamics apply to async blocks, so the move keyword works with async blocks just as it does with closures.

å½“å‰å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯çš„å¼‚æ­¥å—ä»…å€Ÿç”¨ txï¼ˆå› å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ä¸éœ€æ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥èƒ½å°† tx ç§»å…¥è¯¥å¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼Œå®ƒå°†åœ¨å—ç»“æŸæ—¶è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒã€‚ç¬¬13ç« â€œæ•è·å¼•ç”¨æˆ–ç§»åŠ¨æ‰€æœ‰æƒâ€œä¸­å­¦ä¹ äº†å¯¹é—­åŒ…ä½¿ç”¨ move å…³é”®å­—ï¼ˆå¦‚ç¬¬16ç« â€œå¯¹çº¿ç¨‹ä½¿ç”¨ move é—­åŒ…â€œæ‰€è¿°ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹æ—¶ç»å¸¸éœ€å°†æ•°æ®ç§»å…¥é—­åŒ…ï¼‰ã€‚ç›¸åŒåŸç†é€‚ç”¨äºå¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼Œå› æ­¤ move å…³é”®å­—å¯¹å¼‚æ­¥å—çš„ä½œç”¨ä¸é—­åŒ…ç›¸åŒã€‚

In Listing 17-12, we change the block used to send messages from async to async move. When we run this version of the code, it shuts down gracefully after the last message is sent and received.

åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹17-12ä¸­ï¼Œå°†å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯çš„å—ä» async æ”¹ä¸º async moveã€‚è¿è¡Œæ­¤ç‰ˆæœ¬ä»£ç æ—¶ï¼Œæœ€åä¸€æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯å‘é€å’Œæ¥æ”¶åå°†æ­£å¸¸å…³é—­ã€‚

This async channel is also a multiple-producer channel, so we can call clone on tx if we want to send messages from multiple futures, as shown in Listing 17-13.

æ­¤å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¤šç”Ÿäº§è€…é€šé“ï¼Œå› æ­¤è‹¥è¦ä»å¤šä¸ª Future å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯[note]å¯å¯¹ tx è°ƒç”¨ cloneï¼ˆè§ç¤ºä¾‹17-13ï¼‰ã€‚

First, we clone tx, creating tx1 outside the first async block. We move tx1 into that block just as we did before with tx. Then, later, we move the original tx into a new async block, where we send more messages on a slightly slower delay. We happen to put this new async block after the async block for receiving messages, but it could go before it just as well. The key is the order in which the futures are awaited, not in which theyâ€™re created.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—å¤–å…‹éš† tx åˆ›å»º tx1ï¼Œå¹¶å°† tx1 ç§»å…¥è¯¥å—ï¼ˆå¦‚å‰å¤„ç† txï¼‰ã€‚ç„¶åå°†åŸå§‹çš„ tx ç§»å…¥æ–°å¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼ˆä»¥è¾ƒæ…¢å»¶è¿Ÿå‘é€æ›´å¤šæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚æ–°å¼‚æ­¥å—æ°å¥½åœ¨æ¥æ”¶æ¶ˆæ¯å—ä¹‹åï¼Œä½†å…¶ä½ç½®æ— å…³ç´§è¦ï¼ˆå…³é”®æ˜¯ Future çš„ç­‰å¾…é¡ºåºè€Œéåˆ›å»ºé¡ºåºï¼‰ã€‚

Both of the async blocks for sending messages need to be async move blocks so that both tx and tx1 get dropped when those blocks finish. Otherwise, weâ€™ll end up back in the same infinite loop we started out in. Finally, we switch from trpl::join to trpl::join3 to handle the additional future.

ä¸¤ä¸ªå‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯çš„å¼‚æ­¥å—éœ€ä¸º async move å—ï¼ˆä»¥ä¾¿ tx å’Œ tx1 åœ¨å—ç»“æŸæ—¶è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒï¼‰ï¼Œå¦åˆ™ä¼šé™·å…¥ä¹‹å‰çš„æ— é™å¾ªç¯ã€‚æœ€åä» trpl::join åˆ‡æ¢åˆ° trpl::join3 ä»¥å¤„ç†é¢å¤–çš„ Futureã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse futures::future::join3;

Now we see all the messages from both sending futures, and because the sending futures use slightly different delays after sending, the messages are also received at those different intervals.

ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬å°†çœ‹åˆ°æ¥è‡ªä¸¤ä¸ªå‘é€ Future çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼ˆå› å‘é€ Future ä½¿ç”¨ç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„å‘é€åå»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œæ¶ˆæ¯ä¹Ÿä»¥ä¸åŒé—´éš”æ¥æ”¶ï¼‰ã€‚

received 'hi'
received 'more'
received 'from'
received 'the'
received 'messages'
received 'future'
received 'for'
received 'you'

This is a good start, but it limits us to just a handful of futures: two with join, or three with join3. Letâ€™s see how we might work with more futures.

è¿™æ˜¯è‰¯å¥½çš„å¼€ç«¯ï¼Œä½†ä»…é™äºå°‘é‡ Futureï¼ˆjoin å¤„ç†ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼Œjoin3 å¤„ç†ä¸‰ä¸ªï¼‰ã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æ¢è®¨å¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†æ›´å¤š Futureã€‚

Working with Any Number of Futures å¤„ç†ä»»æ„æ•°é‡çš„ Future

When we switched from using two futures to three in the previous section, we also had to switch from using join to using join3. It would be annoying to have to call a different function every time we changed the number of futures we wanted to join. Happily, we have a macro form of join to which we can pass an arbitrary number of arguments. It also handles awaiting the futures itself. Thus, we could rewrite the code from Listing 17-13 to use join! instead of join3, as in Listing 17-14.

åœ¨ä¸Šä¸€èŠ‚ä¸­ï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä½¿ç”¨çš„ Future æ•°é‡ä»ä¸¤ä¸ªå¢åŠ åˆ°ä¸‰ä¸ªæ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿä¸å¾—ä¸ä»ä½¿ç”¨ join åˆ‡æ¢åˆ°ä½¿ç”¨ join3ã€‚æ¯æ¬¡æ”¹å˜æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³è¦åˆå¹¶çš„ Future æ•°é‡æ—¶éƒ½å¿…é¡»è°ƒç”¨ä¸åŒçš„å‡½æ•°ä¼šå¾ˆçƒ¦äººã€‚å¹¸è¿çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª[note]å®å½¢å¼çš„ joinï¼Œå¯ä»¥å‘å®ƒä¼ é€’ä»»æ„æ•°é‡çš„å‚æ•°ã€‚å®ƒè¿˜ä¼šè‡ªå·±å¤„ç†å¯¹ Future çš„ç­‰å¾…ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é‡å†™ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-13 ä¸­çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ join! ä»£æ›¿ join3ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-14 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse futures::join;

This is definitely an improvement over swapping between join and join3 and join4 and so on! However, even this macro form only works when we know the number of futures ahead of time. In real-world Rust, though, pushing futures into a collection and then waiting on some or all the futures of them to complete is a common pattern.

è¿™ç»å¯¹æ¯”åœ¨ joinã€join3ã€join4 ç­‰ä¹‹é—´åˆ‡æ¢è¦å¥½å¾—å¤šï¼ç„¶è€Œï¼Œå³ä½¿è¿™ç§å®å½¢å¼ä¹Ÿä»…åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬äº‹å…ˆçŸ¥é“ Future æ•°é‡æ—¶æ‰æœ‰æ•ˆã€‚åœ¨ç°å®ä¸–ç•Œçš„ Rust ä¸­ï¼Œå°† Future æ¨å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªé›†åˆï¼Œç„¶åç­‰å¾…å…¶ä¸­éƒ¨åˆ†æˆ–å…¨éƒ¨ Future å®Œæˆæ˜¯ä¸€ç§å¸¸è§æ¨¡å¼ã€‚

To check all the futures in some collection, weâ€™ll need to iterate over and join on all of them. The trpl::join_all function accepts any type that implements the Iterator trait, which you learned about back in The Iterator Trait and the next Method Chapter 13, so it seems like just the ticket. Letâ€™s try putting our futures in a vector and replacing join! with join_all as shown in Listing 17-15.

è¦æ£€æŸ¥æŸä¸ªé›†åˆä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰ Futureï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å¯¹æ‰€æœ‰å®ƒä»¬è¿›è¡Œè¿­ä»£å¹¶åˆå¹¶ï¼ˆjoinï¼‰ã€‚trpl::join_all å‡½æ•°æ¥å—ä»»ä½•å®ç°äº† Iterator ç‰¹å¾çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆä½ åœ¨ç¬¬ 13 ç« â€œIterator ç‰¹å¾å’Œ next æ–¹æ³•â€ä¸­å­¦ä¹ è¿‡ï¼‰ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å®ƒçœ‹èµ·æ¥æ­£åˆé€‚ã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å°è¯•å°†æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ Future æ”¾å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªå‘é‡ï¼ˆvectorï¼‰ä¸­ï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨ join_all æ›¿æ¢ join!ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-15 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse futures::future::join_all;

Unfortunately, this code doesnâ€™t compile. Instead, we get this error:

ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™æ®µä»£ç æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¾—åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªé”™è¯¯ï¼š

error[E0308]: mismatched types
  --> src/main.rs:45:37
   |
10 |         let tx1_fut = async move {
   |                       ---------- the expected `async` block
...
24 |         let rx_fut = async {
   |                      ----- the found `async` block
...
45 |         let futures = vec![tx1_fut, rx_fut, tx_fut];
   |                                     ^^^^^^ expected `async` block, found a different `async` block
   |
   = note: expected `async` block `{async block@src/main.rs:10:23: 10:33}`
              found `async` block `{async block@src/main.rs:24:22: 24:27}`
   = note: no two async blocks, even if identical, have the same type
   = help: consider pinning your async block and casting it to a trait object

This might be surprising. After all, none of the async blocks returns anything, so each one produces a Future<Output = ()>. Remember that Future is a trait, though, and that the compiler creates a unique enum for each async block. You canâ€™t put two different hand-written structs in a Vec, and the same rule applies to the different enums generated by the compiler.

è¿™å¯èƒ½ä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶ã€‚æ¯•ç«Ÿï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—è¿”å›ä»»ä½•ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ¯ä¸ªéƒ½äº§ç”Ÿä¸€ä¸ª Future<Output = ()>ã€‚ä½†è¯·è®°ä½ï¼ŒFuture æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆtraitï¼‰ï¼Œ[note]ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¼šä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå”¯ä¸€çš„æšä¸¾ã€‚ä½ ä¸èƒ½å°†ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒæ‰‹å†™çš„ç»“æ„ä½“æ”¾å…¥ Vec ä¸­ï¼ŒåŒæ ·çš„è§„åˆ™ä¹Ÿé€‚ç”¨äºç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç”Ÿæˆçš„ä¸åŒæšä¸¾ã€‚

To make this work, we need to use trait objects, just as we did in â€œReturning Errors from the run functionâ€ in Chapter 12. (Weâ€™ll cover trait objects in detail in Chapter 18.) Using trait objects lets us treat each of the anonymous futures produced by these types as the same type, because all of them implement the Future trait.

ä¸ºäº†ä½¿è¿™ä¸ªå·¥ä½œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨ç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡ï¼ˆtrait objectsï¼‰ï¼Œå°±åƒæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 12 ç« â€œä» run å‡½æ•°è¿”å›é”™è¯¯â€ä¸­æ‰€åšçš„é‚£æ ·ã€‚ï¼ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°†åœ¨ç¬¬ 18 ç« è¯¦ç»†è®¨è®ºç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡ã€‚ï¼‰ä½¿ç”¨ç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†è¿™äº›ç±»å‹äº§ç”Ÿçš„æ¯ä¸ªåŒ¿å Future è§†ä¸ºç›¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬éƒ½å®ç°äº† Future ç‰¹å¾ã€‚

Note: In Using an Enum to Store Multiple Values in Chapter 8, we discussed another way to include multiple types in a Vec: using an enum to represent each type that can appear in the vector. We canâ€™t do that here, though. For one thing, we have no way to name the different types, because they are anonymous. For another, the reason we reached for a vector and join_all in the first place was to be able to work with a dynamic collection of futures where we only care that they have the same output type.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šåœ¨ç¬¬ 8 ç« â€œä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾å­˜å‚¨å¤šä¸ªå€¼â€ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è®¨è®ºäº†åœ¨ Vec ä¸­åŒ…å«å¤šç§ç±»å‹çš„å¦ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•ï¼šä½¿ç”¨æšä¸¾ï¼ˆenumï¼‰æ¥è¡¨ç¤ºå‘é‡ä¸­å¯ä»¥å‡ºç°çš„æ¯ç§ç±»å‹ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è¿™é‡Œä¸èƒ½è¿™æ ·åšã€‚ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ— æ³•å‘½åè¿™äº›ä¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬æ˜¯åŒ¿åçš„ã€‚å¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æœ€åˆé€‰æ‹©ä½¿ç”¨å‘é‡å’Œ join_all çš„åŸå› ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†èƒ½å¤Ÿå¤„ç†ä¸€ä¸ªåŠ¨æ€çš„ Future é›†åˆï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªå…³å¿ƒå®ƒä»¬å…·æœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„è¾“å‡ºç±»å‹ã€‚

We start by wrapping each future in the vec! in a Box::new, as shown in Listing 17-16.

æˆ‘ä»¬é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ vec! ä¸­ç”¨ Box::new åŒ…è£…æ¯ä¸ª Futureï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-16 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

Unfortunately, this code still doesnâ€™t compile. In fact, we get the same basic error we got before for both the second and third Box::new calls, as well as new errors referring to the Unpin trait. Weâ€™ll come back to the Unpin errors in a moment. First, letâ€™s fix the type errors on the Box::new calls by explicitly annotating the type of the futures variable (see Listing 17-17).

ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™æ®µä»£ç ä»ç„¶æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ã€‚å®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œå¯¹äºç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå’Œç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ª Box::new è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¾—åˆ°äº†ä¸ä¹‹å‰åŸºæœ¬ç›¸åŒçš„é”™è¯¯ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶è¿˜å‡ºç°äº†å¼•ç”¨ Unpin ç‰¹å¾çš„æ–°é”™è¯¯ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ç¨åä¼šå›åˆ° Unpin é”™è¯¯ã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œè®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡æ˜¾å¼[note]æ³¨è§£ futures å˜é‡çš„ç±»å‹æ¥ä¿®å¤ Box::new è°ƒç”¨çš„ç±»å‹é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆè§ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-17ï¼‰ã€‚

This type declaration is a little involved, so letâ€™s walk through it:

è¿™ä¸ªç±»å‹å£°æ˜æœ‰ç‚¹å¤æ‚ï¼Œè®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€æ­¥åˆ†æä¸€ä¸‹ï¼š

  1. The innermost type is the future itself. We note explicitly that the output of the future is the unit type () by writing Future<Output = ()>.

  2. Then we annotate the trait with dyn to mark it as dynamic.

  3. The entire trait reference is wrapped in a Box.

  4. Finally, we state explicitly that futures is a Vec containing these items.

  5. æœ€å†…å±‚çš„ç±»å‹æ˜¯ Future æœ¬èº«ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡å†™ Future<Output = ()> æ˜¾å¼æ³¨è§£ Future çš„è¾“å‡ºæ˜¯å•å…ƒç±»å‹ ()ã€‚

  6. ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ dyn æ³¨è§£ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå°†å…¶æ ‡è®°ä¸ºåŠ¨æ€çš„ï¼ˆdynamicï¼‰ã€‚

  7. æ•´ä¸ªç‰¹å¾å¼•ç”¨è¢«åŒ…è£…åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ª Box ä¸­ã€‚

  8. æœ€åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ˜¾å¼å£°æ˜ futures æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å«è¿™äº›é¡¹çš„ Vecã€‚

That already made a big difference. Now when we run the compiler, we get only the errors mentioning Unpin. Although there are three of them, their contents are very similar.

è¿™å·²ç»å¸¦æ¥äº†å¾ˆå¤§çš„æ”¹å˜ã€‚ç°åœ¨å½“æˆ‘ä»¬è¿è¡Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªå¾—åˆ°æåŠ Unpin çš„é”™è¯¯ã€‚è™½ç„¶æœ‰ä¸‰ä¸ªé”™è¯¯ï¼Œä½†å®ƒä»¬çš„å†…å®¹éå¸¸ç›¸ä¼¼ã€‚

error[E0277]: `dyn Future<Output = ()>` cannot be unpinned
   --> src/main.rs:49:24
    |
49  |         trpl::join_all(futures).await;
    |         -------------- ^^^^^^^ the trait `Unpin` is not implemented for `dyn Future<Output = ()>`
    |         |
    |         required by a bound introduced by this call
    |

            consider using `Box::pin` if you need to access the pinned value outside of the current scope

note: required by a bound in `join_all`
   --> file:///home/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-1949cf8c6b5b557f/futures-util-0.3.30/src/future/join_all.rs:105:14

error[E0277]: `dyn Future<Output = ()>` cannot be unpinned
  --> src/main.rs:49:9

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `async_await` (bin "async_await") due to 3 previous errors

That is a lot to digest, so letâ€™s pull it apart. The first part of the message tell us that the first async block (src/main.rs:8:23: 20:10) does not implement the Unpin trait and suggests using pin! or Box::pin to resolve it. Later in the chapter, weâ€™ll dig into a few more details about Pin and Unpin. For the moment, though, we can just follow the compilerâ€™s advice to get unstuck. In Listing 17-18, we start by importing Pin from std::pin. Next we update the type annotation for futures, with a Pin wrapping each Box. Finally, we use Box::pin to pin the futures themselves.

è¿™æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šä¿¡æ¯éœ€è¦æ¶ˆåŒ–ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è®©æˆ‘ä»¬åˆ†è§£ä¸€ä¸‹ã€‚æ¶ˆæ¯çš„ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼ˆsrc/main.rs:8:23: 20:10ï¼‰æ²¡æœ‰å®ç° Unpin ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå¹¶å»ºè®®ä½¿ç”¨ pin! æˆ– Box::pin æ¥è§£å†³å®ƒã€‚åœ¨æœ¬ç« åé¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ›´æ·±å…¥åœ°æ¢è®¨ä¸€äº›å…³äº Pin å’Œ Unpin çš„ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚ä¸è¿‡ç°åœ¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥éµå¾ªç¼–è¯‘å™¨çš„å»ºè®®æ¥è§£å†³é—®é¢˜ã€‚åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-18 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬[note]é¦–å…ˆä» std::pin å¯¼å…¥ Pinã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬æ›´æ–° futures çš„ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£ï¼Œç”¨ Pin åŒ…è£…æ¯ä¸ª Boxã€‚æœ€åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ Box::pin æ¥å›ºå®šï¼ˆpinï¼‰Future æœ¬èº«ã€‚

If we compile and run this, we finally get the output we hoped for:

å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬ç¼–è¯‘å¹¶è¿è¡Œè¿™ä¸ªï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç»ˆäºå¾—åˆ°äº†æˆ‘ä»¬æœŸæœ›çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼š

received 'hi'
received 'more'
received 'from'
received 'messages'
received 'the'
received 'for'
received 'future'
received 'you'

Phew!

å‘¼ï¼

Thereâ€™s a bit more to explore here. For one thing, using Pin<Box<T>> adds a small amount of overhead from putting these futures on the heap with Boxâ€”and weâ€™re only doing that to get the types to line up. We donâ€™t actually need the heap allocation, after all: these futures are local to this particular function. As noted before, Pin is itself a wrapper type, so we can get the benefit of having a single type in the Vecâ€”the original reason we reached for Boxâ€”without doing a heap allocation. We can use Pin directly with each future, using the std::pin::pin macro.

[note]è¿™é‡Œè¿˜æœ‰æ›´å¤šå¯ä»¥æ¢ç´¢çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ Pin<Box<T>> ä¼šå¸¦æ¥ä¸€ç‚¹å¼€é”€ï¼Œè¿™æºäºç”¨ Box æŠŠè¿™äº› future å¯¹è±¡æ”¾åˆ°å †ä¸Šâ€”â€”è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¿™ä¹ˆåšä»…ä»…æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†è®©ç±»å‹èƒ½å¤ŸåŒ¹é…ã€‚æ¯•ç«Ÿï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®é™…ä¸Šå¹¶ä¸éœ€è¦å †åˆ†é…ï¼šè¿™äº› Future æ˜¯ç‰¹å®šäºæ­¤å‡½æ•°çš„å±€éƒ¨å˜é‡ã€‚å¦‚å‰æ‰€è¿°ï¼ŒPin æœ¬èº«æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…è£…ç±»å‹ï¼Œå› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨ Vec ä¸­æ‹¥æœ‰å•ä¸€ç±»å‹â€”â€”è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬æœ€åˆé€‰æ‹© Box çš„åŸå› â€”â€”è€Œæ— éœ€è¿›è¡Œå †åˆ†é…ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ std::pin::pin å®ç›´æ¥åœ¨æ¯ä¸ª Future ä¸Šä½¿ç”¨ Pinã€‚

However, we must still be explicit about the type of the pinned reference; otherwise, Rust will still not know to interpret these as dynamic trait objects, which is what we need them to be in the Vec. We therefore add pin to our list of imports from std::pin. Then we can pin! each future when we define it and define futures as a Vec containing pinned mutable references to the dynamic future type, as in Listing 17-19.

[note]ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶å¿…é¡»æ˜¾å¼å£°æ˜å›ºå®šå¼•ç”¨çš„ç±»å‹ï¼›å¦åˆ™ï¼ŒRust ä»ç„¶ä¸ä¼šçŸ¥é“å°†è¿™äº›è§£é‡Šä¸ºåŠ¨æ€ç‰¹å¾å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œè€Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ Vec ä¸­éœ€è¦çš„ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°† pin æ·»åŠ åˆ°ä» std::pin å¯¼å…¥çš„åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­ã€‚ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨å®šä¹‰æ¯ä¸ª Future æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨ pin! å®å›ºå®šå®ƒï¼Œå¹¶å°† futures å®šä¹‰ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å«å›ºå®šå¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼ˆæŒ‡å‘åŠ¨æ€ Future ç±»å‹ï¼‰çš„ Vecï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-19 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

We got this far by ignoring the fact that we might have different Output types. For example, in Listing 17-20, the anonymous future for a implements Future<Output = u32>, the anonymous future for b implements Future<Output = &str>, and the anonymous future for c implements Future<Output = bool>.

æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡å¿½ç•¥æˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„ Output ç±»å‹è¿™ä¸€äº‹å®æ‰èµ°åˆ°è¿™ä¸€æ­¥ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-20 ä¸­ï¼Œa çš„åŒ¿å Future å®ç°äº† Future<Output = u32>ï¼Œb çš„åŒ¿å Future å®ç°äº† Future<Output = &str>ï¼Œè€Œ c çš„åŒ¿å Future å®ç°äº† Future<Output = bool>ã€‚

We can use trpl::join! to await them, because it allows us to pass in multiple future types and produces a tuple of those types. We cannot use trpl::join_all, because it requires all of the futures passed in to have the same type. Remember, that error is what got us started on this adventure with Pin!

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::join! æ¥ç­‰å¾…å®ƒä»¬ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼ å…¥å¤šç§ Future ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¹¶äº§ç”Ÿè¿™äº›ç±»å‹ç»„æˆçš„å…ƒç»„ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::join_allï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒè¦æ±‚ä¼ å…¥çš„æ‰€æœ‰ Future å…·æœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ã€‚è®°ä½ï¼Œæ­£æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªé”™è¯¯è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å¼€å§‹äº†è¿™æ®µå…³äº Pin çš„å†’é™©ï¼

This is a fundamental tradeoff: we can either deal with a dynamic number of futures with join_all, as long as they all have the same type, or we can deal with a set number of futures with the join functions or the join! macro, even if they have different types. This is the same scenario weâ€™d face when working with any other types in Rust. Futures are not special, even though we have some nice syntax for working with them, and thatâ€™s a good thing.

è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ ¹æœ¬æ€§çš„æƒè¡¡ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬[note]å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ join_all å¤„ç†åŠ¨æ€æ•°é‡çš„ Futureï¼Œåªè¦å®ƒä»¬éƒ½å…·æœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼›æˆ–è€…æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ join ç³»åˆ—å‡½æ•°æˆ– join! å®å¤„ç†å›ºå®šæ•°é‡çš„ Futureï¼Œå³ä½¿å®ƒä»¬å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ã€‚è¿™ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ Rust ä¸­å¤„ç†ä»»ä½•å…¶ä»–ç±»å‹æ—¶é¢ä¸´çš„æƒ…å†µç›¸åŒã€‚Future å¹¶ä¸ç‰¹æ®Šï¼Œå°½ç®¡æˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰ä¸€äº›å¾ˆå¥½çš„è¯­æ³•æ¥å¤„ç†å®ƒä»¬ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä»¶å¥½äº‹ã€‚

Racing Futures Future ç«é€Ÿ

When we â€œjoinâ€ futures with the join family of functions and macros, we require all of them to finish before we move on. Sometimes, though, we only need some future from a set to finish before we move onâ€”kind of similar to racing one future against another.

å½“æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ join ç³»åˆ—å‡½æ•°å’Œå®â€œåˆå¹¶â€ Future æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¦æ±‚å®ƒä»¬éƒ½å®Œæˆæ‰èƒ½ç»§ç»­ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¦é›†åˆä¸­çš„æŸä¸ª Future å®Œæˆå°±å¯ä»¥ç»§ç»­â€”â€”æœ‰ç‚¹åƒè®©ä¸€ä¸ª Future ä¸å¦ä¸€ä¸ª Future èµ›è·‘ï¼ˆraceï¼‰ã€‚

In Listing 17-21, we once again use trpl::race to run two futures, slow and fast, against each other.

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-21 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å†æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::race æ¥è®©ä¸¤ä¸ª Future slow å’Œ fast ç›¸äº’ç«äº‰ã€‚

Each future prints a message when it starts running, pauses for some amount of time by calling and awaiting sleep, and then prints another message when it finishes. Then we pass both slow and fast to trpl::race and wait for one of them to finish. (The outcome here isnâ€™t too surprising: fast wins.) Unlike when we used race back in â€œOur First Async Programâ€, we just ignore the Either instance it returns here, because all of the interesting behavior happens in the body of the async blocks.

æ¯ä¸ª Future åœ¨å¼€å§‹è¿è¡Œæ—¶æ‰“å°ä¸€æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œé€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨å¹¶ç­‰å¾… sleep æš‚åœä¸€æ®µæ—¶é—´ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨å®Œæˆæ—¶æ‰“å°å¦ä¸€æ¡æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬å°† slow å’Œ fast éƒ½ä¼ é€’ç»™ trpl::race å¹¶ç­‰å¾…å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªå®Œæˆã€‚ï¼ˆè¿™é‡Œçš„ç»“æœå¹¶ä¸å¤ªä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶ï¼šfast è·èƒœã€‚ï¼‰ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹‹å‰åœ¨â€œç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç¨‹åºâ€ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ race ä¸åŒï¼Œè¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªæ˜¯å¿½ç•¥å®ƒè¿”å›çš„ Either å®ä¾‹ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰æœ‰è¶£çš„è¡Œä¸ºéƒ½å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨å¼‚æ­¥å—çš„ä¸»ä½“ä¸­ã€‚

Notice that if you flip the order of the arguments to race, the order of the â€œstartedâ€ messages changes, even though the fast future always completes first. Thatâ€™s because the implementation of this particular race function is not fair. It always runs the futures passed in as arguments in the order in which theyâ€™re passed. Other implementations are fair and will randomly choose which future to poll first. Regardless of whether the implementation of race weâ€™re using is fair, though, one of the futures will run up to the first await in its body before another task can start.

è¯·æ³¨æ„ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ ç¿»è½¬ä¼ é€’ç»™ race çš„å‚æ•°é¡ºåºï¼Œâ€œstartedâ€æ¶ˆæ¯çš„é¡ºåºä¹Ÿä¼šæ”¹å˜ï¼Œå³ä½¿ fast Future æ€»æ˜¯æœ€å…ˆå®Œæˆã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸º[note]è¿™ä¸ªç‰¹å®š race å‡½æ•°çš„å®ç°æ˜¯ä¸å…¬å¹³çš„ã€‚å®ƒæ€»æ˜¯æŒ‰ç…§å‚æ•°ä¼ é€’çš„é¡ºåºè¿è¡Œ Futureã€‚å…¶ä»–å®ç°æ˜¯å…¬å¹³çš„ï¼Œä¼šéšæœºé€‰æ‹©é¦–å…ˆè½®è¯¢ï¼ˆpollï¼‰å“ªä¸ª Futureã€‚ä¸è¿‡ï¼Œæ— è®ºæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨çš„ race å®ç°æ˜¯å¦å…¬å¹³ï¼Œæ€»æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª Future ä¼šåœ¨å…¶ä¸»ä½“ä¸­è¿è¡Œåˆ°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª await ç‚¹ï¼Œç„¶åå¦ä¸€ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡æ‰èƒ½å¼€å§‹ã€‚

Recall from Our First Async Program that at each await point, Rust gives a runtime a chance to pause the task and switch to another one if the future being awaited isnâ€™t ready. The inverse is also true: Rust only pauses async blocks and hands control back to a runtime at an await point. Everything between await points is synchronous.

å›æƒ³ä¸€ä¸‹â€œç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥ç¨‹åºâ€ï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ª await ç‚¹ï¼ŒRust éƒ½ä¼šç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆruntimeï¼‰ä¸€ä¸ªæœºä¼šæ¥æš‚åœå½“å‰ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¢«ç­‰å¾…çš„ Future è¿˜æ²¡å‡†å¤‡å¥½ï¼Œå°±åˆ‡æ¢åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ã€‚åä¹‹äº¦ç„¶ï¼š[note]Rust åªåœ¨ await ç‚¹æš‚åœå¼‚æ­¥å—å¹¶å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ã€‚await ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´çš„æ‰€æœ‰ä»£ç éƒ½æ˜¯åŒæ­¥æ‰§è¡Œçš„ã€‚

That means if you do a bunch of work in an async block without an await point, that future will block any other futures from making progress. You may sometimes hear this referred to as one future starving other futures. In some cases, that may not be a big deal. However, if you are doing some kind of expensive setup or long-running work, or if you have a future that will keep doing some particular task indefinitely, youâ€™ll need to think about when and where to hand control back to the runtime.

[note]è¿™æ„å‘³ç€å¦‚æœä½ åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å—ä¸­åšäº†ä¸€å †å·¥ä½œè€Œæ²¡æœ‰ await ç‚¹ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ª Future å°†é˜»å¡å…¶ä»– Future çš„è¿›å±•ã€‚ä½ æœ‰æ—¶å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¬åˆ°è¿™è¢«ç§°ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ª Future é¥¿æ­»ï¼ˆstarvingï¼‰å…¶ä»– Futureã€‚åœ¨æŸäº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œè¿™å¯èƒ½ä¸æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆå¤§é—®é¢˜ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ æ­£åœ¨è¿›è¡ŒæŸç§æ˜‚è´µçš„è®¾ç½®æˆ–é•¿æ—¶é—´è¿è¡Œçš„å·¥ä½œï¼Œæˆ–è€…å¦‚æœä½ æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª Future å°†æ— é™æœŸåœ°æŒç»­æ‰§è¡ŒæŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä½ å°±éœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘ä½•æ—¶ä½•åœ°å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ã€‚

By the same token, if you have long-running blocking operations, async can be a useful tool for providing ways for different parts of the program to relate to each other.

åŒæ ·åœ°ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ æœ‰é•¿æ—¶é—´è¿è¡Œçš„é˜»å¡æ“ä½œï¼Œå¼‚æ­¥å¯ä»¥æˆä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰ç”¨çš„å·¥å…·ï¼Œç”¨äºæä¾›ç¨‹åºä¸åŒéƒ¨åˆ†ä¹‹é—´ç›¸äº’å…³è”çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚

But how would you hand control back to the runtime in those cases?

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨è¿™äº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œä½ å¦‚ä½•å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶å‘¢ï¼Ÿ

Yielding Control to the Runtime å‘è¿è¡Œæ—¶è®©å‡ºæ§åˆ¶æƒ

Letâ€™s simulate a long-running operation. Listing 17-22 introduces a slow function.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ¨¡æ‹Ÿä¸€ä¸ªé•¿æ—¶é—´è¿è¡Œçš„æ“ä½œã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-22 å¼•å…¥äº†ä¸€ä¸ª slow å‡½æ•°ã€‚

This code uses std::thread::sleep instead of trpl::sleep so that calling slow will block the current thread for some number of milliseconds. We can use slow to stand in for real-world operations that are both long-running and blocking.

è¿™æ®µä»£ç ä½¿ç”¨ std::thread::sleep è€Œä¸æ˜¯ trpl::sleepï¼Œå› æ­¤è°ƒç”¨ slow å°†åœ¨å½“å‰çº¿ç¨‹ä¸Šé˜»å¡æŒ‡å®šçš„æ¯«ç§’æ•°ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ slow æ¥ä»£è¡¨ç°å®ä¸–ç•Œä¸­æ—¢é•¿æ—¶é—´è¿è¡Œåˆé˜»å¡çš„æ“ä½œã€‚

In Listing 17-23, we use slow to emulate doing this kind of CPU-bound work in a pair of futures.

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-23 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ slow æ¥æ¨¡æ‹Ÿåœ¨ä¸€å¯¹ Future ä¸­æ‰§è¡Œè¿™ç§ CPU å¯†é›†å‹å·¥ä½œã€‚

To begin, each future only hands control back to the runtime after carrying out a bunch of slow operations. If you run this code, you will see this output:

å¼€å§‹æ—¶ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª Future åªæœ‰åœ¨æ‰§è¡Œäº†ä¸€å †æ…¢æ“ä½œä¹‹åæ‰ä¼šå°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è¿è¡Œè¿™æ®µä»£ç ï¼Œä½ å°†çœ‹åˆ°è¿™æ ·çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼š

'a' started.
'a' ran for 30ms
'a' ran for 10ms
'a' ran for 20ms
'b' started.
'b' ran for 75ms
'b' ran for 10ms
'b' ran for 15ms
'b' ran for 350ms
'a' finished.

As with our earlier example, race still finishes as soon as a is done. Thereâ€™s no interleaving between the two futures, though. The a future does all of its work until the trpl::sleep call is awaited, then the b future does all of its work until its own trpl::sleep call is awaited, and finally the a future completes. To allow both futures to make progress between their slow tasks, we need await points so we can hand control back to the runtime. That means we need something we can await!

ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹‹å‰çš„ä¾‹å­ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œrace ä»ç„¶åœ¨ a å®Œæˆåç«‹å³ç»“æŸã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œä¸¤ä¸ª Future ä¹‹é—´æ²¡æœ‰äº¤é”™æ‰§è¡Œã€‚a Future å®Œæˆäº†å®ƒæ‰€æœ‰çš„å·¥ä½œï¼Œç›´åˆ° trpl::sleep è°ƒç”¨è¢«ç­‰å¾…ï¼Œç„¶å b Future å®Œæˆäº†å®ƒæ‰€æœ‰çš„å·¥ä½œï¼Œç›´åˆ°å®ƒè‡ªå·±çš„ trpl::sleep è°ƒç”¨è¢«ç­‰å¾…ï¼Œæœ€å a Future å®Œæˆã€‚ä¸ºäº†å…è®¸ä¸¤ä¸ª Future åœ¨å®ƒä»¬çš„æ…¢ä»»åŠ¡ä¹‹é—´äº¤æ›¿å–å¾—è¿›å±•ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ await ç‚¹ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä¸€äº›æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ await çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼

We can already see this kind of handoff happening in Listing 17-23: if we removed the trpl::sleep at the end of the a future, it would complete without the b future running at all. Letâ€™s try using the sleep function as a starting point for letting operations switch off making progress, as shown in Listing 17-24.

æˆ‘ä»¬å·²ç»åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-23 ä¸­çœ‹åˆ°äº†è¿™ç§æ§åˆ¶æƒç§»äº¤çš„å‘ç”Ÿï¼šå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬ç§»é™¤ a Future æœ«å°¾çš„ trpl::sleepï¼Œå®ƒå°†åœ¨ b Future æ ¹æœ¬æ²¡æœ‰è¿è¡Œçš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹å®Œæˆã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬å°è¯•ä½¿ç”¨ sleep å‡½æ•°ä½œä¸ºèµ·ç‚¹ï¼Œè®©æ“ä½œäº¤æ›¿å–å¾—è¿›å±•ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-24 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

In Listing 17-24, we add trpl::sleep calls with await points between each call to slow. Now the two futuresâ€™ work is interleaved:

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-24 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æ¯æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ slow ä¹‹é—´æ·»åŠ äº†å¸¦ await ç‚¹çš„ trpl::sleep è°ƒç”¨ã€‚ç°åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ª Future çš„å·¥ä½œæ˜¯äº¤é”™è¿›è¡Œçš„ï¼š

'a' started.
'a' ran for 30ms
'b' started.
'b' ran for 75ms
'a' ran for 10ms
'b' ran for 10ms
'a' ran for 20ms
'b' ran for 15ms
'a' finished.

The a future still runs for a bit before handing off control to b, because it calls slow before ever calling trpl::sleep, but after that the futures swap back and forth each time one of them hits an await point. In this case, we have done that after every call to slow, but we could break up the work in whatever way makes the most sense to us.

a Future åœ¨å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤ç»™ b ä¹‹å‰ä»ç„¶è¿è¡Œäº†ä¸€ä¼šå„¿ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒå…ˆè°ƒç”¨äº† slow ç„¶åæ‰è°ƒç”¨ trpl::sleepï¼Œä½†åœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹åï¼Œæ¯å½“å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ª Future é‡åˆ° await ç‚¹æ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬å°±ä¼šæ¥å›äº¤æ¢ã€‚åœ¨è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æ¯æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ slow ä¹‹åéƒ½è¿™æ ·åšäº†ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç”¨å¯¹æˆ‘ä»¬æœ€æœ‰æ„ä¹‰çš„æ–¹å¼æ¥æ‹†åˆ†å·¥ä½œã€‚

We donâ€™t really want to sleep here, though: we want to make progress as fast as we can. We just need to hand back control to the runtime. We can do that directly, using the yield_now function. In Listing 17-25, we replace all those sleep calls with yield_now.

ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯çœŸçš„æƒ³ä¼‘çœ ï¼ˆsleepï¼‰ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³å°½å¯èƒ½å¿«åœ°å–å¾—è¿›å±•ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¦[note]å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒäº¤è¿˜ç»™è¿è¡Œæ—¶ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨ yield_now å‡½æ•°æ¥å®ç°è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-25 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ yield_now æ›¿æ¢æ‰€æœ‰é‚£äº› sleep è°ƒç”¨ã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse tokio::task::yield_now;

This code is both clearer about the actual intent and can be significantly faster than using sleep, because timers such as the one used by sleep often have limits on how granular they can be. The version of sleep we are using, for example, will always sleep for at least a millisecond, even if we pass it a Duration of one nanosecond. Again, modern computers are fast: they can do a lot in one millisecond!

è¿™æ®µä»£ç åœ¨è¡¨è¾¾å®é™…æ„å›¾ä¸Šæ›´æ¸…æ™°ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”å¯èƒ½æ¯”ä½¿ç”¨ sleep å¿«å¾—å¤šï¼Œå› ä¸ºåƒ sleep ä½¿ç”¨çš„è®¡æ—¶å™¨é€šå¸¸æœ‰æœ€å°ç²’åº¦çš„é™åˆ¶ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œ[note]æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨çš„ sleep ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œå³ä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼ é€’ä¸€çº³ç§’çš„ Durationï¼Œä¹Ÿæ€»æ˜¯ä¼šè‡³å°‘ä¼‘çœ ä¸€æ¯«ç§’ã€‚å†è¯´ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œç°ä»£è®¡ç®—æœºéå¸¸å¿«ï¼šå®ƒä»¬åœ¨ä¸€æ¯«ç§’å†…å¯ä»¥åšå¾ˆå¤šäº‹æƒ…ï¼

You can see this for yourself by setting up a little benchmark, such as the one in Listing 17-26. (This isnâ€™t an especially rigorous way to do performance testing, but it suffices to show the difference here.)

ä½ å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è®¾ç½®ä¸€ä¸ªå°å‹åŸºå‡†æµ‹è¯•è‡ªå·±çœ‹åˆ°è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-26 ä¸­çš„æµ‹è¯•ã€‚ï¼ˆè¿™ä¸æ˜¯è¿›è¡Œæ€§èƒ½æµ‹è¯•çš„ç‰¹åˆ«ä¸¥è°¨çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä½†è¶³ä»¥æ˜¾ç¤ºæ­¤å¤„çš„å·®å¼‚ã€‚ï¼‰

Here, we skip all the status printing, pass a one-nanosecond Duration to trpl::sleep, and let each future run by itself, with no switching between the futures. Then we run for 1,000 iterations and see how long the future using trpl::sleep takes compared to the future using trpl::yield_now.

åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è·³è¿‡æ‰€æœ‰çŠ¶æ€æ‰“å°ï¼Œå°†ä¸€çº³ç§’çš„ Duration ä¼ é€’ç»™ trpl::sleepï¼Œå¹¶è®©æ¯ä¸ª Future è‡ªå·±è¿è¡Œï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ Future ä¹‹é—´çš„åˆ‡æ¢ã€‚ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬è¿è¡Œ 1000 æ¬¡è¿­ä»£ï¼Œçœ‹çœ‹ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::sleep çš„ Future ä¸ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::yield_now çš„ Future ç›¸æ¯”éœ€è¦å¤šé•¿æ—¶é—´ã€‚

The version with yield_now is way faster!

ä½¿ç”¨ yield_now çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬å¿«å¾—å¤šï¼

This means that async can be useful even for compute-bound tasks, depending on what else your program is doing, because it provides a useful tool for structuring the relationships between different parts of the program. This is a form of cooperative multitasking, where each future has the power to determine when it hands over control via await points. Each future therefore also has the responsibility to avoid blocking for too long. In some Rust-based embedded operating systems, this is the only kind of multitasking!

è¿™æ„å‘³ç€å¼‚æ­¥å¯¹äºè®¡ç®—å¯†é›†å‹ä»»åŠ¡ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æœ‰ç”¨ï¼Œè¿™å–å†³äºä½ çš„ç¨‹åºè¿˜åœ¨åšä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä¸ºæ„å»ºç¨‹åºä¸åŒéƒ¨åˆ†ä¹‹é—´çš„å…³ç³»æä¾›äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰ç”¨çš„å·¥å…·ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ç§åä½œå¼å¤šä»»åŠ¡å¤„ç†ï¼ˆcooperative multitaskingï¼‰ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æ¯ä¸ª Future éƒ½æœ‰æƒé€šè¿‡ await ç‚¹å†³å®šä½•æ—¶äº¤å‡ºæ§åˆ¶æƒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª Future ä¹Ÿæœ‰è´£ä»»é¿å…é˜»å¡å¤ªä¹…ã€‚åœ¨ä¸€äº›åŸºäº Rust çš„åµŒå…¥å¼æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¸­ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯å”¯ä¸€çš„å¤šä»»åŠ¡å¤„ç†æ–¹å¼ï¼

In real-world code, you wonâ€™t usually be alternating function calls with await points on every single line, of course. While yielding control in this way is relatively inexpensive, itâ€™s not free. In many cases, trying to break up a compute-bound task might make it significantly slower, so sometimes itâ€™s better for overall performance to let an operation block briefly. Always measure to see what your codeâ€™s actual performance bottlenecks are. The underlying dynamic is important to keep in mind, though, if you are seeing a lot of work happening in serial that you expected to happen concurrently!

åœ¨çœŸå®ä¸–ç•Œçš„ä»£ç ä¸­ï¼Œä½ é€šå¸¸ä¸ä¼šåœ¨æ¯ä¸€è¡Œéƒ½äº¤æ›¿è¿›è¡Œå‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨å’Œ await ç‚¹ã€‚è™½ç„¶ä»¥è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼è®©å‡ºæ§åˆ¶æƒç›¸å¯¹ä¾¿å®œï¼Œä½†å®ƒå¹¶éå…è´¹ã€‚[note]åœ¨è®¸å¤šæƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå°è¯•æ‹†åˆ†ä¸€ä¸ªè®¡ç®—å¯†é›†å‹ä»»åŠ¡å¯èƒ½ä¼šä½¿å…¶æ˜¾è‘—å˜æ…¢ï¼Œå› æ­¤æœ‰æ—¶ä¸ºäº†æ•´ä½“æ€§èƒ½ï¼Œè®©ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œçŸ­æš‚é˜»å¡ä¼šæ›´å¥½ã€‚å§‹ç»ˆæµ‹é‡ä»¥æŸ¥çœ‹ä»£ç çš„å®é™…æ€§èƒ½ç“¶é¢ˆæ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ ç¡®å®çœ‹åˆ°å¤§é‡ä½ æœŸæœ›å¹¶å‘å‘ç”Ÿçš„å·¥ä½œåœ¨ä¸²è¡Œè¿›è¡Œï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆäº†è§£åº•å±‚çš„åŠ¨æ€ç‰¹æ€§éå¸¸é‡è¦ï¼

Building Our Own Async Abstractions æ„å»ºæˆ‘ä»¬è‡ªå·±çš„å¼‚æ­¥æŠ½è±¡

We can also compose futures together to create new patterns. For example, we can build a timeout function with async building blocks we already have. When weâ€™re done, the result will be another building block we could use to create still more async abstractions.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥å°† Future ç»„åˆåœ¨ä¸€èµ·åˆ›å»ºæ–°çš„æ¨¡å¼ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨å·²æœ‰çš„å¼‚æ­¥æ„å»ºå—æ¥æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ª timeout å‡½æ•°ã€‚å®Œæˆåï¼Œç»“æœå°†æ˜¯å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ„å»ºå—ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç”¨å®ƒæ¥åˆ›å»ºæ›´å¤šçš„å¼‚æ­¥æŠ½è±¡ã€‚

Listing 17-27 shows how we would expect this timeout to work with a slow future.

ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-27 å±•ç¤ºäº†æˆ‘ä»¬æœŸæœ›è¿™ä¸ª timeout å¦‚ä½•ä¸ä¸€ä¸ªæ…¢ Future ä¸€èµ·å·¥ä½œã€‚

Letâ€™s implement this! To begin, letâ€™s think about the API for timeout:

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ¥å®ç°å®ƒï¼é¦–å…ˆï¼Œè®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ€è€ƒä¸€ä¸‹ timeout çš„ APIï¼š

  • It needs to be an async function itself so we can await it.

  • Its first parameter should be a future to run. We can make it generic to allow it to work with any future.

  • Its second parameter will be the maximum time to wait. If we use a Duration, that will make it easy to pass along to trpl::sleep.

  • It should return a Result. If the future completes successfully, the Result will be Ok with the value produced by the future. If the timeout elapses first, the Result will be Err with the duration that the timeout waited for.

  • å®ƒæœ¬èº«éœ€è¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ await å®ƒã€‚

  • å®ƒçš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°åº”è¯¥æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¦è¿è¡Œçš„ Futureã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†å…¶è®¾ä¸ºæ³›å‹ï¼Œä»¥å…è®¸å®ƒä¸ä»»ä½• Future ä¸€èµ·å·¥ä½œã€‚

  • å®ƒçš„ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå‚æ•°å°†æ˜¯æœ€å¤§ç­‰å¾…æ—¶é—´ã€‚å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ Durationï¼Œè¿™å°†ä½¿å…¶æ˜“äºä¼ é€’ç»™ trpl::sleepã€‚

  • å®ƒåº”è¯¥è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ª Resultã€‚å¦‚æœ Future æˆåŠŸå®Œæˆï¼ŒResult å°†æ˜¯ Okï¼Œå…¶å€¼æ˜¯è¯¥ Future äº§ç”Ÿçš„å€¼ã€‚å¦‚æœè¶…æ—¶é¦–å…ˆå‘ç”Ÿï¼ŒResult å°†æ˜¯ Errï¼Œå…¶å€¼æ˜¯è¶…æ—¶ç­‰å¾…çš„æ—¶é•¿ã€‚

Listing 17-28 shows this declaration.

ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-28 æ˜¾ç¤ºäº†è¿™ä¸ªå£°æ˜ã€‚

That satisfies our goals for the types. Now letâ€™s think about the behavior we need: we want to race the future passed in against the duration. We can use trpl::sleep to make a timer future from the duration, and use trpl::race to run that timer with the future the caller passes in.

è¿™æ»¡è¶³äº†æˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹ç±»å‹çš„ç›®æ ‡ã€‚ç°åœ¨è®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ€è€ƒæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›å°†ä¼ å…¥çš„ Future ä¸ç»™å®šçš„æ—¶é•¿è¿›è¡Œç«é€Ÿï¼ˆraceï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::sleep ä»è¯¥æ—¶é•¿åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªè®¡æ—¶å™¨ Futureï¼Œå¹¶ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::race æ¥è¿è¡Œè¿™ä¸ªè®¡æ—¶å™¨å’Œè°ƒç”¨è€…ä¼ é€’çš„ Futureã€‚

We also know that race is not fair, polling arguments in the order in which they are passed. Thus, we pass future_to_try to race first so it gets a chance to complete even if max_time is a very short duration. If future_to_try finishes first, race will return Left with the output from future_to_try. If timer finishes first, race will return Right with the timerâ€™s output of ().

æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜çŸ¥é“ race æ˜¯ä¸å…¬å¹³çš„ï¼ŒæŒ‰ç…§å‚æ•°ä¼ é€’çš„é¡ºåºè½®è¯¢å®ƒä»¬ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é¦–å…ˆå°† future_to_try ä¼ é€’ç»™ raceï¼Œè¿™æ ·å³ä½¿ max_time éå¸¸çŸ­ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿæœ‰æœºä¼šå®Œæˆã€‚å¦‚æœ future_to_try å…ˆå®Œæˆï¼Œrace å°†è¿”å› Leftï¼Œå…¶å€¼æ˜¯ future_to_try çš„è¾“å‡ºã€‚å¦‚æœ timer å…ˆå®Œæˆï¼Œrace å°†è¿”å› Rightï¼Œå…¶å€¼æ˜¯è®¡æ—¶å™¨çš„è¾“å‡º ()ã€‚

In Listing 17-29, we match on the result of awaiting trpl::race.

åœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-29 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åŒ¹é…ç­‰å¾… trpl::race çš„ç»“æœã€‚

If the future_to_try succeeds and we get a Left(output), we return Ok(output). If the sleep timer elapses instead and we get a Right(()), we ignore the () with _ and return Err(max_time) instead.

å¦‚æœ future_to_try æˆåŠŸå¹¶ä¸”æˆ‘ä»¬å¾—åˆ° Left(output)ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±è¿”å› Ok(output)ã€‚å¦‚æœç¡çœ è®¡æ—¶å™¨å…ˆç»“æŸè€Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¾—åˆ° Right(())ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ _ å¿½ç•¥ ()ï¼Œç„¶åè¿”å› Err(max_time)ã€‚

With that, we have a working timeout built out of two other async helpers. If we run our code, it will print the failure mode after the timeout:

å°±è¿™æ ·ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰äº†ä¸€ä¸ªç”±å¦å¤–ä¸¤ä¸ªå¼‚æ­¥è¾…åŠ©å‡½æ•°æ„å»ºçš„å·¥ä½œä¸­çš„ timeoutã€‚å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬è¿è¡Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œå®ƒå°†åœ¨è¶…æ—¶åæ‰“å°å¤±è´¥æ¨¡å¼ï¼š

Failed after 2 seconds

Because futures compose with other futures, you can build really powerful tools using smaller async building blocks. For example, you can use this same approach to combine timeouts with retries, and in turn use those with operations such as network calls (one of the examples from the beginning of the chapter).

å› ä¸º Future å¯ä»¥ä¸å…¶ä»– Future ç»„åˆï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨è¾ƒå°çš„å¼‚æ­¥æ„å»ºå—æ„å»ºéå¸¸å¼ºå¤§çš„å·¥å…·ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„æ–¹æ³•å°†è¶…æ—¶ä¸é‡è¯•ç»“åˆèµ·æ¥ï¼Œåè¿‡æ¥åˆå¯ä»¥å°†è¿™äº›ç”¨äºç½‘ç»œè°ƒç”¨ç­‰æ“ä½œï¼ˆæœ¬ç« å¼€å¤´æåˆ°çš„ä¾‹å­ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼‰ã€‚

In practice, youâ€™ll usually work directly with async and await, and secondarily with functions and macros such as join, join_all, race, and so on. Youâ€™ll only need to reach for pin now and again to use futures with those APIs.

åœ¨å®è·µä¸­ï¼Œä½ é€šå¸¸ä¼šç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨ async å’Œ awaitï¼Œå…¶æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨åƒ joinã€join_allã€race ç­‰å‡½æ•°å’Œå®ã€‚ä½ åªéœ€è¦å¶å°”ä½¿ç”¨ pin æ¥é…åˆè¿™äº› API ä½¿ç”¨ Futureã€‚

Weâ€™ve now seen a number of ways to work with multiple futures at the same time. Up next, weâ€™ll look at how we can work with multiple futures in a sequence over time with streams. Here are a couple more things you might want to consider first, though:

æˆ‘ä»¬ç°åœ¨å·²ç»çœ‹åˆ°äº†å¤šç§åŒæ—¶å¤„ç†å¤šä¸ª Future çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†çœ‹çœ‹å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨æµï¼ˆstreamsï¼‰æŒ‰æ—¶é—´é¡ºåºå¤„ç†å¤šä¸ª Futureã€‚ä¸è¿‡ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œè¿˜æœ‰å‡ ä»¶äº‹ä½ å¯èƒ½æƒ³å…ˆè€ƒè™‘ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼š

  • We used a Vec with join_all to wait for all of the futures in some group to finish. How could you use a Vec to process a group of futures in sequence instead? What are the tradeoffs of doing that?
  • æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨å¸¦æœ‰ join_all çš„ Vec æ¥ç­‰å¾…æŸä¸ªç»„ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰ Future å®Œæˆã€‚ä½ å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ Vec æ¥æŒ‰é¡ºåºå¤„ç†ä¸€ç»„ Futureï¼Ÿè¿™æ ·åšçš„æƒè¡¡æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ
  • Take a look at the futures::stream::FuturesUnordered type from the futures crate. How would using it be different from using a Vec? (Donâ€™t worry about the fact that itâ€™s from the stream part of the crate; it works just fine with any collection of futures.)
  • çœ‹çœ‹ futures crate ä¸­çš„ futures::stream::FuturesUnordered ç±»å‹ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨å®ƒä¸ä½¿ç”¨ Vec æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆä¸åŒï¼Ÿï¼ˆä¸ç”¨æ‹…å¿ƒå®ƒæ¥è‡ª crate çš„ stream éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼›å®ƒä¸ä»»ä½• Future é›†åˆä¸€èµ·å·¥ä½œå¾—å¾ˆå¥½ã€‚ï¼‰

Streams: Futures in Sequence æµï¼šæŒ‰é¡ºåºå¤„ç†çš„ Future

So far in this chapter, weâ€™ve mostly stuck to individual futures. The one big exception was the async channel we used. Recall how we used the receiver for our async channel earlier in this chapter in the â€œMessage Passingâ€ section. The async recv method produces a sequence of items over time. This is an instance of a much more general pattern known as a stream.

æœ¬ç« åˆ°ç›®å‰ä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸»è¦ä¸“æ³¨äºå•ä¸ª Futureã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªé‡è¦çš„ä¾‹å¤–æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨è¿‡çš„å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“ã€‚å›é¡¾æœ¬ç« åœ¨â€œæ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’â€œéƒ¨åˆ†ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“æ¥æ”¶å™¨çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼šå¼‚æ­¥ recv æ–¹æ³•ä¼šéšæ—¶é—´äº§ç”Ÿä¸€ç³»åˆ—é¡¹ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯æ›´é€šç”¨æ¨¡å¼â€”â€”æµï¼ˆstreamï¼‰â€”â€”çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå®ä¾‹ã€‚

We saw a sequence of items back in Chapter 13, when we looked at the Iterator trait in The Iterator Trait and the next Method section, but there are two differences between iterators and the async channel receiver. The first difference is time: iterators are synchronous, while the channel receiver is asynchronous. The second is the API. When working directly with Iterator, we call its synchronous next method. With the trpl::Receiver stream in particular, we called an asynchronous recv method instead. Otherwise, these APIs feel very similar, and that similarity isnâ€™t a coincidence. A stream is like an asynchronous form of iteration. Whereas the trpl::Receiver specifically waits to receive messages, though, the general-purpose stream API is much broader: it provides the next item the way Iterator does, but asynchronously.

æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬13ç« è®¨è®ºIteratorç‰¹æ€§æ—¶å°±è§è¿‡é¡¹çš„åºåˆ—ï¼Œä½†è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“æ¥æ”¶å™¨æœ‰ä¸¤ç‚¹åŒºåˆ«ã€‚ç¬¬ä¸€ç‚¹æ˜¯æ—¶é—´æ€§ï¼šè¿­ä»£å™¨æ˜¯åŒæ­¥çš„ï¼Œè€Œé€šé“æ¥æ”¶å™¨æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥çš„ã€‚ç¬¬äºŒç‚¹æ˜¯ APIï¼šç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨ Iterator æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è°ƒç”¨å…¶åŒæ­¥çš„ next æ–¹æ³•ï¼›è€Œå¯¹äº trpl::Receiver æµï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è°ƒç”¨çš„æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥çš„ recv æ–¹æ³•ã€‚é™¤æ­¤ä¹‹å¤–ï¼Œè¿™äº› API éå¸¸ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œè¿™ç§ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§å¹¶éå¶ç„¶ã€‚æµå°±åƒæ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„è¿­ä»£ã€‚è™½ç„¶ trpl::Receiver ä¸“é—¨ç”¨äºç­‰å¾…æ¥æ”¶æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œä½†é€šç”¨æµ API æ›´ä¸ºå¹¿æ³›ï¼šå®ƒåƒ Iterator ä¸€æ ·æä¾›ä¸‹ä¸€é¡¹ï¼Œä½†é‡‡ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥æ–¹å¼ã€‚

The similarity between iterators and streams in Rust means we can actually create a stream from any iterator. As with an iterator, we can work with a stream by calling its next method and then awaiting the output, as in Listing 17-30.
