Rust ä¸­è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸æµçš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§æ„å‘³ç€æˆ‘ä»¬å®é™…ä¸Šå¯ä»¥ä»ä»»ä½•è¿­ä»£å™¨åˆ›å»ºæµã€‚å¦‚è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨æµçš„ next æ–¹æ³•å¹¶ç­‰å¾…å…¶è¾“å‡ºæ¥å¤„ç†æµï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-30 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse tokio_stream::iter;

We start with an array of numbers, which we convert to an iterator and then call map on to double all the values. Then we convert the iterator into a stream using the trpl::stream_from_iter function. Next, we loop over the items in the stream as they arrive with the while let loop.

æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—æ•°ç»„å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå°†å…¶è½¬æ¢ä¸ºè¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼Œç„¶åè°ƒç”¨ map å°†æ‰€æœ‰å€¼åŠ å€ã€‚æ¥ç€ä½¿ç”¨ trpl::stream_from_iter å‡½æ•°å°†è¿­ä»£å™¨è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæµã€‚ç„¶åä½¿ç”¨ while let å¾ªç¯éå†æµä¸­åˆ°è¾¾çš„é¡¹ã€‚

Unfortunately, when we try to run the code, it doesnâ€™t compile, but instead it reports that thereâ€™s no next method available:

é—æ†¾çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œå°è¯•è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç æ—¶æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æŠ¥å‘Šæ‰¾ä¸åˆ° next æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

error[E0599]: no method named `next` found for struct `Iter` in the current scope
  --> src/main.rs:10:40
   |
10 |         while let Some(value) = stream.next().await {
   |                                        ^^^^
   |
   = note: the full type name has been written to 'file:///projects/async-await/target/debug/deps/async_await-575db3dd3197d257.long-type-14490787947592691573.txt'
   = note: consider using `--verbose` to print the full type name to the console
   = help: items from traits can only be used if the trait is in scope
help: the following traits which provide `next` are implemented but not in scope; perhaps you want to import one of them
   |
1  + use crate::trpl::StreamExt;
   |
1  + use futures_util::stream::stream::StreamExt;
   |
1  + use std::iter::Iterator;
   |
1  + use std::str::pattern::Searcher;
   |
help: there is a method `try_next` with a similar name
   |
10 |         while let Some(value) = stream.try_next().await {
   |                                        ~~~~~~~~

As this output explains, the reason for the compiler error is that we need the right trait in scope to be able to use the next method. Given our discussion so far, you might reasonably expect that trait to be Stream, but itâ€™s actually StreamExt. Short for extension, Ext is a common pattern in the Rust community for extending one trait with another.

å¦‚è¾“å‡ºæ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨æŠ¥é”™çš„åŸå› æ˜¯éœ€è¦å°†æ­£ç¡®çš„ç‰¹æ€§å¼•å…¥ä½œç”¨åŸŸæ‰èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ next æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æ ¹æ®ç›®å‰çš„è®¨è®ºï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½åˆç†é¢„æœŸè¯¥ç‰¹æ€§æ˜¯ Streamï¼Œä½†å®é™…ä¸Šæ˜¯ StreamExtã€‚Ext æ˜¯â€œæ‰©å±•â€œï¼ˆextensionï¼‰çš„ç¼©å†™ï¼Œåœ¨ Rust ç¤¾åŒºä¸­æ˜¯æ‰©å±•ç‰¹æ€§çš„å¸¸è§æ¨¡å¼ã€‚

Weâ€™ll explain the Stream and StreamExt traits in a bit more detail at the end of the chapter, but for now all you need to know is that the Stream trait defines a low-level interface that effectively combines the Iterator and Future traits. StreamExt supplies a higher-level set of APIs on top of Stream, including the next method as well as other utility methods similar to those provided by the Iterator trait. Stream and StreamExt are not yet part of Rustâ€™s standard library, but most ecosystem crates use the same definition.

æœ¬ç« æœ«å°¾ä¼šæ›´è¯¦ç»†è§£é‡Š Stream å’Œ StreamExt ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥é“ï¼š[note]Stream ç‰¹æ€§å®šä¹‰äº†ä¸€ä¸ªåº•å±‚æ¥å£ï¼Œæœ‰æ•ˆç»“åˆäº† Iterator å’Œ Future ç‰¹æ€§ï¼›StreamExt åœ¨ Stream ä¹‹ä¸Šæä¾›äº†ä¸€å¥—é«˜çº§ APIï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬ next æ–¹æ³•ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–ç±»ä¼¼ Iterator ç‰¹æ€§çš„å®ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ã€‚Stream å’Œ StreamExt å°šæœªæˆä¸º Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œä½†å¤§å¤šæ•°ç”Ÿæ€åº“ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„å®šä¹‰ã€‚

The fix to the compiler error is to add a use statement for trpl::StreamExt, as in Listing 17-31.

ä¿®å¤ç¼–è¯‘é”™è¯¯çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯æ·»åŠ  use trpl::StreamExt; è¯­å¥ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-31 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼šuse tokio_stream::StreamExt;

With all those pieces put together, this code works the way we want! Whatâ€™s more, now that we have StreamExt in scope, we can use all of its utility methods, just as with iterators. For example, in Listing 17-32, we use the filter method to filter out everything but multiples of three and five.

æ‰€æœ‰éƒ¨åˆ†ç»„åˆåï¼Œä»£ç æŒ‰é¢„æœŸå·¥ä½œï¼æ›´é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œç°åœ¨ StreamExt åœ¨ä½œç”¨åŸŸä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨å…¶æ‰€æœ‰å®ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå°±åƒä½¿ç”¨è¿­ä»£å™¨ä¸€æ ·ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-32 ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨ filter æ–¹æ³•è¿‡æ»¤æ‰é 3 æˆ– 5 çš„å€æ•°ã€‚

Of course, this isnâ€™t very interesting, since we could do the same with normal iterators and without any async at all. Letâ€™s look at what we can do that is unique to streams.

å½“ç„¶ï¼Œè¿™å¹¶ä¸æœ‰è¶£ï¼Œå› ä¸ºç”¨æ™®é€šè¿­ä»£å™¨æ— éœ€å¼‚æ­¥ä¹Ÿèƒ½å®ç°ã€‚ç°åœ¨æ¥çœ‹æµç‹¬æœ‰çš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Composing Streams ç»„åˆæµ

Many concepts are naturally represented as streams: items becoming available in a queue, chunks of data being pulled incrementally from the filesystem when the full data set is too large for the computerâ€™s memory, or data arriving over the network over time. Because streams are futures, we can use them with any other kind of future and combine them in interesting ways. For example, we can batch up events to avoid triggering too many network calls, set timeouts on sequences of long-running operations, or throttle user interface events to avoid doing needless work.

è®¸å¤šæ¦‚å¿µå¤©ç„¶é€‚åˆç”¨æµè¡¨ç¤ºï¼šé˜Ÿåˆ—ä¸­å¯ç”¨çš„é¡¹ã€å½“æ•°æ®é›†è¿‡å¤§æ— æ³•è½½å…¥å†…å­˜æ—¶ä»æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿåˆ†å—å¢é‡æ‹‰å–çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œæˆ–éšæ—¶é—´åˆ°è¾¾çš„ç½‘ç»œæ•°æ®ã€‚ç”±äºæµå°±æ˜¯ Futureï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†å®ƒä»¬ä¸å…¶ä»– Future ç»“åˆä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œå®ç°æœ‰è¶£ç»„åˆã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼šæ‰¹é‡å¤„ç†äº‹ä»¶ä»¥å‡å°‘ç½‘ç»œè°ƒç”¨ã€ä¸ºé•¿æ“ä½œåºåˆ—è®¾ç½®è¶…æ—¶ã€æˆ–èŠ‚æµç”¨æˆ·ç•Œé¢äº‹ä»¶ä»¥é¿å…å†—ä½™å·¥ä½œã€‚

Letâ€™s start by building a little stream of messages as a stand-in for a stream of data we might see from a WebSocket or another real-time communication protocol, as shown in Listing 17-33.

é¦–å…ˆæ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ¶ˆæ¯æµä½œä¸º WebSocket æˆ–å…¶ä»–å®æ—¶é€šä¿¡åè®®çš„æ›¿èº«ï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-33 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

[note]æ³¨ï¼štokio_stream::wrappers::UnboundedReceiverStream

First, we create a function called get_messages that returns impl Stream<Item = String>. For its implementation, we create an async channel, loop over the first 10 letters of the English alphabet, and send them across the channel.

é¦–å…ˆåˆ›å»ºè¿”å› impl Stream<Item = String> çš„å‡½æ•° get_messagesã€‚åœ¨å®ç°ä¸­ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå¼‚æ­¥é€šé“ï¼Œéå†è‹±æ–‡å­—æ¯è¡¨å‰ 10 ä¸ªå­—æ¯å¹¶é€šè¿‡é€šé“å‘é€ã€‚

We also use a new type: ReceiverStream, which converts the rx receiver from the trpl::channel into a Stream with a next method. Back in main, we use a while let loop to print all the messages from the stream.

è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨äº†[note]æ–°ç±»å‹ ReceiverStreamï¼Œå®ƒå°† trpl::channel çš„ rx æ¥æ”¶å™¨è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå¸¦ next æ–¹æ³•çš„ Streamã€‚åœ¨ main ä¸­ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ while let å¾ªç¯æ‰“å°æµä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

When we run this code, we get exactly the results we would expect:

è¿è¡Œä»£ç å°†å¾—åˆ°é¢„æœŸç»“æœï¼š

Message: 'a'
Message: 'b'
Message: 'c'
Message: 'd'
Message: 'e'
Message: 'f'
Message: 'g'
Message: 'h'
Message: 'i'
Message: 'j'

Again, we could do this with the regular Receiver API or even the regular Iterator API, though, so letâ€™s add a feature that requires streams: adding a timeout that applies to every item in the stream, and a delay on the items we emit, as shown in Listing 17-34.

è™½ç„¶å¸¸è§„ Receiver API æˆ– Iterator API ä¹Ÿèƒ½å®ç°æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œç°åœ¨æ·»åŠ æµç‹¬æœ‰çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼šä¸ºæµä¸­æ¯ä¸ªé¡¹æ·»åŠ è¶…æ—¶å’Œå»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-34 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

We start by adding a timeout to the stream with the timeout method, which comes from the StreamExt trait. Then we update the body of the while let loop, because the stream now returns a Result. The Ok variant indicates a message arrived in time; the Err variant indicates that the timeout elapsed before any message arrived. We match on that result and either print the message when we receive it successfully or print a notice about the timeout. Finally, notice that we pin the messages after applying the timeout to them, because the timeout helper produces a stream that needs to be pinned to be polled.

é¦–å…ˆ[note]ä½¿ç”¨ StreamExt çš„ timeout æ–¹æ³•ä¸ºæµæ·»åŠ è¶…æ—¶ã€‚æ¥ç€æ›´æ–° while let å¾ªç¯ä½“ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæµç°åœ¨è¿”å› Resultï¼šOk å˜ä½“è¡¨ç¤ºæ¶ˆæ¯åŠæ—¶åˆ°è¾¾ï¼›Err å˜ä½“è¡¨ç¤ºè¶…æ—¶åæ— æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ°è¾¾ã€‚é€šè¿‡ match å¤„ç†ç»“æœï¼šæˆåŠŸæ¥æ”¶æ—¶æ‰“å°æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œè¶…æ—¶åˆ™æ‰“å°é€šçŸ¥ã€‚æœ€åæ³¨æ„ï¼š[note]åº”ç”¨è¶…æ—¶åéœ€å›ºå®šï¼ˆpinï¼‰æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¶…æ—¶è¾…åŠ©å™¨ç”Ÿæˆçš„æµéœ€è¦å›ºå®šæ‰èƒ½è½®è¯¢ï¼ˆpollï¼‰ã€‚

However, because there are no delays between messages, this timeout does not change the behavior of the program. Letâ€™s add a variable delay to the messages we send, as shown in Listing 17-35.

ä½†ç”±äºæ¶ˆæ¯é—´æ— å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œè¶…æ—¶ä¸ä¼šæ”¹å˜ç¨‹åºè¡Œä¸ºã€‚ç°åœ¨ä¸ºå‘é€çš„æ¶ˆæ¯æ·»åŠ å¯å˜å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-35 æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

In get_messages, we use the enumerate iterator method with the messages array so that we can get the index of each item weâ€™re sending along with the item itself. Then we apply a 100-millisecond delay to even-index items and a 300-millisecond delay to odd-index items to simulate the different delays we might see from a stream of messages in the real world. Because our timeout is for 200 milliseconds, this should affect half of the messages.

åœ¨ get_messages ä¸­ï¼Œå¯¹ messages æ•°ç»„ä½¿ç”¨ enumerate è¿­ä»£å™¨æ–¹æ³•ä»¥è·å–ç´¢å¼•ã€‚ç„¶åä¸ºå¶æ•°ç´¢å¼•é¡¹æ·»åŠ  100 æ¯«ç§’å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œä¸ºå¥‡æ•°ç´¢å¼•é¡¹æ·»åŠ  300 æ¯«ç§’å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Œæ¨¡æ‹ŸçœŸå®æ¶ˆæ¯æµçš„å·®å¼‚å»¶è¿Ÿã€‚ç”±äºè¶…æ—¶ä¸º 200 æ¯«ç§’ï¼Œè¿™å°†å½±å“åŠæ•°æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚

To sleep between messages in the get_messages function without blocking, we need to use async. However, we canâ€™t make get_messages itself into an async function, because then weâ€™d return a Future<Output = Stream<Item = String>> instead of a Stream<Item = String>>. The caller would have to await get_messages itself to get access to the stream. But remember: everything in a given future happens linearly; concurrency happens between futures. Awaiting get_messages would require it to send all the messages, including the sleep delay between each message, before returning the receiver stream. As a result, the timeout would be useless. There would be no delays in the stream itself; they would all happen before the stream was even available.

è¦åœ¨ get_messages ä¸­éé˜»å¡åœ°ç¡çœ ï¼Œéœ€ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥ã€‚ä½†ä¸èƒ½å°† get_messages æ”¹ä¸ºå¼‚æ­¥å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¦åˆ™å°†è¿”å› Future<Output = Stream<Item = String>> è€Œé Stream<Item = String>ã€‚è°ƒç”¨æ–¹éœ€å…ˆç­‰å¾… get_messages æ‰èƒ½è·å–æµã€‚æ³¨æ„ï¼šç»™å®š Future ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ“ä½œæ˜¯çº¿æ€§çš„ï¼›å¹¶å‘å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨ Future ä¹‹é—´ã€‚ç­‰å¾… get_messages ä¼šè¦æ±‚å…¶åœ¨è¿”å›æ¥æ”¶å™¨æµå‰å‘é€æ‰€æœ‰æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼ˆå«å»¶è¿Ÿï¼‰ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´è¶…æ—¶å¤±æ•ˆï¼ˆæµä¸­æ— å»¶è¿Ÿï¼‰ã€‚

Instead, we leave get_messages as a regular function that returns a stream, and we spawn a task to handle the async sleep calls.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œä¿æŒ get_messages ä¸ºè¿”å›æµçš„å¸¸è§„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¹¶ç”Ÿæˆä»»åŠ¡å¤„ç†å¼‚æ­¥ sleep è°ƒç”¨ã€‚

Note: Calling spawn_task in this way works because we already set up our runtime; had we not, it would cause a panic. Other implementations choose different tradeoffs: they might spawn a new runtime and avoid the panic but end up with a bit of extra overhead, or they may simply not provide a standalone way to spawn tasks without reference to a runtime. Make sure you know what tradeoff your runtime has chosen and write your code accordingly!

æ³¨æ„ï¼šæ­¤æ–¹å¼è°ƒç”¨ spawn_task æœ‰æ•ˆæ˜¯å› ä¸ºå·²è®¾ç½®è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼›å¦åˆ™ä¼š panicã€‚å…¶ä»–å®ç°å¯èƒ½é€‰æ‹©ä¸åŒæƒè¡¡ï¼šç”Ÿæˆæ–°è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆé¿å… panic ä½†å¢åŠ å¼€é”€ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ–ä¸æä¾›ç‹¬ç«‹äºè¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„ä»»åŠ¡ç”Ÿæˆæ–¹å¼ã€‚è¯·æ ¹æ®æ‰€ç”¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„è®¾è®¡ç¼–å†™ä»£ç ï¼

Now our code has a much more interesting result. Between every other pair of messages, a Problem: Elapsed(()) error.

ç°åœ¨ç¨‹åºç»“æœæ›´æœ‰è¶£ï¼šåœ¨æ¯å¯¹æ¶ˆæ¯ä¹‹é—´ä¼šå‡ºç° Problem: Elapsed(()) é”™è¯¯ã€‚

Message: 'a'
Problem: Elapsed(())
Message: 'b'
Message: 'c'
Problem: Elapsed(())
Message: 'd'
Message: 'e'
Problem: Elapsed(())
Message: 'f'
Message: 'g'
Problem: Elapsed(())
Message: 'h'
Message: 'i'
Problem: Elapsed(())
Message: 'j'

The timeout doesnâ€™t prevent the messages from arriving in the end. We still get all of the original messages, because our channel is unbounded: it can hold as many messages as we can fit in memory. If the message doesnâ€™t arrive before the timeout, our stream handler will account for that, but when it polls the stream again, the message may now have arrived.

è¶…æ—¶ä¸ä¼šé˜»æ­¢æ¶ˆæ¯æœ€ç»ˆåˆ°è¾¾ã€‚ç”±äºé€šé“æ˜¯æ— ç•Œçš„ï¼ˆå¯å®¹çº³ä»»æ„å¤šæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åŸå§‹æ¶ˆæ¯ä»ä¼šåˆ°è¾¾ã€‚è‹¥æ¶ˆæ¯åœ¨è¶…æ—¶å‰æœªåˆ°è¾¾ï¼Œæµå¤„ç†å™¨ä¼šå¤„ç†è¯¥æƒ…å†µï¼Œä½†å†æ¬¡è½®è¯¢æµæ—¶æ¶ˆæ¯å¯èƒ½å·²åˆ°è¾¾ã€‚

You can get different behavior if needed by using other kinds of channels or other kinds of streams more generally. Letâ€™s see one of those in practice by combining a stream of time intervals with this stream of messages.

é€šè¿‡ä½¿ç”¨å…¶ä»–é€šé“æˆ–æµç±»å‹ï¼Œå¯è·å¾—ä¸åŒè¡Œä¸ºã€‚ç°åœ¨é€šè¿‡å°†æ—¶é—´é—´éš”æµä¸æ¶ˆæ¯æµç»“åˆæ¥å®è·µè¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚

Merging Streams åˆå¹¶æµ

First, letâ€™s create another stream, which will emit an item every millisecond if we let it run directly. For simplicity, we can use the sleep function to send a message on a delay and combine it with the same approach we used in get_messages of creating a stream from a channel. The difference is that this time, weâ€™re going to send back the count of intervals that have elapsed, so the return type will be impl Stream<Item = u32>, and we can call the function get_intervals (see Listing 17-36).

é¦–å…ˆåˆ›å»ºå¦ä¸€ä¸ªæµï¼šè‹¥ç›´æ¥è¿è¡Œï¼Œè¯¥æµæ¯æ¯«ç§’å‘å°„ä¸€ä¸ªé¡¹ã€‚ç®€åŒ–ä¸ºï¼šä½¿ç”¨ sleep å‡½æ•°åœ¨å»¶è¿Ÿåå‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå¹¶é‡‡ç”¨ä¸ get_messages ç›¸åŒçš„é€šé“æµæ–¹æ³•ã€‚åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºï¼šæ­¤æ¬¡å‘é€å·²è¿‡å»çš„æ—¶é—´é—´éš”è®¡æ•°ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿”å›ç±»å‹ä¸º impl Stream<Item = u32>ï¼Œå‡½æ•°å‘½åä¸º get_intervalsï¼ˆè§ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-36ï¼‰ã€‚

We start by defining a count in the task. (We could define it outside the task, too, but itâ€™s clearer to limit the scope of any given variable.) Then we create an infinite loop. Each iteration of the loop asynchronously sleeps for one millisecond, increments the count, and then sends it over the channel. Because this is all wrapped in the task created by spawn_task, all of itâ€”including the infinite loopâ€”will get cleaned up along with the runtime.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ä»»åŠ¡ä¸­å®šä¹‰ countï¼ˆä¹Ÿå¯å®šä¹‰åœ¨ä»»åŠ¡å¤–ï¼Œä½†é™å®šå˜é‡ä½œç”¨åŸŸæ›´æ¸…æ™°ï¼‰ã€‚ç„¶ååˆ›å»ºæ— é™å¾ªç¯ï¼šæ¯æ¬¡è¿­ä»£å¼‚æ­¥ç¡çœ  1 æ¯«ç§’ï¼Œå¢åŠ è®¡æ•°å¹¶é€šè¿‡é€šé“å‘é€ã€‚ç”±äºæ‰€æœ‰æ“ä½œå°è£…åœ¨ spawn_task ç”Ÿæˆçš„ä»»åŠ¡ä¸­ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬æ— é™å¾ªç¯åœ¨å†…çš„å†…å®¹éƒ½ä¼šéšè¿è¡Œæ—¶æ¸…ç†ã€‚

This kind of infinite loop, which ends only when the whole runtime gets torn down, is fairly common in async Rust: many programs need to keep running indefinitely. With async, this doesnâ€™t block anything else, as long as there is at least one await point in each iteration through the loop.

æ­¤ç±»æ— é™å¾ªç¯ï¼ˆä»…åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªè¿è¡Œæ—¶å…³é—­æ—¶ç»“æŸï¼‰åœ¨å¼‚æ­¥ Rust ä¸­å¾ˆå¸¸è§ï¼šè®¸å¤šç¨‹åºéœ€æ°¸ä¹…è¿è¡Œã€‚åªè¦æœ‰ await ç‚¹ï¼Œå¼‚æ­¥å°±ä¸ä¼šé˜»å¡å…¶ä»–æ“ä½œã€‚

Now, back in our main functionâ€™s async block, we can attempt to merge the messages and intervals streams, as shown in Listing 17-37.

ç°åœ¨å›åˆ°ä¸»å‡½æ•°çš„å¼‚æ­¥å—ï¼Œå°è¯•åˆå¹¶ messages å’Œ intervals æµï¼ˆè§ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-37ï¼‰ã€‚

We start by calling get_intervals. Then we merge the messages and intervals streams with the merge method, which combines multiple streams into one stream that produces items from any of the source streams as soon as the items are available, without imposing any particular ordering. Finally, we loop over that combined stream instead of over messages.

é¦–å…ˆè°ƒç”¨ get_intervalsï¼Œç„¶å[note]ä½¿ç”¨ merge æ–¹æ³•åˆå¹¶ messages å’Œ intervals æµã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•å°†å¤šä¸ªæµåˆå¹¶ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªæµï¼Œåœ¨æºæµé¡¹å¯ç”¨æ—¶ç«‹å³ç”Ÿæˆï¼ˆä¸å¼ºåˆ¶ç‰¹å®šé¡ºåºï¼‰ã€‚æœ€åéå†åˆå¹¶åçš„æµè€Œé messagesã€‚

At this point, neither messages nor intervals needs to be pinned or mutable, because both will be combined into the single merged stream. However, this call to merge doesnâ€™t compile! (Neither does the next call in the while let loop, but weâ€™ll come back to that.) This is because the two streams have different types. The messages stream has the type Timeout<impl Stream<Item = String>>, where Timeout is the type that implements Stream for a timeout call. The intervals stream has the type impl Stream<Item = u32>. To merge these two streams, we need to transform one of them to match the other. Weâ€™ll rework the intervals stream, because messages is already in the basic format we want and has to handle timeout errors (see Listing 17-38).

æ­¤æ—¶ï¼Œmessages å’Œ intervals éƒ½æ— éœ€å›ºå®šæˆ–å¯å˜ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬å°†åˆå¹¶åˆ°å•ä¸ª merged æµä¸­ã€‚ä½†æ­¤ merge è°ƒç”¨æ— æ³•ç¼–è¯‘ï¼ï¼ˆwhile let å¾ªç¯ä¸­çš„ next è°ƒç”¨ä¹Ÿä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¯‘ï¼Œç¨åå¤„ç†ã€‚ï¼‰åŸå› æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªæµç±»å‹ä¸åŒï¼šmessages æ˜¯ Timeout<impl Stream<Item = String>>ï¼ˆTimeout æ˜¯å®ç° timeout è°ƒç”¨çš„æµç±»å‹ï¼‰ï¼›intervals æ˜¯ impl Stream<Item = u32>ã€‚è¦åˆå¹¶éœ€è½¬æ¢å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªæµã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é‡æ„ intervals æµï¼Œå› ä¸º messages å·²æ˜¯æ‰€éœ€æ ¼å¼ä¸”éœ€å¤„ç†è¶…æ—¶é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆè§ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-38ï¼‰ã€‚

First, we can use the map helper method to transform the intervals into a string. Second, we need to match the Timeout from messages. Because we donâ€™t actually want a timeout for intervals, though, we can just create a timeout which is longer than the other durations we are using. Here, we create a 10-second timeout with Duration::from_secs(10). Finally, we need to make stream mutable, so that the while let loopâ€™s next calls can iterate through the stream, and pin it so that itâ€™s safe to do so. That gets us almost to where we need to be. Everything type checks. If you run this, though, there will be two problems. First, it will never stop! Youâ€™ll need to stop it with ctrl-c. Second, the messages from the English alphabet will be buried in the midst of all the interval counter messages:

é¦–å…ˆä½¿ç”¨ map æ–¹æ³•å°† intervals è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚å…¶æ¬¡éœ€åŒ¹é… messages çš„ Timeoutã€‚ç”±äºæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸éœ€è¦ intervals çš„è¶…æ—¶ï¼Œå¯åˆ›å»ºæ¯”å…¶ä»–æŒç»­æ—¶é—´æ›´é•¿çš„è¶…æ—¶ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„ä¸º 10 ç§’ï¼‰ã€‚æœ€åéœ€å°† stream è®¾ä¸ºå¯å˜ä»¥ä¾¿ while let å¾ªç¯è°ƒç”¨ nextï¼Œå¹¶å›ºå®šå®ƒä»¥ä¿è¯å®‰å…¨ã€‚è¿™å‡ ä¹è¾¾åˆ°è¦æ±‚ï¼šç±»å‹æ£€æŸ¥é€šè¿‡ã€‚ä½†è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¼šé‡åˆ°ä¸¤ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼š1) æ°¸ä¸åœæ­¢ï¼ˆéœ€æŒ‰ ctrl-c ç»ˆæ­¢ï¼‰ï¼›2) å­—æ¯æ¶ˆæ¯æ·¹æ²¡åœ¨é—´éš”è®¡æ•°æ¶ˆæ¯ä¸­ï¼š

--snip--
Interval: 38
Interval: 39
Interval: 40
Message: 'a'
Interval: 41
Interval: 42
Interval: 43
--snip--

Listing 17-39 shows one way to solve these last two problems.

ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-39 å±•ç¤ºæœ€åä¸¤ä¸ªé—®é¢˜çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚

First, we use the throttle method on the intervals stream so that it doesnâ€™t overwhelm the messages stream. Throttling is a way of limiting the rate at which a function will be calledâ€”or, in this case, how often the stream will be polled. Once every 100 milliseconds should do, because thatâ€™s roughly how often our messages arrive.

é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ intervals æµä¸Š[note]ä½¿ç”¨ throttle æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œé¿å…å…¶æ·¹æ²¡ messages æµã€‚èŠ‚æµï¼ˆthrottlingï¼‰ç”¨äºé™åˆ¶å‡½æ•°è°ƒç”¨é¢‘ç‡ï¼ˆæ­¤å¤„é™åˆ¶æµè½®è¯¢é¢‘ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚è®¾ä¸ºæ¯ 100 æ¯«ç§’ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼ˆæ¥è¿‘æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ°è¾¾é¢‘ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚

To limit the number of items we will accept from a stream, we apply the take method to the merged stream, because we want to limit the final output, not just one stream or the other.

[note]ä¸ºé™åˆ¶æµçš„æ€»å¤„ç†é‡ï¼Œå¯¹ merged æµåº”ç”¨ take æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆéœ€é™åˆ¶æœ€ç»ˆè¾“å‡ºè€Œéå•ä¸ªæµï¼‰ã€‚

Now when we run the program, it stops after pulling 20 items from the stream, and the intervals donâ€™t overwhelm the messages. We also donâ€™t get Interval: 100 or Interval: 200 or so on, but instead get Interval: 1, Interval: 2, and so onâ€”even though we have a source stream that can produce an event every millisecond. Thatâ€™s because the throttle call produces a new stream that wraps the original stream so that the original stream gets polled only at the throttle rate, not its own â€œnativeâ€ rate. We donâ€™t have a bunch of unhandled interval messages weâ€™re choosing to ignore. Instead, we never produce those interval messages in the first place! This is the inherent â€œlazinessâ€ of Rustâ€™s futures at work again, allowing us to choose our performance characteristics.

ç°åœ¨ç¨‹åºåœ¨ä»æµä¸­æ‹‰å– 20 é¡¹ååœæ­¢ï¼Œä¸”é—´éš”æ¶ˆæ¯ä¸å†æ·¹æ²¡å­—æ¯æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚è™½ç„¶æºæµæ¯æ¯«ç§’å¯ç”Ÿæˆäº‹ä»¶ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬å¾—åˆ°çš„æ˜¯ Interval: 1ã€Interval: 2 ç­‰ï¼ˆè€Œé Interval: 100ï¼‰ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸º throttle è°ƒç”¨äº§ç”Ÿçš„æ–°æµåŒ…è£…äº†åŸå§‹æµï¼Œä½¿åŸå§‹æµä»…æŒ‰èŠ‚æµé€Ÿç‡ä¸ºè½®è¯¢ï¼Œè€Œéâ€œåŸç”Ÿâ€œé€Ÿç‡ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¹¶éå¿½ç•¥æœªå¤„ç†çš„é—´éš”æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä»ä¸ç”Ÿæˆè¿™äº›æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼è¿™å†æ¬¡ä½“ç°äº† Rust Future å›ºæœ‰çš„â€œæƒ°æ€§â€œï¼Œå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬é€‰æ‹©æ€§èƒ½ç‰¹å¾ã€‚

Interval: 1
Message: 'a'
Interval: 2
Interval: 3
Problem: Elapsed(())
Interval: 4
Message: 'b'
Interval: 5
Message: 'c'
Interval: 6
Interval: 7
Problem: Elapsed(())
Interval: 8
Message: 'd'
Interval: 9
Message: 'e'
Interval: 10
Interval: 11
Problem: Elapsed(())
Interval: 12

Thereâ€™s one last thing we need to handle: errors! With both of these channel-based streams, the send calls could fail when the other side of the channel closesâ€”and thatâ€™s just a matter of how the runtime executes the futures that make up the stream. Up until now, weâ€™ve ignored this possibility by calling unwrap, but in a well-behaved app, we should explicitly handle the error, at minimum by ending the loop so we donâ€™t try to send any more messages. Listing 17-40 shows a simple error strategy: print the issue and then break from the loops.

æœ€åéœ€å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯ï¼è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ª[note]åŸºäºé€šé“çš„æµä¸­ï¼Œå½“é€šé“å¦ä¸€ç«¯å…³é—­æ—¶ send è°ƒç”¨å¯èƒ½å¤±è´¥ï¼ˆè¿™å–å†³äºè¿è¡Œæ—¶æ‰§è¡Œ Future çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼‰ã€‚æ­¤å‰æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡ unwrap å¿½ç•¥æ­¤å¯èƒ½æ€§ï¼Œä½†åœ¨å¥å£®åº”ç”¨ä¸­åº”æ˜¾å¼å¤„ç†é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆè‡³å°‘ç»ˆæ­¢å¾ªç¯ä»¥é¿å…ç»§ç»­å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 17-40 å±•ç¤ºç®€å•é”™è¯¯ç­–ç•¥ï¼šæ‰“å°é—®é¢˜å¹¶ break è·³å‡ºå¾ªç¯ã€‚

As usual, the correct way to handle a message send error will vary; just make sure you have a strategy.

é€šå¸¸ï¼Œå¤„ç†æ¶ˆæ¯å‘é€é”™è¯¯çš„æ–¹å¼å› åœºæ™¯è€Œå¼‚ï¼›å…³é”®æ˜¯åˆ¶å®šç­–ç•¥ã€‚

Now that weâ€™ve seen a bunch of async in practice, letâ€™s take a step back and dig into a few of the details of how Future, Stream, and the other key traits Rust uses to make async work.

å®è·µå¤§é‡å¼‚æ­¥æ“ä½œåï¼Œç°åœ¨æ·±å…¥æ¢è®¨ Futureã€Stream ç­‰ Rust å¼‚æ­¥æ ¸å¿ƒç‰¹æ€§çš„ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚

A Closer Look at the Traits for Async æ·±å…¥æ¢ç´¢å¼‚æ­¥ç‰¹æ€§

Throughout the chapter, weâ€™ve used the Future, Pin, Unpin, Stream, and StreamExt traits in various ways. So far, though, weâ€™ve avoided getting too far into the details of how they work or how they fit together, which is fine most of the time for your day-to-day Rust work. Sometimes, though, youâ€™ll encounter situations where youâ€™ll need to understand a few more of these details. In this section, weâ€™ll dig in just enough to help in those scenarios, still leaving the really deep dive for other documentation.

åœ¨æœ¬ç« ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥å¤šç§æ–¹å¼ä½¿ç”¨äº† Futureã€Pinã€Unpinã€Stream å’Œ StreamExt ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ä½†åˆ°ç›®å‰ä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é¿å…æ·±å…¥æ¢è®¨å®ƒä»¬çš„[note]å·¥ä½œåŸç†æˆ–å¦‚ä½•ååŒå·¥ä½œï¼Œè¿™å¯¹æ—¥å¸¸ Rust å·¥ä½œé€šå¸¸å·²è¶³å¤Ÿã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶ä½ ä¼šé‡åˆ°éœ€è¦ç†è§£æ›´å¤šç»†èŠ‚çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚æœ¬èŠ‚å°†æ·±å…¥æ¢è®¨è¿™äº›ç»†èŠ‚ä»¥åº”å¯¹æ­¤ç±»åœºæ™¯ï¼Œæ›´æ·±å…¥çš„å†…å®¹åˆ™ç•™ç»™å…¶ä»–æ–‡æ¡£ã€‚

The Future Trait Future ç‰¹å¾

Letâ€™s start by taking a closer look at how the Future trait works. Hereâ€™s how Rust defines it:

é¦–å…ˆæ·±å…¥äº†è§£ Future ç‰¹å¾çš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯ Rust çš„å®šä¹‰æ–¹å¼ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::pin::Pin;
use std::task::{Context, Poll};

pub trait Future {
    type Output;

    fn poll(self: Pin<&mut Self>, cx: &mut Context<'_>) -> Poll<Self::Output>;
}
}

That trait definition includes a bunch of new types and also some syntax we havenâ€™t seen before, so letâ€™s walk through the definition piece by piece.

è¯¥ç‰¹å¾å®šä¹‰åŒ…å«å¤šä¸ªæ–°ç±»å‹åŠæœªè§çš„è¯­æ³•ï¼Œå› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬å°†é€éƒ¨åˆ†è§£æã€‚

First, Futureâ€™s associated type Output says what the future resolves to. This is analogous to the Item associated type for the Iterator trait. Second, Future also has the poll method, which takes a special Pin reference for its self parameter and a mutable reference to a Context type, and returns a Poll<Self::Output>. Weâ€™ll talk more about Pin and Context in a moment. For now, letâ€™s focus on what the method returns, the Poll type:

é¦–å…ˆï¼ŒFuture çš„å…³è”ç±»å‹ Output è¡¨ç¤º Future çš„è§£æç»“æœã€‚è¿™ç±»ä¼¼äº Iterator ç‰¹å¾çš„ Item å…³è”ç±»å‹ã€‚å…¶æ¬¡ï¼ŒFuture è¿˜åŒ…å« poll æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒæ¥æ”¶ä¸€ä¸ªç‰¹æ®Šçš„ Pin å¼•ç”¨ä½œä¸º self å‚æ•°ï¼Œä»¥åŠä¸€ä¸ª Context ç±»å‹çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œå¹¶è¿”å› Poll<Self::Output>ã€‚ç¨åå°†è¯¦ç»†è®¨è®º Pin å’Œ Contextï¼Œç°åœ¨å…ˆå…³æ³¨è¿”å›å€¼ Poll ç±»å‹ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Poll<T> {
    Ready(T),
    Pending,
}
}

This Poll type is similar to an Option. It has one variant that has a value, Ready(T), and one which does not, Pending. Poll means something quite different from Option, though! The Pending variant indicates that the future still has work to do, so the caller will need to check again later. The Ready variant indicates that the future has finished its work and the T value is available.

Poll ç±»å‹ç±»ä¼¼äº Optionï¼šåŒ…å«å¸¦å€¼çš„ Ready(T) å˜ä½“å’Œæ— å€¼çš„ Pending å˜ä½“ã€‚ä½† Poll çš„å«ä¹‰ä¸ Option æˆªç„¶ä¸åŒï¼Pending è¡¨ç¤º Future ä»éœ€å·¥ä½œï¼Œè°ƒç”¨æ–¹éœ€ç¨åé‡è¯•ï¼›Ready è¡¨ç¤º Future å·²å®Œæˆå·¥ä½œï¼Œå€¼ T å·²å°±ç»ªã€‚

Note: With most futures, the caller should not call poll again after the future has returned Ready. Many futures will panic if polled again after becoming ready. Futures that are safe to poll again will say so explicitly in their documentation. This is similar to how Iterator::next behaves.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šå¯¹å¤šæ•° Future è€Œè¨€ï¼Œåœ¨è¿”å› Ready åä¸åº”å†æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨ pollã€‚è‹¥åœ¨å°±ç»ªåè½®è¯¢ï¼Œè®¸å¤š Future ä¼šè§¦å‘ panicã€‚å¯å®‰å…¨é‡å¤è½®è¯¢çš„ Future ä¼šåœ¨æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­æ˜ç¡®è¯´æ˜ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äº Iterator::next çš„è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

When you see code that uses await, Rust compiles it under the hood to code that calls poll. If you look back at Listing 17-4, where we printed out the page title for a single URL once it resolved, Rust compiles it into something kind of (although not exactly) like this:

å½“ä½¿ç”¨ await æ—¶ï¼ŒRust åœ¨åº•å±‚å°†å…¶ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºè°ƒç”¨ poll çš„ä»£ç ã€‚å›é¡¾æ¸…å• 17-4ï¼ˆå• URL é¡µé¢æ ‡é¢˜æ‰“å°ï¼‰ï¼ŒRust ä¼šå°†å…¶ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºç±»ä¼¼ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç ï¼ˆéå®Œå…¨ä¸€è‡´ï¼‰ï¼š

match page_title(url).poll() {
    Ready(page_title) => match page_title {
        Some(title) => println!("The title for {url} was {title}"),
        None => println!("{url} had no title"),
    }
    Pending => {
        // But what goes here?
    }
}

What should we do when the future is still Pending? We need some way to try again, and again, and again, until the future is finally ready. In other words, we need a loop:

å½“ Future ä»ä¸º Pending æ—¶è¯¥å¦‚ä½•å¤„ç†ï¼Ÿæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä¸€ç§èƒ½åå¤é‡è¯•ç›´è‡³å°±ç»ªçš„æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå³å¾ªç¯ï¼š

let mut page_title_fut = page_title(url);
loop {
    match page_title_fut.poll() {
        Ready(value) => match page_title {
            Some(title) => println!("The title for {url} was {title}"),
            None => println!("{url} had no title"),
        }
        Pending => {
            // continue
        }
    }
}

If Rust compiled it to exactly that code, though, every await would be blockingâ€”exactly the opposite of what we were going for! Instead, Rust makes sure that the loop can hand off control to something that can pause work on this future to work on other futures and then check this one again later. As weâ€™ve seen, that something is an async runtime, and this scheduling and coordination work is one of its main jobs.

è‹¥ Rust ç›´æ¥ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºæ­¤ä»£ç ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª await éƒ½ä¼šé˜»å¡â€”â€”è¿™ä¸æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç›®æ ‡èƒŒé“è€Œé©°ï¼å®é™…ä¸Šï¼ŒRust ç¡®ä¿å¾ªç¯èƒ½å°†æ§åˆ¶æƒè½¬ç§»ç»™å¯æš‚åœå½“å‰ Future ä»¥å¤„ç†å…¶ä»– Future çš„è°ƒåº¦å™¨ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ç¨åé‡æ–°æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬æ‰€è§ï¼Œè°ƒåº¦å™¨å°±æ˜¯å¼‚æ­¥è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼Œå…¶æ ¸å¿ƒèŒè´£ä¹‹ä¸€æ­£æ˜¯æ­¤ç±»è°ƒåº¦åè°ƒã€‚

Earlier in the chapter, we described waiting on rx.recv. The recv call returns a future, and awaiting the future polls it. We noted that a runtime will pause the future until itâ€™s ready with either Some(message) or None when the channel closes. With our deeper understanding of the Future trait, and specifically Future::poll, we can see how that works. The runtime knows the future isnâ€™t ready when it returns Poll::Pending. Conversely, the runtime knows the future is ready and advances it when poll returns Poll::Ready(Some(message)) or Poll::Ready(None).

æœ¬ç« å‰åŠéƒ¨åˆ†æè¿°çš„ rx.recv ç­‰å¾…ï¼šrecv è¿”å› Futureï¼Œè€Œ await ä¼šè½®è¯¢è¯¥ Futureã€‚è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¼šåœ¨é€šé“å…³é—­å‰æš‚åœ Futureï¼Œç›´åˆ°è¿”å› Some(message) æˆ– Noneã€‚é€šè¿‡å¯¹ Future ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆå°¤å…¶æ˜¯ pollï¼‰çš„æ·±å…¥ç†è§£ï¼Œå¯æ˜ç¡®å…¶æœºåˆ¶ï¼šå½“è¿”å› Poll::Pending æ—¶ï¼Œè¿è¡Œæ—¶çŸ¥æ™“ Future æœªå°±ç»ªï¼›åä¹‹å½“è¿”å› Poll::Ready(Some(message)) æˆ– Poll::Ready(None) æ—¶ï¼Œè¿è¡Œæ—¶çŸ¥æ™“ Future å·²å°±ç»ªå¹¶æ¨è¿›å…¶çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

The exact details of how a runtime does that are beyond the scope of this book, but the key is to see the basic mechanics of futures: a runtime polls each future it is responsible for, putting the future back to sleep when it is not yet ready.

è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„å…·ä½“å®ç°è¶…å‡ºæœ¬ä¹¦èŒƒå›´ï¼Œä½†å…³é”®åœ¨äºç†è§£ Future çš„åŸºæœ¬æœºåˆ¶ï¼šè¿è¡Œæ—¶è½®è¯¢å…¶ç®¡ç†çš„æ¯ä¸ª Futureï¼Œåœ¨æœªå°±ç»ªæ—¶ä½¿å…¶ä¼‘çœ ã€‚

The Pin and Unpin Traits Pin ä¸ Unpin ç‰¹å¾

When we introduced the idea of pinning in Listing 17-16, we ran into a very gnarly error message. Here is the relevant part of it again:

åœ¨æ¸…å• 17-16 å¼•å…¥å›ºå®šï¼ˆpinningï¼‰æ¦‚å¿µæ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é‡åˆ°äº†å¤æ‚é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å…¶æ ¸å¿ƒéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼š

error[E0277]: `{async block@src/main.rs:10:23: 10:33}` cannot be unpinned
  --> src/main.rs:48:33
   |
48 |         trpl::join_all(futures).await;
   |                                 ^^^^^ the trait `Unpin` is not implemented for `{async block@src/main.rs:10:23: 10:33}`
   |
   = note: consider using the `pin!` macro
           consider using `Box::pin` if you need to access the pinned value outside of the current scope
   = note: required for `Box<{async block@src/main.rs:10:23: 10:33}>` to implement `Future`
note: required by a bound in `futures_util::future::join_all::JoinAll`
  --> file:///home/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-1949cf8c6b5b557f/futures-util-0.3.30/src/future/join_all.rs:29:8
   |
27 | pub struct JoinAll<F>
   |            ------- required by a bound in this struct
28 | where
29 |     F: Future,
   |        ^^^^^^ required by this bound in `JoinAll`

This error message tells us not only that we need to pin the values but also why pinning is required. The trpl::join_all function returns a struct called JoinAll. That struct is generic over a type F, which is constrained to implement the Future trait. Directly awaiting a future with await pins the future implicitly. Thatâ€™s why we donâ€™t need to use pin! everywhere we want to await futures.

æ­¤é”™è¯¯ä¸ä»…æç¤ºéœ€å›ºå®šå€¼ï¼Œè¿˜è§£é‡Šäº†åŸå› ï¼štrpl::join_all è¿”å›çš„ JoinAll ç»“æ„ä½“å¯¹ç±»å‹ F æœ‰æ³›å‹çº¦æŸï¼Œè¦æ±‚å…¶å®ç° Future ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡ await ç­‰å¾… Future ä¼šéšå¼å›ºå®šè¯¥ Futureï¼Œå› æ­¤æ— éœ€åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªç­‰å¾…å¤„æ˜¾å¼ä½¿ç”¨ pin!ã€‚

However, weâ€™re not directly awaiting a future here. Instead, we construct a new future, JoinAll, by passing a collection of futures to the join_all function. The signature for join_all requires that the types of the items in the collection all implement the Future trait, and Box<T> implements Future only if the T it wraps is a future that implements the Unpin trait.

ä½†æ­¤å¤„å¹¶éç›´æ¥ç­‰å¾… Futureï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯é€šè¿‡å‘ join_all ä¼ é€’ Future é›†åˆæ¥æ„é€ æ–° Future JoinAllã€‚join_all çš„ç­¾åè¦æ±‚é›†åˆä¸­æ‰€æœ‰é¡¹å‡å®ç° Future ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œè€Œ Box<T> ä»…åœ¨åŒ…è£…çš„ T å®ç° Unpin ç‰¹å¾æ—¶æ‰å®ç° Futureã€‚

Thatâ€™s a lot to absorb! To really understand it, letâ€™s dive a little further into how the Future trait actually works, in particular around pinning.

ä¿¡æ¯é‡å·¨å¤§ï¼ä¸ºæ·±å…¥ç†è§£ï¼Œéœ€è¿›ä¸€æ­¥æ¢ç©¶ Future ç‰¹å¾çš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯å›ºå®šæœºåˆ¶ã€‚

Look again at the definition of the Future trait:

å†æ¬¡æŸ¥çœ‹ Future ç‰¹å¾å®šä¹‰ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::pin::Pin;
use std::task::{Context, Poll};

pub trait Future {
    type Output;

    // Required method
    fn poll(self: Pin<&mut Self>, cx: &mut Context<'_>) -> Poll<Self::Output>;
}
}

The cx parameter and its Context type are the key to how a runtime actually knows when to check any given future while still being lazy. Again, the details of how that works are beyond the scope of this chapter, and you generally only need to think about this when writing a custom Future implementation. Weâ€™ll focus instead on the type for self, as this is the first time weâ€™ve seen a method where self has a type annotation. A type annotation for self works like type annotations for other function parameters, but with two key differences:

cx å‚æ•°åŠå…¶ Context ç±»å‹æ˜¯è¿è¡Œæ—¶å®ç°æƒ°æ€§è°ƒåº¦çš„å…³é”®ã€‚å…¶ç»†èŠ‚è¶…å‡ºæœ¬ç« èŒƒå›´ï¼Œé€šå¸¸ä»…åœ¨è‡ªå®šä¹‰ Future å®ç°æ—¶éœ€å…³æ³¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†èšç„¦ self çš„ç±»å‹â€”â€”è¿™æ˜¯é¦–æ¬¡åœ¨æ–¹æ³•ä¸­çœ‹åˆ°å¸¦ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£çš„ selfã€‚self çš„ç±»å‹æ³¨è§£ä¸å…¶ä»–å‡½æ•°å‚æ•°ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œä½†æœ‰ä¸¤ç‚¹å…³é”®åŒºåˆ«ï¼š

  • It tells Rust what type self must be for the method to be called.
  • å®ƒæŒ‡å®šè°ƒç”¨æ–¹æ³•æ—¶ self å¿…é¡»å…·å¤‡çš„ç±»å‹
  • It canâ€™t be just any type. Itâ€™s restricted to the type on which the method is implemented, a reference or smart pointer to that type, or a Pin wrapping a reference to that type.
  • å®ƒä¸èƒ½æ˜¯ä»»æ„ç±»å‹ï¼Œä»…é™äºæ–¹æ³•å®ç°çš„ç±»å‹ã€è¯¥ç±»å‹çš„å¼•ç”¨/æ™ºèƒ½æŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œæˆ–åŒ…è£¹è¯¥ç±»å‹å¼•ç”¨çš„ Pin

Weâ€™ll see more on this syntax in Chapter 18. For now, itâ€™s enough to know that if we want to poll a future to check whether it is Pending or Ready(Output), we need a Pin-wrapped mutable reference to the type.

ç¬¬ 18 ç« å°†è¯¦è¿°æ­¤è¯­æ³•ã€‚ç›®å‰åªéœ€çŸ¥æ™“ï¼šè½®è¯¢ Future æ£€æŸ¥å…¶çŠ¶æ€ï¼ˆPending æˆ– Ready(Output)ï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œéœ€è¦è¯¥ç±»å‹çš„ Pin åŒ…è£¹çš„å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨ã€‚

Pin is a wrapper for pointer-like types such as &, &mut, Box, and Rc. (Technically, Pin works with types that implement the Deref or DerefMut traits, but this is effectively equivalent to working only with pointers.) Pin is not a pointer itself and doesnâ€™t have any behavior of its own like Rc and Arc do with reference counting; itâ€™s purely a tool the compiler can use to enforce constraints on pointer usage.

Pin æ˜¯æŒ‡é’ˆç±»ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ &ã€&mutã€Boxã€Rcï¼‰çš„åŒ…è£…å™¨ï¼ˆä¸¥æ ¼è¯´ï¼ŒPin é€‚ç”¨äºå®ç° Deref æˆ– DerefMut çš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œä½†æ•ˆæœç­‰åŒäºä»…å¤„ç†æŒ‡é’ˆï¼‰ã€‚Pin æœ¬èº«éæŒ‡é’ˆï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸åƒ Rc å’Œ Arc å…·å¤‡å¼•ç”¨è®¡æ•°ç­‰è¡Œä¸ºï¼›å®ƒçº¯ç²¹æ˜¯ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç”¨äºå¼ºåˆ¶æ‰§è¡ŒæŒ‡é’ˆçº¦æŸçš„å·¥å…·ã€‚

Recalling that await is implemented in terms of calls to poll starts to explain the error message we saw earlier, but that was in terms of Unpin, not Pin. So how exactly does Pin relate to Unpin, and why does Future need self to be in a Pin type to call poll?

å›é¡¾ await é€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨ poll å®ç°ï¼Œå¯éƒ¨åˆ†è§£é‡Šä¹‹å‰çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä½†é”™è¯¯æ¶‰åŠ Unpin è€Œé Pinã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆ Pin ä¸ Unpin ç©¶ç«Ÿæœ‰ä½•å…³è”ï¼Ÿä¸ºä½• Future è°ƒç”¨ poll æ—¶è¦æ±‚ self ä¸º Pin ç±»å‹ï¼Ÿ

Remember from earlier in this chapter a series of await points in a future get compiled into a state machine, and the compiler makes sure that state machine follows all of Rustâ€™s normal rules around safety, including borrowing and ownership. To make that work, Rust looks at what data is needed between one await point and either the next await point or the end of the async block. It then creates a corresponding variant in the compiled state machine. Each variant gets the access it needs to the data that will be used in that section of the source code, whether by taking ownership of that data or by getting a mutable or immutable reference to it.

æœ¬ç« å‰æ–‡æåˆ°ï¼ŒFuture ä¸­çš„ä¸€ç³»åˆ—ç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ä¼šè¢«ç¼–è¯‘ä¸ºçŠ¶æ€æœºï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç¡®ä¿è¯¥çŠ¶æ€æœºéµå¾ª Rust çš„å®‰å…¨è§„åˆ™ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬å€Ÿç”¨å’Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒï¼‰ã€‚ä¸ºæ­¤ï¼ŒRust åˆ†æä»ä¸€ä¸ªç­‰å¾…ç‚¹åˆ°ä¸‹ä¸€ç­‰å¾…ç‚¹ï¼ˆæˆ– async å—ç»“æŸï¼‰æ‰€éœ€çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ç¼–è¯‘åçš„çŠ¶æ€æœºä¸­åˆ›å»ºå¯¹åº”å˜ä½“ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªå˜ä½“é€šè¿‡è·å–æ‰€æœ‰æƒæˆ–å¯å˜/ä¸å¯å˜å¼•ç”¨æ¥è®¿é—®è¯¥ä»£ç æ®µæ‰€éœ€æ•°æ®ã€‚

So far, so good: if we get anything wrong about the ownership or references in a given async block, the borrow checker will tell us. When we want to move around the future that corresponds to that blockâ€”like moving it into a Vec to pass to join_allâ€”things get trickier.

ç›®å‰ä¸€åˆ‡æ­£å¸¸ï¼šè‹¥åœ¨ async å—ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰æƒæˆ–å¼•ç”¨å¤„ç†æœ‰è¯¯ï¼Œå€Ÿç”¨æ£€æŸ¥å™¨ä¼šæŠ¥é”™ã€‚ä½†å½“ç§»åŠ¨è¯¥å—å¯¹åº”çš„ Future æ—¶ï¼ˆå¦‚ç§»å…¥ Vec ä»¥ä¼ é€’ç»™ join_allï¼‰ï¼Œæƒ…å†µå˜å¾—å¤æ‚ã€‚

When we move a futureâ€”whether by pushing it into a data structure to use as an iterator with join_all or by returning it from a functionâ€”that actually means moving the state machine Rust creates for us. And unlike most other types in Rust, the futures Rust creates for async blocks can end up with references to themselves in the fields of any given variant, as shown in the simplified illustration in Figure 17-4.

ç§»åŠ¨ Futureï¼ˆæ— è®ºæ˜¯å°†å…¶æ¨å…¥æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ä¾› join_all è¿­ä»£ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯ä»å‡½æ•°è¿”å›ï¼‰å®é™…æ˜¯ç§»åŠ¨ Rust ç”Ÿæˆçš„çŠ¶æ€æœºã€‚ä¸å¤šæ•° Rust ç±»å‹ä¸åŒï¼Œasync å—ç”Ÿæˆçš„ Future å¯èƒ½åœ¨å…¶ä»»æ„å˜ä½“å­—æ®µä¸­åŒ…å«æŒ‡å‘è‡ªèº«çš„å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œå¦‚å›¾ 17-4 çš„ç®€åŒ–ç¤ºæ„å›¾æ‰€ç¤ºã€‚

By default, though, any object that has a reference to itself is unsafe to move, because references always point to the actual memory address of whatever they refer to (see Figure 17-5). If you move the data structure itself, those internal references will be left pointing to the old location. However, that memory location is now invalid. For one thing, its value will not be updated when you make changes to the data structure. For anotherâ€”more importantâ€”thing, the computer is now free to reuse that memory for other purposes! You could end up reading completely unrelated data later.

é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒåŒ…å«è‡ªå¼•ç”¨çš„å¯¹è±¡ç§»åŠ¨æ˜¯ä¸å®‰å…¨çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå¼•ç”¨æ€»æŒ‡å‘å…¶ç›®æ ‡çš„å†…å­˜åœ°å€ï¼ˆè§å›¾ 17-5ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥ç§»åŠ¨æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼Œå†…éƒ¨å¼•ç”¨å°†æŒ‡å‘æ—§åœ°å€ï¼Œè€Œè¯¥åœ°å€ç°å·²å¤±æ•ˆï¼šå€¼æ›´æ–°ä¸ä¼šåæ˜ ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œä¸”è®¡ç®—æœºå¯é‡ç”¨è¯¥å†…å­˜ï¼æœ€ç»ˆå¯èƒ½è¯»å–åˆ°æ— å…³æ•°æ®ã€‚

Theoretically, the Rust compiler could try to update every reference to an object whenever it gets moved, but that could add a lot of performance overhead, especially if a whole web of references needs updating. If we could instead make sure the data structure in question doesnâ€™t move in memory, we wouldnâ€™t have to update any references. This is exactly what Rustâ€™s borrow checker requires: in safe code, it prevents you from moving any item with an active reference to it.

ç†è®ºä¸Šï¼ŒRust ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å¯åœ¨å¯¹è±¡ç§»åŠ¨æ—¶æ›´æ–°æ‰€æœ‰å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œä½†è¿™ä¼šå¸¦æ¥æ€§èƒ½å¼€é”€ï¼ˆå°¤å…¶å½“å¼•ç”¨ç½‘ç»œåºå¤§æ—¶ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥ç¡®ä¿æ•°æ®ç»“æ„å†…å­˜ä½ç½®å›ºå®šï¼Œåˆ™æ— éœ€æ›´æ–°å¼•ç”¨ã€‚è¿™æ­£æ˜¯ Rust å€Ÿç”¨æ£€æŸ¥å™¨çš„è¦æ±‚ï¼šåœ¨å®‰å…¨ä»£ç ä¸­ï¼Œç¦æ­¢ç§»åŠ¨å­˜åœ¨æ´»è·ƒå¼•ç”¨çš„é¡¹ã€‚

Pin builds on that to give us the exact guarantee we need. When we pin a value by wrapping a pointer to that value in Pin, it can no longer move. Thus, if you have Pin<Box<SomeType>>, you actually pin the SomeType value, not the Box pointer. Figure 17-6 illustrates this process.

Pin åŸºäºæ­¤æä¾›æ‰€éœ€ä¿è¯ï¼šå½“é€šè¿‡ Pin åŒ…è£¹æŒ‡å‘å€¼çš„æŒ‡é’ˆæ¥å›ºå®šè¯¥å€¼æ—¶ï¼Œå…¶ä½ç½®å°†ä¸å¯ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè‹¥æŒæœ‰ Pin<Box<SomeType>>ï¼Œå®é™…å›ºå®šçš„æ˜¯ SomeType å€¼è€Œé Box æŒ‡é’ˆã€‚å›¾ 17-6 å±•ç¤ºäº†æ­¤è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚

In fact, the Box pointer can still move around freely. Remember: we care about making sure the data ultimately being referenced stays in place. If a pointer moves around, but the data it points to is in the same place, as in Figure 17-7, thereâ€™s no potential problem. As an independent exercise, look at the docs for the types as well as the std::pin module and try to work out how youâ€™d do this with a Pin wrapping a Box.) The key is that the self-referential type itself cannot move, because it is still pinned.

å®é™…ä¸Š Box æŒ‡é’ˆä»å¯è‡ªç”±ç§»åŠ¨ï¼ˆè§å›¾ 17-7ï¼‰ã€‚å…³é”®ç‚¹åœ¨äºç¡®ä¿è¢«å¼•ç”¨çš„æ•°æ®ä½ç½®å›ºå®šã€‚è‹¥æŒ‡é’ˆç§»åŠ¨ä½†æŒ‡å‘çš„æ•°æ®æœªç§»åŠ¨ï¼ˆä½œä¸ºç‹¬ç«‹ç»ƒä¹ ï¼Œå¯æŸ¥é˜…ç›¸å…³ç±»å‹åŠ std::pin æ–‡æ¡£ï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™æ— æ½œåœ¨é—®é¢˜ã€‚æ ¸å¿ƒåœ¨äºè‡ªå¼•ç”¨ç±»å‹æœ¬èº«ä¸å¯ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œå› å…¶ä»å¤„äºå›ºå®šçŠ¶æ€ã€‚

However, most types are perfectly safe to move around, even if they happen to be behind a Pin wrapper. We only need to think about pinning when items have internal references. Primitive values such as numbers and Booleans are safe because they obviously donâ€™t have any internal references. Neither do most types you normally work with in Rust. You can move around a Vec, for example, without worrying. Given only what we have seen so far, if you have a Pin<Vec<String>>, youâ€™d have to do everything via the safe but restrictive APIs provided by Pin, even though a Vec<String> is always safe to move if there are no other references to it. We need a way to tell the compiler that itâ€™s fine to move items around in cases like thisâ€”and thatâ€™s where Unpin comes into play.

ä½†å¤šæ•°ç±»å‹å¯å®‰å…¨ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œå³ä½¿è¢« Pin åŒ…è£¹ã€‚ä»…å½“é¡¹å­˜åœ¨å†…éƒ¨å¼•ç”¨æ—¶æ‰éœ€è€ƒè™‘å›ºå®šã€‚åŸå§‹å€¼ï¼ˆå¦‚æ•°å­—ã€å¸ƒå°”å€¼ï¼‰æ˜¾ç„¶å®‰å…¨ï¼ŒRust ä¸­å¤šæ•°å¸¸ç”¨ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ Vecï¼‰äº¦ç„¶ã€‚è‹¥æŒæœ‰ Pin<Vec<String>>ï¼Œå³ä½¿ Vec<String> åœ¨æ— å…¶ä»–å¼•ç”¨æ—¶å¯å®‰å…¨ç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œä¹Ÿéœ€é€šè¿‡ Pin æä¾›çš„å®‰å…¨ä½†å—é™çš„ API æ“ä½œã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä¸€ç§æ–¹å¼å‘ŠçŸ¥ç¼–è¯‘å™¨æ­¤ç±»æƒ…å†µå¯å®‰å…¨ç§»åŠ¨â€”â€”è¿™æ­£æ˜¯ Unpin çš„ä½œç”¨ã€‚

Unpin is a marker trait, similar to the Send and Sync traits we saw in Chapter 16, and thus has no functionality of its own. Marker traits exist only to tell the compiler itâ€™s safe to use the type implementing a given trait in a particular context. Unpin informs the compiler that a given type does not need to uphold any guarantees about whether the value in question can be safely moved.

Unpin æ˜¯æ ‡è®°ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼ç¬¬ 16 ç« çš„ Send å’Œ Syncï¼‰ï¼Œè‡ªèº«æ— åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æ ‡è®°ç‰¹å¾ä»…ç”¨äºå‘ŠçŸ¥ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å¯åœ¨ç‰¹å®šä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­å®‰å…¨ä½¿ç”¨å®ç°è¯¥ç‰¹å¾çš„ç±»å‹ã€‚Unpin å‘ç¼–è¯‘å™¨å£°æ˜ï¼šæŸç±»å‹æ— éœ€ä¿è¯å…¶å€¼å¯å®‰å…¨ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

Just as with Send and Sync, the compiler implements Unpin automatically for all types where it can prove it is safe. A special case, again similar to Send and Sync, is where Unpin is not implemented for a type. The notation for this is impl !Unpin for SomeType, where SomeType is the name of a type that does need to uphold those guarantees to be safe whenever a pointer to that type is used in a Pin.

ä¸ Send å’Œ Sync ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨ä¼šä¸ºå¯è¯æ˜å®‰å…¨çš„æ‰€æœ‰ç±»å‹è‡ªåŠ¨å®ç° Unpinã€‚ç‰¹æ®Šæƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒæŸç±»å‹å¯èƒ½æœªå®ç° Unpinï¼Œè®°ä¸º impl !Unpin for SomeTypeï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºè¯¥ç±»å‹éœ€åœ¨ Pin åŒ…è£¹çš„æŒ‡é’ˆä½¿ç”¨æ—¶æ»¡è¶³å®‰å…¨ä¿è¯ã€‚

In other words, there are two things to keep in mind about the relationship between Pin and Unpin. First, Unpin is the â€œnormalâ€ case, and !Unpin is the special case. Second, whether a type implements Unpin or !Unpin only matters when youâ€™re using a pinned pointer to that type like Pin<&mut SomeType>.

ç»¼ä¸Šï¼Œå…³äº Pin å’Œ Unpin éœ€æ³¨æ„ä¸¤ç‚¹ï¼š

  1. Unpin æ˜¯â€œå¸¸æ€â€ï¼Œ!Unpin æ˜¯ç‰¹ä¾‹
  2. ä»…å½“ä½¿ç”¨å›ºå®šæŒ‡é’ˆï¼ˆå¦‚ Pin<&mut SomeType>ï¼‰æ—¶ï¼Œç±»å‹æ˜¯å¦å®ç° Unpin æ‰æœ‰æ„ä¹‰

To make that concrete, think about a String: it has a length and the Unicode characters that make it up. We can wrap a String in Pin, as seen in Figure 17-8. However, String automatically implements Unpin, as do most other types in Rust.

ä»¥ String ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼ˆè§å›¾ 17-8ï¼‰ï¼šå…¶é•¿åº¦å’Œå­—ç¬¦æ•°æ®å¯è¢« Pin åŒ…è£¹ï¼Œä½† String è‡ªåŠ¨å®ç° Unpinï¼ˆRust ä¸­å¤šæ•°ç±»å‹å¦‚æ­¤ï¼‰ã€‚

As a result, we can do things that would be illegal if String implemented !Unpin instead, such as replacing one string with another at the exact same location in memory as in Figure 17-9. This doesnâ€™t violate the Pin contract, because String has no internal references that make it unsafe to move around! That is precisely why it implements Unpin rather than !Unpin.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œè‹¥ String å®ç° !Unpin æœ¬åº”éæ³•çš„æ“ä½œï¼ˆå¦‚åœ¨å†…å­˜ç›¸åŒä½ç½®æ›¿æ¢å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œè§å›¾ 17-9ï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨ Unpin ä¸‹æ˜¯å…è®¸çš„ã€‚è¿™ä¸è¿å Pin çº¦å®šï¼Œå› ä¸º String æ— ä½¿å…¶ç§»åŠ¨ä¸å®‰å…¨çš„å†…éƒ¨å¼•ç”¨ï¼è¿™æ­£æ˜¯å…¶å®ç° Unpin è€Œé !Unpin çš„åŸå› ã€‚

Now we know enough to understand the errors reported for that join_all call from back in Listing 17-17. We originally tried to move the futures produced by async blocks into a Vec<Box<dyn Future<Output = ()>>>, but as weâ€™ve seen, those futures may have internal references, so they donâ€™t implement Unpin. They need to be pinned, and then we can pass the Pin type into the Vec, confident that the underlying data in the futures will not be moved.

ç°åœ¨å¯ç†è§£æ¸…å• 17-17 ä¸­ join_all è°ƒç”¨çš„æŠ¥é”™äº†ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬å°è¯•å°† async å—ç”Ÿæˆçš„ Future ç§»å…¥ Vec<Box<dyn Future<Output = ()>>>ï¼Œä½†è¿™äº› Future å¯èƒ½æœ‰å†…éƒ¨å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œæ•…æœªå®ç° Unpinã€‚å®ƒä»¬éœ€è¢«å›ºå®šåï¼Œæ‰èƒ½å°† Pin ç±»å‹ä¼ å…¥ Vecï¼Œç¡®ä¿ Future åº•å±‚æ•°æ®ä¸ä¼šç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

Pin and Unpin are mostly important for building lower-level libraries, or when youâ€™re building a runtime itself, rather than for day-to-day Rust code. When you see these traits in error messages, though, now youâ€™ll have a better idea of how to fix your code!

Pin å’Œ Unpin ä¸»è¦ç”¨äºæ„å»ºåº•å±‚åº“æˆ–è¿è¡Œæ—¶æœ¬èº«ï¼Œè€Œéæ—¥å¸¸ Rust ç¼–ç ã€‚ä½†å½“åœ¨é”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯ä¸­é‡åˆ°è¿™äº›ç‰¹å¾æ—¶ï¼Œä½ ç°åœ¨åº”èƒ½æ›´å¥½åœ°ä¿®å¤ä»£ç ï¼

Note: This combination of Pin and Unpin makes it possible to safely implement a whole class of complex types in Rust that would otherwise prove challenging because theyâ€™re self-referential. Types that require Pin show up most commonly in async Rust today, but every once in a while, you might see them in other contexts, too.

æ³¨æ„ï¼šPin ä¸ Unpin çš„ç»„åˆä½¿ Rust èƒ½å®‰å…¨å®ç°ä¸€ç±»å¤æ‚ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦åˆ™å› è‡ªå¼•ç”¨ç‰¹æ€§éš¾ä»¥å®ç°ï¼‰ã€‚éœ€ Pin çš„ç±»å‹æœ€å¸¸è§äºå¼‚æ­¥ Rustï¼Œä½†å¶å°”ä¹Ÿå‡ºç°åœ¨å…¶ä»–åœºæ™¯ã€‚

The specifics of how Pin and Unpin work, and the rules theyâ€™re required to uphold, are covered extensively in the API documentation for std::pin, so if youâ€™re interested in learning more, thatâ€™s a great place to start.

Pin å’Œ Unpin çš„å…·ä½“å·¥ä½œåŸç†åŠçº¦æŸè§„åˆ™è¯¦è§ std::pin çš„ API æ–‡æ¡£ã€‚

If you want to understand how things work under the hood in even more detail, see Chapters 2 and 4 of Asynchronous Programming in Rust.

è‹¥éœ€æ›´æ·±å…¥ç†è§£åº•å±‚æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…ã€ŠRust å¼‚æ­¥ç¼–ç¨‹ã€‹ç¬¬ 2 ç« å’Œç¬¬ 4 ç« ã€‚

The Stream Trait Stream ç‰¹å¾

Now that you have a deeper grasp on the Future, Pin, and Unpin traits, we can turn our attention to the Stream trait. As you learned earlier in the chapter, streams are similar to asynchronous iterators. Unlike Iterator and Future, however, Stream has no definition in the standard library as of this writing, but there is a very common definition from the futures crate used throughout the ecosystem.

æ·±å…¥ç†è§£ Futureã€Pin å’Œ Unpin åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†è½¬å‘ Stream ç‰¹å¾ã€‚å¦‚æœ¬ç« å‰æ–‡æ‰€è¿°ï¼Œæµï¼ˆStreamï¼‰ç±»ä¼¼äºå¼‚æ­¥è¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚ä½†ä¸åŒäº Iterator å’Œ Futureï¼Œæˆªè‡³æœ¬æ–‡å†™ä½œæ—¶ Stream åœ¨æ ‡å‡†åº“ä¸­æ— å®šä¹‰ï¼Œç”Ÿæ€ä¸­æ™®éä½¿ç”¨çš„æ˜¯ futures crate çš„å®šä¹‰ã€‚

Letâ€™s review the definitions of the Iterator and Future traits before looking at how a Stream trait might merge them together. From Iterator, we have the idea of a sequence: its next method provides an Option<Self::Item>. From Future, we have the idea of readiness over time: its poll method provides a Poll<Self::Output>. To represent a sequence of items that become ready over time, we define a Stream trait that puts those features together:

åœ¨æ¢è®¨å¦‚ä½•åˆå¹¶ Stream ç‰¹å¾å‰ï¼Œå…ˆå›é¡¾ Iterator å’Œ Future çš„å®šä¹‰ã€‚Iterator ä½“ç°åºåˆ—æ€§ï¼šå…¶ next æ–¹æ³•è¿”å› Option<Self::Item>ã€‚Future ä½“ç°éšæ—¶é—´å°±ç»ªæ€§ï¼šå…¶ poll æ–¹æ³•è¿”å› Poll<Self::Output>ã€‚ä¸ºè¡¨ç¤ºéšæ—¶é—´å°±ç»ªçš„é¡¹åºåˆ—ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰ç»“åˆè¿™ä¸¤è€…çš„ Stream ç‰¹å¾ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::pin::Pin;
use std::task::{Context, Poll};

trait Stream {
    type Item;

    fn poll_next(
        self: Pin<&mut Self>,
        cx: &mut Context<'_>
    ) -> Poll<Option<Self::Item>>;
}
}

The Stream trait defines an associated type called Item for the type of the items produced by the stream. This is similar to Iterator, where there may be zero to many items, and unlike Future, where there is always a single Output, even if itâ€™s the unit type ().

Stream ç‰¹å¾å®šä¹‰å…³è”ç±»å‹ Item è¡¨ç¤ºæµç”Ÿæˆçš„é¡¹ç±»å‹ã€‚è¿™ç±»ä¼¼äº Iteratorï¼ˆå¯èƒ½ç”Ÿæˆé›¶è‡³å¤šé¡¹ï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œæœ‰åˆ«äº Futureï¼ˆå³ä½¿è¾“å‡ºä¸ºå•å…ƒç±»å‹ ()ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ€»æœ‰å•ä¸ª Outputï¼‰ã€‚

Stream also defines a method to get those items. We call it poll_next, to make it clear that it polls in the same way Future::poll does and produces a sequence of items in the same way Iterator::next does. Its return type combines Poll with Option. The outer type is Poll, because it has to be checked for readiness, just as a future does. The inner type is Option, because it needs to signal whether there are more messages, just as an iterator does.

Stream è¿˜å®šä¹‰äº†è·å–é¡¹çš„æ–¹æ³• poll_nextï¼Œå…¶å‘½åæ˜ç¡®ä½“ç°ç±»ä¼¼ Future::poll çš„è½®è¯¢æœºåˆ¶å’Œç±»ä¼¼ Iterator::next çš„åºåˆ—ç”Ÿæˆç‰¹æ€§ã€‚è¿”å›ç±»å‹ç»“åˆäº† Poll å’Œ Optionï¼šå¤–å±‚ä¸º Pollï¼ˆéœ€æ£€æŸ¥å°±ç»ªæ€§ï¼Œå¦‚ Futureï¼‰ï¼Œå†…å±‚ä¸º Optionï¼ˆéœ€è¡¨ç¤ºæ˜¯å¦æœ‰æ›´å¤šæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå¦‚è¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼‰ã€‚

Something very similar to this definition will likely end up as part of Rustâ€™s standard library. In the meantime, itâ€™s part of the toolkit of most runtimes, so you can rely on it, and everything we cover next should generally apply!

ç±»ä¼¼å®šä¹‰å¾ˆå¯èƒ½çº³å…¥ Rust æ ‡å‡†åº“ã€‚ç›®å‰å®ƒå·²æ˜¯å¤šæ•°è¿è¡Œæ—¶çš„å·¥å…·é›†ç»„æˆéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä½ å¯ä¾èµ–å®ƒï¼Œä¸”ä¸‹æ–‡å†…å®¹é€šå¸¸é€‚ç”¨ï¼

In the example we saw in the section on streaming, though, we didnâ€™t use poll_next or Stream, but instead used next and StreamExt. We could work directly in terms of the poll_next API by hand-writing our own Stream state machines, of course, just as we could work with futures directly via their poll method. Using await is much nicer, though, and the StreamExt trait supplies the next method so we can do just that:

ä½†åœ¨æœ¬ç« æµå¤„ç†çš„ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æœªä½¿ç”¨ poll_next æˆ– Streamï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨äº† next å’Œ StreamExtã€‚å½“ç„¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡ poll_next API æ‰‹åŠ¨ç¼–å†™ Stream çŠ¶æ€æœºï¼ˆå¦‚åŒé€šè¿‡ poll æ–¹æ³•ç›´æ¥æ“ä½œ Futureï¼‰ã€‚ä½†ä½¿ç”¨ await æ›´ä¼˜é›…ï¼Œè€Œ StreamExt ç‰¹å¾æä¾›çš„ next æ–¹æ³•ä½¿ä¹‹æˆä¸ºå¯èƒ½ï¼š

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::pin::Pin;
use std::task::{Context, Poll};

trait Stream {
    type Item;
    fn poll_next(
        self: Pin<&mut Self>,
        cx: &mut Context<'_>,
    ) -> Poll<Option<Self::Item>>;
}

trait StreamExt: Stream {
    async fn next(&mut self) -> Option<Self::Item>
    where
        Self: Unpin;

    // other methods...
}
}

Note: The actual definition we used earlier in the chapter looks slightly different than this, because it supports versions of Rust that did not yet support using async functions in traits. As a result, it looks like this:

æ³¨æ„ï¼šæœ¬ç« æ—©å‰ä½¿ç”¨çš„å®é™…å®šä¹‰ç•¥æœ‰ä¸åŒï¼ˆå› æ”¯æŒåœ¨ç‰¹å¾ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ async å‡½æ•°çš„ Rust ç‰ˆæœ¬è¾ƒæ–°ï¼‰ã€‚å…¶å½¢å¼å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

fn next(&mut self) -> Next<'_, Self> where Self: Unpin;

That Next type is a struct that implements Future and allows us to name the lifetime of the reference to self with Next<'_, Self>, so that await can work with this method.

æ­¤å¤„çš„ Next æ˜¯å®ç°äº† Future çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ Next<'_, Self> æ˜¾å¼å‘½å self å¼•ç”¨çš„ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸï¼Œä½¿ await å¯ä½œç”¨äºè¯¥æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

The StreamExt trait is also the home of all the interesting methods available to use with streams. StreamExt is automatically implemented for every type that implements Stream, but these traits are defined separately to enable the community to iterate on convenience APIs without affecting the foundational trait.

StreamExt ç‰¹å¾ä¹ŸåŒ…å«æ‰€æœ‰æµæ“ä½œçš„æœ‰ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ã€‚è¯¥ç‰¹å¾è‡ªåŠ¨ä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰å®ç° Stream çš„ç±»å‹æä¾›å®ç°ï¼Œä½†ä¸åŸºç¡€ç‰¹å¾åˆ†ç¦»å®šä¹‰ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ç¤¾åŒºè¿­ä»£ä¾¿åˆ© API è€Œä¸å½±å“æ ¸å¿ƒã€‚

In the version of StreamExt used in the trpl crate, the trait not only defines the next method but also supplies a default implementation of next that correctly handles the details of calling Stream::poll_next. This means that even when you need to write your own streaming data type, you only have to implement Stream, and then anyone who uses your data type can use StreamExt and its methods with it automatically.

åœ¨ trpl crate ä½¿ç”¨çš„ StreamExt ç‰ˆæœ¬ä¸­ï¼Œè¯¥ç‰¹å¾ä¸ä»…å®šä¹‰ next æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¿˜æä¾›æ­£ç¡®å¤„ç† Stream::poll_next ç»†èŠ‚çš„é»˜è®¤å®ç°ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€å³ä½¿éœ€è‡ªå®šä¹‰æµæ•°æ®ç±»å‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿä»…éœ€å®ç° Streamï¼Œä½¿ç”¨è€…å³å¯è‡ªåŠ¨ä½¿ç”¨ StreamExt çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Thatâ€™s all weâ€™re going to cover for the lower-level details on these traits. To wrap up, letâ€™s consider how futures (including streams), tasks, and threads all fit together!

å…³äºè¿™äº›ç‰¹å¾çš„åº•å±‚ç»†èŠ‚åˆ°æ­¤ç»“æŸã€‚æœ€åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¢è®¨ Futureï¼ˆå«æµï¼‰ã€ä»»åŠ¡å’Œçº¿ç¨‹å¦‚ä½•ååŒå·¥ä½œï¼

Putting It All Together: Futures, Tasks, and Threads æ•´åˆï¼šFutureã€ä»»åŠ¡ä¸çº¿ç¨‹

As we saw in Chapter 16, threads provide one approach to concurrency. Weâ€™ve seen another approach in this chapter: using async with futures and streams. If youâ€˜re wondering when to choose method over the other, the answer is: it depends! And in many cases, the choice isnâ€™t threads or async but rather threads and async.

å¦‚ç¬¬ 16 ç« æ‰€è§ï¼Œçº¿ç¨‹æä¾›äº†ä¸€ç§å¹¶å‘é€”å¾„ã€‚æœ¬ç« å±•ç¤ºäº†å¦ä¸€ç§é€”å¾„ï¼šä½¿ç”¨ async ä¸ Future åŠæµã€‚è‹¥ä½ å›°æƒ‘å¦‚ä½•é€‰æ‹©ï¼Œç­”æ¡ˆæ˜¯ï¼šè§†æƒ…å†µè€Œå®šï¼å¤šæ•°æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©éçº¿ç¨‹æˆ–å¼‚æ­¥ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯çº¿ç¨‹ä¸å¼‚æ­¥ååŒã€‚

Many operating systems have supplied threading-based concurrency models for decades now, and many programming languages support them as a result. However, these models are not without their tradeoffs. On many operating systems, they use a fair bit of memory for each thread, and they come with some overhead for starting up and shutting down. Threads are also only an option when your operating system and hardware support them. Unlike mainstream desktop and mobile computers, some embedded systems donâ€™t have an OS at all, so they also donâ€™t have threads.

è®¸å¤šæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿæä¾›åŸºäºçº¿ç¨‹çš„å¹¶å‘æ¨¡å‹å·²æ•°åå¹´ï¼Œå¤šæ•°ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€å› æ­¤æ”¯æŒå®ƒä»¬ã€‚ä½†è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹å­˜åœ¨ä»£ä»·ï¼šè®¸å¤šç³»ç»Ÿä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªçº¿ç¨‹åˆ†é…è¾ƒå¤šå†…å­˜ï¼Œä¸”å¯åŠ¨/å…³é—­æœ‰å¼€é”€ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œä»…å½“æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿå’Œç¡¬ä»¶æ”¯æŒæ—¶çº¿ç¨‹æ‰å¯ç”¨ï¼ˆåµŒå…¥å¼ç³»ç»Ÿç­‰æ—  OS ç¯å¢ƒä¸é€‚ç”¨ï¼‰ã€‚

The async model provides a differentâ€”and ultimately complementaryâ€”set of tradeoffs. In the async model, concurrent operations donâ€™t require their own threads. Instead, they can run on tasks, as when we used trpl::spawn_task to kick off work from a synchronous function in the streams section. A task is similar to a thread, but instead of being managed by the operating system, itâ€™s managed by library-level code: the runtime.

å¼‚æ­¥æ¨¡å‹æä¾›äº†ä¸€å¥—ä¸åŒä¸”äº’è¡¥çš„æƒè¡¡æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚å¼‚æ­¥æ¨¡å‹ä¸­ï¼Œå¹¶å‘æ“ä½œæ— éœ€ç‹¬å çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è¿è¡Œåœ¨ä»»åŠ¡ï¼ˆtaskï¼‰ä¸Šï¼ˆå¦‚åœ¨æµå¤„ç†ç« èŠ‚é€šè¿‡ trpl::spawn_task ä»åŒæ­¥å‡½æ•°å¯åŠ¨å·¥ä½œï¼‰ã€‚ä»»åŠ¡ç±»ä¼¼äºçº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œä½†éç”±æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿç®¡ç†ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç”±åº“çº§ä»£ç ï¼ˆè¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼‰ç®¡ç†ã€‚

In the previous section, we saw that we could build a stream by using an async channel and spawning an async task we could call from synchronous code. We can do the exact same thing with a thread. In Listing 17-40, we used trpl::spawn_task and trpl::sleep. In Listing 17-41, we replace those with the thread::spawn and thread::sleep APIs from the standard library in the get_intervals function.

ä¸ŠèŠ‚ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“æ„å»ºæµï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡å¼‚æ­¥ä»»åŠ¡ä»åŒæ­¥ä»£ç è°ƒç”¨ã€‚çº¿ç¨‹ä¹Ÿå¯å®ç°ç›¸åŒåŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æ¸…å• 17-40 ä½¿ç”¨äº† trpl::spawn_task å’Œ trpl::sleepï¼Œæ¸…å• 17-41 åˆ™åœ¨ get_intervals å‡½æ•°ä¸­æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºæ ‡å‡†åº“çš„ thread::spawn å’Œ thread::sleep APIã€‚

If you run this code, the output is identical to that of Listing 17-40. And notice how little changes here from the perspective of the calling code. Whatâ€™s more, even though one of our functions spawned an async task on the runtime and the other spawned an OS thread, the resulting streams were unaffected by the differences.

è¿è¡Œæ­¤ä»£ç ï¼Œè¾“å‡ºä¸æ¸…å• 17-40 å®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒã€‚æ³¨æ„è°ƒç”¨ä»£ç çš„æ”¹åŠ¨æå°ï¼æ›´é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œå°½ç®¡ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°åœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶ç”Ÿæˆå¼‚æ­¥ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªç”Ÿæˆ OS çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œä½†äº§ç”Ÿçš„æµä¸å—å·®å¼‚å½±å“ã€‚

Despite their similarities, these two approaches behave very differently, although we might have a hard time measuring it in this very simple example. We could spawn millions of async tasks on any modern personal computer. If we tried to do that with threads, we would literally run out of memory!

å°½ç®¡ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œè¿™ä¸¤ç§æ–¹å¼è¡Œä¸ºè¿¥å¼‚ï¼ˆåœ¨æ­¤ç®€å•ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­éš¾ä»¥æµ‹é‡ï¼‰ã€‚ç°ä»£ä¸ªäººè®¡ç®—æœºå¯ç”Ÿæˆæ•°ç™¾ä¸‡å¼‚æ­¥ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä½†ä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹å°è¯•æ­¤æ“ä½œä¼šè€—å°½å†…å­˜ï¼

However, thereâ€™s a reason these APIs are so similar. Threads act as a boundary for sets of synchronous operations; concurrency is possible between threads. Tasks act as a boundary for sets of asynchronous operations; concurrency is possible both between and within tasks, because a task can switch between futures in its body. Finally, futures are Rustâ€™s most granular unit of concurrency, and each future may represent a tree of other futures. The runtimeâ€”specifically, its executorâ€”manages tasks, and tasks manage futures. In that regard, tasks are similar to lightweight, runtime-managed threads with added capabilities that come from being managed by a runtime instead of by the operating system.

ä½†ä¸¤ç§ API ç›¸ä¼¼å­˜åœ¨åŸå› ï¼šçº¿ç¨‹ä½œä¸ºåŒæ­¥æ“ä½œçš„è¾¹ç•Œï¼Œæ”¯æŒçº¿ç¨‹é—´å¹¶å‘ï¼›ä»»åŠ¡ä½œä¸ºå¼‚æ­¥æ“ä½œçš„è¾¹ç•Œï¼Œæ”¯æŒä»»åŠ¡é—´ä¸ä»»åŠ¡å†…å¹¶å‘ï¼ˆå› ä»»åŠ¡å¯åœ¨å…¶ä½“å†…åˆ‡æ¢ Futureï¼‰ã€‚æœ€ç»ˆï¼ŒFuture æ˜¯ Rust æœ€ç»†ç²’åº¦çš„å¹¶å‘å•å…ƒï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª Future å¯è¡¨ç¤ºå…¶ä»– Future çš„æ ‘å½¢ç»“æ„ã€‚è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆå…·ä½“æŒ‡å…¶æ‰§è¡Œå™¨ï¼‰ç®¡ç†ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä»»åŠ¡ç®¡ç† Futureã€‚å°±æ­¤è€Œè¨€ï¼Œä»»åŠ¡ç±»ä¼¼äºç”±è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆè€Œéæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿï¼‰ç®¡ç†çš„è½»é‡çº§çº¿ç¨‹ï¼Œå¹¶å…·å¤‡é¢å¤–èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚

This doesnâ€™t mean that async tasks are always better than threads (or vice versa). Concurrency with threads is in some ways a simpler programming model than concurrency with async. That can be a strength or a weakness. Threads are somewhat â€œfire and forgetâ€; they have no native equivalent to a future, so they simply run to completion without being interrupted except by the operating system itself. That is, they have no built-in support for intratask concurrency the way futures do. Threads in Rust also have no mechanisms for cancellationâ€”a subject we havenâ€™t covered explicitly in this chapter but was implied by the fact that whenever we ended a future, its state got cleaned up correctly.

è¿™ä¸æ„å‘³ç€å¼‚æ­¥ä»»åŠ¡æ€»ä¼˜äºçº¿ç¨‹ï¼ˆæˆ–åä¹‹ï¼‰ã€‚çº¿ç¨‹å¹¶å‘æ¨¡å‹åœ¨æŸäº›æ–¹é¢æ¯”å¼‚æ­¥æ›´ç®€å•ï¼Œè¿™å¯èƒ½æ˜¯ä¼˜åŠ¿ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æ˜¯åŠ£åŠ¿ã€‚çº¿ç¨‹æŸç§ç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šæ˜¯â€œå³å‘å³å¼ƒâ€ï¼›å®ƒä»¬æ— åŸç”Ÿç­‰ä»·äº Future çš„æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä»…è¿è¡Œè‡³å®Œæˆï¼ˆé™¤éè¢«æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿä¸­æ–­ï¼‰ã€‚å³ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬æ— å†…ç½®çš„ä»»åŠ¡å†…å¹¶å‘æ”¯æŒï¼ˆå¦‚ Futureï¼‰ã€‚Rust çº¿ç¨‹ä¹Ÿæ— å–æ¶ˆæœºåˆ¶ï¼ˆæœ¬ç« æœªæ˜ç¡®æ¶‰åŠï¼Œä½†é€šè¿‡ Future çŠ¶æ€æ­£ç¡®æ¸…ç†å·²éšå«æ­¤èƒ½åŠ›ï¼‰ã€‚

These limitations also make threads harder to compose than futures. Itâ€™s much more difficult, for example, to use threads to build helpers such as the timeout and throttle methods we built earlier in this chapter. The fact that futures are richer data structures means they can be composed together more naturally, as we have seen.

è¿™äº›é™åˆ¶ä¹Ÿä½¿çº¿ç¨‹æ¯” Future æ›´éš¾ç»„åˆã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹æ„å»ºç±»ä¼¼æœ¬ç« æ—©å‰çš„ timeout å’Œ throttle æ–¹æ³•æ›´ä¸ºå›°éš¾ã€‚Future ä½œä¸ºæ›´ä¸°å¯Œçš„æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼Œå¯æ›´è‡ªç„¶åœ°ç»„åˆï¼ˆå¦‚å‰æ‰€è§ï¼‰ã€‚

Tasks, then, give us additional control over futures, allowing us to choose where and how to group them. And it turns out that threads and tasks often work very well together, because tasks can (at least in some runtimes) be moved around between threads. In fact, under the hood, the runtime weâ€™ve been usingâ€”including the spawn_blocking and spawn_task functionsâ€”is multithreaded by default! Many runtimes use an approach called work stealing to transparently move tasks around between threads, based on how the threads are currently being utilized, to improve the systemâ€™s overall performance. That approach actually requires threads and tasks, and therefore futures.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œä»»åŠ¡èµ‹äºˆæˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹ Future çš„é¢å¤–æ§åˆ¶æƒï¼Œå…è®¸é€‰æ‹©åˆ†ç»„æ–¹å¼ã€‚äº‹å®è¯æ˜ï¼Œçº¿ç¨‹ä¸ä»»åŠ¡å¸¸èƒ½å‡ºè‰²åä½œï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»»åŠ¡å¯ï¼ˆè‡³å°‘åœ¨æŸäº›è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¸­ï¼‰åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚å®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨çš„è¿è¡Œæ—¶ï¼ˆå« spawn_blocking å’Œ spawn_task å‡½æ•°ï¼‰é»˜è®¤æ˜¯å¤šçº¿ç¨‹çš„ï¼è®¸å¤šè¿è¡Œæ—¶é‡‡ç”¨å·¥ä½œçªƒå–ï¼ˆwork stealingï¼‰ç­–ç•¥ï¼Œæ ¹æ®çº¿ç¨‹å½“å‰åˆ©ç”¨ç‡åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹é—´é€æ˜è¿ç§»ä»»åŠ¡ä»¥æå‡æ•´ä½“æ€§èƒ½ã€‚æ­¤ç­–ç•¥å®é™…éœ€çº¿ç¨‹ä¸ä»»åŠ¡ï¼ˆè¿›è€Œéœ€ Futureï¼‰ååŒå·¥ä½œã€‚

When thinking about which method to use when, consider these rules of thumb:

é€‰æ‹©æ–¹æ³•æ—¶å¯å‚è€ƒä»¥ä¸‹ç»éªŒæ³•åˆ™ï¼š

  • If the work is very parallelizable, such as processing a bunch of data where each part can be processed separately, threads are a better choice.
  • [note]é«˜åº¦å¯å¹¶è¡Œå·¥ä½œï¼ˆå¦‚å„éƒ¨åˆ†å¯ç‹¬ç«‹å¤„ç†çš„æ•°æ®å¤„ç†ï¼‰ï¼šçº¿ç¨‹æ›´ä¼˜
  • If the work is very concurrent, such as handling messages from a bunch of different sources that may come in at different intervals or different rates, async is a better choice.
  • [note]é«˜åº¦å¹¶å‘å·¥ä½œï¼ˆå¦‚å¤„ç†ä¸åŒé—´éš”/é€Ÿç‡çš„å¤šæºæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ï¼šå¼‚æ­¥æ›´ä¼˜

And if you need both parallelism and concurrency, you donâ€™t have to choose between threads and async. You can use them together freely, letting each one play the part itâ€™s best at. For example, Listing 17-42 shows a fairly common example of this kind of mix in real-world Rust code.

è‹¥éœ€å¹¶è¡Œä¸å¹¶å‘ï¼Œæ— éœ€åœ¨çº¿ç¨‹å’Œå¼‚æ­¥é—´äºŒé€‰ä¸€ã€‚å¯è‡ªç”±ç»„åˆä¸¤è€…ï¼Œå‘æŒ¥å„è‡ªä¼˜åŠ¿ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæ¸…å• 17-42 å±•ç¤ºäº†çœŸå® Rust ä»£ç ä¸­æ­¤ç±»æ··åˆçš„å¸¸è§ç¤ºä¾‹ã€‚

We begin by creating an async channel, then spawn a thread that takes ownership of the sender side of the channel. Within the thread, we send the numbers 1 through 10, sleeping for a second between each. Finally, we run a future created with an async block passed to trpl::run just as we have throughout the chapter. In that future, we await those messages, just as in the other message-passing examples we have seen.

æˆ‘ä»¬åˆ›å»ºå¼‚æ­¥é€šé“ï¼Œç”Ÿæˆæ‹¥æœ‰é€šé“å‘é€ç«¯æ‰€æœ‰æƒçš„çº¿ç¨‹ã€‚çº¿ç¨‹å†…æ¯ç§’å‘é€æ•°å­— 1 åˆ° 10ã€‚æœ€åï¼Œé€šè¿‡ä¼ é€’ç»™ trpl::run çš„ async å—è¿è¡Œ Futureï¼ˆå¦‚å…¨ç« æ‰€ç¤ºï¼‰ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ç­‰å¾…æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼å…¶ä»–æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼‰ã€‚

To return to the scenario we opened the chapter with, imagine running a set of video encoding tasks using a dedicated thread (because video encoding is compute-bound) but notifying the UI that those operations are done with an async channel. There are countless examples of these kinds of combinations in real-world use cases.

å›åˆ°æœ¬ç« å¼€ç¯‡åœºæ™¯ï¼šç”¨ä¸“ç”¨çº¿ç¨‹è¿è¡Œè§†é¢‘ç¼–ç ä»»åŠ¡ï¼ˆå› ç¼–ç æ˜¯è®¡ç®—å¯†é›†å‹ï¼‰ï¼Œä½†é€šè¿‡å¼‚æ­¥é€šé“é€šçŸ¥ UI æ“ä½œå®Œæˆã€‚ç°å®æ¡ˆä¾‹ä¸­æœ‰æ— æ•°æ­¤ç±»ç»„åˆã€‚

Summary æ€»ç»“

This isnâ€™t the last youâ€™ll see of concurrency in this book. The project in Chapter 21 will apply these concepts in a more realistic situation than the simpler examples discussed here and compare problem-solving with threading versus tasks more directly.

æœ¬ä¹¦åç»­ä»æ¶‰åŠå¹¶å‘ã€‚ç¬¬ 21 ç« çš„é¡¹ç›®å°†åœ¨æ›´çœŸå®åœºæ™¯åº”ç”¨è¿™äº›æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œå¹¶æ›´ç›´æ¥å¯¹æ¯”çº¿ç¨‹ä¸ä»»åŠ¡çš„è§£é¢˜æ–¹å¼ã€‚

No matter which of these approaches you choose, Rust gives you the tools you need to write safe, fast, concurrent codeâ€”whether for a high-throughput web server or an embedded operating system.

æ— è®ºé€‰æ‹©ä½•ç§æ–¹å¼ï¼ŒRust éƒ½ä¸ºä½ æä¾›ç¼–å†™å®‰å…¨ã€å¿«é€Ÿã€å¹¶å‘ä»£ç çš„å·¥å…·â€”â€”æ— è®ºç”¨äºé«˜åå Web æœåŠ¡å™¨è¿˜æ˜¯åµŒå…¥å¼æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿã€‚

Next, weâ€™ll talk about idiomatic ways to model problems and structure solutions as your Rust programs get bigger. In addition, weâ€™ll discuss how Rustâ€™s idioms relate to those you might be familiar with from object-oriented programming.

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢è®¨éšç€ Rust ç¨‹åºè§„æ¨¡å¢é•¿ï¼Œå¦‚ä½•ä»¥æƒ¯ç”¨æ–¹å¼å»ºæ¨¡é—®é¢˜ä¸æ„å»ºè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå¹¶è®¨è®º Rust æƒ¯ç”¨æ³•ä¸ä½ å¯èƒ½ç†Ÿæ‚‰çš„é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹æƒ¯ç”¨æ³•çš„å…³è”ã€‚

Object-Oriented Programming Features é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹ç‰¹æ€§

Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a way of modeling programs. Objects as a programmatic concept were introduced in the programming language Simula in the 1960s. Those objects influenced Alan Kayâ€™s programming architecture in which objects pass messages to each other. To describe this architecture, he coined the term object-oriented programming in 1967. Many competing definitions describe what OOP is, and by some of these definitions Rust is object oriented but by others it is not. In this chapter, weâ€™ll explore certain characteristics that are commonly considered object oriented and how those characteristics translate to idiomatic Rust. Weâ€™ll then show you how to implement an object-oriented design pattern in Rust and discuss the trade-offs of doing so versus implementing a solution using some of Rustâ€™s strengths instead.

é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼ˆOOPï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç¨‹åºå»ºæ¨¡æ–¹å¼ã€‚å¯¹è±¡ä½œä¸ºç¼–ç¨‹æ¦‚å¿µäº1960å¹´ä»£åœ¨Simulaè¯­è¨€ä¸­è¢«å¼•å…¥ï¼Œè¿™äº›å¯¹è±¡å½±å“äº†Alan Kayçš„ç¼–ç¨‹æ¶æ„â€”â€”å…¶ä¸­å¯¹è±¡ç›¸äº’ä¼ é€’æ¶ˆæ¯ã€‚ä¸ºæè¿°æ­¤æ¶æ„ï¼Œä»–åœ¨1967å¹´åˆ›é€ äº†æœ¯è¯­é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹ã€‚å…³äºOOPçš„å®šä¹‰å­˜åœ¨è®¸å¤šäº‰è®®ï¼ŒæŒ‰æŸäº›å®šä¹‰Rustæ˜¯é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡çš„ï¼Œè€ŒæŒ‰å¦ä¸€äº›åˆ™ä¸æ˜¯ã€‚æœ¬ç« å°†æ¢è®¨é€šå¸¸è¢«è§†ä¸ºé¢å‘å¯¹è±¡çš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œä»¥åŠè¿™äº›ç‰¹æ€§å¦‚ä½•è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºRustçš„æƒ¯ç”¨å®ç°ã€‚éšåæˆ‘ä»¬å°†å±•ç¤ºå¦‚ä½•åœ¨Rustä¸­å®ç°é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è®¾è®¡æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå¹¶è®¨è®ºä¸åˆ©ç”¨Rustè‡ªèº«ä¼˜åŠ¿å®ç°æ–¹æ¡ˆçš„æƒè¡¡ã€‚

Characteristics of Object-Oriented Languages é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è¯­è¨€çš„ç‰¹æ€§

There is no consensus in the programming community about what features a language must have to be considered object oriented. Rust is influenced by many programming paradigms, including OOP; for example, we explored the features that came from functional programming in Chapter 13. Arguably, OOP languages share certain common characteristics, namely objects, encapsulation, and inheritance. Letâ€™s look at what each of those characteristics means and whether Rust supports it.

ç¼–ç¨‹ç•Œå¯¹äºä¸€é—¨è¯­è¨€å¿…é¡»å…·å¤‡å“ªäº›ç‰¹æ€§æ‰èƒ½è¢«è§†ä¸ºé¢å‘å¯¹è±¡å°šæœªè¾¾æˆå…±è¯†ã€‚Rust å—åˆ°å¤šç§ç¼–ç¨‹èŒƒå¼çš„å½±å“ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼ˆOOPï¼‰ï¼›ä¾‹å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 13 ç« æ¢è®¨äº†æ¥è‡ªå‡½æ•°å¼ç¼–ç¨‹çš„ç‰¹æ€§ã€‚å¯ä»¥è¯´ï¼Œé¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è¯­è¨€å…·æœ‰æŸäº›å…±åŒç‰¹å¾ï¼šå³å¯¹è±¡ã€å°è£…å’Œç»§æ‰¿ã€‚è®©æˆ‘ä»¬é€ä¸€åˆ†æè¿™äº›ç‰¹æ€§çš„å«ä¹‰ä»¥åŠ Rust æ˜¯å¦æ”¯æŒå®ƒä»¬ã€‚

Objects Contain Data and Behavior å¯¹è±¡åŒ…å«æ•°æ®å’Œè¡Œä¸º

The book Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides (Addison-Wesley, 1994), colloquially referred to as The Gang of Four book, is a catalog of object-oriented design patterns. It defines OOP in this way:

Erich Gammaã€Richard Helmã€Ralph Johnson å’Œ John Vlissides æ‰€è‘—çš„ã€Šè®¾è®¡æ¨¡å¼ï¼šå¯å¤ç”¨é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è½¯ä»¶çš„åŸºç¡€ã€‹ï¼ˆAddison-Wesley, 1994ï¼‰ï¼Œé€šå¸¸è¢«ç§°ä¸ºã€Šå››äººå¸®ã€‹ï¼ˆGang of Fourï¼‰è‘—ä½œï¼Œå…¶ä¸­è¿™æ ·å®šä¹‰é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¼–ç¨‹ï¼š

Object-oriented programs are made up of objects. An object packages both data and the procedures that operate on that data. The procedures are typically called methods or operations.

é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡ç¨‹åºç”±å¯¹è±¡ç»„æˆã€‚å¯¹è±¡ åŒæ—¶æ‰“åŒ…äº†æ•°æ®åŠæ“ä½œè¿™äº›æ•°æ®çš„æµç¨‹ã€‚è¿™äº›æµç¨‹é€šå¸¸è¢«ç§°ä¸º æ–¹æ³• æˆ– æ“ä½œã€‚

Using this definition, Rust is object oriented: structs and enums have data, and impl blocks provide methods on structs and enums. Even though structs and enums with methods arenâ€™t called objects, they provide the same functionality, according to the Gang of Fourâ€™s definition of objects.

æ ¹æ®æ­¤å®šä¹‰ï¼ŒRust æ˜¯é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡çš„ï¼šç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ˆstructï¼‰å’Œæšä¸¾ï¼ˆenumï¼‰æ‹¥æœ‰æ•°æ®ï¼Œè€Œ impl å—ä¸ºç»“æ„ä½“å’Œæšä¸¾æä¾›äº†æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å°½ç®¡å¸¦æ–¹æ³•çš„ç»“æ„ä½“å’Œæšä¸¾ä¸è¢«ç§°ä¸ºå¯¹è±¡ï¼Œä½†æ ¹æ®å››äººå¸®çš„å¯¹è±¡å®šä¹‰ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬æä¾›äº†ç›¸åŒçš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

Encapsulation That Hides Implementation Details éšè—å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚çš„å°è£…

Another aspect commonly associated with OOP is the idea of encapsulation, which means that the implementation details of an object arenâ€™t accessible to code using that object. Therefore, the only way to interact with an object is through its public API; code using the object shouldnâ€™t be able to reach into the objectâ€™s internals and change data or behavior directly. This enables the programmer to change and refactor an objectâ€™s internals without needing to change the code that uses the object.

é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸è§ç‰¹æ€§æ˜¯ å°è£…ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€ä½¿ç”¨å¯¹è±¡çš„ä»£ç æ— æ³•è®¿é—®å…¶å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä¸å¯¹è±¡äº¤äº’çš„å”¯ä¸€æ–¹å¼æ˜¯é€šè¿‡å…¶å…¬å…± APIï¼›ä½¿ç”¨å¯¹è±¡çš„ä»£ç ä¸åº”ç›´æ¥è§¦åŠå¯¹è±¡å†…éƒ¨æ¥ä¿®æ”¹æ•°æ®æˆ–è¡Œä¸ºã€‚è¿™ä½¿å¾—ç¨‹åºå‘˜èƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨ä¸å½±å“ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥å¯¹è±¡ä»£ç çš„å‰æä¸‹ï¼Œä¿®æ”¹å’Œé‡æ„å¯¹è±¡å†…éƒ¨å®ç°ã€‚

We discussed how to control encapsulation in Chapter 7: we can use the pub keyword to decide which modules, types, functions, and methods in our code should be public, and by default everything else is private. For example, we can define a struct AveragedCollection that has a field containing a vector of i32 values. The struct can also have a field that contains the average of the values in the vector, meaning the average doesnâ€™t have to be computed on demand whenever anyone needs it. In other words, AveragedCollection will cache the calculated average for us. Listing 18-1 has the definition of the AveragedCollection struct.

æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¬¬ 7 ç« è®¨è®ºäº†å¦‚ä½•æ§åˆ¶å°è£…ï¼šä½¿ç”¨ pub å…³é”®å­—å†³å®šä»£ç ä¸­å“ªäº›æ¨¡å—ã€ç±»å‹ã€å‡½æ•°å’Œæ–¹æ³•åº”å…¬å¼€ï¼Œå…¶ä»–å†…å®¹é»˜è®¤ç§æœ‰ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚å¯å®šä¹‰åŒ…å« i32 å€¼å‘é‡çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ AveragedCollectionï¼Œè¯¥ç»“æ„ä½“è¿˜åŒ…å«å­—æ®µå­˜å‚¨å‘é‡çš„å¹³å‡å€¼ï¼Œé¿å…æ¯æ¬¡éœ€è¦æ—¶é‡å¤è®¡ç®—ã€‚æ¢è¨€ä¹‹ï¼ŒAveragedCollection ä¼šç¼“å­˜è®¡ç®—ç»“æœï¼ˆå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 18-1 æ‰€ç¤ºï¼‰ã€‚

The struct is marked pub so that other code can use it, but the fields within the struct remain private. This is important in this case because we want to ensure that whenever a value is added or removed from the list, the average is also updated. We do this by implementing add, remove, and average methods on the struct, as shown in Listing 18-2.

ç»“æ„ä½“æ ‡è®°ä¸º pub å¯ä¾›å¤–éƒ¨ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä½†å…¶å†…éƒ¨å­—æ®µä¿æŒç§æœ‰ã€‚è¿™å¾ˆå…³é”®ï¼Œå› ä¸ºéœ€ç¡®ä¿åˆ—è¡¨å¢åˆ å€¼æ—¶åŒæ­¥æ›´æ–°å¹³å‡å€¼ã€‚é€šè¿‡åœ¨ç»“æ„ä½“ä¸Šå®ç° addã€remove å’Œ average æ–¹æ³•å®ç°æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ï¼ˆå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 18-2ï¼‰ã€‚

The public methods add, remove, and average are the only ways to access or modify data in an instance of AveragedCollection. When an item is added to list using the add method or removed using the remove method, the implementations of each call the private update_average method that handles updating the average field as well.

å…¬å…±æ–¹æ³• addã€remove å’Œ average æ˜¯è®¿é—®æˆ–ä¿®æ”¹ AveragedCollection å®ä¾‹çš„å”¯ä¸€é€”å¾„ã€‚å½“é€šè¿‡ add æ·»åŠ æˆ– remove åˆ é™¤åˆ—è¡¨é¡¹æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•ä¼šè°ƒç”¨ç§æœ‰çš„ update_average æ–¹æ³•æ›´æ–° average å­—æ®µã€‚

We leave the list and average fields private so there is no way for external code to add or remove items to or from the list field directly; otherwise, the average field might become out of sync when the list changes. The average method returns the value in the average field, allowing external code to read the average but not modify it.

é€šè¿‡ä¿æŒ list å’Œ average å­—æ®µç§æœ‰ï¼Œå¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç æ— æ³•ç›´æ¥ä¿®æ”¹ listï¼Œç¡®ä¿ average å§‹ç»ˆä¸åˆ—è¡¨çŠ¶æ€åŒæ­¥ã€‚average æ–¹æ³•ä»…è¿”å›å­—æ®µå€¼ï¼Œå…è®¸å¤–éƒ¨è¯»å–ä½†ç¦æ­¢ä¿®æ”¹ã€‚

Because weâ€™ve encapsulated the implementation details of the struct AveragedCollection, we can easily change aspects, such as the data structure, in the future. For instance, we could use a HashSet<i32> instead of a Vec<i32> for the list field. As long as the signatures of the add, remove, and average public methods stayed the same, code using AveragedCollection wouldnâ€™t need to change. If we made list public instead, this wouldnâ€™t necessarily be the case: HashSet<i32> and Vec<i32> have different methods for adding and removing items, so the external code would likely have to change if it were modifying list directly.

ç”±äºå°è£…äº† AveragedCollection çš„å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚ï¼Œæœªæ¥å¯è½»æ¾è°ƒæ•´å†…éƒ¨æ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚å°† list å­—æ®µçš„ Vec<i32> æ”¹ä¸º HashSet<i32>ï¼‰ã€‚åªè¦ addã€remove å’Œ average çš„æ–¹æ³•ç­¾åä¸å˜ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ AveragedCollection çš„ä»£ç å°±æ— éœ€ä¿®æ”¹ã€‚è‹¥å°† list å…¬å¼€åˆ™æ— æ³•ä¿è¯è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹â€”â€”HashSet<i32> å’Œ Vec<i32> çš„å¢åˆ æ–¹æ³•ä¸åŒï¼Œç›´æ¥æ“ä½œ list ä¼šè¿«ä½¿å¤–éƒ¨ä»£ç ä¿®æ”¹ã€‚

If encapsulation is a required aspect for a language to be considered object oriented, then Rust meets that requirement. The option to use pub or not for different parts of code enables encapsulation of implementation details.

è‹¥å°è£…æ˜¯é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è¯­è¨€çš„å¿…è¦æ¡ä»¶ï¼Œåˆ™ Rust æ»¡è¶³æ­¤è¦æ±‚ã€‚é€šè¿‡ pub é€‰æ‹©æ€§å…¬å¼€å®ç°äº†å®ç°ç»†èŠ‚çš„å°è£…ã€‚

Inheritance as a Type System and as Code Sharing ä½œä¸ºç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿä¸ä»£ç å…±äº«çš„ç»§æ‰¿

Inheritance is a mechanism whereby an object can inherit elements from another objectâ€™s definition, thus gaining the parent objectâ€™s data and behavior without you having to define them again.

ç»§æ‰¿ æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå¯¹è±¡é€šè¿‡ç»§æ‰¿å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡çš„å®šä¹‰å…ƒç´ ï¼Œæ— éœ€é‡å¤å®šä¹‰å³å¯è·å¾—çˆ¶å¯¹è±¡çš„æ•°æ®å’Œè¡Œä¸ºã€‚

If a language must have inheritance to be object oriented, then Rust is not such a language. There is no way to define a struct that inherits the parent structâ€™s fields and method implementations without using a macro.

è‹¥é¢å‘å¯¹è±¡è¯­è¨€å¿…é¡»æ”¯æŒç»§æ‰¿ï¼Œåˆ™ Rust ä¸ç¬¦åˆæ ‡å‡†ã€‚æ— æ³•ç›´æ¥å®šä¹‰ç»§æ‰¿çˆ¶ç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µå’Œæ–¹æ³•å®ç°çš„ç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ˆå®é™¤å¤–ï¼‰ã€‚

However, if youâ€™re used to having inheritance in your programming toolbox, you can use other solutions in Rust, depending on your reason for reaching for inheritance in the first place.

ä½†å¯¹äºä¹ æƒ¯ä½¿ç”¨ç»§æ‰¿çš„å¼€å‘äººå‘˜ï¼Œå¯æ ¹æ®éœ€æ±‚é€‰æ‹© Rust çš„å…¶ä»–è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚

You would choose inheritance for two main reasons. One is for reuse of code: you can implement particular behavior for one type, and inheritance enables you to reuse that implementation for a different type. You can do this in a limited way in Rust code using default trait method implementations, which you saw in Listing 10-14 when we added a default implementation of the summarize method on the Summary trait. Any type implementing the Summary trait would have the summarize method available on it without any further code. This is similar to a parent class having an implementation of a method and an inheriting child class also having the implementation of the method. We can also override the default implementation of the summarize method when we implement the Summary trait, which is similar to a child class overriding the implementation of a method inherited from a parent class.

ç»§æ‰¿ä¸»è¦æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªç›®çš„ï¼šé¦–å…ˆæ˜¯ ä»£ç å¤ç”¨â€”â€”ä¸ºæŸç±»å‹å®ç°ç‰¹å®šè¡Œä¸ºåï¼Œç»§æ‰¿å¯å°†å…¶å¤ç”¨äºå…¶ä»–ç±»å‹ã€‚åœ¨ Rust ä¸­å¯é€šè¿‡ç‰¹è´¨ï¼ˆtraitï¼‰çš„é»˜è®¤æ–¹æ³•å®ç°æœ‰é™åœ°è¾¾æˆæ­¤ç›®æ ‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ä»£ç æ¸…å• 10-14 ä¸­ä¸º Summary ç‰¹è´¨æ·»åŠ çš„ summarize é»˜è®¤å®ç°ï¼‰ã€‚ä»»ä½•å®ç° Summary ç‰¹è´¨çš„ç±»å‹éƒ½ä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨è·å¾— summarize æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¿™ç±»ä¼¼äºçˆ¶ç±»æ–¹æ³•è¢«å­ç±»ç»§æ‰¿ã€‚å®ç° Summary ç‰¹è´¨æ—¶ä¹Ÿå¯è¦†ç›–é»˜è®¤æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºå­ç±»é‡å†™çˆ¶ç±»æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

The other reason to use inheritance relates to the type system: to enable a child type to be used in the same places as the parent type. This is also called polymorphism, which means that you can substitute multiple objects for each other at runtime if they share certain characteristics.

ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªç›®çš„æ˜¯ ç±»å‹ç³»ç»Ÿâ€”â€”å…è®¸å­ç±»å‹åœ¨çˆ¶ç±»å‹é€‚ç”¨çš„åœºæ™¯ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚è¿™ä¹Ÿç§°ä¸º å¤šæ€ï¼ˆpolymorphismï¼‰ï¼Œå³åœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¯æ›¿æ¢å…·æœ‰æŸäº›å…±åŒç‰¹å¾çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚

Polymorphism å¤šæ€æ€§

To many people, polymorphism is synonymous with inheritance. But itâ€™s actually a more general concept that refers to code that can work with data of multiple types. For inheritance, those types are generally subclasses.

å¯¹è®¸å¤šäººè€Œè¨€ï¼Œå¤šæ€ç­‰åŒäºç»§æ‰¿ã€‚ä½†å®ƒå®é™…æ˜¯æ›´å¹¿æ³›çš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼ŒæŒ‡èƒ½å¤„ç†å¤šç§ç±»å‹æ•°æ®çš„ä»£ç ã€‚åœ¨ç»§æ‰¿ä¸­ï¼Œè¿™äº›ç±»å‹é€šå¸¸æ˜¯å­ç±»ã€‚

Rust instead uses generics to abstract over different possible types and trait bounds to impose constraints on what those types must provide. This is sometimes called bounded parametric polymorphism.

Rust æ”¹ç”¨æ³›å‹ï¼ˆgenericsï¼‰æŠ½è±¡ä¸åŒç±»å‹ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡ç‰¹è´¨çº¦æŸï¼ˆtrait boundsï¼‰é™åˆ¶ç±»å‹éœ€æä¾›çš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼æœ‰æ—¶ç§°ä¸º æœ‰ç•Œå‚æ•°åŒ–å¤šæ€ï¼ˆbounded parametric polymorphismï¼‰ã€‚

Rust has chosen a different set of tradeoffs by not offering inheritance. Inheritance is often at risk of sharing more code than necessary. Subclasses shouldnâ€™t always share all characteristics of their parent class but will do so with inheritance. This can make a programâ€™s design less flexible. It also introduces the possibility of calling methods on subclasses that donâ€™t make sense or that cause errors because the methods donâ€™t apply to the subclass. In addition, some languages will only allow single inheritance (meaning a subclass can only inherit from one class), further restricting the flexibility of a programâ€™s design.

Rust é€šè¿‡èˆå¼ƒç»§æ‰¿é€‰æ‹©äº†ä¸åŒçš„æƒè¡¡æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚ç»§æ‰¿æœºåˆ¶å¾€å¾€å¯¼è‡´è¿‡åº¦å…±äº«ä»£ç â€”â€”å­ç±»ä¸åº”å§‹ç»ˆå…±äº«çˆ¶ç±»çš„å…¨éƒ¨ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œä½†ç»§æ‰¿ä¼šå¼ºåˆ¶å…±äº«ã€‚è¿™ä¼šé™ä½ç¨‹åºè®¾è®¡çš„çµæ´»æ€§ï¼Œå¹¶å¯èƒ½å¼•å‘é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆå¯¹å­ç±»è°ƒç”¨æ— æ„ä¹‰çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼‰ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼ŒæŸäº›è¯­è¨€ä»…æ”¯æŒ å•ç»§æ‰¿ï¼ˆå­ç±»åªèƒ½ç»§æ‰¿ä¸€ä¸ªçˆ¶ç±»ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿›ä¸€æ­¥é™åˆ¶äº†ç¨‹åºè®¾è®¡çš„çµæ´»æ€§ã€‚

For these reasons, Rust takes the different approach of using trait objects instead of inheritance to enable polymorphism. Letâ€™s look at how trait objects work.

å› æ­¤ Rust é‡‡ç”¨ç‰¹è´¨å¯¹è±¡ï¼ˆtrait objectï¼‰è€Œéç»§æ‰¿æ¥å®ç°å¤šæ€ã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¢è®¨ç‰¹è´¨å¯¹è±¡çš„å·¥ä½œæœºåˆ¶ã€‚

Using Trait Objects to Abstract over Shared Behavior ä½¿ç”¨ Trait å¯¹è±¡æŠ½è±¡å…±äº«è¡Œä¸º

In Chapter 8, we mentioned that one limitation of vectors is that they can store elements of only one type. We created a workaround in Listing 8-9 where we defined a SpreadsheetCell enum that had variants to hold integers, floats, and text. This meant we could store different types of data in each cell and still have a vector that represented a row of cells. This is a perfectly good solution when our interchangeable items are a fixed set of types that we know when our code is compiled.

åœ¨ç¬¬ 8 ç« ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æåˆ°å‘é‡çš„ä¸€ä¸ªé™åˆ¶æ˜¯åªèƒ½å­˜å‚¨å•ä¸€ç±»å‹çš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç¤ºä¾‹ 8-9 ä¸­åˆ›å»ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é€šæ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå®šä¹‰äº†åŒ…å«ä¸åŒæˆå‘˜çš„ SpreadsheetCell æšä¸¾æ¥å­˜å‚¨æ•´æ•°ã€æµ®ç‚¹æ•°å’Œæ–‡æœ¬ã€‚è¿™æ„å‘³ç€æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå•å…ƒæ ¼å­˜å‚¨ä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„æ•°æ®ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä»æ‹¥æœ‰è¡¨ç¤ºæ•´è¡Œå•å…ƒæ ¼çš„å‘é‡ã€‚å½“å¯äº’æ¢é¡¹æ˜¯ç¼–è¯‘æ—¶å·²çŸ¥çš„å›ºå®šç±»å‹é›†åˆæ—¶ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå®Œç¾çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚

However, sometimes we want our library user to be able to extend the set of types that are valid in a particular situation.
